the next regular appointment time by the Mayor pursuant to §
30.65. The Chairman of this Committee and the Mayor shall serve on the Town
Waterworks and Sewer Commission as provided by state statute.
(Ord. 95035, passed 8-7-95; Am. Ord. 17064, passed 1-10-18; Am. Ord. 21078,
passed 1-11-22)
§ 32.12 COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORTATION.
   (A)   Mission and purposes. Study, analyze, plan, and develop policy
recommendations for Council and respond to issues which are associated with
vehicular and pedestrian transportation, and public transportation
infrastructure, including roads, streets, signalization, sidewalks, bikes
paths, and mass transit equipment and facilities.
   (B)   Composition. The Committee on Transportation shall consist of the
Mayor, acting as Chairperson, and a minimum of two and a maximum of three
members of Town Council, said numerical make-up being at the discretion of the
Mayor.
   (C)   Duties. The Committee shall be responsible for the following:
      (1)   Citizen requests for installation or modification of traffic
control devices such as stop signs.
      (2)   Citizen requests for the alteration of existing transportation
system infrastructure such as the closure of existing roads and streets.
      (3)   Planning for expansion of pedestrian and bike way systems
throughout the town.
      (4)   Monitoring of the Charleston Transportation Committee road
maintenance and improvement program.
      (5)   Review data, information, traffic trends, and proposed plans
pertaining to the modification and expansion of the road network in Mount
Pleasant. Routine maintenance will continue to be a function of the Public
Services Committee.
      (6)   Prepare recommendations pertaining to review, amendment, and
implementation of the Mount Pleasant Transportation Plan.
      (7)   Review broad and specific issues, of both a long and short term
nature related to traffic and transportation in Mount Pleasant.
      (8)   Review budget recommendations from the Town Administrator relative
to transportation system improvements other than routine maintenance which will
continue to be reviewed by the Public Services Committee.
      (9)   Review and recommend consultant services to support transportation
programs.
      (10)   Review requests for abandonment and acquisition of street right of
ways.
      (11)   Coordinate RTA issues prior to submittal to Town Council. A
representative of the Transportation Committee will serve as a second
representative to the RTA pursuant to statutory authorization.
      (12)   Review matters pertaining to the maintenance and/or installation
of traffic signalization.
      (13)   Review annual submittal of projects to CHATS enhancement
subcommittee for recommendation to Council.
      (14)   Review and approve, or recommend approval, as appropriate,
modifications to street light system.
      (15)   Any and all other matters necessary to accomplish the stated
mission and purpose.
(Ord. 97063, passed 11-7-97; Am. Ord. 98055, passed 1-12-99; Am. Ord. 14094,
passed 1-13-15; Am. Ord. 17064, passed 1-10-18)
§ 32.13 COMMITTEE ON ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT.
   (A)   Composition. The Committee on Economic Development shall consist of a
minimum of three and a maximum of four members of Town Council, said numerical
make-up being at the discretion of the Mayor, and one voting ex officio member
of the Mount Pleasant Waterworks.
   (B)   Purpose. The Committee on Economic Development shall be responsible
for the following:
      (1)   Receive regular reports from Town Administrator and Economic
Development Coordinator regarding economic development plans/projects.
      (2)   Consider requests for economic development incentives and make
recommendations to Town Council.
      (3)   Review ordinances and policies relative to economic development and
make recommendations to Town Council on approval.
      (4)   Review proposals to provide public infrastructure projects in
support of economic development.
      (5)   Recommend land use, zoning, and other policy changes to Town
Council.
   (C)   Notwithstanding division (A) of §
30.65, members of the Committee on Economic Development shall be appointed by
the Mayor each year at the regular monthly meeting in December to serve a one-
year term, commencing January 1 and ending December 31.
(Ord. 04065, passed 12-14-04; Am. Ord. 05096, passed 1-11-06; Am. Ord. 17064,
passed 1-10-18)
§ 32.14 COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION.
   The Committee on Education shall consist of a minimum of three and a maximum
of four members of Town Council, said numerical make-up being at the discretion
of the Mayor, to whom shall be referred all appropriate matters relating to
education in the town and all issues pertaining thereto.
(Ord. 14093, passed 1-13-15; Am. Ord. 17064, passed 1-10-18)
§ 32.15 COMMITTEE ON FLOOD RESILIENCE.
   The Committee on Flood Resilience shall consist of four members of the Town
Council to whom shall be referred all appropriate matters governing flooding
and drainage issues, public projects and any policy matters concerning flooding
and drainage in the town and all issues pertaining thereto.
(Ord. 20008, passed 2-19-20)
CULTURE, ARTS, AND PRIDE COMMISSION
§ 32.20 CREATION.
   The Town Council hereby finds that it is in the best interests of the town
to create and form the Culture, Arts, and Pride Commission.
(Ord. 12090, passed 1-8-13; Am. Ord. 14047, passed 8-12-14)
§ 32.21 MISSION.
    It shall be the mission of the Culture, Arts, and Pride Commission to:
improve the community's quality of life through the appreciation and promotion
of artistic and cultural expressions, as well as the demonstration of civic
pride and volunteerism; identify opportunities for the public to experience the
arts and to give back to the community through volunteer efforts; make
recommendations to Town Council about these opportunities; and through the
support of the Community Development and Tourism Office, organize and lead
various events pertaining to its purpose.
(Ord. 12090, passed 1-8-13; Am. Ord. 14047, passed 8-12-14)
§ 32.22 MAIN OBJECTIVES.
   The Commission's main objectives shall be to: organize community cleanup and
beautification events; encourage volunteerism and civic pride; promote public
interest in the preservation of the town's unique culture and heritage by
providing opportunities for citizens to experience cultural events and
activities; highlight local artists and local art traditions; and sponsor
local, public art events and art education programs.
(Ord. 12090, passed 1-8-13; Am. Ord. 14047, passed 8-12-14)
§ 32.23 ORGANIZATION.
   (A)   The Commission shall be comprised of seven numbered seats. All members
shall be approved by the Town Council and shall serve as volunteers without
compensation.
   (B)   Terms for each seat shall be four years. However, initial terms for
seats one through four shall be for two years, and terms thereafter shall be
for four years. Initial terms for seats five through seven shall be for three
years, and terms thereafter shall be for four years. No member shall be
immediately eligible for reappointment after serving two consecutive terms,
however such members shall be eligible following a period of two years.
   (C)   Members shall be an art professional, a member of a community
development or art-focused nonprofit, an art educator, a benefactor of local
culture and tradition, or a civic-minded citizen, and must live in the town.
   (D)   The Commission shall meet on a quarterly basis, at a minimum, and
shall be subject to all state and federal disclosure laws. Each member is
required to attend 75% of called meetings per year on a rolling- year basis
which shall be measured on the first of every month for the preceding year.
Each member shall be afforded one excused absence which shall not be counted
towards the attendance requirement. If removal due to attendance is necessary,
the Town Administrator shall then remove that member from the Commission prior
to the next scheduled meeting and notify Town Council.
   (E)   The Commission shall establish and maintain by-laws consistent with
the provisions of this subchapter. By-laws and subsequent amendments shall be
approved by the Town Council
(Ord. 12090, passed 1-8-13; Am. Ord. 14047, passed 8-12-14; Am. Ord. 18035,
passed 6-14-18)
ACCOMMODATIONS TAX ADVISORY  COMMITTEE
§ 32.30 CREATION.
   Pursuant to S.C. Code § 6-4-5, et seq., as amended, an Accommodations Tax
Advisory Committee was created by Town Council and is currently composed of
seven members who are appointed and approved by Town Council.
(Ord. 24041, passed 1-21-25)
§ 32.31 ORGANIZATION.
   (A)   Membership.
      (1)   The Accommodations Tax Advisory Committee shall be composed of
seven members appointed and approved by Town Council.
      (2)   At least four members shall be selected from the hospitality
industry of the town, with at least two of the hospitality industry members
from the lodging industry.
      (3)   One member shall represent a cultural organization(s) in the town.
   (B)   Terms of office. Committee members shall serve staggered terms. Three
members shall serve two-year terms, and four members shall serve three-year
terms; provided that upon the creation of a vacancy on the Committee, the
replacement member shall fill the unexpired term of the member he or she has
replaced. In no case shall a member be eligible to serve more than four
consecutive terms.
   (C)   Vacancy, absence, and removal.
      (1)   A vacancy in a term of office shall occur whenever it is found that
a member has resigned, is unable to serve for whatever reason, or is removed in
accordance with the provisions of this section.
      (2)   Neglect of duty, no longer representing the hospitality or lodging
industry in the town, if applicable, or misconduct in office shall constitute
just cause.
         (a)   Each member is required to attend 75% of called meetings per
year on a rolling-year basis which shall be measured on the first of every
month for the preceding year. Each member shall be afforded one excused absence
which shall not be counted towards the attendance requirement.
         (b)   Excused and un-excused absences are to be determined by the
Chairperson or, in his or her absence, the Vice-Chairperson, and are to be
stated on the record at each meeting.
            1.   Excused absences are generally defined as medical or family
emergencies or unavoidable business/personal conflicts.
            2.   Each member is responsible for notifying the Chairperson or
the appropriate staff at least two full working days prior to the meeting, if
he or she will not be in attendance.
            3.   The member shall also state a reason for the anticipated
absence.
            4.   Emergency situations that arise within this 48-hour period can
be considered excused by the Chairperson.
      (3)   If removal for cause, except due to attendance, appears imminent,
the Chairperson shall contact the member and ascertain whether removal should
be considered by the Mayor and Town Council. The Chairperson shall then make a
recommendation to Council, prior to Council action on the matter.
      (4)   If removal due to attendance is necessary, the Town Administrator
shall remove the member from the Committee prior to the next scheduled meeting
and shall notify Town Council.
      (5)   Any vacancy in the membership shall be filled for the unexpired
term, as soon as may reasonably be accomplished by the Mayor and Town Council,
in the same manner as the original appointment.
   (D)   Compensation. All members shall serve without compensation.
   (E)   Chairperson; Secretary; rules of procedure.
      (1)   The Committee shall organize itself, electing by secret ballot and
majority vote a Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson from among its members.
         (a)   The election shall be held at the first meeting of each calendar
year.
         (b)   If a vacancy occurs in an office prior to the expiration of the
full term, another election to fill the remainder of the term of office shall
be conducted at the first meeting thereafter.
         (c)   The election procedures stated herein shall be followed in
filling an unexpired term of office.
      (2)   A staff member of the town shall serve as Secretary of the
Committee.
      (3)   The Committee shall adopt rules of procedure at the first meeting
in each calendar year. Such rules shall not conflict with the procedures stated
in this section or applicable state law.
         (a)   The Committee shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the
vote of each member upon each question, in accordance with applicable state and
federal laws and regulations.
         (b)   Robert’s Rules of Order shall govern the conduct of meetings
except as otherwise provided by the Committee.
   (F)   Meetings and quorum.
      (1)   A majority of members of the Committee shall constitute a quorum
for conducting business.
      (2)   Meetings of the Committee must be held at the call of the
Chairperson, and at such other times as the Committee may determine.
      (3)   All meetings shall be advertised in accordance with applicable
state and federal laws and regulations.
      (4)   The Committee shall meet as often as necessary to perform its
designated function, but no less than once per year.
      (5)   Upon request by Town Council, the Committee shall meet to consider
and make recommendations concerning any matter within its purview, as set forth
in §
32.32.
(Ord. 24041, passed 1-21-25)
§ 32.32 PURPOSE; POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   The Accommodations Tax Advisory Committee shall be an advisory
committee to Town Council and shall make recommendations to Town Council
concerning the expenditure of revenues received by the town which have been
generated from the accommodations tax, consistent with the requirements of S.C.
Code §§ 6-4-5, et seq., as amended.
   (B)   The Accommodations Tax Advisory Committee shall, in furtherance of the
purpose stated herein and the requirements of S.C. Code §§ 6-4-5, et seq., as
amended, have the following powers and duties:
      (1)   Ensure that accommodations tax revenue is used to maximize tourism
benefits for the town with the primary goal to increase room night sales within
the town’s limits.
      (2)   Establish procedures for organizations to submit funding requests.
These procedures shall include informing applicants of any reporting
requirements, including, but not limited to, required accountings for awarded
funds.
      (3)   Make recommendations based on the eligible funding determined
annually by Town Council in its budget process and return any unused funds to
the Accommodations Tax Fund. In making its recommendations, the Accommodations
Tax Advisory Committee shall give funding priority to applicants who are a
nonprofit organization, as defined under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal
Revenue Code.
      (4)   For funds expended for a specific event, ensure that the event
occurs and require a full return of funds to the town if the event is postponed
more than 180 days from the originally approved date or if the event is
canceled for reasons other than an Act of God (e.g., rain, hurricane).
(Ord. 24041, passed 1-21-25)

§ 33.01 ESTABLISHED.
   A Fire Department is established for the municipality.
('81 Code, § 33.01) (Am. Ord. 01060, passed 11-13-01)
Statutory reference:
   Fire departments in cities and towns; fire limits and construction, see S.C.
Code § 5-25-20
§ 33.02 FUNCTIONS OF THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.
   (A)   The Fire Department shall provide comprehensive programs and services
to the municipality, including but not be limited to, fire prevention and
inspection, fire suppression, emergency medical assists to the sick and
injured, hazardous materials response. weapons of mass destruction response,
shipboard firefighting, confined space rescue, and other related emergency
operations and functions approved by Council.
   (B)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall ensure that the Department
trains on and follows the National Incident Command System and establishes
written standard operating procedures for general and specific duties and
responses encountered when responding to fire, medical assist, rescue or other
emergency management and mitigation functions where their services are used.
   (C)   The Fire Department shall identify and design standards of response to
risk hazards associated within the town and/or their primary response district.
   (D)   The Fire Department shall utilize an appropriate system of
accountability when operating in an emergency mode.
(Ord. 01060, passed 11-13-01)
§ 33.03 COMPOSITION.
   The personnel of the Fire Department shall consist of both full-time paid
and volunteer members, the number in each category to be determined by Council,
and shall include a Chief, Assistant Chief, Fire Marshals and Battalion Chiefs,
as approved by Council, provided the Chief Assistant Chief and Battalion Chiefs
are full-time paid officers. The names of such persons who desire to become
members of the Fire Department, other than the Chief, shall be submitted by the
Chief, with his or her recommendations to the Town Administrator, who shall
approve all, or as many of those persons suggested, as he or she may deem
advisable. Only those persons so approved shall become members of the Fire
Department.
('81 Code, § 33.02) (Am. Ord. 01060, passed 11-13-01)
§ 33.04 CHIEF OF THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.
   The Fire Chief will be appointed by the Town Council, with the
recommendation of the Town Administrator, and will serve at the pleasure of
Council.
('81 Code, § 33.05) (Am. Ord. passed 3-5-79; Am. Ord. passed 9-9-85; Am. Ord.
01060, passed 11-13-01)
Cross-reference:
   Public Safety and Housing Officer ex officio duty of Fire Chief, see §
150.050
§ 33.05 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   The Chief of the Fire Department shall be the commanding officer of
the Fire Department, and shall be responsible for its proper management and for
the preservation and maintenance of its property. The Chief shall enforce all
rules and regulations of the Fire Department, and when any violation comes to
his or her attention, the Chief shall forthwith take such action as may be
appropriate with respect thereto.
   (B)   It shall be the duty of the Chief of the Fire Department to inspect
the engines, ladder trucks, and special apparatus for service at fires or
emergencies on a continuous basis, and to conduct a formal pumping test
annually.
   (C)   It shall be the duty of the Chief of the Fire Department to establish
and conduct a training program to thoroughly familiarize all members of the
Department with the operation of the engines, aerial and ground ladders, rescue
and special equipment, firefighting tactics and strategy, and medical and
rescue equipment.
('81 Code, § 33.06) (Am. Ord. 01060, passed 11-13-01)
§ 33.06 CONTROL AT SCENE OF FIRE OR EMERGENCY.
   The Chief of the Fire Department shall have control of operations at the
scene of a fire, hazardous materials incident, entrapment, rescue, or other
Fire Department-related emergency. In the event of the Chief’s incapacity or
absence, such control shall devolve upon the Assistant Chief, Battalion Chiefs,
and company officers. In the event of the incapacity or absence of the
Assistant Chief, Battalion Chiefs, or company officers, such control shall
devolve on a the most senior paid member of the Fire Department present at the
scene.
('81 Code, § 33.04) (Am. Ord. 01060, passed 11-13-01)
§ 33.07 LOCAL INSPECTOR OF BUILDINGS AND GROUNDS.
   (A)   The Chief of the Fire Department is designated the local Inspector of
Buildings and Grounds, with respect to fire hazards and safety, and it shall be
his or her duty to make reports to the Mayor, the Town Administrator and
Council, of the condition of such buildings and grounds he or she has
inspected.
   (B)   The Chief of the Fire Department is also designated as the local
Inspector of Buildings with respect to inquiries into the origin of fires
within the municipality and reporting thereon to law enforcement, other fire
departments, insurance companies or their agents as required by law, and in
this capacity the Chief shall have the powers and perform the duties prescribed
for local inspectors of buildings in S.C. Code §§ 5-25-160 through 5-25-210.
('81 Code, § 33.07) (Am. Ord. 01060, passed 11-13-01)
§ 33.08 ASSISTANT FIRE CHIEF.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of the Chief of the Fire Department to appoint an
Assistant Fire Chief.
   (B)   The Chief shall submit the name of such person selected, with his or
her recommendation, to the Town Administrator for final approval.
   (C)   The Assistant Fire Chief shall be second in command of all Fire
Department operations and administration, and in the Chief’s absence shall
assume all duties and responsibilities of that position.
(Ord. 01160, passed 11-13-01)
§ 33.09 BATTALION CHIEFS.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of the Chief of the Fire Department to appoint
any one of several Battalion Chiefs.
   (B)   The Battalion Chiefs shall be responsible for the daily emergency and
routine operations of the Fire Department, and at emergency scenes shall assume
command of the Department.
   (C)   In the event of the incapacity or absence of the Chief or the
Assistant Chief, the most senior Battalion Chief shall be in charge of
Department administration and operations.
('81 Code, § 33.08) (Am. Ord. 01060, passed 11-13-01)
§ 33.10 FIRE MARSHALS.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of the Chief of the Fire Department to appoint
any one of several Fire Marshals.
   (B)   As designated by the Chief of the Fire Department, the Fire Marshals
shall administer and enforce the provision of Chapter 92 of this code, and he
or she shall have such powers and perform such duties as may be provided for
him or her in the chapter or as provided in any other town or state ordinances/
statutes.
('81 Code, § 31.78) (Ord. Passed 12-8-92; Am. Ord. 01060, passed 11-13-01)
Cross-reference:
   Fire prevention, see
Ch. 92
   Municipal ordinance summons, see §
35.10
Statutory reference:
   Resident fire marshals, see S.C. Code § 23-9-30
§ 33.11 DRIVING OF VEHICLES WHILE RESPONDING TO FIRE ALARMS OR EMERGENCIES.
   (A)   When answering a fire alarm, medical assist, rescue or other
emergency, members of the Fire Department will proceed to the scene of the
fire, medical assist, rescue or other emergency, as instructed by the Chief,
and shall observe all traffic regulations, provided drivers of town vehicles
equipped to meet the requirements for, and duly designated as, emergency
vehicles as defined in S.C. Code § 56-5-170, shall observe the traffic
regulations applicable to such authorized emergency vehicles.
   (B)   Vehicles and apparatus of the Fire Department shall be driven only by
members of the Fire Department.
('81 Code, § 33.09) (Am. Ord. 01160, passed 11-13-01)
§ 33.12 RESPONSE TO CALLS BEYOND MUNICIPAL LIMITS.
   The Fire Department shall not answer any fire, medical assist, rescue or
other emergency calls outside the municipal limits, except under the following
conditions:
   (A)   Responding to a call from another municipality or government agency
under a pre-signed and approved automatic or mutual aid agreement, including
the statewide mutual aid program.
   (B)   Responding to a call from within an area designated as the East Cooper
Fire District.
   (C)   Responding to a call from Charleston County Emergency Medical
Services, the Charleston County Rescue Squad, or town, county or state police
for assistance at entrapment, wreck, drowning or other life-threatening
emergency.
(Ord. 01060, passed 11-13-01)
§ 33.13 FIREFIGHTERS’ INSURANCE AND INSPECTION FUND.
   Since the state has enacted a law providing for the payment of a
firefighters’ fund tax by fire insurance companies for business done in cities
and municipalities within the state, and since the firefighting equipment of
the municipality, fire inspection of buildings, and membership in the South
Carolina State Fireman’s Association qualifies it to partake from this fund,
under certain prescribed regulations, the municipality accepts all terms and
conditions of the act of the State General Assembly pertaining to the same.
('81 Code, § 33.13) (Am. Ord. 01060, passed 11-13-01)
Statutory reference:
   Firefighter’s Insurance and Inspection Fund, see S.C. Code §§ 23-9-310
through 23-9-470

§ 34.01 COMPOSITION.
   The Police Department shall consist of the Chief of Police and such other
personnel, having such ranks or grades, as may from time to time be determined
by the Council.
('81 Code, § 34.01)
§ 34.02 CHIEF OF POLICE; BOND.
   (A)   The Police Chief will be appointed by the Council and will serve at
the pleasure of Council.
   (B)   Before entering on the discharge of the duties of office, the Chief of
Police shall enter into Bond for the municipality in the amount of $5,000,
conditioned on the faithful performance of all duties and a true accounting for
all funds of the municipality which may come into his or her hands, custody, or
control, and such bond shall be provided by a bonding or casualty company
licensed to do business in this state, and shall be approved by the Mayor and
Council or its appropriate committee.
('81 Code, § 34.03) (Am. Ord. passed 3-5-79; Am. Ord. passed 9-9-85)
§ 34.03 POWERS AND DUTIES; PATROL.
   The Chief of Police shall be the commanding officer of the Police
Department. The property of the Police Department shall be within the care of
the Chief of Police, who shall be directly responsible therefor. The Chief of
Police shall be the principal law enforcement officer and shall enforce within
the municipality all provisions of state law, this code, and other ordinances
not the primary concern of some other officer to enforce, and he or she shall
cooperate with and assist other officers in the enforcement of statutes and
ordinances for which they are primarily responsible. It shall be the duty of
the Chief of Police to see that all departmental rules, regulations, and orders
are promptly and faithfully respected and obeyed, and whenever any violation
thereof is reported to the Chief or comes under the Chief’s personal
observation, he or she shall promptly investigate the matter and report it to
the Mayor and Police Department Committee of the Council. The Chief of Police
is authorized to summarily terminate and suspend from duty any member of the
Police Department for cause. The Chief of Police shall perform such other
duties as may be required by the Council.
('81 Code, § 34.04)
Cross-reference:
   Police Chief as Sergeant at Arms, see §
30.27
§ 34.04 EMPLOYMENT OF SPECIAL POLICE OFFICERS.
   The Police Chief, upon the approval of the Mayor, shall, whenever he or she
deems it necessary, appoint temporarily such number of special police officers
as may in the Chief’s sound discretion be deemed necessary for carrying out and
enforcing any or all ordinances of the municipality for the preservation of the
public health, safety, and general welfare, subject to availability of funds
for such purpose.
('81 Code, § 34.02)
§ 34.05 CHAIN OF COMMAND; RANKS AND GRADES.
   (A)   All personnel of the Police Department shall be subject to the
supervision and control of the Chief of Police and shall perform such general
and special duties and acts as the Chief may from time to time require and
direct, subject to the policies, rules and regulations of the town. In the
event of the absence or incapacity of the Chief of Police, the Police
Department chain of command shall be followed.
   (B)   Members of the Police Department subordinate to the Chief of Police
shall be appointed, promoted, and demoted in rank or grade by the Chief of
Police.
('81 Code, § 34.05)
§ 34.06 UNIFORMS AND EQUIPMENT.
   Members of the Police Department shall be provided by the municipality with
such articles of uniform, insignia, weapons, and equipment as may from time to
time be prescribed for them by the Chief of Police.
('81 Code, § 34.06)
§ 34.07 BAIL.
   On any arrest being made by any police officer, such arrest shall be
communicated immediately to the municipal judge or a magistrate for
instruction, and until the police officer receives such instruction the party
arrested shall be detained in custody, unless such deposit of money is made
with the Clerk of Court as will be required for his or her appearance before
the municipal judge or magistrate to answer the charges preferred against him
or her.
('81 Code, § 34.07)
CHAPTER 35: MUNICIPAL COURT

§ 35.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is established a Municipal Court for the municipality which shall be a
part of the unified judicial system of the state, pursuant to Act No. 480 of
1980 (S.C. Code §§ 14-25-5 et seq.) for the trial and determination of all
cases within its jurisdiction.
('81 Code, § 35.01)
Statutory reference:
   Authority to establish Municipal Court, S.C. Code § 14-25-5
§ 35.02 JUDGE.
   (A)   The Court shall be presided over by one or more full-time or part-time
Judges at the discretion of Council. The Municipal Court Judge or Judges shall
be appointed for a term of two years. All terms hereunder shall, however,
continue until a successor is appointed, approved, and sworn by Town Council.
The Mayor and Council shall act promptly after the expiration of a term to make
appointments and swear in Judges as soon as may reasonably be accomplished.
   (B)   In the event a Judge does not complete his or her term, Council may
appoint a new Judge to fill the unexpired term. Vacancies shall be filled in
accordance with S.C. Code § 14-25-25.
   (C)   The compensation of the Municipal Judge shall be as from time to time
may be determined by Council.
('81 Code, § 35.02) (Am. Ord. passed 7-7-86; Am. Ord. 94040, passed 9-22-94;
Am. Ord. 96041, passed 9-20-96; Am. Ord. 01038, passed 6-25-01; Am. Ord. 04042,
passed 8-10-04; Am. Ord. 10050, passed 10-12-10)
§ 35.03 CLERK.
   Council shall designate a Clerk of Municipal Court, who shall keep such
records and make such reports as may be required by the Council and/or the
State Court Administrator.
('81 Code, § 35.03)
§ 35.04 JURY COMMISSIONERS.
   The Clerk of Court and his or her assistant shall serve as jury
commissioners for the Municipal Court. The Council shall appoint not less than
three nor more than five persons to serve as jury commissioners for the
Municipal Court in accordance with S.C. Code § 14-25-155.
('81 Code, § 35.09)
§ 35.05 JURISDICTION.
   The Municipal Court shall have jurisdiction to try all cases arising under
the ordinances of the municipality. The Court shall also have all such powers,
duties, and jurisdiction in criminal cases made under state law and conferred
upon magistrates. The Court shall have the power to punish for contempt of
court by imposition of sentences up to the limits imposed on municipal courts.
The Court shall have no jurisdiction in civil matters.
(S.C. Code § 14-25-45) ('81 Code, § 35.04)
§ 35.06 DISPOSITION OF FINES AND PENALTIES.
   All fines and penalties collected by the Municipal Court shall be forthwith
turned over to the Director of Administrative Services for deposit to the
general fund of the municipality.
('81 Code, § 35.06)
§ 35.07 APPEALS.
   (A)   Any party shall have the right to appeal from the sentence or judgment
of the Municipal Court to a court of competent jurisdiction. Notice of
intention to appeal, setting forth the grounds for appeal, shall be given in
writing and served on the Municipal Judge or the Clerk of the Municipal Court
within ten days after sentence is passed or judgment rendered, or the appeal
shall be deemed waived. The party appealing shall enter into a bond, payable to
the municipality, to appear and defend such appeal in the court to which the
appeal is taken, or shall pay the fine assessed.
   (B)   In the event of an appeal, the Municipal Judge shall make a return to
the court to which the appeal is taken as provided by S.C. Code § 14-25-105.
(S.C. Code §§ 14-25-95 and 14-25-105) ('81 Code, § 35.07)
§ 35.08 JURY TRIAL.
   Any person to be tried in the Municipal Court may, prior to trial, demand a
jury trial, and such jury when demanded, shall be composed of six persons drawn
from the qualified electors of the municipality in the manner prescribed by
law. The right to a jury trial shall be deemed to have been waived unless
demand is made prior to trial.
(S.C. Code § 14-25-125) ('81 Code, § 35.08)
Statutory reference:
   Council may act as jury commissioners, see S.C. Code § 14-25-135
   Juries, see S.C. Code §§ 14-25-145 through 14-25-185
§ 35.09 STENOGRAPHIC AND MECHANICAL RECORDINGS.
   Any party shall have the right to have the testimony given at a jury trial
in the Municipal Court taken stenographically or mechanically by a reporter;
provided that nothing herein shall operate to prevent any such party from
mechanically recording the proceedings himself or herself. The requesting party
shall pay the charges of such reporter for taking and transcribing if testimony
is recorded by a Municipal Court reporter.
(S.C. Code § 14-25-125) ('81 Code, § 35.10)
§ 35.10 MUNICIPAL UNIFORM ORDINANCE SUMMONS.
   (A)   Any person or entity violating any provision of this code, or any code
adopted pursuant thereto, within the corporate limits of the town may be issued
a uniform ordinance summons. Issuance of the uniform ordinance summons shall
vest jurisdiction in the Town Municipal Court to hear and dispose of the charge
for which the uniform ordinance summons was issued and served. The uniform
ordinance summons may be issued by any town law enforcement officer or any
other town employee designated as a code enforcement officer pursuant to this
Code or by Town Council or the Town Administrator. The bond amount for
violations shall be prescribed by a Municipal Court Judge. Town law enforcement
or code enforcement officers are prohibited from accepting bonds. The uniform
ordinance summons shall not be used to perform a custodial arrest.
   (B)   This section does not apply to any ordinance which regulates the use
of motor vehicles on the public roads.
   (C)   An ordinance summons must cite only one violation per summons and must
contain at least the following information:
      (1)   The name and address of the person or entity charged;
      (2)   The name and title of the issuing officer;
      (3)   The time, date, and location of the hearing;
      (4)   A description of the ordinance the person or entity is charged with
violating;
      (5)   The procedure to post bond; and
      (6)   Any other notice or warning otherwise required by law.
   (D)   The ordinance summonses must be consecutively and discretely numbered.
The ordinance summonses must be audited as part of the annual independent audit
required in S.C. Code § 5-7-240, 1976 as amended and a separate copy of each
audit must be furnished to the chief administrative officer of the
municipality.
   (E)   Any law enforcement officer or code enforcement officer who serves an
ordinance summons must allow the person served to proceed without first having
to post bond or to appear before a Municipal Judge. Acceptance of an ordinance
summons constitutes a person’s recognizance to comply with the terms of the
summons.
   (F)   This statute does not prohibit the municipality from enforcing
ordinances by means otherwise authorized by law.
   (G)   The form set out in the appendix following this chapter is adopted as
the Town Uniform Ordinance Summons.
('81 Code, § 35.11) (Ord. passed 12-8-92) Penalty, see §
35.99
§ 35.11 COURT FEES.
   (A)   Deferred prosecution fee.
      (1)   The following findings of facts are adopted herewith:
         (a)   Deferred prosecution of a charge is beneficial to an accused.
         (b)   Deferred prosecution involves additional time, effort and
follow-up on the part of the court staff, which involves a cost to taxpayers.
         (c)   The cost of the follow-up involved with a deferred prosecution
shall be borne by the recipient of this favorable option.
         (d)   Based on all of the specifics involved with monitoring and
follow-up in a deferred prosecution, $50 is a fair and reasonable cost to
charge each accused/recipient involved.
      (2)   A deferred prosecution fee for the deferred prosecution program is
hereby established for the Municipal Court in the amount of $50. This fee shall
apply to any charge or charges deferred for an accused based on certain
conditions being accomplished. The Municipal Court shall promulgate paperwork,
procedures and policies to administer this program and fee.
   (B)   Administrative service fee.
      (1)   The following are adopted as findings of fact as evidence of
specific work done by the court for offenders who are found guilty in the Mount
Pleasant Municipal Court:
         (a)   Court continuances due to conflicts with the assigned court
date.
         (b)   Record checks for other agencies and for employment purposes.
         (c)   Researching information requested on court case dispositions.
         (d)   Faxing information, then mailing the original.
         (e)   Processing warrants for non- sufficient checks. Takes staff away
from the office in order to process with the magistrate’s office.
         (f)   Processing cases with the Court of General Sessions results in
staff going to the Charleston County Clerk of Court’s office to have tickets
signed off, which verifies that specific cases were disposed of.
         (g)   Sending notices to offenders by certified mail to insure
individuals are notified. This is done to avoid having offenders tried in their
absence.
         (h)   As a courtesy to offenders, this court sends certified letters
notifying them of pending bench warrants. This letter is to advise them that
they have ten days in which to pay their fine in order to avoid a formal
arrest.
         (i)   Expungement of offenders’ court records.
         (j)   Requests for copies of tickets, letters, and the like are made
on a daily basis.
      (2)   The amount of $10 is found to be a fair and reasonable amount to
charge all guilty offenders in the Municipal Court.
      (3)   An administrative service fee for offenders who are found guilty in
the Municipal Court is hereby established for the Municipal Court in the amount
of $10. The Municipal Court shall promulgate paperwork, procedures and policies
to administer the fee.
(Ord. 00045, passed 8-8-00)
Cross-Reference:
   Collection of delinquent debts, see §
40.20
§ 35.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Uniform ordinance summons. Any person who fails to appear before the
Court as required by an ordinance summons, without first having posted such
bond as may be required or without having been granted a continuance by the
Court, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, must be fined not more
than $500 or imprisoned for not more than 30 days; provided, however, that no
penalty shall exceed that provided for a similar offense under state law.
('81 Code, § 35.11) (Ord. passed 12-8-92)
   (B)   Violation of ordinance.
      (1)   Whenever the Municipal Judge of the Town Municipal Court finds a
party guilty of violating a municipal ordinance or a state law within the
jurisdiction of the Court, he or she may impose a fine of not more than $500 or
imprisonment for not more than 30 days, or both; provided, however, that no
penalty shall exceed that provided for a similar offense under state law. This
provision supersedes any and all other provisions in this code.
      (2)   The Municipal Judge of the Town Municipal Court may suspend
sentences imposed by him or her on such terms and conditions as deemed
appropriate, including restitution and/or community service. The Municipal
Judge is further specifically authorized in criminal cases to order a defendant
to make restitution to their victim(s) in an amount the Judge deems
appropriate, as a condition of a suspended sentence or in addition to any other
penalty imposed.
(S.C. Code §§ 14-25-65 and 14-25-75) ('81 Code, § 35.05) (Am. Ord. 93048,
passed 9-14-93)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 36.01 QUALIFIED VOTERS.
   All electors of the municipality duly qualified to vote under the
constitution and laws of the state shall be permitted to vote.
('81 Code, § 36.01)
§ 36.02 REGISTRATION OF VOTERS.
   The appointment of the supervisor of municipal registration and the conduct
of the registration by such supervisor shall conform to the requirements of the
state statutes applicable thereto.
('81 Code, § 36.02)
§ 36.03 POLLING PLACES.
   All elections shall be held at such places as shall be designated by
Council, in conformity with state law.
('81 Code, § 36.03)
§ 36.04 VOTING HOURS.
   The polls shall be open on each election day from 7:00 a.m. until 7:00 p.m.
('81 Code, § 36.04) (Am. Ord. passed 4-12-88)
ELECTIONS
§ 36.20 SPECIAL ELECTIONS.
   Special elections shall be ordered from time to time, as occasion may
demand. When required or permitted by law, candidates must file a statement of
candidacy with the Charleston County Board of Elections and Voter Registration,
together with a $150 filing fee, not later than twelve o’clock noon, 45 days
prior to the election. If, however, S.C. Code § 7-13-190(C) is applicable, the
notice requirements of said section of the State Code shall be controlling over
this section.
('81 Code, § 36.05) (Am. Ord. passed 1-9-90; Am. Ord. 99018, passed 6-8-99; Am.
Ord. 09064, passed 10-13-09)
§ 36.21 REGULAR ELECTION DATE FOR MAYOR AND COUNCILMEMBERS.
   General elections will be held in the town on the first Tuesday after the
first Monday in November in odd-numbered years. Offices for Mayor and
Councilmembers filled in the election of 2004 will be up for election in 2009
and every four years thereafter. Offices for Mayor and Councilmembers filled in
the election of 2006 will be up for election in 2011 and every four years
thereafter, saving and excepting one Council seat filled as a two-year vacancy,
which will be up for election in 2009 and every four years thereafter.
('81 Code, § 36.06) (Am. Ord. 93077, passed 1-11-94; Am. Ord. 07033, passed 6-
12-07)
Statutory reference:
   Nominations and elections for municipal offices, see S.C. Code §§ 5-15-10 et
seq.
§ 36.22 NONPARTISAN ELECTIONS; PLURALITY METHOD.
   All regular and special elections for the offices of Mayor and Council shall
be nonpartisan general elections using the plurality method, pursuant to S.C.
Code § 5-15-61.
(‘81 Code, § 36.07) (Ord. passed 3-6-78; Am. Ord. passed 5-12-80; Am. Ord.
passed 4-12-88; Am. Ord. passed 4-10-90; Am. Ord. 13040, passed 8-13-13; Am.
Ord. 19034, passed 5-14-19)
§ 36.23 FILING OF STATEMENT OF CANDIDACY.
   (A)   Statements of candidacy for the offices of Mayor, Council and for the
Commissioners of Public Works in a general election shall be filed with the
Charleston County Board of Elections and Voter Registration, together with a
$150 filing fee, not later than 60 days prior to the election. The Charleston
County Board of Elections and Voter Registration shall verify the information
in the statements and shall place the name of the candidate on the ballot.
   (B)   Any person declaring candidacy under this section who cannot afford
the required filing fee and so declares himself or herself to be an indigent
shall file a written appeal for relief with the Charleston County Board of
Elections and Voter Registration, not later than 60 days prior to the election.
('81 Code, § 36.08) (Ord. passed 3-6-78; Am. Ord. passed 6-6-88; Am. Ord.
passed 1-9-90; Am. Ord. passed 4-10-90; Am. Ord. 99018, passed 6-8-99; Am. Ord.
99039, passed 9-21-99; Am. Ord. 09064, passed 10-13-09)
§ 36.24 ADVANCE NOTICE OF GENERAL AND SPECIAL ELECTIONS.
   Two notices of the time, place, and object of any general or special
election held in the town shall be published in a newspaper of general
circulation in the town. The first notice must appear not later than 90 days
before the election and the second notice must appear not later than two weeks
after the first notice.
('81 Code, § 36.10) (Am. Ord. passed 12-10-91; Am. Ord. 99039, passed 9-21-99)
§ 36.30 TRANSFER OF CERTAIN AUTHORITY TO THE CHARLESTON COUNTY BOARD OF
ELECTIONS AND VOTER REGISTRATION.
   (A)   Pursuant to Mount Pleasant Ordinance Nos. 08027 and 09028, and
Charleston County Council Ordinance Nos. 1561 and 1605, certain authority to
conduct municipal elections was transferred to, and accepted by, the Charleston
County Council and the Charleston County Board of Elections and Voter
Registration.
   (B)   The Charleston County Board of Elections and Voter Registration shall
have the following authority and responsibilities with respect to all Mount
Pleasant regular and special elections:
      (1)   Publishing proper notices of elections.
      (2)   Insuring the provision of proper books for registration.
      (3)   Preparing and distributing ballots and election materials.
      (4)   Preparing and staffing an absentee ballot precinct.
      (5)   Appointing and training poll managers.
      (6)   Providing voting machines.
      (7)   Joint supervision, along with the Mount Pleasant Election
Commission, of the polls on election day. Ultimate decisions and final
authority in this regard shall remain with the Mount Pleasant Election
Commission.
      (8)   Tabulating all election votes.
      (9)   Certifying election results to the Mount Pleasant Election
Commission.
      (10)   Conducting all Mount Pleasant municipal elections, special and
general, pursuant to the requirements of the South Carolina Code of Laws.
      (11)   Review of and decisions on challenges from candidates.
      (12)   Review of and decisions on challenged ballots.
      (13)   Protest filed or litigation commenced, in connection with the
conduct of a municipal election, shall be heard by the Charleston County Board
of Elections and Voter Registration and defended by its attorney, with the town
being responsible for all fees, costs and expenses incurred in such protest or
litigation.
      (14)   Supervision of the polls on election day.
      (15)   Certification of results to the Mount Pleasant Town Council.
      (16)   Statements of candidacies, and fees therewith, shall be filed with
the Charleston County Board of Elections and Voter Registration.
      (17)   Any and all other authority relative to conducting a municipal
election that is not specifically excluded hereinbelow.
   (C)   The following specific authority is maintained by the Mount Pleasant
Election Commission and is not granted to the Charleston County Board of
Elections and Voter Registration:
      (1)   Authority to call special elections and to set the date of same
pursuant to the requirements of the South Carolina Code of Laws, if applicable,
in addition to drafting and proposing referendum questions to the voters.
      (2)   Authority to cancel/revoke this transfer of authority by ordinance,
at anytime, shall remain with the Town Council.
      (3)   Expenses for municipal elections will be borne by the town and, as
such, the county will be reimbursed for any such expenses incurred.
(Ord. 08027, passed 6-11-08; Am. Ord. 09014, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 09064,
passed 10-13-09)
ELECTION RESULTS
§ 36.40 COUNTING OF VOTES.
   Immediately upon the closing of the polls, the Charleston County Board of
Elections and Voter Registration shall proceed to count publicly the votes cast
and shall continue such count until completed.
('81 Code, § 36.12) (Am. Ord. 09014, passed 4-14-09)
§ 36.41 CERTIFICATION OF ELECTION RESULTS.
   The Charleston County Board of Elections and Voter Registration shall
certify all election results, including the whole number of votes cast,
together with the number cast for each candidate for Mayor and for each
candidate for Councilmember, and, when applicable, the number of votes cast for
and against each proposition voted on at the election, and transmit the same in
writing to the Town Council in a timely manner.
('81 Code, § 36.13) (Am. Ord. 09014, passed 4-14-09; Am. Ord. 09064, passed 10-
13-09)
§ 36.42 SPECIAL MEETING OF COUNCIL TO RECEIVE ELECTION RETURNS.
   A special meeting of the Council shall be held within three days after a
municipal election as the Charleston County Board of Elections and Voter
Registration shall be ready to transmit their statement of the result of the
election to the Council as provided in §
36.41.
('81 Code, § 36.14) (Am. Ord. 95067, passed 12-8-95; Am. Ord. 09064, passed 10-
13-09)
§ 36.43 ANNOUNCEMENT OF ELECTION RESULTS.
   Immediately upon receipt by the Council of the statement of the Charleston
County Board of Elections and Voter Registration, the Mayor shall open and
publish the statement by announcing the total number of votes cast for each
candidate for Mayor and for each candidate for Councilmember, and, when
applicable, the total number of votes cast for and against each proposition
voted on at the election.
('81 Code, § 36.16) (Am. Ord. 09064, passed 10-13-09)
§ 36.44 DETERMINATION OF ELECTION; FORMAL DECLARATION.
   The person receiving the highest number of votes for Mayor shall be declared
duly elected Mayor. The persons receiving the highest number of votes for
Councilmember, in number equal to the number of Councilmembers to be chosen,
shall be declared duly elected Councilmembers. Such declaration shall be by
resolution of the Council.
('81 Code, § 36.17)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 37.01 MISCONDUCT.
   (A)   Any person elected or appointed to any office in the municipal
government and any person employed by the municipality shall abide by the state
Ethics, Government and Accountability and Campaign Reform Act of 1991. All
employees shall also be governed by the policies, rules and regulations as set
forth in the town Personnel Manual.
   (B)   The Council may by resolution adopt, and from time to time amend,
personnel regulations governing such matters as, among others, the terms and
conditions for employment, promotion, demotion, suspension, and dismissal,
vacation leaves, sick leaves, and military leaves, classification of positions,
and all other matters customarily governed by municipal personnel regulations.
On the adoption of any such resolution and the filing thereof in the office of
the Clerk of Council, the rules and regulations contained therein shall apply
to all persons to whom they are by such resolution made applicable, and it
shall be unlawful for any such person to violate or fail to comply therewith.
§ 37.02 COMPENSATION.
   The Mayor, Councilmembers, and other municipal officers and the municipal
employees shall be entitled to receive and shall be paid such salary or
compensation during their respective terms of office or employment as may be
provided for and regulated by resolution or ordinance of the Council.
('81 Code, § 37.03(A)) (Ord. passed 12-7-70)
§ 37.03 TOWN’S STATUS AS AN AT-WILL EMPLOYER.
   It is hereby declared to be the policy of the town that, notwithstanding any
policies, memoranda or handbooks it has promulgated, or any of its employment
practices:
   (A)   All town employees are employed at-will and may resign or be
discharged from employment at any time.
   (B)   As authorized by the Mayor and Town Council, only the town shall have
the right to enter into contracts for other than at-will employment on the
town’s behalf.
   (C)   Any contract for other than at-will employment must:
      (1)   Be in writing;
      (2)   Be executed by the Town Council;
      (3)   Specify the duration of the employment; and
      (4)   Specifically state that the contract is being created pursuant to
the town’s authority under this section.
(Ord. 03056, passed 10-14-03)
