§ 156.039 R-1, R-2, R-3, AND R-4 (RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS).
   (A)   Purpose.
      (1)   The purposes of the R-1, R-2, R-3, and R-4 Residential Districts
are to provide for residential neighborhoods with small and medium lot sizes
and to encourage the formation and continuation of a stable, healthy
residential environment.
      (2)   The regulations that apply within these districts are designed to:
         (a)   Discourage unwarranted and blighting encroachments by limiting
commercial uses and prohibiting industrial uses;
         (b)   Disallow any other use that would subsequently interfere with
the development or continuation of residential uses; and
         (c)   Discourage any use that would generate traffic on minor streets
other than that required to serve residences on these streets.
   (B)   Location.
      (1)   The R-1 and R-2 Districts are generally appropriate in areas
designated as Conventional Residential Neighborhood, Traditional Residential
Neighborhood, and Mixed Neighborhood on the Comprehensive Plan Future Land Use
Map.
      (2)   The R-3 and R-4 Districts are generally appropriate in areas
designated as Traditional Residential Neighborhood and Mixed Neighborhood on
the Comprehensive Plan Future Land Use Map.
   (C)   Allowed uses. See
Subchapter C.
   (D)   Dimensional standards. Table 156.039-1 establishes dimensional
standards for the Residential Districts based on dwelling type.

§ 156.040 TH (TOWNHOUSE DISTRICT).
   (A)   Purpose.
      (1)   The purpose of the TH, Townhouse, District is to provide for
quality residential developments primarily containing attached dwellings on
individual lots.
      (2)   The regulations that apply within this district are designed to:
         (a)   Discourage unwarranted and blighting encroachments by
prohibiting the commercial and industrial uses of land; and
         (b)   Disallow any other use that would substantially interfere with
the development and continuation of attached dwelling developments.
   (B)   Location. The TH District is generally appropriate in areas designated
as Traditional Residential Neighborhood, Mixed Neighborhood, Community Scale
Hub, and Redevelopment Center on the Comprehensive Plan Future Land Use Map.
   (C)   Allowed uses. See
Subchapter C.
   (D)   Dimensional standards. 
Table 156.040-1 establishes dimensional standards for the TH District.
   (E)   Maximum development. No more than eight townhouse dwellings shall be
constructed or attached together in a continuous row, and no such row shall
exceed 200 feet in length.
   (F)   Off-site parking allowed.
      (1)   Off-street parking as required by Subchapter F may be provided on
the premises or in a community parking lot or garage, the title to which and/or
easement for the use of which runs with and/or is appurtenant to the title of
townhouse.
      (2)   An off-site parking lot or garage shall be located a maximum of 200
feet from the entrance to the dwelling it serves.
   (G)   Recreation area required.
      (1)   In new townhouse subdivisions with six or more dwelling units, at
least 8% of net development acreage shall be designated for recreational open
space use.
      (2)         (2)   The 8% of land area shall not include freshwater or
saltwater wetlands, or land used to provide minimum yard requirements, parking
areas for dwelling units, or streets.

§ 156.041 RM (MIXED RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT).
   (A)   Purpose. The purpose of the RM, Mixed Residential, District, is to:
      (1)   Promote mixed use neighborhoods in appropriate locations;
      (2)   Encourage a mixture of housing types and sizes to increase housing
choice; and
      (3)   Encourage small-scale, neighborhood retail and service uses in
proximity to dwellings to reduce vehicle trips and encourage walkable
neighborhoods.
   (B)   Location. The RM District is generally appropriate in areas designated
as Mixed Neighborhood and Redevelopment Center on the Comprehensive Plan Future
Land Use Map.
   (C)   Allowed uses. See
Subchapter C.
   (D)   Dimensional standards.
      (1)   
Table 156.041-1 establishes dimensional standards for the RM District.
      (2)   Dimensional standards for detached houses apply to non-residential
lots and structures.
   (E)   Maximum development. No more than eight townhouse dwellings shall be
constructed or attached together in a continuous row, and no such row shall
exceed 200 feet in length.
   (F)   Recreation area required.
      (1)   In new developments with six or more dwelling units, at least 8% of
net development acreage shall be designated for recreational open space use.
      (2)   The 8% of land area shall not include freshwater or saltwater
wetlands, or land used to provide minimum yard requirements, parking areas for
dwelling units, or streets.
   (G)   Placement of drives and parking areas. All driveways and parking areas
shall be located at least ten feet from any lot line.

§ 156.055 OP-1 (OFFICE PROFESSIONAL DISTRICT).
   (A)   Purpose. The OP-1 District is intended to accommodate residential
dwellings and small professional offices compatible with nearby residences.
This district is designed to exclude retail and other types of uses that would
generate excessive traffic to the site by limiting lot and building size.
   (B)   Location. The OP-1 District is generally appropriate in areas
designated as Neighborhood Scale Commercial on the Comprehensive Plan Future
Land Use Map.
   (C)   Allowed uses. See
Subchapter C.

standards for the OP-1 District.

§ 156.061 ED (ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT DISTRICT).
   (A)   Generally. The Economic Development District shall be developed and
reserved for purposes and uses that are compatible with the town's economic
development strategy.
   (B)   Purpose. The purpose of the ED, Economic Development, District is to
support the town’s vision for economic development that encourages economic
vitality, promotes fiscal integrity, and increases the local standards of
living while preserving and enhancing the quality of life in Mount Pleasant.
   (C)   Objectives. The regulations that apply within this district are
designed to achieve the town’s objectives to:
      (1)   Implement the most recently adopted economic development strategy;
      (2)   Establish Mount Pleasant’s reputation as a regionally competitive
and welcoming destination for economic development;
      (3)   Attract and retain high-quality, high-wage jobs in target clusters;
      (4)   Remove barriers to development within target clusters;
      (5)   Expand use of economic incentives; and,
      (6)   Prioritize quality of life initiatives to support local workforce
and residents.
   (D)   Location. The ED District is generally appropriate in areas designated
as Town Scale Commercial and Business and Industry on the Comprehensive Plan
Future Land Use Map.
   (E)   Allowed uses. See
Subchapter C.

standards for the ED District, which may be adjusted through the design review
process as specified in division (G) below.

a Planned Development District; provided, however, that the provisions shall
only apply to the economic development use as specified in the Use Table when
other permitted uses are also allowed on the parcel.
      (2)   Types of variations allowed. In general, all applicable off-street
parking, loading, bufferyard, and supplemental regulations apply to uses within
this district; provided, however, that variations may be made to such
provisions during the design review process as may be necessary to accomplish
unique operational requirements or characteristics inherent with individual
businesses. An example may be the allowance of additional paved parking for an
office use with a significant number of cubicles, sometimes referred to as a
“cube farm” that has higher daily parking demand, as opposed to a shopping
center’s desire for additional paved parking to accommodate sales on one or two
days a year.
      (3)   Setbacks. All setbacks may be adjusted during the design review
process.
      (4)   Justification in the record of approval/notations on plans.
         (a)   Justification for such variations from the normal development
standards shall be specified on the approved plans and/or elsewhere in the
approval record.
         (b)   Variations from the prescribed development standards shall only
be allowed if the appearance and form of improvements remain consistent, to the
maximum extent possible, with the general context of the area in which the use
is located to ensure an acceptable coexistence with the neighboring uses.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)

§§ 156.063 THROUGH 156.079 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.3: CL (CULTURAL  LANDSCAPE DISTRICT)
§ 156.080 PURPOSE.
   (A)   The purpose of the CL, Cultural Landscape, District is to implement
the recommendations of the Comprehensive Plan by:
      (1)   Recognizing and conserving existing agricultural and other
traditional landscapes in their historic form and/or their historic uses;
      (2)   Preserving and enhancing these traditional landscapes; and
      (3)   Increasing access to and interpretation of these landscapes to
residents and visitors;
   (B)   The district is intended to:
      (1)   Perpetuate rural character;
      (2)   Preserve and protect natural and cultural resources, sensitive
areas, historic sites, and agriculturally significant lands;
      (3)   Promote agricultural pursuits; and
      (4)   Balance the urban environment.
   (C)   As part of the nationally-recognized Gullah Geechee Heritage Corridor,
this area should serve as a focus of low impact tourist activity for the town
with an interconnected system of trails and public access to the water where
available.
   (D)   Development should complement and be compatible with existing land
uses and so should occur in a sensitive way that minimizes the visual impact on
traditional landscapes and is compatible with low intensity development forms.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)

   This zoning district classification is available for implementation on
parcels that were designated for Cultural Landscape land uses in the 2009-2019
Comprehensive Plan, as illustrated in Figure 156.081: Parcels Designated for CL
District.

§ 156.083 DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS.
   (A)   Bufferyard requirements. Minimum bufferyard requirements are set forth
in
Subchapter D: Buffers and Screening; however, crop production and horticultural
uses do not require a buffer but all other farm uses do require a buffer.
   (B)   Parking requirements. Minimum parking requirements are set forth in
Subchapter F; however, parking areas may be constructed of pervious materials
as approved by the Town Engineer.
   (C)   Pedestrian facilities.
      (1)   All developments containing six or more dwelling units shall
incorporate a pedestrian and bicycle trail system that connects residential
areas with open space areas, neighborhood amenities, transportation routes,
and, where feasible, adjacent properties.
      (2)   Subject to Planning Commission approval through the sketch plan
process, such trail system may consist of a roadside sidewalk or a path outside
of the right-of- way, or a combination of both.
      (3)   Non-residential developments are required to incorporate new
pedestrian facilities and connect to existing pedestrian facilities.
      (4)   Where appropriate, the trail system may be constructed of pervious
materials or asphalt or similar material.
      (5)   Pedestrian amenities, such as benches and trash cans, shall be
provided where feasible.
      (6)   The trail system shall be improved and maintained by the property
owner.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.084 THROUGH 156.089 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.4: SCW (SHEM CREEK  WATERFRONT DISTRICTS)
§ 156.090 SCW PURPOSE AND FINDINGS.
   (A)   Purpose. The purpose of the SCW, Shem Creek Waterfront, Districts is
to implement the 2019 Shem Creek Area Management Plan by retaining and
protecting the town's:
      (1)   Working waterfront such that the important industries of commercial
fishing and historic water-based recreational uses remain part of the town's
heritage, economy, and quality of life;
      (2)   Waterfront entertainment, dining, and other hospitality venues
along with other supportive water-based commercial operations, including
excursions, vessel rentals, and seafood sales; and
      (3)   Historic, locally-based office and commercial uses in a manner
compatible with the historic character of Shem Creek with nearby marshlands and
wetland habitats.
   (B)   Findings.
      (1)   The 2019 Shem Creek Area Management Plan recommended preserving the
unique history, nature, and economy of Shem Creek and its character as a
working waterfront and destination for town residents, employees, and visitors.
      (2)   Since the 1930s, Shem Creek has been home to commercial scale
water-dependent commercial activities, including fishing, shrimping,
recreational boating, and fuel dispensing, among others. Since the 1960s, these
uses have diminished along the creek but remain viable along the creek today.
      (3)   In the 1960s, Shem Creek began its recent history of restaurants,
recreational boating opportunities, and other new uses available to town
residents and visitors, and as a source of local employment opportunities.
      (4)   Shem Creek's distinguished history has included limited, but
compatible, land uses that provide investment and employment opportunities to
town residents, including small offices and restaurants with opportunities to
view and experience the town's unique marsh environments and habitats.
      (5)   Maintaining the historic design features and scale of the built
environment along Shem Creek is critical to facilitating the objectives and
goals of the Shem Creek Area Management Plan.
      (6)   The Area Management Plan further found that incompatible land uses
have encroached upon working waterfront areas of Shem Creek, to the point where
its use and viability as a working waterfront is in peril.
      (7)   Based on the findings and objectives of the Shem Creek Area
Management Plan, it is important to preserve and provide opportunities for
compatible historic land uses like restaurants, water-based recreational
activities, and other compatible supporting land uses.
      (8)   Based on the findings and objectives of the Area Management Plan,
it is important to preserve and provide opportunities for improving locally-
based non-residential uses that are compatible with nearby marshland habitats
and environmental resources.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.091 DISTRICT BOUNDARY.
   (A)   This subpart establishes three Shem Creek Waterfront Districts:
      (1)   SCW-W (Shem Creek Waterfront– Working District);

      (3)   SCW-N (Shem Creek Waterfront– Natural District).

with the findings and recommendations of the 2019 Shem Creek Area Management

SUBPART 2.5: WG-C (WATERFRONT  GATEWAY–COOPER RIVER DISTRICT)
§ 156.105 PURPOSE AND GOALS.
   (A)   The purpose and intent of the WG-C, Waterfront Gateway–Cooper River,
District is to provide a mechanism for achieving a cohesive, vibrant, active,
and lively waterfront gathering place that acts as a destination for residents
and visitors alike, providing opportunities for employment, housing, lodging,
entertainment, shopping, and dining.
   (B)   The following goals are hereby stated to accomplish the purpose and
intent of the district.
      (1)   This district should seek to take optimum advantage of the town's
waterfront as an opportunity for place making, cultural district, and a tourist
destination. This district will better connect Memorial Waterfront Park with
Patriot's Point and its attractions, as well as connecting back to Coleman and
Johnnie Dodds Boulevards. The Waterfront Gateway District should be an
integrated district with a network of pedestrian paths and streetscapes,
including walks along the waterfront. Land uses should be mixed, including
hotels and lodging facilities, tourist attractions, recreational and marine
facilities, restaurants, and entertainment venues. The creation of public
spaces and outdoor retail environments is encouraged, and events should be
programmed to help keep the district active and lively. Developments should
promote internal trip capture and alternative means of transportation, as this
area has limited transportation access. Land use in this Waterfront Gateway
District will be evaluated based upon transportation impacts. Also, as the term
"Gateway" implies, the appearance of the Waterfront Gateway District must
present an attractive image for the Mount Pleasant community and avoid any
monolithic or out-of-scale structures.
      (2)   The Waterfront Gateway District should be a destination for
tourism, business conventions, events, culture, and arts for Mount Pleasant to
increase the attractiveness of the community for all ages.
      (3)   A high priority for town residents is to expand public access to
the water. This concept includes increasing public access to and views of
natural waterways; creating opportunities for boating, fishing, and other
recreation; and integrating first-class public spaces near natural waterways.
It involves preserving existing view corridors of surrounding water and marsh
from public streets and other public places and developing new and improved
public parks and gathering places along waterfront locations by providing
additional facilities and potential new locations for water access.
      (4)   Promote a "Park Once" policy in the district. Circulation within
the area should be primarily on foot or bicycle, though use of trolleys or
other transit services is encouraged. Development of intermodal transportation
facilities, to include both land-based and water-based transportation options,
is also encouraged. While many people will arrive at the district by car, once
they arrive they should be able to park their vehicles and leave them in one
location. Another advantage of a Park Once Policy is that it encourages shared
parking arrangements, reducing the amount of land needed for parking and
freeing up land for quality, compact, mixed use development.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.106 LOCATION.
   (A)   This zoning district classification is available for implementation on
parcels located west of Magrath Darby Boulevard and all properties located
along Patriots Point and Harry M. Hallman, Jr. Boulevards.
   (B)   These parcels are illustrated in Figure 156.106-1: Parcels Designated
for WG-C District.

IMAGES/0-0-0-12935.png]
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.107 USE MIXING REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Generally. In order to create a district that is successful and
dynamic, an appropriate mix of complementary uses located in relatively close
proximity to each other is required.
   (B)   Horizontal or vertical mixed use. Uses may be horizontally or
vertically mixed. In order to facilitate the mixture of commercial and
residential uses in the same building, residential uses may occur on the street
level or any building level containing commercial uses.
   (C)   Proximity of different uses. In order to accomplish the goal of mixed
use in a horizontally mixed use development, different uses should, to the
greatest extent possible, be located one-quarter mile or less from each other.
   (D)   Land use groups. The required mixture of uses shall include uses from
the following four land use groups, as specified in Table 156.107-1: WG-C Use
Mixing Requirements and as allowed by
Subchapter C:
      (1)   Group 1. Restaurant, entertainment, recreation, and civic uses;
      (2)   Group 2. Retail uses;
      (3)   Group 3. Office and hotel uses; and
      (4)   Group 4. Residential uses.
   (E)   Parcels one acre or less in size. The mixed use requirement shall not
apply on parcels one acre or less in size where a mixture of uses is not
feasible. However, aggregation of multiple smaller parcels is highly encouraged
in order to promote a more effective utilization of land in creating well-
designed projects, connected and unified in design and function. The maximum
benefit allowed by the provisions of this district will result from such
aggregation of properties.
   (F)   Subdivision. Subdivision of property in order to subvert the use
mixing requirement is prohibited.
   (G)   Phasing requirements.
      (1)   Since a goal of this district is to achieve a variety of uses that
will create a vibrancy and attractiveness of use by the public, it is important
for the first phase of a mixed use development to include uses from at least
two land use groups specified in division (D) above.
      (2)   In consideration that market factors may make this provision
difficult to achieve, a phasing plan shall be submitted for approval in
conjunction with a concept plan or sketch plan, as applicable, for any
development proposing not to include two or more uses in the first phase of
construction.

(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.108 DEVELOPMENT AND DESIGN STANDARDS.
   (A)   High quality public realm. In this district, form is as important as
use and a high quality public realm is critical in successfully creating an
environment in which people want to live, work, and play. Primary entrances to
buildings shall be located near the public realm streetscape. An emphasis
should be placed upon a high degree of design quality for the building façade
and a strong interaction between the buildings and the public realm. Public
spaces, such as plazas, should be integrated with surrounding development.
   (B)   Design review required. All development within the WG-C is subject to
the design review process as provided in this chapter. However, in order to
achieve the goals of the WG-C, when in conflict, the site development
requirements as set forth in this subpart take precedence over those found
within other subchapters.
   (C)   Siting and design of buildings and parking areas. Siting and design of
buildings and parking areas shall be closely evaluated to ensure avoidance of
the "silo effect" of buildings surrounded by asphalt parking lots with no
meaningful relationship to adjacent developments.
   (D)   Civic uses. Because of the nature of their uses, build-to lines,
setbacks, and other design elements for civic uses shall be determined through
the design review process.
   (E)   Interconnectivity.
      (1)   Streets should be interconnected where possible. Site plans should
provide opportunities for future interconnectivity if such cannot be
accomplished at the time of development.
      (2)   Cul-de-sacs or dead end streets are not permitted unless they have
a terminal vista of the waterfront.
   (F)   Alternative modes of transportation.
      (1)   A development shall accommodate a variety of modes of
transportation.
      (2)   A pedestrian/bicycle system and related amenities shall be provided
in strategic locations, and shall be interconnected both within the development
and to other adjacent developments.
      (3)   Provision of a shuttle service is highly encouraged. Such service
should be coordinated with surrounding properties, and all developments should
include an area designated for shuttle access.
      (4)   Provision of bus shelters is highly encouraged and will require
coordination with CARTA early in the development process. Bus shelter location
and design shall be subject to approval through the design review process.
   (G)   Terminal vistas.
      (1)   Properties that terminate views down streets shall be identified
during the design review process, and will be held to a higher architectural
standard along this visible façade.
      (2)   Such identified properties are those that are located across from
side streets that intersect the primary street and terminate or intersect and
continue at a different angle. Properties that are at the end of a straightaway
on a primary street shall also meet this requirement.
   (H)   Avian habitats. As the Cooper River Waterfront Gateway District area
is an important stopover site for migratory birds, required landscaping shall
incorporate bird-friendly plants with an intention to create or augment habitat
areas.
   (I)   Open space. A minimum of 10% of the total project area shall be
reserved as contiguous open space. A portion of this open space is encouraged
to be natural open space in order to serve as wildlife corridors/conservation
areas.
   (J)   Public realm. An engaging public realm is critical to the success of
this district and its importance cannot be overstated. To this end, a high
degree of design and material quality is expected. The various public realm
components are subject to approval through the design review process, but shall
generally adhere to the specifications listed below.
      (1)   Waterfront public walkways and pedestrian waterfront connections.
Recognizing the importance of public access to the waterfront, construction and
dedication of a public walkway is required for properties adjacent to the
river/marsh. The walkway shall be constructed and dedicated prior to approval
of a final plat for any portion of the proposed development. If a final plat is
not required, the walkway shall be constructed and dedicated prior to issuance
of a certificate of occupancy for any portion of the proposed development. A
strong emphasis shall also be placed on areas that connect pedestrians from the
street to the waterfront. Such pedestrian waterfront connections are required
for properties adjacent to the river/marsh. Generally, these areas shall
consist of the following elements:
         (a)   Dimensions and location of waterfront public walkways.
Waterfront public walkways shall be generally located parallel to the shoreline
and shall include an open area with a minimum width of ten feet and an average
width of 40 feet measured landward from the critical line, which may include
the critical line buffer where such buffer is required. Waterfront public
walkways shall include a primary path or boardwalk with a minimum clear width
of ten feet, located to the greatest extent possible adjacent to the shoreline.
The primary path may be located within the required critical line buffer.
Secondary paths may be provided and shall be at least six feet in width.
         (b)   Dimensions and location of pedestrian waterfront connections.
Pedestrian waterfront connections shall be generally located perpendicular to
the shoreline, shall include an open area with a minimum width of 30 feet, and
shall include a primary path with a minimum clear width of eight feet. The
number and location of pedestrian waterfront connections shall be determined
through the design review process.
         (c)   Landscaping. Public walkways and waterfront connections shall be
planted with high quality native or naturalized coastal vegetation, to include
of a minimum of one 2.5-inch caliper canopy tree for approximately every 100
linear feet of area in addition to other appropriate landscaping, to include
understory trees, shrubs, and grasses. Lawn area may be used but it must remain
accessible.
         (d)   Acreage to count towards open space requirements. Waterfront
public walkways may satisfy all or a portion of the open space requirements of
this section.
      (2)   Streetscape. As another critical component of the public realm, a
strong emphasis shall be placed on the appearance of the streetscape.
Generally, this area shall consist of the following elements:
         (a)   Landscaping. Three canopy trees of a minimum four-inch caliper
shall be required for each 100 linear feet of street frontage using species
approved during the design review process. Such tree types shall be consistent
with each block and evenly spaced, with exceptions made for curb cuts,
utilities, and other obstructions. Planters shall be required as a design
element to soften the building exterior and enhance the streetscape appearance.
         (b)   Relationship of buildings to the street. Changes in elevation
between the building front and the street shall be avoided to the fullest
extent possible. Stairs abutting the sidewalk may be utilized to accommodate a
change in grade elevation. Stair design shall be integrated into the overall
streetscape design.
         (c)   Sidewalks. There shall be a public sidewalk at least ten feet in
width located on both sides of all streets within the WG-C, either within the
right-of-way or within a pedestrian easement on private property.
      (3)   Site furnishings.
         (a)   To ensure consistency throughout the WG-C, site furnishings
should be similar to the current styles used at the Memorial Waterfront Park,
as illustrated in Figure 156.108-1: WG-C Site Furnishings.
         (b)   Permanent or temporary design features shall not impede
pedestrian access on the public sidewalk.
         (c)   Benches shall be located in visible and convenient locations.
The public realm should also include trash receptacles at sufficient intervals,
as well as strategically placed bicycle parking facilities.
         (d)   All site furnishings shall be installed at the time of
construction.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-12937.png]
 
      ( 4)   Lighting. At a minimum, safety lighting shall be provided along
the length of the walkways and waterfront connections and shall be installed at
the time of construction. To ensure consistency throughout the Waterfront
Gateway District, the streetscape shall include light fixtures similar to those
currently existing in the area, as illustrated in Figure 156.108-2: WG-C Light
Fixtures.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-12939.png]
 
      (5)   Signs. Standard wayfinding signs shall be placed in strategic
locations throughout the public realm. Wayfinding signs are intended to convey
navigational directions to pedestrians and bicyclists.
      (6)   Maintenance responsibility. The waterfront public walkways and
pedestrian waterfront connections shall be established within a recorded public
access easement. The waterfront public walkways and pedestrian waterfront
connections, as well as all site furnishings/public amenities, shall be
installed and maintained by the property owner.
   (K)   Bufferyards. In general, bufferyard requirements on individual parcels
are specified in Subchapter D; except that front bufferyards are not required
in lieu of the streetscape requirements contained in this subpart. However,
contingent upon approval through the design review process, developments
providing opportunities for interconnectivity with adjacent parcels may forgo
side and rear bufferyards along parcel lines.
   (L)   Density. The maximum residential density is 12 dwelling units per
acre.
   (M)   Side yard setback. A minimum side yard setback is not required.
   (N)   Rear yard setback. The minimum rear yard setback is 15 feet, except as
provided below:
      (1)   Contingent upon approval through the design review process,
development utilizing an integrated site plan involving multiple parcels may
forgo rear yard setbacks along parcel lines.
      (2)   Setbacks for civic uses shall be in accordance with the provisions
of division (D), above.
   (O)   Elevated buildings.
      (1)   Buildings in flood zones.
         (a)   In order to project a pedestrian-friendly streetscape, it is
highly recommended that alternatives to elevating non-residential and mixed use
buildings located in "A" flood zones be pursued. This may be accomplished by
floodproofing or altering the elevation of the finished floor inside the
building.
         (b)   However, in the event that these techniques are not feasible and
the building must be elevated, such elevation may not exceed the minimum
elevation required, which includes two feet of additional freeboard. To the
greatest extent possible, elevating the building shall not compromise the width
and integrity of the public realm.
      (2)   Buildings elevated for parking. Buildings may be elevated to
accommodate grade-level parking, pursuant to the provisions of §
156.109(F).
   (P)   Gated access. Gated access to a development is prohibited, although
gated access to parking areas may be permitted subject to the design review
process if access to open space is not impeded.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.109 PARKING REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Shared parking requirements for mixed use developments. Because one of
the primary functions of the district is to provide a pedestrian-oriented
experience and an overabundance of parking areas would detract from this goal,
parking within a mixed-use development shall be shared for all uses.
   (B)   Parking for non-residential uses. Required parking is calculated
utilizing the shared parking standards established by the Urban Land Institute
(ULI). ULI parking standards must meet a Level of Service (LOS) A or B for
walking distance. If shared parking standards cannot be achieved, the ratios
specified in Subchapter F, Part 2 apply.
   (C)   Parking for residential uses. Parking spaces for residential uses is
limited to a range of a minimum of 1.5 spaces and a maximum of 2.0 spaces per
dwelling unit.
   (D)   On-street parking.
      (1)   On-street parking is allowed within the district if it is depicted
on an on-street parking plan map, submitted with the development site plan, and
approved through the design review process.
      (2)   The on-street parking plan shall include detailed design guidelines
for the spaces, specifying items such as paving materials and the manner in
which the spaces shall be identified.
   (E)   Design of parking lots and loading areas. All parking lots and
exterior loading areas shall be buffered from any adjacent pedestrian way by
planting street trees and providing a landscaped area with a continuous row of
high shrubs, or a fence or seating wall.
   (F)   Parking structures.
      (1)   Screening required. All parking structures that front primary
streets or relate to the public realm shall be screened. Screening may include
residences, retail storefronts, other nonresidential uses, landscaping, or
other appropriate architectural features as determined through the design
review process.
      (2)   Sloping floors. Sloping floors shall not be visible from primary
streets.
      (3)   Vehicular access. Wherever possible, vehicular access to parking
structures shall be from side streets or alleys and not directly from the
primary street.
      (4)   Incentive for parking structures. There is no maximum parking limit
for non-residential uses if a parking structure is utilized on site.
   (G)   Parking for outdoor dining uses. Parking for outdoor dining uses shall
be as provided in Subchapter F, Part 2 for restaurant use and not based upon
square footage of the outdoor use area.
   (H)   Parking for streetside dining uses. Additional parking is not required
for streetside dining uses.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.110 THROUGH 156.114 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.6: CONSERVATION AND  RECREATION DISTRICTS
§ 156.115 CO (CONSERVATION-OPEN SPACE DISTRICT).
   (A)   Purpose. The purposes of the CO, Conservation-Open Space, District are
to:
      (1)   Lessen the hazards and loss of property, life, and the reduction of
health and safety due to periodic inundation of flood waters, by restricting or
prohibiting uses in these areas;
      (2)   Ensure the preservation of significant natural amenities against
incompatible development;
      (3)   Provide for opportunities for improved public recreation
activities; a community-wide recreational network of public paths,
watercourses, buffer zones, and recreation spaces; and a scenic easement where
important views and vistas that could preserve the community heritage could be
maintained for the public good; and
      (4)   Provide for, and permit, an appropriate valuation by the tax
assessor and/or land appraiser that reflects the conservation and/or open space
use of land.
   (B)   Location. The CO District is generally appropriate in areas designated
as Conservation Open Space and Agricultural/Forested on the Comprehensive Plan
Future Land Use Map.
   (C)   Allowed uses. See
Subchapter C.
   (D)   Dimensional standards. Table 156.115-1 establishes dimensional
standards for the CO District.

§ 156.116 CRO (CONSERVATION- RECREATION-OPEN SPACE DISTRICT).
   (A)   Purpose. The purposes of the CRO, Conservation-Recreation-Open Space,
District are to:
      (1)   Provide opportunities for improved public and/or private recreation
activities; and to provide for a community-wide network of open space, buffer
zones, and recreation spaces;
      (2)   Ensure the preservation of conservation, recreation and/or open
space use of land against undesirable development;
      (3)   Lessen the hazards and loss of property, life, and the reduction of
health and safety due to periodic inundation of flood waters, by restricting or
prohibiting uses in these areas; and
      (4)   Provide for, and permit, an appropriate valuation by the tax
assessor and/or land appraiser that reflects the conservation, recreation and/
or open space use of land.
   (B)   Location. The CRO District is generally appropriate in areas
designated as Conservation Open Space and Recreational Open Space on the
Comprehensive Plan Future Land Use Map.
   (C)   Allowed uses. See
Subchapter C.
   (D)   Dimensional standards. Table 156.116-1 establishes dimensional

§§ 156.117 THROUGH 156.124 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.7: PUBLIC-INSTITUTIONAL  DISTRICTS
§ 156.125 PURPOSE.
   This subpart recognizes that certain public, civic, and institutional
support uses and activities are necessary and proper for the conduct of a
civilized society and that, in the proper context, such uses may coexist with
little harm to other neighboring uses. This subpart establishes two districts
that accommodate public and institutional uses of varying intensities.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.126 SITE AND ARCHITECTURAL DESIGN IN PUBLIC-INSTITUTIONAL DISTRICTS.
   (A)   The appearance and form of improvements with respect to site and
architectural design shall be consistent with the general theme of the area in
which the use is located. This requirement will be based upon a site-specific
analysis (site plan review) and may necessitate such reasonable additional
requirements as may be judged prudent to achieve the desired results of
acceptable coexistence with neighboring uses.
   (B) Special considerations may be given to such site-specific design
elements as may be required to accommodate operational or other unique
characteristics of the individual uses, which may enhance or relax the minimum
standards prescribed herein, with specific written justification for the same
noted on the plans.
   (C)   All lights or lighting arrangements used for purposes of advertising
or night operations shall be directed away from adjoining or nearby residential
properties, and further meet the requirements in
Subchapter H, Part 3, Subpart 3.4.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.127 PI-1 (PUBLIC-INSTITUTIONAL-1 DISTRICT).
   (A)   Purpose. The purpose of the PI-1, Public-Institutional 1, District is
intended to accommodate certain public, civic, and institutional support uses
and activities of a generally low level of intensity, such as schools,
libraries, police and fire stations, religious facilities, judicial centers and
governmental or public utility administration buildings and uses, pump
stations, and the like.
   (B)   Location. The PI-1 District is generally appropriate in areas
designated as Community Facilities, and Recreational Open Space on the
Comprehensive Plan Future Land Use Map.
   (C)   Allowed uses. See
Subchapter C.
   (D)   General conditions of use.
      (1)   Uses allowed in PI-1 are limited to those uses of a generally
comparable level of intensity with respect to size, scale, and vehicle-trip
generation in relation to surrounding uses, with the obvious exception to
certain large-scale uses listed.
      (2)   PI-1 uses are characterized by a higher level of site and building
design and materials, resulting in an orderly arrangement of parking and
storage in designated areas that are properly surfaced and landscaped with an
integrated drainage plan.
      (3)   Buildings and sites shall be designed and constructed in a manner
that blends in with adjoining residential character of the area, if applicable.
   (E)   Dimensional standards. Table 156.127-1 establishes dimensional
standards for the PI-1 District.

§ 156.128 PI-2 (PUBLIC-INSTITUTIONAL-2 DISTRICT).
   (A)   Purpose. The purpose of the PI-2, Public-Institutional 2, District is
intended to accommodate certain public, civic, and institutional support uses
and activities of a generally high level of intensity, such uses being
characterized as more industrial in nature and consisting of public works and
sanitation sites and facilities, treatment facilities, lay-down yards and open
lot storage of materials, heavy equipment and vehicles, and the like.
   (B)   Location. The PI-2 District is generally appropriate in areas
designated as Community Facilities on the Comprehensive Plan Future Land Use
Map.
   (C)   Allowed uses. See
Subchapter C.
   (D)   General conditions of use.
      (1)   Uses allowed in PI-2 may be those of a generally higher level of
intensity with respect to size, scale, and vehicle-trip generation in relation
to surrounding uses.
      (2)   These uses may be characterized by higher level of service-vehicle-
trip generation and conditions that result in a generally more offensive visual
display of site utilization. However, every effort shall be made to maintain an
orderly arrangement of parking and storage in designated areas that are
properly surfaced and landscaped with an integrated drainage plan.
      (3)   Buildings and sites shall be designed and constructed in a manner
that blends in with adjoining character of the area to the extent possible,
utilizing such techniques as larger lots, and more intensive screening and
buffering requirements to shield unattractive elements from view.
      (4)   Lighting standards may reflect the need for security, but must also
recognize the need to minimize sky glow and light pollution, and adverse impact
on adjoining properties.
   (E)   Dimensional standards. Table 156.128-1 establishes dimensional
standards for the PI-2 District.

§§ 156.129 THROUGH 156.159 RESERVED.
PART 3: PLANNED DISTRICTS
SUBPART 3.1: PD (PLANNED DEVELOPMENT DISTRICT)
§ 156.160 PURPOSE.
   (A)   The purpose of the PD, Planned Development, District is to:
      (1)   Achieve the objectives of the Comprehensive Plan by allowing
flexibility in development that will result in improved design, character, and
quality of new mixed use developments that also preserve natural and scenic
features of open spaces as a design component;
      (2)   Encourage flexibility in the development of land in order to
promote its most appropriate use;
      (3)   Improve the design, character, and quality of new development;
      (4)   Facilitate the provision of streets and utilities; and
      (5)   Preserve the natural and scenic features of open areas.
   (B)   The PD District provisions must exhibit innovative site planning for a
mixture of residential and non-residential uses as reflected in the PD District
map, which becomes the zoning district map for the property.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.161 LOCATION AND APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   The PD District is available for implementation:
      (1)   Throughout the town or in conjunction with an annexation of
property into the town; and
      (2)   On sites at least three acres in size.
   (B)   Any area may be zoned as a Planned Development District if:
      (1)   The proposed development meets the requirements of §§ 6-29-720(C)
(4) and 6-29-740 of the South Carolina Local Government Comprehensive Planning
Enabling Act of 1994, as amended;
      (2)   Two or more principal dwelling types and at least one commercial
use are proposed for development on a single parcel or on multiple contiguous
parcels; and
      (3)   The proposed development cannot be accomplished under a standard
base zoning district.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.162 ALLOWED USES.
   (A)   Any use proposed by the developer and considered by the Planning
Commission and Town Council as being compatible with other nearby uses within
and beyond the district may be allowed in a PD District.
   (B)   A list of allowed uses within a particular PD District shall be
adopted as part of the regulations applying to that district.
   (C)   Thereafter, the uses allowed in the district shall be restricted to
those listed, approved, and adopted.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.163 DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS.
   (A)   Generally. Overall site design shall be harmonious in terms of
landscaping, enclosure of principal and accessory uses, size of structures,
street patterns, and use relationships. Variety in building types, heights,
facades, setbacks, and size of open spaces is encouraged.
   (B)   Variations from Zoning Code regulations.
      (1)   A PD District may provide for variations from the regulations of
the other established zoning districts concerning use, setbacks, lot size,
density, bulk, and other requirements to accommodate flexibility in the
arrangement of uses for the general purpose of promoting and protecting the
public health, safety, and general welfare.
      (2)   The permitted uses and development standards must be specifically
enumerated in the planned development ordinance. To the extent not specifically
modified by the PD ordinance, all other applicable provisions of this chapter
apply to the development and use of the property.
      (3)   When a proposed PD District is located within the boundary of an
overlay district, the proposed PD design and development standards will be
considered in context with the purpose of the overlay district.
      (4)   PD Districts, whether existing or proposed, that do not establish
minimum yard requirements, shall utilize R-1 District minimum yard
requirements. This provision shall apply to minimum yard requirements only and
not to minimum lot requirements or density.
   (C)   Bufferyards. Bufferyards are required along the periphery of a PD. The
type of bufferyard depends on the proposed peripheral use and the adjacent land
use, in accordance with Subchapter D: Buffers and Screening.
   (D)   Off-street parking and loading. Areas designated for parking and
loading or for traffic ways shall be physically separated from public streets
by suitable barriers against the unchanneled ingress and egress of motor
vehicles.
      (1)   Commercial, industrial, institutional, and apartment complex uses
shall have not more than two access points to any one public street, unless
unusual circumstances dictate otherwise.
      (2)   All uses shall be located at least 100 feet from the intersection
of any street lines, and shall be designed in a manner conducive to safe
ingress and egress.
   (E)   Open space. A minimum of 10% of total land area must be reserved for
open space, which may be in the form of urban parks or squares.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.164 PLANNED DEVELOPMENT DISTRICT MAP.
   (A)   The rezoning application must contain a map depicting the allowed
location(s) for the land uses allowed in the district.
   (B)   Upon approval of the rezoning application, the PD District map becomes
the zoning map for the subject property.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.165 THROUGH 156.179 RESERVED.
PART 4: OVERLAY DISTRICTS
SUBPART 4.1: MIXED USE CENTERS OVERLAY DISTRICT
§ 156.180 PURPOSE.
   (A)   This subpart is intended to implement the 2019-2029 Town of Mount
Pleasant Comprehensive Plan by shifting from high-intensity linear development
to the creation of more compact community-building centers of activity through
the redevelopment of mixed-use centers.
   (B)   This subpart defines mixed-use centers by their location, situation,
and function within the town.
      (1)   The neighborhood and community mixed use centers are local mixed-
use centers at the neighborhood and community scale. Their main purpose is the
support of surrounding neighborhoods and creation of community space.
      (2)   The redevelopment centers are typically older commercial and multi-
family areas that may be approaching the end of their development cycle. The
goal is that redevelopment in these areas captures the essence of the community
mixed use centers, but at a larger scale, providing community spaces along with
businesses, attainable and senior housing, and employment opportunities.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.181 DISTRICT BOUNDARY.
   (A)   The Mixed Use Centers Overlay District, depicted in Figure 156.181-1,
is comprised of three subdistricts:
      (1)   NMU-OD (Neighborhood Mixed Use Overlay District);
      (2)   CMU-OD (Community Mixed Use Overlay District); and
      (3)   RC-OD (Redevelopment Center Overlay District).
   (B)   Each subdistrict regulates development in at least two geographic
areas.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-12941.png]
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.182 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   The overlay district applies to all lots, except those zoned PI-1 or
PI-2, located within each geographic subdistrict area, as illustrated on the
maps in this Subpart.
   (B)   The use regulations in the Mixed Use Centers Overlay District apply to
all lots subject to the overlay.
   (C)   All other provisions of the Mixed Use Centers Overlay District apply
to:
      (1)   The establishment of a new use on a previously undeveloped lot;
      (2)   A change in use of a developed lot;
      (3)   The construction of any new building or structure and its
associated site improvements, if all project costs exceed $250,000; and
      (4)   The renovation, repair, alteration, or other improvement of an
existing structure that exceeds the lesser of:
         (a)   $250,000 in total project costs; or
         (b)   50% of its replacement value at the time of renovation, repair,
or alteration. Replacement value of existing principal structures is determined
using the taxable/use value of improvement established by the Charleston County
Assessor’s Office.
   (D)   The thresholds in division (C)(4) above apply cumulatively, rather
than for individual improvements. PLAN Department staff tracks improvements to
existing structures to ensure compliance with these provisions.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.183 DESIGN REVIEW REQUIRED.
   All development within the Mixed Use Centers Overlay District is subject to
Subchapter H and requires design review approval in accordance with
Subchapter I, Part 12.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.184 HIERARCHY OF STANDARDS.
   (A)   The Mixed Use Centers Overlay District specifies certain development
standards. Where not modified by this overlay district, the development
standards applicable to the base zoning district apply.
   (B)   Where conflicts arise, applicable standards are determined using the
following hierarchy:
      (1)   First in application are standards specified in existing, in force
development agreements;
      (2)   Second in application are standards specified in existing Planned
Development District ordinances;
      (3)   Third in application are standards specified in the Mixed Use
Centers Overlay District;
      (4)   Fourth in application are standards specified in
Subchapter H; and
      (5)   Fifth in application are the underlying base zoning district or
other applicable zoning district standards and land development regulations.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.185 BUFFERYARDS.
   (A)   Exterior bufferyards. 
Subchapter D, Part 2 applies along the exterior boundaries of a development
site.
   (B)   Interior bufferyards. On the interior of a site, developments must
include at least three street trees per 100 linear feet.
   (C)   Parking lot bufferyards. In addition to the right-of-way bufferyard
required by
Subchapter D, Part 2, the street frontage of surface parking areas must be
screened in accordance with §
156.186(C)(2).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.186 PARKING.
   (A)   Generally. Parking spaces must be provided in accordance with
Subchapter F, unless otherwise specified in this subpart.
   (B)   Location of parking spaces.
      (1)   In all subdistricts, parking spaces may be located:
         (a)   In off-street surface parking areas, which may be shared in
accordance with §
156.774; and
         (b)   On-street, in accordance with §
156.773. In the CMU-OD and RC-OD, on-street parking spaces shall be located
only on private streets.
      (2)   In the RC-OD, parking spaces may also be located in parking
structures.
   (C)   Surface parking areas. Surface parking areas:
      (1)   Shall not occupy more than one-third of a lot’s frontage along the
primary street, except when the surface parking area is the principal use of
the lot; and
      (2)   Shall be buffered from all adjacent streets by:
         (a)   A landscaped area with a continuous row of high shrubs; or
         (b)   A masonry wall that is three feet to four feet in height.
      (3)   This division does not apply to parking spaces for individual
townhouse dwelling units, if provided on the same lot as the dwelling unit.
   (D)   Parking structures.
      (1)   Retail storefronts or other commercial uses must comprise at least
60% of the ground floor street frontage of a parking structure.
      (2)   Vehicular access to a parking structure shall be from side streets
or alleys and not directly from the primary street.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)

   (B)   Residential uses.
      (1)   PD District required.

only if approved through a Planned Development District ordinance (see

Subchapter I, Part 6). The three-acre minimum site area for a PD District does
not apply.
         (b)   All other new residential uses are prohibited, except when
allowed by an existing PD District.

in accordance with §
156.892.

      (1)   Amount and type of open space required. At least one activity zone
or plaza is required for each development.
      (2)   Minimum area. An activity zone or plaza must comprise at least 5%
of the total area of the development.
      (3)   Location and design.
         (a)   Activity zones. When a proposed building is not located adjacent
to a street right-of-way, the activity zone is located adjacent to the building
where it is usable and easily accessible by the building occupants.
         (b)   Plazas. A plaza is centrally located within a proposed
development where it is easily accessible by the development’s occupants. The
design review process establishes the appropriate location for a plaza.
      (4)   Parking. Activity zones and plazas do not require additional
parking spaces.
      (5)   Low impact development. Developments that are subject to the
Environmental Guidelines for Land Development (see §
155.054(B)) should incorporate low impact development features into the
required open space.

   (B)   Residential uses.

156.338, except lay-down yards and maintenance facilities with open lot storage
of materials, vehicles, and equipment; ports; and recycling and waste-related
facilities; and
         (g)   Transportation terminals for public transit.
   (D)   Accessory and temporary uses. Accessory and temporary uses are allowed
in accordance with the regulations applicable to the base district.
   (E)   Height.
      (1)   The height of structures within the RC-OD along public streets and
along any lot line that adjoins a residential zoning district located outside
the RC-OD or a lot containing only dwelling units located outside the RC-OD is
limited to three stories or 45 feet, whichever is less.
      (2)   Where the Building Height Plan Map allows for a structure more than
three stories, a “step-back” building design is required in accordance with §
156.892.
   (F)   Open space.

      (3)   Location and design.

to a street right-of-way, the activity zone is located adjacent to the building
where it is usable and easily accessible by the building occupants.
         (b)   Plazas. A plaza is centrally located within a proposed
development where it is easily accessible by the development’s occupants. The
design review process establishes the appropriate location for a plaza.

Environmental Guidelines for Land Development (see §
155.054(B)) should incorporate low impact development features into the
required open space.

§§ 156.190 THROUGH 156.199 RESERVED.
SUBPART 4.2: NP-OD (NEIGHBORHOOD CHARACTER PRESERVATION OVERLAY DISTRICT)
§ 156.200 PURPOSE AND FINDINGS.
   (A)   Purpose. The purpose of the NP-OD, Neighborhood Character Preservation
Overlay District, is to:
      (1)   Acknowledge the inherent attributes of older, established
neighborhoods and their associated characteristics of walkable development
patterns, urban design, streetscape, and architecture that contribute to the
identity of Mount Pleasant;
      (2)   Allow for the continued construction, addition to, and renovation
of homes located in these older neighborhoods of Mount Pleasant, nearest to
Coleman Boulevard, Shem Creek, and the Historic District, by creating a special
overlay zoning classification with flexible development standards that allow
for the continuation of the distinctive and identifiable attributes of a given
neighborhood; and
      (3)   Provide protection for persons and property within this district
against flooding and improve drainage.
   (B)   Findings. In furtherance of the stated purpose, Town Council finds and
declares the following.
      (1)   This district is in the older part of the town developed before the
current ordinances were enacted. Subsequently, many of the lots and structures
are nonconforming.
      (2)   The homes located in this area are considerably smaller than new
homes being built on similarly zoned lots elsewhere in the town.
      (3)   Creating a special overlay district will enable homeowners to add
porches and increased unenclosed living areas to homes that are currently at or
over the front yard setback required.
      (4)   The area where the impervious surface limit applies is largely
developed and is in an older and traditional part of town that is naturally
prone to flooding. The impervious surface limit will serve to reduce flooding
and improve drainage in this described area.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.201 DISTRICT BOUNDARY.
   (A)   The boundaries of this district encompass several neighborhoods along
Coleman Boulevard, including:
      (1)   Old Mount Pleasant, as bounded by lots on the southwest by the
northeast side of Whilden Street/Royall Avenue, on the north by Coleman-Ben
Sawyer Boulevard, and on the southeast by marsh areas along the Intracoastal
Waterway and Jeanette Creek;
      (2)   The Groves, including lots fronting Lansing Drive, Tall Pine Road,
Cliffwood Drive, Groves Manor Court, Lakeview Drive, Palm Street, Shannon
Drive, and Japonica Road;
      (3)   Cooper Estates, including lots fronting Cottingham Drive, Pelzer
Drive, Pawley Road, Trowman Lane, Cummings Circle, Searle Court, Meader Lane,
and Noble Lane, and lots on the south side of Williamson Drive;
      (4)   Shemwood, including lots fronting Vincent Drive, Ellen Avenue,
Pearl Avenue, Joyce Avenue, Shem Drive, Bose Court, Elizabeth Court, Camelia
Drive, Toler Drive, Armsway Street, North Shem Drive, South Shem Drive, and
Charlotte Lane; and
      (5)   Bayview Acres, including lots fronting Bayview Drive, Garland Road,
Harborgate Drive, Queens Court, Hawthorne Street, Quince Street, and Palm
Street.
   (B)   Figure 156.201-1 depicts the boundary of the NP-OD.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-12978.png]
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.202 APPLICABILITY.
   The NP-OD standards apply within the district boundary to lots with the
following base zoning districts:
   (A)   R-1;
   (B)   R-2;
   (C)   R-3;
   (D)   R-4, for impervious coverage standards only; and
   (E)   PD, for impervious coverage standards only.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.203 DIMENSIONAL STANDARDS.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   Dimensional standards for lots subject to this subpart shall be in
accordance with those specified in Subchapter B, Part 2 for the underlying
district, except as modified in this section.
      (2)   When in conflict, the standards in this subpart take precedence
over the standards for the village scale pedestrian area. (See Subchapter H)
   (B)   Front yard setback.
      (1)   The following front yard setbacks are allowed for porches,
balconies, stoops, and other similar unenclosed architectural features that may
or may not have a roof. Other building elements are subject to the generally
applicable front yard setback for the underlying zoning district.
      (2)   Nonconforming lots in this overlay shall not receive the additional
20% reduction on front yard setbacks as provided in Subchapter K.

§§ 156.204 THROUGH 156.214 RESERVED.
SUBPART 4.3: OV-HD (OLD VILLAGE  HISTORIC DISTRICT)
§ 156.215 PURPOSE.
   The intent of the OV-HD is to:
   (A)   Protect, preserve, and enhance the architecture of the Old Village;
   (B)   Promote the economic and general welfare of the residents of the Old
Village and the town;
   (C)   Foster civic pride;
   (D)   Encourage harmonious growth and development within the Old Village
Historic District; and
   (E)   Promote the use and preservation of the historic district for the
education and welfare of the residents of the town.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.216 DISTRICT BOUNDARY.
   (A)   Old Village Historic District.
      (1)   The boundaries encompassed by the OV-HD are described as:
         (a)   On the north beginning at the intersection of Whilden and Live
Oak Streets and running generally southeasterly following the western side of
Whilden Street, however, including the property on the east side of Whilden
Street located at 440 Whilden Street know as St. Andrews Episcopal Church, and
continuing on as Whilden Street becomes Royall Avenue to the common corporate
municipal limit line of the town and the Town of Sullivan's Island;
         (b)   Then running generally southwesterly to the town corporate
municipal boundary line in Charleston Harbor;
         (c)   Then generally northwesterly to a point at the centerline of the
mouth of Shem Creek from the northern extended side property line of the
residentially zoned lot at the foot of Haddrell Street, following the same
generally southwesterly and extending east back to the intersection of Whilden
and Live Oak Streets, including only the residentially zoned lots abutting
Haddrell Street, Magwood Lane, Live Oak Street, and Church Street, saving and
excepting therefrom the residential house lots on the south side of Shem Creek
in the development known as The Boatyard.
      (2)   These boundaries are represented in Figure 156.216-1 with the black
outline.
   (B)   National Register of Historic Places Historic District.
      (1)   Partially within the boundaries of the locally designated historic
district is a 30-block area listed on the National Register of Historic Places
(NRHP) on March 30, 1973; the boundaries of which are as follows:
         (a)   On the north by Shem Creek;
         (b)   On the east by the western edge of Whilden Street and Royal
Avenue (with the exception of the lot on the east side of the street containing
the Mount Pleasant (St. Andrews) Episcopal Church);
         (c)   On the south by McCants Drive; and
         (d)   On the west by Charleston Harbor.
      (2)   These boundaries are represented in Figure 156.216-1 with the red-
colored hatch.
      (3)   This subpart does not apply to lots located in the NRHP historic
district but outside the OV-HD boundary.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-12980.png]
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.217 PROHIBITED USES.
   (A)   Short-term rental of any residentially-zoned parcel is prohibited. A
short-term rental is the rental or lease of a residential dwelling unit for a
duration of less than 30 consecutive days.
   (B)   Roofs and roofed structures on docks are prohibited.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.218 LOT DIMENSIONAL, FRONTAGE, COVERAGE, YARD, AND HEIGHT REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Minimum requirements. The minimum dimensional requirements described
in the underlying zoning district apply to all residential lots, except as
otherwise expressly provided herein.
   (B)   Minimum lot frontage. Lots shall have at least 60 feet of frontage on
a public street.
   (C)   Impervious surface coverage. No more than 40% of a lot may be covered
by impervious surfaces as defined in Subchapter N.
   (D)   Yard requirements. For properties located within the Old Village
Historic District, principal structure setback distances shall be determined
during the certificate of appropriateness review process. Justification for
setback distances shall be based on the established pattern of historic
principal structures on adjacent lots and the block with respect to the overall
character of the streetscape and district by citing the specific historic
principal structures and setback used to determine the setback for new
construction, additions, or alterations.
   (E)   Accessory structure height. Accessory structures, including detached
accessory dwelling units, are limited to the maximum height specified in §
156.424 or the height of the principal structure, whichever is less.
   (F)   Accessory structure location.
      (1)   Single-frontage and corner lots. For parcels abutting one right-of-
way or two rights-of-way intersecting one another, accessory structures shall
be sited to the rear of the primary structure as shown in Figure 156.218-1:
Accessory Structures on Single-Frontage and Corner Lots in the OV-HD.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-12982.png]
 
      (2)   Double frontage lots.
         (a)   For parcels abutting non-intersecting rights-of-way, accessory
structures shall be sited to the interior of the parcels as shown in Figure
156.218-2: Accessory Structures on Double-Frontage Lots in the OV-HD except as
provided in division (F)(2)(b) below.
         (b)   For parcels abutting wetlands/marsh or harbor, an accessory pool
or spa may be placed in closer proximity to the wetland/marsh or harbor.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-12984.png]
 
         (c)   Historic designated accessory structures shall be considered
conforming regardless of location on the lot.
         (d)   The harbor, marsh, and any street or alley shall be considered
rights-of-way for the purposes of siting accessory buildings.
         (e)   The Historic District Preservation Commission may not reduce the
setbacks for accessory structures.
   (G)   Additional development requirements.
      (1)   Design guidelines. New construction, exterior remodeling, and
demolition of any building is subject to the Old Village Historic District
Guidelines.
      (2)   Construction on public property.
         (a)   The HDPC shall not approve any porches, steps, posts, fences,
walks, or other appurtenances extending over, on, or within a public sidewalk,
alleyway, or street right-of-way, unless the particular item is necessary for
the authentic restoration or maintenance of the particular project and will not
impede pedestrian or vehicular traffic or constitute a public safety hazard.
The preceding shall not allow approval of on-street parking located in the
public right-of-way.
         (b)   Any area restored or maintained on, over, or within a public
sidewalk or public alley under the authority hereof shall be the responsibility
of the owner.
         (c)   The owner's restoration, reconstruction, or maintenance of any
such item within such area shall constitute the owner's agreement to protect
and hold the town harmless against any and all liability, cost, damage, or
expense suffered or sustained by the town, as a result of, or growing out of,
the restoration, reconstruction, or maintenance.
      (3)   Maintenance and repair.
         (a)   Nothing in this subpart shall be construed to prevent the
ordinary maintenance or repair of any exterior architectural feature that does
not involve a change in design, material, color, or outer appearance thereof.
         (b)   Nor shall it be construed to prevent the construction,
reconstruction, alteration, restoration, or demolition of any such feature that
the Building Official or similar official certifies is required by the public
safety because of an unsafe or dangerous condition.
      (4)   Building area ratio (BAR) requirement.
         (a)   New construction of residential dwellings, including additions
and their accessory use buildings, are subject to a building area ratio (BAR).
         (b)   The BAR is calculated by ascertaining the total of number of
square feet of building areas taken on a horizontal plane, specifically
including any cantilevered areas, of the principal building and all accessory
buildings (except those less than 144 square feet in area), exclusive of
uncovered porches (decks), terraces, and steps.
            1.   Building area in two-story rooms (i.e., cathedral ceilings) is
counted twice.
            2.   Building area in a crawl space is not counted.
            3.   Garage area is counted, regardless of whether it is located
underneath a house or in an accessory building.
         (c)   The BAR shall not comprise more than 50% of the lot size.
However, a minimum house size of 2,500 square feet is allowed regardless of lot
size, if 40% lot coverage is not exceeded.
            1.   The maximum building area, including accessory structures, is
5,500 square feet regardless of lot size.
            2.   For lots containing tidally influenced saltwater wetlands/
marsh or open water beyond the delineated DHEC-OCRM critical line, BAR shall be
calculated using only the "high ground" of the lots and specifically excluding
the wetlands/ marsh or open water.
         (d)   At least 10% of the BAR must be comprised of porches.
         (e)   Exceptions.
            1.   The BAR shall not apply to garage space located under a house
when the house is required to be elevated a minimum of eight feet above
finished grade in order to comply with FEMA regulations.
            2.   The BAR shall not apply to basement space where a sub-grade
basement can be accommodated without the use of fill.
            3.   The BAR shall not apply to alterations that do not change the
massing of a structure. Examples include, but are not limited to, finished
space in an attic or under an elevated structure.
      (5)   Historic buildings.
         (a)   Historic buildings located on historic properties, as defined
herein, may be considered conforming with respect to any height, setback, yard,
area, or other dimension found by the HDPC to be of historic significance.
         (b)   In this regard, these existing conditions may supersede any
conflicting standard set forth in the zoning district in which the building is
located, and may be applied to the building and the site in making future
determinations of conformity as to the existing building or any changes
consistent with an approved certificate of appropriateness.
      (6)   Parking requirements. Notwithstanding other provisions found
elsewhere in this chapter, these parking requirements shall apply to all
residential use properties located within the OVHD.
         (a)   A minimum of two off-street parking spaces per residence is
required.
         (b)   Additional spaces for homes over 2,500 square feet of BAR are
required at the rate of one space per every 1,000 square feet, or portion
thereof, of BAR over 2,5000 square feet of BAR.
         (c)   Required off-street parking shall be allowed to be parked in
tandem and encroach within required yard requirements.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.219 THROUGH 156.229 RESERVED.
SUBPART 4.4: SB-OD (SWEETGRASS  BASKET OVERLAY DISTRICT)
§ 156.230 PURPOSE.
   (A)   Generally. The SB-OD, Sweetgrass Basket Overlay District, is intended
to:
      (1)   Provide development regulations consistent with those of Charleston
County;
      (2)   Protect the sweetgrass basket-making culture by allowing their sale
through traditional roadside stands;
      (3)   Preserve the rural character of the community;
      (4)   Provide interconnectivity between and within developments; and
      (5)   Provide an access management plan for safe and efficient traffic
flow.
   (B)   Residential Area. The Residential Area is intended to maintain the
large-lot development that has been the tradition and is characteristic of lots
in the area at the time of original adoption of the SBOD.
   (C)   Old Georgetown Road Loop Office Area. This area is intended solely for
low-intensity professional office uses having minimal impact on adjacent
residences due to limited hours of operation and traffic generated primarily by
automobiles rather than delivery trucks, but also fulfilling the intent for
access management by encouraging access from Old Georgetown Road and shared
access if from U.S. Highway 17 North.
   (D)   Village Commercial Area, from Old Georgetown Road to Hamlin Road. This
area is intended to allow low-intensity commercial uses, and to provide safe,
convenient, and efficient traffic movement by utilizing secondary roads and
creating interconnectivity among developed parcels, thereby reducing the need
for traffic trips onto U.S. Highway 17 North.
   (E)   Village Commercial Area, from Hamlin Road to Porchers Bluff Road. This
area is intended to allow appropriate commercial uses in conjunction with the
existing residential uses and to provide safe, convenient, and efficient
traffic movement by implementing an appropriate access management plan, thereby
reducing the need for vehicle trips onto U.S. Highway 17 North.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.231 DISTRICT BOUNDARY.
   (A)   The lots subject to the SB-OD regulations are all those within the
area generally bounded by a portion of the Isle of Palms Connector, U.S.
Highway 17 North, Porchers Bluff Road, and Rifle Range Road, as more accurately
depicted on the Zoning Map.
   (B)   The SB-OD is further distinguished by a Residential Area, an Old
Georgetown Road Loop Area, and two Village Commercial Areas, which are more
fully described below and depicted on
Figure 156.231-1: SB-OD Subareas.
      (1)   Residential Area. Properties included in the Residential Area are
all those not included in the Old Georgetown Road Loop Area or in the Village
Commercial Area.
      (2)   Old Georgetown Road Loop Office Area. Properties included in the
Old Georgetown Road Loop office area are those located between U.S. Highway 17
North and Old Georgetown Road.
      (3)   Village Commercial Area, from Old Georgetown Road to Hamlin Road.
This Village Commercial Area applies to the area 400 feet in depth from the
edge of the right-of-way on properties having frontage on U.S. Highway 17
North.
      (4)   Village Commercial Area, from Hamlin Road to Porchers Bluff Road.
This Village Commercial Area applies to the area 400 feet in depth, from the
edge of the right-of-way on properties having frontage on U.S. Highway 17
North.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-12986.png]
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.232 ALLOWED USES.
   (A)   Sweetgrass basket stands. Sweetgrass basket stands are allowed on all
lots and within all buffers and rights-of-way if:
      (1)   The entity having jurisdiction over encroachments to the right-of-
way extends permission;
      (2)   All sweetgrass basket stands utilize safe ingress and egress; and
      (3)   Parking for sweetgrass basket stands is located in an area furthest
from the roadway.
   (B)   Residential uses.
      (1)   Uses in the Residential Area shall be all those as provided in the
CC, Community Conservation District, including accessory, conditional, and
special exception uses, subject to their respective approval processes; and
      (2)   Lots in the Old Georgetown Road Loop Office Area or Village
Commercial Areas may utilize uses provided in the CC, Community Conservation
District, including accessory, conditional and special exception uses, subject
to those approval processes.
   (C)   Commercial uses.
      (1)   In order to maintain the intent of the Old Georgetown Road Loop
Office Area, commercial uses shall be limited to those permitted in the OP-1,
Office Professional-1, zoning district, including accessory, conditional, and
special exception uses, subject to those approval processes;
      (2)   Hours of operation for uses located within the Old Georgetown Road
Loop Office Area shall be limited to between 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m.;
      (3)   In the Village Commercial areas, properties with frontage on
Highway 17 may have commercial uses within 400 feet of the highway right-of-way
consistent with NC-2, Neighborhood Commercial-2, zoning district, including
accessory, conditional, and special exception uses, subject to those approval
processes. If the property extends beyond that depth, the remainder of the
property shall be considered to be in the Residential Area, with those allowed
uses;
      (4)   Except for hotels, hours of operation for uses located within the
Village Commercial Areas shall be limited to between 6:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m.;
and
      (5)   Any use involving the sale or dispensing of fuel requires special
exception approval pursuant to Subchapter I: Procedures.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
