§ 156.234 BUFFERYARD REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Planting of sweetgrass encouraged. To help fulfill preservation of the
sweetgrass basketmaking craft, planting and cultivation of all grasses used in
their making is encouraged.
   (B)   Old Georgetown Road Loop Office Area and Village Commercial Area, from
Old Georgetown Road to Hamlin Road. Buffers are required in accordance with
Subchapter D.
   (C)   Village Commercial Area, from Hamlin Road to Porchers Bluff Road. All
bufferyards shall be provided in accordance with the requirements of Subchapter
D; provided, however, that the width of these bufferyards may be reduced by a
maximum of one-third of the required width, if the area of all required
bufferyards exceeds 30% of the area of the site. Bufferyards adjacent to
residentially zoned properties may not be reduced.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.235 COMMERCIAL SITE DESIGN STANDARDS
   (A)   Village Commercial Area, from Old Georgetown Road to Hamlin Road.
      (1)   Site design of one parcel shall include interconnectivity for
parking and access with the adjoining parcels, if possible.
      (2)   Stub-out connections for future shared parking and access are
required if such interconnectivity cannot be achieved in the current design.
   (B)   Village Commercial Area, from Hamlin Road to Porchers Bluff Road.
      (1)   A more rural visual context. The design guidelines in Subchapter H
shall generally be followed with the emphasis and exceptions provided herein.
The intent of the design requirements for the SB-OD is to reflect a more rural
visual context rather than a suburban or urban look.
         (a)   Therefore, building materials should consist of cementitious
siding to give the appearance of wood siding rather than brick or adorned
masonry siding, pitched roofs are preferred over flat roofs, and the use of
porches are encouraged.
      (b)   Corrugated metal and unadorned masonry may be acceptable as siding
material in the proper context.
      (c)   Figure 156.235-1 shows examples of the desired treatment.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-12990.png]
 
      (2)   Buildings on corner lots. Notwithstanding the provisions of §
156.891, buildings located on a corner lot may be set back from U.S. Highway 17
North and designed to address the side street as the primary street, if
continuous, interconnecting access is provided through the adjoining parcels of
the block between side streets.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.236 THROUGH 156.249 RESERVED.
SUBPART 4.5: VSP-OD (VILLAGE-SCALE  PEDESTRIAN OVERLAY DISTRICT)
§ 156.250 PURPOSE.
   The VSP-OD, Village-Scale Pedestrian Overlay District, is intended to:
   (A)   Foster an active, pedestrian-oriented form of development where the
form is as important as use, with buildings and primary entrances located near
the public realm and high-quality pedestrian streetscapes in front;
   (B)   Encourage a high degree of design quality for the building façade and
a strong interaction between the buildings and the public realm; and
   (C)   Emphasize the importance of the public realm and integrate public
spaces, such as plazas, with surrounding development.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.251 DISTRICT BOUNDARY.
   (A)   The lots subject to the VSP-OD regulations are generally described as
those properties abutting:
      (1)   Johnnie Dodds Boulevard;
      (2)   Coleman Boulevard;
      (3)   Ben Sawyer Boulevard, between its intersection with Coleman
Boulevard and Chuck Dawley Boulevard and the western side only of its
intersection with Rifle Range Road;
      (4)   Chuck Dawley Boulevard; and
      (5)   Bowman Road, west of Stuart Engals Boulevard and terminating at
Mathis Ferry Road.
   (B)   This triangular-shaped area, which is bounded on the west by the
Ravenel Bridge and on the east by I-526, represents the core of the southern
end of town.
   (C)   Figure 156.251-1: Village Scale Pedestrian Overlay District Boundary
generally depicts the VSPOD boundary. Boundaries are most accurately depicted
on the Zoning Map.
Figure 156.251-1: Village Scale Pedestrian Overlay District Boundary
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-12992.png]
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.252 DESIGN REVIEW REQUIRED.
   All lots in the VSP-OD are subject to
Subchapter H, including Part 4, and to the design review process (See
Subchapter I).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.253 OPEN SPACE AND PARKS.
   (A)   For any development containing residential dwelling units, at least 8%
of the development acreage, excluding the activity zone (see §
156.1036), shall be designed and utilized as open space and/or parks in the
form of active and passive parks, plazas, or public gathering spaces.
   (B)   The location and design of the open space or park area is subject to
Planning Commission or Design Review Board approval, as applicable for the
proposed development.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.254 COLEMAN BOULEVARD DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS.
   (A)   Applicability. This section applies to lots in the VSP-OD that
generally abut Coleman Boulevard and Ben Sawyer Boulevard, between the
intersections of Magrath Darby Boulevard on the north and Patriot's Point
Boulevard on the south and the west side of the intersection of Ben Sawyer
Boulevard and Rifle Range Road, specifically excluding lots located within the
Shem Creek Waterfront District and the residential subdivision of Bayview
Acres, as shown on
Figure 156.251-1: Village Scale Pedestrian Overlay District Boundary.
   (B)   Generally. 
Table 156.254-1: Coleman Boulevard Development Standards specifies building
height, build-to lines, and setbacks for all lots in the VSP-OD along Coleman,
West Coleman, and Ben Sawyer Boulevards based on the lot’s location (“area”) as
shown on
Figure 156.254-1: Coleman Boulevard Area Map.
   (C)   Building height.
      (1)   All structures shall have at least two floors, with a maximum of
three floors allowed. The two-floor minimum only applies to buildings fronting
the boulevard.
      (2)   Where indicated on
Table 156.254-1: Coleman Boulevard Development Standards as 45 feet/55 feet,
the maximum building height along all streets is 45 feet. A maximum building
height of 55 feet is allowed on the interior portion of the development site.
      (3)   Any portion of a building exceeding 45 feet in height must be set
back from all right-of-way lines, at a distance to be determined through the
design review process.
      (4)   Any portion of a building exceeding 45 feet in height shall have a
maximum of four floors. In cases where buildings utilize a flat roof, the
maximum height is measured to the top of the roof structure.
      (5)   Areas above the maximum height or maximum number of stories:
         (a)   Shall not be used to create an extra floor of living area or
enclosed commercial space;
         (b)   Shall not be used for open decks, multi-level decks, or rooftop
restaurants; and
         (c)   May be used for storage.
   (D)   Build-to lines/setbacks for civic uses. The build-to line or setback
for civic uses is determined through the design review process.
   (E)   Building footprint limitations. Because "big box" retail development
is inconsistent with the purpose of the VSP-OD, the building footprint of any
individual structure is limited to 50,000 square feet.

1 The maximum height for buildings located within 50 feet of an abutting
residential property line, or an abutting street right-of-way adjoining
residential property if that residential property is located outside the
VSP-OD, is 40 feet or three stories, whichever is less. This height is
measured from grade to roof ridge.
2 Where rear or side property lines abut residential properties lying
outside the VSP-OD, a minimum 15-foot setback is required, within which a
minimum 10-foot type "C" bufferyard with an F3 fence is also required (see
§
156.604).
3 Common wall construction to adjacent properties spanning property lines
may be utilized in accordance with applicable Building and Fire Code
requirements. Bufferyards are not required where interconnectivity between
parcels is provided or shown on the plan for future connection, or when
common wall construction to adjacent properties spanning property lines is
utilized. Where interconnectivity or common wall construction is not
provided, the plant material required for a Type "A" bufferyard is required
(see §
156.604).
4 The height of all buildings in this subarea is measured from the
elevation of the top of the curb on Coleman Boulevard. The 45-foot building
height limit applies to the façade of any building located along and
parallel to Coleman Boulevard or a façade on those portions of Broadway
Street that are perpendicular to Coleman Boulevard. To achieve the maximum
allowed height of 55 feet, all portions of a building above the height of
perimeter façades must be set back away from a street and be contained
within a building envelope established using a 1:4 slope beginning at the
top of the facade on Coleman Boulevard or a facade on those portions of
Broadway Street that are perpendicular to Coleman Boulevard. A height step-
back is not required for facades that front on the remainder of Broadway
Street.
5 The 20-foot setback applies to all side streets except Mill Street, where
a 20 to 30 ft. build-to is required.
6 The 20-foot setback applies to all side streets except Simmons Street,
where a 20 to 30 ft. build-to is required.
7 The 45-foot building height limit shall apply to those portions of a
building immediately located along a street frontage. Portions of a
building between 45 feet and 55 feet must be set back from the right-of-
way, at a distance to be determined through the design review process.
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.255 JOHNNIE DODDS BOULEVARD DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS.
   (A)   Applicability. This section applies to lots generally located between
Magrath Darby Boulevard on the southwest and Interstate 526 on the northeast,
as shown on
Figure 156.251-1: Village Scale Pedestrian Overlay District Boundary. This
includes lots:
      (1)   That generally abut Houston Northcutt Boulevard, Bowman Road, and
Johnnie Dodds Boulevard or its frontage roads, specifically excluding portions
of the Groves residential subdivision;
      (2)   Located between Johnnie Dodds Boulevard and Mathis Ferry Road,
specifically excluding the residential subdivisions of Queens Row and Parish
Place; and
      (3)   Located between Stuart Engals Boulevard and Interstate 526.
   (B)   Number of stories.
      (1)   Buildings fronting on the frontage road shall be at least two
stories.
      (2)   Buildings fronting on side streets (non-frontage roads) and
buildings located at the intersections between the frontage road and Johnnie
Dodds Boulevard may utilize a single story.
   (C)   Front build-to line.
      (1)   The front build-to line for buildings fronting on the frontage road
is 20 to 30 feet, with a minimum eight-foot sidewalk.
      (2)   The front build-to line for buildings fronting on side streets
(non-frontage roads) and for intersection properties is 20 to 30 feet, with a
minimum five-foot sidewalk. For properties where the Mathis Ferry Road buffer
applies, the build-to line is determined through the design review process.
   (D)   Rear yard setback. The rear yard setback is 15 feet.
   (E)   Exceptions. Contingent upon approval through the design review
process, development utilizing an integrated site plan involving multiple
parcels may forgo rear yard setbacks along parcel lines, except when commercial
uses abut residential uses lying outside the district boundaries. In the latter
case, a minimum 15-foot setback is required.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.256 CHUCK DAWLEY BOULEVARD DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS.
   (A)   Applicability. This section applies to lots in the VSP-OD that
generally abut Chuck Dawley Boulevard, specifically excluding most
residentially-zoned lots, as shown on
Figure 156.251-1: Village Scale Pedestrian Overlay District Boundary.
   (B)   Front yard build-to line. The front yard build-to line is 20 to 30
feet, which includes an eight-foot sidewalk only when an activity zone is
included as part of the development plan. Otherwise, the existing sidewalk is
sufficient to meet the intent of this section, unless no sidewalk exists in
which case installation of a five-foot sidewalk is required.
   (C)   Rear yard setback. The rear yard setback is 15 feet.
   (D)   Exceptions. Contingent upon approval through the design review
process, development utilizing an integrated site plan involving multiple
parcels may forgo rear yard setbacks along lot lines, except when commercial
uses abut residential uses lying outside the district boundaries. In the latter
case, a 15-foot setback is required.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.257 THROUGH 156.299 RESERVED.
SUBCHAPTER C: USE REGULATIONS
PART 1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 156.300 PURPOSE.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   The purpose of this subchapter is to:
         (a)   Promote the public health, safety, morals, and general welfare;
and
         (b)   Protect and preserve places and areas of environmental,
historical, cultural, and architectural importance and significance.
      (2)   These regulations are adopted in accordance with the Comprehensive
Plan and are designed to:
         (a)   Distribute land uses to meet the physical, social, cultural,
economic, and energy needs of present and future populations;
         (b)   Ensure that new development is compatible with surrounding
development in use, character, and scale;
         (c)   Protect natural, historical, and cultural resources;
         (d)   Provide for land uses that serve important public needs, such as
affordable housing and employment generators;
         (e)   Integrate civic uses into neighborhoods;
         (f)   Promote infill housing and residential development;
         (g)   Promote mixed use districts and neighborhoods that allow
residents to access daily needs and services via multiple modes of
transportation; and
         (h)   Promote retail, office, and other commercial development in
appropriate locations.
   (B)   Regulation of land use. In accordance with the purposes described in
division (A) above, this subchapter:
      (1)   Establishes the land uses allowed in each zoning district;
      (2)   Establishes supplemental regulations for conditional and certain
special exception uses, which have unique operational characteristics or
impacts; and
      (3)   Establishes regulations for accessory and temporary uses.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.301 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   This subchapter regulates the use of land throughout the Town of Mount
Pleasant.
   (B)   Part 3: Principal Uses and Structures applies to all principal uses
and structures.
   (C)   Part 4: Accessory Uses and Structures applies to all accessory uses
and structures.
   (D)   Part 5: Temporary Uses and Structures applies to all temporary uses
and structures, including interim and part-time uses and structures.
   (E)   Part 6: Short-Term Rentals applies to all short-term rental uses.
   (F)   Part 7: Small Wireless Facilities and Telecommunications Towers
applies to all small wireless facilities in the right-of-way and all
telecommunications towers.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.302 ZONING PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   Pursuant to
Subchapter I, Part 7, zoning permit approval is required prior to the:
         (a)   Clearing, excavation, or filling of any lot for any site
improvements;
         (b)   Commencement of construction or demolition of any building; or
         (c)   Moving or alteration of any building.
      (2)   Zoning permits are also required prior to the establishment of
principal uses and structures, certain accessory uses and structures, and
certain temporary uses and structures.
   (B)   Principal uses and structures.
      (1)   Prior to the establishment of a new principal use or structure or a
change from one principal use to another, an applicant must receive a zoning
permit.
      (2)   Special exception uses and structures require approval by the Board
of Zoning Appeals (see Subchapter I, Part 9). If approved by the Board of
Zoning Appeals, a special exception use also requires a zoning permit prior to
establishment of the use.
   (C)   Accessory uses and structures.
      (1)   Prior to the establishment of an accessory use or structure, an
applicant must receive a zoning permit if required by §
156.436.
      (2)   Accessory uses or structures that do not require a zoning permit
must comply with all applicable provisions of
Subchapter C, Part 4.
   (D)   Temporary uses and structures.
      (1)   Prior to the establishment of a temporary use, an applicant must
receive a zoning permit if required by §
156.487.
      (2)   Temporary uses that do not require a zoning permit must comply with
all applicable provisions of
Subchapter C, Part 5.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.303 REPLACEMENT OF AN EXISTING DETACHED HOUSE DWELLING.
   (A)   The Zoning Administrator may issue a conditional zoning permit for the
construction of a detached house dwelling to replace an existing detached house
dwelling. This conditional zoning permit allows the lot owner to live in the
existing detached house dwelling during the construction of another detached
house dwelling located on the same lot.
   (B)   The lot owner shall apply for and receive a demolition permit for the
existing detached house dwelling prior to the issuance of a certificate of
occupancy for the new dwelling.
   (C)   The lot owner must complete the demolition and removal of the existing
dwelling within 90 days of the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for the
new dwelling. The Zoning Administrator may approve up to three 90-day
extensions upon a showing of good cause. Examples of good cause include events
and conditions beyond the lot owner’s reasonable control, such as:
      (1)   Natural disasters, such as hurricanes and fires;
      (2)   Significant illness or family emergency;
      (3)   Military deployment;
      (4)   An inability to obtain sufficient project financing due to economic
and market conditions; or
      (5)   Scarcity of labor or materials.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.304 CRITICAL FACILITIES IN SPECIAL FLOOD HAZARD AREAS.
   (A)   As specified in §
152.20(M), new critical facilities are prohibited from the 500-year floodplain.
   (B)   “Critical facilities” have the meaning specified in §
152.04.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.305 OUTDOOR STORAGE OF VEHICLES.
   (A)   Commercial vehicles in residential areas.
      (1)   In residential areas, up to one commercial vehicle may be parked or
stored outside of an enclosed building. Acceptable commercial vehicles include
standard size vans, sport utility vehicles, and pick-up trucks.
      (2)   Other commercial vehicles, including dump trucks; wreckers; utility
trucks; tractor-trailer rigs; field service trucks; delivery trucks; open or
enclosed trailers with a principal purpose to store or haul tools, materials,
or equipment of a commercial and/or business nature; and the like are
prohibited in residential areas.
   (B)   Exterior storage of vehicles.
      (1)   Except as otherwise specifically allowed in this subchapter, it is
unlawful to keep, store, or otherwise maintain, indoors or outdoors, for a
period in excess of 48 hours, any motor vehicle that meets any of the following
criteria:
         (a)   Has been damaged to such an extent that the cost of repairs
would exceed the cost of the repaired vehicle;
         (b)   Does not have a current motor vehicle license;
         (c)   Does not have a current inspection sticker; or
         (d)   Is inoperable.
      (2)   This division does not prohibit the restoration of licensed antique
automobiles or other motor vehicles of special value.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.306 THROUGH 156.314 RESERVED.
PART 2: ATTAINABLE HOUSING
§ 156.315 GENERALLY.
   Where
Subchapter B or
Subchapter C requires attainable housing, the requirements in this part apply.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.316 ATTAINABLE HOUSING UNITS DEFINED.
   (A)   Owner-occupied attainable housing units.
      (1)   Attainable homeownership dwelling units are owner-occupied units
where the monthly mortgage payment (including principal, interest, property
taxes, homeowners’ insurance, private mortgage insurance, and property owners'
association fees) does not exceed 30% of the owner household’s gross monthly
income.
      (2)   Attainable homeownership dwelling units are occupied by households
earning up to 120% of the Median Family Income (MFI) for the Charleston-North
Charleston, SC Metropolitan Statistical Area (MSA), as published annually by
the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) and adjusted for
household size.
   (B)   Rental attainable housing units.
      (1)   Attainable rental dwelling units are renter-occupied units where
the monthly rental rate plus the cost of all major utilities (excluding
telephone, cable or satellite television, and internet service) does not exceed
the fair market rent (FMR) for the Charleston-North Charleston, SC MSA, as
published annually by HUD and adjusted for the number of bedrooms in the
dwelling unit.
      (2)   Attainable rental dwelling units are occupied by households earning
up to 80% of the median family income (MFI) for the Charleston-North
Charleston, SC MSA, as published annually by HUD and adjusted for household
size.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.317 ELIGIBILITY.
   (A)   Owner-occupied attainable housing units.
      (1)   Primary residence. The attainable housing unit shall serve as the
owner's primary residence for the duration of ownership or until the deed
restrictions required by this part have expired.
      (2)   Initial eligibility determination process.
         (a)   Prospective buyers of new attainable housing units shall be
screened and determined eligible by the developer, or their designee, prior to
occupancy.
         (b)   Prior to closing on a new attainable housing unit, the developer
shall submit an affidavit to the town that verifies the unit will be occupied
by a household qualified pursuant to the requirements of this subpart.
      (3)   Increase in household income or change in employment during
occupancy.
         (a)   A household is not required to vacate an attainable housing unit
if:
            1.   The household's income increases to an amount above 120% of
the median family income; or
            2.   The household’s employment situation changes such that no
member of the household is employed at a business located within the town.
         (b)   Upon vacating the premises naturally, the unit shall be sold to
a qualifying household pursuant to the requirements of this part if the deed
restrictions required by §
156.318 are still in effect.
   (B)   Renter-occupied attainable housing units.
      (1)   Primary residence. The attainable housing unit shall serve as the
owner's primary residence for the duration of the lease or until the deed
restrictions required by this part have expired.
      (2)   Eligibility determination process. Prospective renters of
attainable housing units shall be screened and determined eligible by the
property owner, or their designee, prior to occupancy. Both of the following
requirements are applicable and subject to final approval by the town:
         (a)   The owner shall provide proof to the town, upon initial
occupancy and anytime the lease is renewed thereafter, that the current tenants
meet the necessary qualifications.
         (b)   Any time a new tenant occupies an attainable housing unit, the
owner shall submit an affidavit to the town that verifies the unit will be
occupied by a household qualified pursuant to the requirements of this subpart.
      (3)   Minimum lease term. A minimum lease term of six months is required
for all attainable housing units.
      (4)   Increase in household income or change in employment during
occupancy.
         (a)   A household is not required to vacate an attainable housing unit
if:
            1.   The household's income increases to an amount above 80% of the
median family income; or
            2.   The household’s employment situation changes such that no
member of the household is employed at a business located within the town.
         (b)   The tenant may renew the lease for one additional term, not to
exceed two years. Upon vacating the premises, the unit shall be rented to a
qualifying household pursuant to the requirements of this part if the deed
restrictions required by §
156.318 are still in effect.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.318 DEED RESTRICTIONS.
   (A)   The applicant must submit draft deed restrictions for review by the
Town Attorney in conjunction with any application required to establish the
proposed use or development.
   (B)   The deed restrictions shall limit the resale or occupancy of an
attainable housing unit to a household eligible, as described in this part, for
a period of at least 30 years after issuance of the certificate of occupancy.
   (C)   The deed restrictions shall be recorded prior to issuance of a
building permit for any portion of the development.
   (D)   The deed restrictions shall include, at a minimum, the following
elements:
      (1)   Duration;
      (2)   Occupancy requirement and restrictions against leasing/subleasing;
      (3)   Restriction on resale;
      (4)   Requirement to notify the town in the case of conveyance (for
owner-occupied units), lease renewal (for rental units), or establishment of a
new rental contract (for rental units), and provide verification that the
purchaser or tenant is qualified pursuant to the requirements of this part;
      (5)   Right of first refusal, if applicable;
      (6)   Distribution of gross sales proceeds, if applicable; and
      (7)   Procedure in the case of foreclosure (for owner-occupied units
only).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.319 DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS.
   (A)   Exterior appearance of dwellings. Attainable housing units shall be
indistinguishable from market-rate units. External building materials and
finishes for attainable housing units shall be the same in type and quality as
the market-rate units.
   (B)   Interior features of dwelling units. Interior features of attainable
housing units shall be functionally equivalent to the market-rate units, though
the finishes and materials need not be identical.
   (C)   Energy efficiency improvements. Attainable housing units shall be
comparable to the market-rate units in terms of improvements related to energy
efficiency, which include but are not limited to, mechanical equipment and
plumbing, insulation, windows, and heating and cooling systems.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.320 ATTAINABLE HOUSING PLAN.
   (A)   The associated application must include a preliminary attainable
housing plan that contains, at a minimum, the following information:
      (1)   A general description of the development, including whether the
development will contain owner-occupied or rental units, or both;
      (2)   The total number and type of market-rate units and attainable
housing units in the development; and
      (3)   The number of bedrooms in each market-rate unit and in each
attainable unit.
   (B)   Prior to the issuance of building permits for any portion of the
development, a finalized attainable housing plan must be submitted to the town
that includes the information specified in division (A) above as well as the
address and parcel identification number of each attainable housing unit.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.321 THROUGH 156.324 RESERVED.
PART 3: PRINCIPAL USES AND STRUCTURES
SUBPART 3.1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 156.325 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   This part applies to all principal uses and structures. These
standards supplement the other requirements of this chapter.
   (B)   Principal uses are allowed within the base zoning districts in
accordance with §
156.338.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.326 MULTIPLE PRINCIPAL USES ON A SINGLE PARCEL.
   (A)   Non-residential uses and mixed use developments. Where multiple
principal uses are proposed to be located on a single parcel, all applicable
conditions must be met for each proposed use. For example, if the proposed use
is a gas station with a convenience store and a car wash, all requirements and
conditions for gas station, car wash, and retail sales uses must be met.
   (B)   Residential uses. No more than one principal dwelling may be located
on a single parcel, except in the case of apartment complexes.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.327 THROUGH 156.334 RESERVED.
SUBPART 3.2: PRINCIPAL USE TABLE
§ 156.335 INTRODUCTION.
   (A)   Generally. §
156.338 establishes the categories of uses specified in
Table 156.335-1: Categories of Uses for all of the base zoning districts and
floating zoning districts.
   (B)   Cumulative zoning. All uses allowed in the OP-1, OP-2, NC-1, and NC-
2 Districts are allowed in the AB-1 District. All uses allowed in the AB-
1 District are allowed in the AB-2 District.
   (C)   Allowed uses in planned districts. Allowed uses in a Planned
Development District are specified in the rezoning ordinance that established
the PD District and any amendments thereto.
   (D)   Explanation of use table. The top row of the use table contains the
zoning districts and left side of the table contains various uses. The uses
listed in the use table are allowed or prohibited in each zoning district
according to the letter coding described in Table 156.335-1: Categories of
Uses.

(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.336 CLASSIFICATION OF NEW AND UNLISTED PRINCIPAL USES.
   (A)   The Zoning Administrator may determine that an unlisted use is:
      (1)   Allowed in one or more zoning districts as a permitted use,
conditional use, or special exception use if sufficiently similar in nature and
impact to a permitted, conditional, or special exception use listed in §
156.338; or
      (2)   Prohibited in all zoning districts.
   (B)   In making this determination, the Zoning Administrator may refer to
any of the following factors as guidance:
      (1)   The definitions contained in Subchapter N;
      (2)   Whether the use is consistent with the purpose of the zoning
district in which it would be allowed;
      (3)   Whether the use has visual, traffic, environmental, or other
impacts similar to an expressly listed use. The Zoning Administrator may refer
to empirical studies or generally accepted planning or engineering sources in
making this determination; and
      (4)   Whether the use is within the same industry classification as
another allowed use. In making this determination, the Zoning Administrator may
refer to the most recent edition of the North American Industry Classification
Manual (“NAICS”) and/or the American Planning Association’s Land-Based
Classification Standards (LBCS) Tables.
   (C)   The burden is on the applicant to establish that the unlisted proposed
use is similar to the expressly listed use. The applicant shall submit
verification that shows the proposed use is similar to another permitted,
conditional, or special exception use and could be allowed.
   (D)   The Zoning Administrator shall determine whether a proposed use is
similar to another permitted, conditional, or special exception use in the
zoning district and could be allowed or is not similar and therefore
prohibited. If the Zoning Administrator determines that:
      (1)   The proposed use is sufficiently similar in nature and impact to a
permitted use, the applicant may proceed with any application necessary to
establish the use;
      (2)   The proposed use is sufficiently similar in nature and impact to a
conditional use, the applicant may submit a zoning permit application (see
Subchapter I, Part 7) demonstrating compliance with the applicable conditions
specified in
Subchapter C, Subpart 3.3;
      (3)   The proposed use is sufficiently similar in nature and impact to a
special exception use, the applicant may submit a special exception application
(see
Subchapter I, Part 9); or
      (4)   The proposed use is not sufficiently similar in nature and impact
to a permitted use, conditional use, or special exception use, then the
proposed use shall be denied and the applicant notified in writing.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.337 PREEMPTION.
   Uses regulated by the State of South Carolina and exempt from local control
are permitted subject to state regulations.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)

§§ 156.339 THROUGH 156.344 RESERVED.
SUBPART 3.3: PRINCIPAL USE CONDITIONS
§ 156.345 APPLICABILITY.
   The conditions specified in this subpart apply to uses listed as
“conditional” or “special exception” in §
156.338. Special exception uses are also subject to the conditions specified in
Subchapter I, Part 9.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.346 ADULT USES.
   The parcel on which the use will occur is not located within 1,500 feet of a
place of worship, school, day care, playground, public or private recreation
facility, property zoned to allow residential uses, or property with existing
residential uses.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.347 AGRICULTURAL, PRODUCE, OR SEAFOOD STAND.
   (A)   Dimensional standards.
      (1)   Maximum size. Stands shall not exceed 2,000 square feet in area,
either under a roof or around the perimeter of the structure without a roof.
      (2)   Setbacks. Stands shall be located at least ten feet from all
property lines.
   (B)   Development standards.
      (1)   Off-street parking areas. Parking areas are not subject to the
paving requirements of
Subchapter F.
      (2)   Signs. Signs for such uses are limited to one non-illuminated free-
standing sign, not to exceed ten square feet in area and eight feet in height,
or one non-illuminated sign attached to the structure, not to exceed ten square
feet in area. Materials and illumination shall comply with
Subchapter G.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.348 AGRICULTURAL STORAGE.
   All storage areas shall be screened by fencing, landscaping, and/or other
appropriate materials so as not to be visible from adjacent public streets.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.349 AIRPORT OR AVIATION FACILITY.
   When located in the PI-2 District, the facility shall be owned by a public
or quasi-public organization.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.350 AMENITY BUILDING AND/OR FACILITY IN A RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT.
   (A)   Such uses shall not be illuminated.
   (B)   Any buildings shall be primarily open-air.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.351 AMUSEMENT CENTER.
   (A)   The parcel on which the use will occur shall not be located within
1,500 feet of a place of worship, school, daycare, playground, or public or
private recreation facility.
   (B)   Hours of operation are limited from 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.352 ANIMAL BOARDING FACILITY, DAY CARE, OR SHELTER.
   (A)   Overnight kennels must be located indoors.
   (B)   Where located adjacent to residential properties, outdoor areas shall
be fenced or walled with an acoustic fence or other sound-absorbing materials;
except that this condition does not apply in the RC-1 and RC-2 Districts.
   (C)   In the RC-1 and RC-2 Districts, outdoor areas shall be located at
least 100 feet from all property lines.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.353 APICULTURE.
   (A) There is no minimum parcel size for beekeeping; however, the maximum
density is two colonies per one-quarter acre.
   (B)   Hives shall be located at least 20 feet from all property lines. The
opening of the hive shall be oriented away from adjoining properties.
   (C)   For colonies located within 25 feet of a property boundary, a flyway
barrier at least six feet in height consisting of a solid wall, fence, or dense
hedge parallel to the property line and extending ten feet beyond the apiary in
each direction is required.
   (D)   A constant supply of fresh water is required. It shall be readily
accessible to the bees and to allow them to access water by landing on a hard
surface. A water supply is not required during winter and other inactive
months.
   (E)   Hives not being actively maintained shall be removed.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.354 ARTISAN WORKSHOP OR ARTIST STUDIO WITHOUT RETAIL SALES.
   (A)   All structures associated with such use are limited to a maximum gross
floor area of 3,000 square feet.
   (B)   All structures associated with such use shall appear more residential
in character and shall not detract from the residential character of the
surrounding area.
   (C)   Outdoor storage of materials or equipment is prohibited.
   (D)   Setback requirements for detached house dwellings apply.
   (E)   No traffic shall be generated by such use in greater volumes than
would normally be expected in a residential neighborhood, and any need for
parking generated by the conduct of such use shall be met off the street and
other than in a required front yard.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.355 BOAT LAUNCH OR DOCK.
   (A)   Within the SCW-W District, boat launches and docks are appropriate for
any lawful commercial, personal, or public purpose. However, within the SCW-
H and SCW-N Districts boat launches and docks are appropriate for any lawful
commercial or public purpose, but not for personal use.
   (B)   In all other districts, the boat launch or dock shall be owned and/or
operated by a public or quasi-public organization.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.356 BOUTIQUE HOTEL OR INN.
   Such uses shall only be located on properties designated as:
   (A)   Community Scale Commercial in the 2019 Comprehensive Plan, including:
      (1)   Belle Hall Hub, as shown in
Figure 156.356-1;
      (2)   Seaside Hub, as shown in
Figure 156.356-2;
      (3)   Sea Island Hub, as shown in
Figure 156.356-3;
      (4)   Highway 41 Hub, as shown in
Figure 156.356-4;
      (5)   Shelmore Village Hub, as shown in
Figure 156.356-5;
      (6)   Six Mile Market Place Hub, as shown in
Figure 156.356-6;
   (B)   Waterfront District on Highway 41; or
   (C)   Properties designated as Town Scale Commercial or Waterfront District
(Patriots Point) in the 2019 Comprehensive Plan.

(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.357 BREWERY, WINERY, OR DISTILLERY.
   (A)   All manufacturing activities and storage shall take place within an
enclosed building.
   (B)   Structures related to manufacturing and/or storage of components and/
or finished product shall be located at least 100 feet from all side and rear
property lines.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.358 CAMPGROUND OR CAMPSITE.
   In the PI-1 and PI-2 Districts, the campgro und or campsite shall be owned
and/or operated by a public or quasi-public organization.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.359 CAR WASH.
   (A)    Where such use is located adjacent to residenti ally-zoned property
or property used for residential purposes:
      (1)   A Type E buffer with a full masonry wall is required; and
      (2)   Hours of operation are limited to between 6:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m.
   (B)   Noise-generating activities shall be oriented away from residential
areas, and the location of such activities on the site shall be determined
through the design review process. If determined to be necessary through this
process, sound mitigation techniques shall be utilized in order to reduce noise
impacts on surrounding properties.
   (C)   When operational changes are made to add noise-generating activities,
such as blowers/dryers, to existing facilities, the location of such activities
on the site shall be determined by the Zoning Administrator through the zoning
permit approval process (see
Subchapter I, Part 7).
      (1)   If determined to be necessary through this process, sound
mitigation techniques shall be utilized in order to reduce noise impacts on
surrounding properties.
      (2)   In such cases, the limitation on hours of operation specified above
shall apply.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.360 COMMUNITY SERVICE FACILITY.
   Community service facilities are subject to the design review process (see
Subchapter I, Part 12) to ensure the site and any structures are designed and
constructed in a manner that blends in with the character of the area.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.361 CULTURAL FACILITY.
   (A)   Cultural facilities are subject to the design review process (see
Subchapter I, Part 12) to ensure the site and any structures are designed and
constructed in a manner that blends in with the character of the area.
   (B)   When located in the CO District, any buildings associated with such
facilities shall be primarily open-air and shall not be illuminated.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.362 DUPLEX DWELLING.
   (A)   Duplex dwellings located in the R-4 District.
      (1)   Duplex dwellings shall be located on a corner lot.
      (2)   The dimensional standards are the same as those specified in
Table 156.039-1: R-1, R-2, R-3, and R-4 Districts Dimensional Standards for
detached houses.
      (3)   The front setback for the district shall be met along both street
frontages.
      (4)   If the duplex dwelling includes separate entrances for each
dwelling unit, each entrance must face a different street.
   (B)   Duplex dwellings located in the CL District.
      (1)   Duplex dwellings may be constructed in the CL District only when
the cluster development subdivision design technique is utilized (see
Chapter 155); and
      (2)   When located in the CL District, the total number of duplex
dwelling units shall comprise no more than 20% of the total number of dwelling
units allowed in the development.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.363 EQUESTRIAN FACILITY.
   (A)   Any outdoor lighting shall be oriented to minimize spillover or glare
on surrounding properties or rights-of-way; and
   (B)   Structures, storage areas, and parking areas shall be located at least
50 feet from any external property line.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.364 HIGH-IMPACT ENTERTAINMENT AND HIGH IMPACT RECREATION.
   (A)   Such uses shall generally be located on a major road in a
predominantly commercial area.
   (B)   In instances where an impact assessment is not required, a traffic
analysis may be required to analyze the level of service during events in order
for the Zoning Administrator, in consultation with the Town Director of
Engineering and Development Services, to determine whether traffic improvements
or controls shall be required.
   (C)   Where such uses are not located within a completely enclosed building,
the following conditions shall also apply:
      (1)   Hours of operation are limited to 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m.;
      (2)   Noise-generating activities shall be oriented away from residential
areas and the location of such activities on the site shall be determined
through the design review process;
      (3)   If determined necessary through the design review process, sound
mitigation techniques shall be utilized in order to reduce noise impacts on
surrounding properties; and
      (4)   Where such uses are located adjacent to residential properties, a
Type E buffer with a full masonry wall is required.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.365 HOTEL, MOTEL, OR EXTENDED STAY.
   Such uses shall only be located on properties designated:
   (A)   As Town Scale Commercial or Waterfront District (Patriots Point and
Highway 41) in the 2019 Comprehensive Plan; or
   (B)   For AB-1, Areawide Business-1 District, uses and ED, Economic
Development District, uses that are located within the Oakland Plantation
Planned Development District.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.366 MANUFACTURING AND PRODUCTION.
   (A)   The use shall be conducted within a fully enclosed building.
   (B)   No obnoxious light, vibrations, smoke, gas, fume, odor, or dust, or
other objectionable effects shall be perceptible beyond the lot line.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.367 MIXED USE BUILDING.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   Residential uses shall not be located on any building level that
contains non-residential uses.
      (2)   All dwelling units shall have direct access to the street level.
      (3)   Non-residential uses in a mixed use building are limited to those
allowed in the zoning district in which the mixed use building is located.
   (B)   Density. Density shall not exceed four units per acre. However,
density may be increased to eight units per acre if the additional units are
dedicated to attainable housing, as defined in
Subchapter C, Part 2.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.368 MOTOR VEHICLE RENTAL OR SALES.
   Sales are limited to heavy equipment or machinery such as, but not limited
to, tandem-axle dump trucks, backhoes, tractors, cranes, and the like.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.369 MOTOR VEHICLE SERVICE OR REPAIR.
   (A)   All service and repair operations are conducted within a fully
enclosed building or buildings.
   (B)   Any outdoor storage meets the conditions of §
156.452.
   (C)   No obnoxious vibration, fume, light, or electrical disturbance created
as a result of such repair or service operation shall be perceptible beyond the
lot line.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.370 NEIGHBORHOOD GATHERING PLACE.
   (A)   Maximum size. All structures shall have a gross floor area less than
or equal to 3,000 square feet.
   (B)   Location. A neighborhood gathering place shall be located on a
collector street or thoroughfare or be located at a major intersection within
the community.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.371 NEIGHBORHOOD RECREATION.
   (A)   Such uses shall not be illuminated.
   (B)   Any buildings associated with such use shall be primarily open-air.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.372 NURSERY OPERATION, COMMERCIAL.
   (A)   Ancillary items, such as mulch, sand, gravel or similar materials, and
seasonal items, such as Christmas trees and pumpkins, may be sold in addition
to plants, but must clearly be incidental to the primary use as a wholesale or
retail landscape plant nursery.
   (B)   Aggregate materials, such as mulch, sand, gravel, or similar
materials, are kept inside a building or, if outside, in bins or sufficiently
screened from view of adjoining properties or public roads by way of fencing or
landscaping.
   (C)   Large vehicles, equipment, and machinery are housed inside a building
or sufficiently screened from view of adjoining properties or public roads by
way of fencing or landscaping.
   (D)   Accessory uses or structures, such as but not limited to, dumpsters,
refuse containers, portable bathroom facilities and the like, are sufficiently
screened from view of adjoining properties or public roads by way of fencing or
landscaping.
   (E)   Plants and other merchandise or materials are kept in a neat and
orderly fashion on the premises, either outdoors or inside a building.
   (F)   Permanent and temporary buildings or structures are approved through
the design review process.
   (G)   The requirements specified in divisions (A) through (F) above, shall
be indicated on a site plan for the property approved through the design review
process; with such process having discretion in the location and arrangement of
the various site components to minimize any negative impacts associated with
the use of the property.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.373 PARKING LOT OR STRUCTURE.
   (A)   Overnight parking of tractor trailers and/or truck cabs is prohibited.
   (B)   A parking lot or structure located in the PI-1 or PI-2 District shall
be available for use by the general public for no charge or for a nominal fee,
or shall serve an adjacent PI District use.
   (C)   A parking lot or structure located in the ED District shall serve an
adjacent ED District use.
   (D)   Within the SCW-W, SCW-H, and SCW-N Districts, a maximum of 10% of
surface parking areas shall be covered by impervious surfaces.
   (E)   Parking structures are prohibited in the SCW Districts.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.374 PRE-SCHOOL, EDUCATIONAL NURSERY, OR DAY CARE.
   Such facilities are subject to the design review process (see
Subchapter I, Part 12) to ensure the site and any structures are designed and
constructed in a manner that blends in with the character of the area.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.375 PUMP STATION.
   (A)   Applicability.
      (1)   This section applies to all pump stations regardless of the
parcel’s zoning or the existing land use on adjacent property.
      (2)   Existing pump stations proposed to be improved shall conform with
the requirements in this section to the maximum degree possible based on site
conditions. Those with existing buffers greater than required by this section
shall maintain the established buffer to the greatest extent possible.
   (B)   Setbacks. Pump stations shall be set back at least seven feet from all
property lines.
   (C)   Buffers.
      (1)   Pump stations shall have a seven-foot buffer with a minimum six-
foot tall wood fence or wall of similar materials at the same height.
      (2)   Plantings in the buffer shall include one evergreen tree species
per seven linear feet calculated from the exterior of the subject parcel. The
evergreen trees shall be at least as tall as the height of the fence at the
time of planting.
      (3)   This buffer is not required where an access gate to the pump
station is located or within two and one-half feet of either side of any
underground utility in the buffer. However, access gates must have a primary
façade constructed of wood or comparable material. Underground utilities shall
be located within the access gate to the greatest extent possible.
   (D)   Tree protection. Any protected, significant, or historic trees that
will need to be removed for construction shall be mitigated pursuant to the
requirements of the town's tree protection ordinances. Replacement trees are
not required to be planted on the pump station property.
   (E)   Site plan review required. All pump station site designs require
review and approval through the design review process (see
Subchapter I, Part 12).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.376 RURAL COMPOUND.
   (A)   On lots containing one acre or less, a maximum of three principal
dwelling units is allowed, if all applicable lot area and setback requirements
are met for all dwellings as if they were established on individual lots.
   (B)   On lots containing more than one acre, the maximum number of principal
dwelling units allowed is limited by density and lot area and dimensional
requirements, not to exceed a total of five dwelling units.
   (C)   Lots shall be arranged to ensure public street access in the event the
property on which the dwellings are located is subsequently subdivided for sale
or transfer. Such public street access may be direct, or may be provided
through an access easement of sufficient width, design, and material so as to
accommodate fire apparatus and other emergency and service vehicles.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.377 SCHOOL, PRIMARY AND SCHOOL, SECONDARY.
   (A)   The appearance and form of improvements with respect to site and
architectural design shall be consistent with the general theme of the area in
which the use is located. This requirement will be based upon a site-specific
analysis (site plan review) and may necessitate such reasonable additional
requirements as may be judged prudent to achieve the desired results of
acceptable coexistence with neighboring uses.
   (B)   Special considerations may be given to such site-specific design
elements as may be required to accommodate operational or other unique
characteristics of the individual uses, which may enhance or relax the minimum
standards prescribed herein, with specific written justification for the same
noted on the plans.
   (C)   All lights or lighting arrangements used shall be directed away from
adjoining or nearby residential properties, and further meet the requirements
in
Subchapter H, Part 3, Subpart 3.4.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.378 SELF-SERVICE STORAGE FACILITY.
   (A)   Neither commercial nor personal sale of any goods, product, or service
shall be performed in individual units, though the facility ownership may sell
or rent incidental items including moving and packing supplies or moving
trucks. The facility ownership may also hold on-site auctions to sell the
contents of a unit or units as a result of non-payment of fees.
   (B)   Any outdoor storage area shall be designated as such on the submitted
site plan, and shall not be visible from any existing street or right-of-way.
No outdoor storage is allowed in other areas.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.379 SHOOTING RANGE, INDOOR.
   (A)   A total ambient noise level of no more than 67 decibels (dBA) is
created at all external lot lines adjacent to residential zoning districts, or
72 decibels at all external lot lines adjacent to non-residential zoning
districts.
   (B)   A total vibration level of no more than 65 velocity decibels (VdB) is
created at any internal lot line.
   (C)   Glare is less than 50 foot lamberts or one-half of a foot candle on
land within residential zoning districts, when measured at the lot line.
   (D)   Proof of all permits and approvals required by any state or federal
governmental entity are secured in advance, including providing assurance that
South Carolina state air pollution control regulations are met.
   (E)   Demonstration that the proposed use meets the above standards must be
submitted by the property owner in conjunction with the zoning permit
application.
      (1)   The Zoning Administrator may require the property owner to conduct
periodic monitoring to ensure the standards are continuously met or may
undertake such on its own.
      (2)   Equipment used for measurement must meet the standards of the
American National Standards Institute.
      (3)   All costs associated with such measurements shall be the
responsibility of the property owner.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.380 SWEETGRASS BASKET STAND.
   (A)   Location. Sweetgrass basket stands:
      (1)   Are allowed on lots located between Venning Road and the town's
northern corporate limits, as well as in historic settlement communities;
      (2)   Shall be located outside the right-of-way; and
      (3)   May be located within a roadside buffer.
   (B)   Use of stand. A sweetgrass basket stand may only be used as a place
where sweetgrass baskets are made and/or sold.
   (C)   Maximum size. Sweetgrass basket stands are limited to 250 square feet
in area (two-dimensional horizontal plane).
   (D)   Location. Sweetgrass basket stands must be located outside the right-
of-way and required buffers, unless unique site conditions identified as part
of site plan review demonstrate that encroachment into the buffer is warranted.
   (E)   Parking.
      (1)   All sweetgrass basket stands shall utilize safe ingress and egress.
Access to the stand is approved in accordance with Subchapter H.
      (2)   Parking for sweetgrass basket stands shall be located in an area
furthest from the roadway.
      (3)   When the sweetgrass basket stand is established as an accessory
use:
         (a)   No additional parking is required for the stand; and
         (b)   Provision shall be made for sweetgrass vendors and their patrons
to share access to the stand and parking with the lot upon which the sweetgrass
basket stand is accessory.
   (F)   Design. The design of the stand shall be consistent with the photos
shown in
Figure 156.380-1: Sweetgrass Basket Stand Design.
   (G)   Signs.
      (1)   Signs for sweetgrass basket stands are limited to:
         (a)   One non-illuminated free-standing sign, not to exceed ten square
feet in area and eight feet in height; or
         (b)   One non-illuminated sign attached to the structure, not to
exceed ten square feet in area.
      (2)   Materials shall comply with the
Subchapter G.
      (3)   Off-premises signs are prohibited.
Figure 156.380-1: Sweetgrass Basket Stand Design

IMAGES/0-0-0-13167.png]
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.381 TATTOO OR BODY PIERCING STUDIO.
   (A)   The proposed location of a tattoo or body piercing studio shall not be
closer than 1,000 feet to a place of worship; school; day care; playground;
public or private recreation facility; property zoned to allow residential
uses; or property in any zoning district with existing residential uses.
   (B)   A copy of the DHEC operating permit must be provided to the town.
   (C)   Mobile units are prohibited.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.382 TOWNHOUSE DWELLING.
   (A)   Townhouse dwellings may be constructed in the CL District only when
the cluster development    subdivision design technique is utilized.
   (B)   When located in the CL District, townhouse dwelling units may comprise
no more than 20% of the total number of dwelling units allowed in the
development.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.383 WATERCRAFT OR MARINE EQUIPMENT SERVICE OR REPAIR.
   (A)   All service and repair operations shall be conducted within a fully
enclosed building or buildings.
   (B)   Any outdoor storage shall meet the conditions of §
156.452.
   (C)   Outdoor storage of wrecked vehicles, dismantled parts, or supplies is
prohibited.
   (D)   No obnoxious sound, vibration, fume, light, or electrical disturbance
created as a result of such repair or service operation is perceptible beyond
the premises.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.384 WHOLESALE SALES.
   In the AB-1 District, such use may only be conducted in conjunction with a
permitted retail sales use.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.385 THROUGH 156.419 RESERVED.
PART 4: ACCESSORY USES AND STRUCTURES
SUBPART 4.1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 156.420 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   This part applies to any subordinate use of a building or other
structure, or use of land that is:
      (1)   Conducted on the same lot as the principal use to which it is
related; and
      (2)   Clearly incidental to, and customarily found in connection with,
the principal use or structure.
   (B)   Where a principal use or structure is allowed by §
156.338, such use includes customary accessory uses and structures subject to
this part.
   (C)   Major accessory uses and structures in a PD District must be expressly
allowed by the PD District rezoning ordinance.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.421 COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER REGULATIONS.
   (A)   All accessory uses and structures must comply with the provisions of
this part, as well as any other applicable town codes and ordinances and state
and federal statutes and regulations.
      (1)   The applicant for a new accessory use or structure shall obtain a
building permit, if required by the Building Code.
      (2)   Accessory uses and structures located in zoning districts subject
to the design review process must receive design review approval prior to
construction.
   (B)   As specified in §
156.1100, when a proposed accessory use or structure requires approval by
another local, state, or federal agency, the applicant must provide proof of
such approval (or pending approval) in conjunction with the zoning permit
application.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.422 ESTABLISHMENT OF ACCESSORY USES AND STRUCTURES.
   (A)   Permitted accessory uses and structures. Accessory uses and structures
that are subordinate and incidental to and customarily associated with the
principal use or structure and that are located on the same lot with the
principal use are generally allowed, subject to the limitations of this
chapter.
   (B)   Conditional accessory uses and structures. Certain accessory uses and
structures are subject to additional use-specific conditions, which are
specified in
Subchapter C, Part 4, Subpart 4.3.
   (C)   Use must be accessory and located on same lot as principal use.
      (1)   Accessory structures and uses, except for docks, shall not be
constructed or established without an associated principal structure or use. An
accessory structure or use may only be located on the same lot as the principal
structure or use that it serves.
      (2)   An accessory building or use established on a vacant lot is
considered the principal use of the lot and may only be established if allowed
by §
156.338.
      (3)   An accessory structure may be constructed at the same time as the
principal structure. However, a certificate of occupancy for the accessory
structure shall not be issued prior to the certificate of occupancy for the
associated principal structure.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.423 MAJOR AND MINOR ACCESSORY STRUCTURES DEFINED.
   (A)   Generally. For the purposes of this part, accessory uses and
structures are categorized as major or minor depending on their
characteristics.
   (B)   Major accessory uses and structures.
      (1)   Major accessory uses and structures are substantial uses and
structures that are generally obvious from outside the parcel and vary by
district.
      (2)   Examples of major residential accessory buildings include detached
garages and carports, storage sheds, workshops, utility buildings, gazebos,
stables, and private kennels.
      (3)   Examples of major residential accessory uses and structures include
tennis courts; swimming pools; patios; barns and stables; parking or overnight
storage of recreational vehicles including but not limited to watercraft, tow-
behind trailers, and campers; satellite dishes; and antennas (ham radio, CB,
TV).
      (4)   Examples of major commercial and industrial accessory buildings
include detached garages, storage buildings, and utility buildings.
      (5)   Examples of major commercial and industrial accessory uses and
structures include garbage dumpster surrounds and pads, loading docks, and
storage tanks.
   (C)   Minor accessory uses and structures.
      (1)   Minor accessory uses and structures include uses and structures
that are not unique to a particular land use.
      (2)   Examples include mailboxes; flagpoles; fences; landscape features;
fruit, vegetable, and ornamental gardens; driveways; parking areas; swing sets,
play houses, and play equipment, including basketball goals; and retaining
walls less than four feet in height.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)

      (1)

from the lot line.

the principal structure. Accessory structures connected to the principal
structure by conditioned space or that share a common wall, roof, or foundation
with the principal structure or that are otherwise connected to the principal
structure (such as a deck) are considered part of the principal structure and
must meet the setback requirements of the zoning district.

§§ 156.425 THROUGH 156.434 RESERVED.

§ 156.435 INTRODUCTION.
   Accessory uses and structures are allowed in the locations specified in §
156.436, if the use complies with all applicable use conditions in
Subchapter C, Part 4, Subpart 4.3 and other provisions of this part.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
