(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.544 HISTORIC AND DESIGN DISTRICTS.
   (A)   This section may not be construed to limit a municipality’s authority
to enforce historic preservation zoning regulations consistent with the
preservation of local zoning authority under 47 U.S.C. § 332(c)(7), the
requirements for facility modifications under 47 U.S.C. § 1455(a), or the
National Historic Preservation Act of 1966 (54 U.S.C. §§ 300101 et seq.), and
the regulations adopted to implement those laws.
   (B)   As a condition for approval of new small wireless facilities or new
wireless support structure in the Old Village Historic District (OVHD) or the
districts subject to Subchapter H, the wireless services provider shall comply
with the design and aesthetic standards of the OVHD or
Subchapter H to minimize the negative impact to the aesthetics in those
districts.
   (C)   If design and concealment treatments are determine d on review by the
town to be insufficient to mitigate harm to the OVHD or the districts subject
to
Subchapter H, the application will be denied.
   (D)    Existing neighborh ood and supplemental review districts.
      (1)   Nothing in this subpart shall prohibit or otherwise limit the town
from establishing subsequent supplemental review districts, provided however,
that facilities and structures for which a permit was approved or deemed
approved pursuant to this subpart prior to the establishment of the
supplemental review district remain subject to the provisions of this subpart,
including routine maintenance and replacement of those facilities and
structures.
      (2)   If a wireless services provider or a wireless infrastructure
provider replaces such facilities in a manner that does not comply with this
subpart, or if a wireless services provider or a wireless infrastructure
provider relocates such facilities, such replacement or relocation is subject
to the then-existing provisions and requirements of the supplemental review
district.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.545 COVERED AREAS IN NEIGHBORHOODS ZONED FOR RESIDENTIAL USE.
   To the extent practicable, and subject to town overlay or historic districts
and town design guidelines, SWF installed in residential neighborhoods shall
utilize single pole support structures of like appearance, material, color, or
other distinguishing characteristic as existing neighborhood street light
fixtures. Total maximum height of the SWF, including all components shall be no
more than 40 feet.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.546 GENERAL CONDITIONS AND REQUIREMENTS OF PERMIT APPROVAL.
   (A)   Standard conditions of approval. SWF in rights-of-way shall be
considered a permitted use. Permission to site SWF in the right-of-way shall be
conditioned on compliance with the standard conditions of approval provided in
this subpart.
   (B)   Permit effect and duration. The town’s approval term for construction
of an attachment to a wireless support structure shall be for a period of nine
months. A permit from the town authorizes an applicant to undertake only
certain activities in accordance with this subpart, and does not create a
property right or grant any authority whatsoever to the applicant to impinge
upon the rights of others who may already have an interest in the covered area.
   (C)   Compliance with all applicable laws and Town Code.
      (1)   Permittee shall always maintain compliance with all applicable
federal, state, and local laws, regulations, ordinances, or other rules.
      (2)   If state or federal standards and regulations are amended, the
owners of any portion of SWF governed by this subpart shall bring any
facilities and/or structures into compliance with the revised standards and
regulations within the time mandated by such amendment or, if no time is
mandated, as soon as practicable under the circumstances, but no longer than 90
days.
      (3)   The town is not required to provide notice of any amendments in
order to trigger this responsibility.
      (4)   Failure to bring SWF into compliance with any revised standards and
regulations shall constitute grounds for removal at the owner’s expense.
   (D)   Inspections; emergencies.
      (1)   The town or its designee may inspect any portion of SWF in the
right-of-way upon reasonable notice to the permittee. The permittee shall
cooperate with all inspections.
      (2)   The town reserves the right to support, repair, disable, or remove
any elements of the facility in emergencies or when the facility threatens
imminent harm to persons or property.
      (3)   If circumstances permit, the town shall notify the wireless service
provider and provide the opportunity to move such facilities, poles, or support
structures prior to the town doing so, and the town shall notify the provider
after doing so.
   (E)   Relocation or adjustment as requested by town. If requested by the
town, in order to accomplish construction and maintenance activities directly
related to improvements for the health, safety, and welfare of the public, an
operator shall relocate or adjust its facilities within the right-of-way at no
cost to the town, as long as such request similarly binds all users in or on
such public way. Such relocation or adjustment shall be completed in accordance
with law.
   (F)   Contact information for responsible parties. Within ten days of any
changes to any of the contact information provided in the application, the
applicant shall provide notice of the change to the Director of the Planning,
Land Use, and Neighborhoods Department.
   (G)   Indemnification. Any entity who owns or operates SWF in the right-of-
way shall indemnify, protect, defend, and hold the town and its elected
officials, officers, employees, agents, and volunteers harmless against any and
all claims, lawsuits, judgments, costs, liens, losses, expenses, fees (to
include reasonable attorney fees), and costs of defense, proceedings, actions,
demands, causes of action, liability, and suits of any kind and nature,
including personal or bodily injury or death, property damage or other harm for
which recovery of damages is sought, to the extent that it is caused by the
negligence of the entity who owns or operates the SWF and wireless service in
the right-of-way, any agent, officer, director, representative, employee,
affiliate, or subcontractor of the operator, or their respective officers,
agents, employees, directors, or representatives while installing, repairing,
or maintaining facilities in the right-of-way.
   (H)   Good condition required. SWF shall at all times be kept and maintained
in good condition, order, and repair by qualified maintenance and construction
personnel, so that the same shall not menace or endanger the health, safety or
welfare of any person or property. All SWF shall be subject to generally
applicable property maintenance requirements and to visual inspection by code
enforcement officers.
   (I)   Relocation for public improvement projects. To the extent that the
town requires it to do so in the reasonable exercise of its police powers,
permittee shall remove and relocate the permitted SWF at permittee’s sole
expense to accommodate construction of a public improvement project by the
town.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.547 COVERED AREAS IN ANY ZONING DISTRICT IN WHICH OVERHEAD LINES HAVE
BEEN PLACED UNDERGROUND.
   (A)   The town is currently engaged in having certain overhead utility lines
placed underground for aesthetic and enhanced service reasons.
   (B)   Within 90 days following written notice from the town, any wireless
service provider shall, at its own expense, disconnect, remove, relocate,
change, or alter the position of any SWF within the rights-of-way whenever the
town, in the reasonable exercise of it police powers, has determined that such
removal, relocation, change, or alteration is reasonably necessary to meet the
objectives of having the overhead utility lines being placed underground and
will ensure public health, safety, and welfare. Subject to the above and upon a
determination by Planning staff, applicant may be allowed to replace any SWF
with a decorative style support structure, meeting decorative pole appearance,
materials, concealment, and underground support structure requirements in
compliance with this subpart.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.548 REMOVAL OF SWF IF USE DISCONTINUED OR ABANDONED.
   (A)   If a SWF is discontinued for a period of 60 days or is abandoned
without notice from the owner, it shall be considered abandoned and the town
may remove it at the owner’s expense to ensure the public health, safety, and
welfare if the town provides written notice of its intent to remove under this
section and, within 30 days after receipt of such written notice, the owner of
the SWF does not reply to the town in writing that the SWF continues to be in
operation.
   (B)   The town reserves the right to inspect and to request information from
the operator, which the operator shall provide following such request, as to
the continued use of the operator’s SWF(s) within the right-of-way.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.549 SAFETY REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Prevention of failures and accidents. Any person who owns or operates
a portion of a SWT sited in the right-of-way shall always employ ordinary and
reasonable care and install and maintain it using industry standard technology
for preventing failures and accidents which are likely to cause damage, injury,
or nuisance to the public.
   (B)   Compliance with fire safety and FCC regulations. All SWF, including,
but not limited to wires, cables, fixtures, and other equipment, shall be
installed and maintained in compliance with the requirements of the National
Electric Code, all FCC, state, and local regulations, and in such manner that
will not interfere with the use of other property or any existing public/
private utilities or public safety systems.
   (C)   Marker or insignia required. Each attachment of wireless facilities
should bear a marker or insignia legible at street level, identifying the owner
of the SWF and contact information.
   (D)   Surety bond or equivalent financial tool for cost of removal.
      (1)   All owners must procure and provide to the town a bond, or must
provide proof of an equivalent financial mechanism, to ensure compliance with
all provisions of this code. The bond or equivalent financial method must
specifically cover the cost of removal of unused or abandoned SWF or damage to
town property caused by an operator or its agent of each SWF in case the town
has to remove or pay for its removal.
      (2)   Acceptable alternatives to a bond include: a fund set-aside; a
letter of credit; and a demonstration that the owner has operated in the town
for at least the years and that the owner or its parent or affiliated companies
maintain a net worth of at least $300,000.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.550 APPEALS.
   Any determination rendered by the Planning, Land Use, and Neighborhoods
Department may be appealed to the Board of Zoning Appeals in accordance with
Subchapter I, Part 17.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.551 SEVERABILITY.
   The provisions of this subpart are severable. If any provision or division,
or the application of any provision or division to any person or circumstances
is held invalid, the remaining provisions, divisions, and applications of such
ordinance to other persons or circumstances shall not be made invalid as well.
It is declared to be the intent of this section that the remaining provisions
would have been adopted had such invalid provisions not been included in this
subpart when originally adopted by Council.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.552 PENALTIES.
   (A)   In addition to any other penalties set forth in this chapter, any
person or permittee violating any provision in this subpart shall be guilty of
a minor misdemeanor. Each day the violation continues shall be deemed a
separate offense.
   (B)   Nothing herein shall prevent the town from taking any other lawful
action, including civil actions at law or equity, including temporary
restraining orders, preliminary injunctions and permanent injunctions, as is
necessary to prevent or remedy any violations.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.553 THROUGH 156.559 RESERVED.
SUBPART 7.2: TELECOMMUNICATIONS  TOWERS
§ 156.560 TITLE.
   This subpart shall be known and may be cited as the Town of Mount Pleasant
telecommunications tower regulations.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.561 PURPOSE.
   (A)   The purpose of the telecommunications tower regulations is to ensure
that residents, public safety operations and businesses have reliable access to
wireless telecommunications networks and communications services, while
preserving the intrinsic aesthetic character of the community by regulating the
placement, construction, and modification of wireless communications
facilities.
   (B)   By enacting these telecommunications tower regulations, it is the
town's intent to:
      (1)   Ensure sufficient wireless infrastructure to support public safety
communications;
      (2)   Ensure access to reliable wireless communications throughout all
areas of the town;
      (3)   Encourage the use of existing structures for the location and
collocation of telecommunications facilities;
      (4)   Facilitate the responsible deployment of telecommunications
facilities in appropriate areas; and
      (5)   Ensure protection of the public health, safety, convenience, order,
appearance, prosperity and general welfare of the town.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.562 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of the telecommunications tower regulations, the following
definitions apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different
meaning.
   CALF. A portable cell site that involves the temporary placement of
additional antennas on an existing telecommunications tower, with the ancillary
equipment located on a mobile platform or vehicle utilized to provide temporary
or emergency service.
   CARRIER ON WHEELS OR CELL ON WHEELS (COW). A portable self-contained cell
site that is normally vehicle-mounted and contains a telescoping boom as the
antenna support structure that can be moved to a location and set up to provide
wireless services on a temporary or emergency basis.
   COLLOCATION ON TELECOMMUNICATIONS TOWER. The placement of antennas on an
existing telecommunications tower without the need to construct a new support
structure or extend the height of the existing tower.
   MONOPOLE. A single, free-standing pole-type structure supporting one or more
antenna.
   STEALTH TECHNOLOGY. The treatment of telecommunications apparatus that
integrates the same into an architectural feature of an existing structure, or
is so designed that its purpose as a structure for providing wireless services
is not readily apparent to a casual observer.
   TELECOMMUNICATIONS TOWER. A tower, pole, or similar vertical structure that
supports a telecommunications antenna and is utilized to provide wireless
transmission of voice, data, images, or other information.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.563 PERMITTED USE.
   (A)   The collocation of additional antennas for existing or new providers
on an existing telecommunications tower, located in any zoning district
regardless of conforming or compliant status, that do not increase the height
of the existing tower and only involves the installation of additional antennas
and ground-mounted equipment in the general vicinity of existing ground-mounted
equipment and within the setback area of the zoning district, is a permitted
use.
   (B)   The location or collocation of providers on existing buildings or
structures, such as water towers, electrical transmission or distribution
towers, and likewise, located in any zoning district, provided that the overall
height of the building or structure is not increased by more than 30 feet, is a
permitted use.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.564 CONDITIONAL USE.
   Monopole, stealth, free-standing, or guy-wire telecommunications towers are
allowed in the LI, Light Industrial District, subject to the following
conditions:
   (A)   The applicant must provide written verification that no feasible
alternative exists to the construction of a new tower, such as collocation on
an existing tower or structure;
   (B)   The tower owner must provide a written agreement acknowledging that
additional providers may collocate on the new tower at the prevailing market
rate, subject to the engineering capabilities of the structure;
   (C)   The minimum setback from the center of the tower to an adjacent
residentially zoned property is equal to the height of the tower, measured to
the closest property line;
   (D)   The minimum setback from the center of the tower to all other adjacent
non-residentially zoned property or street right-of-way is determined by the
fall zone, such that in the event of failure the fall zone shall prevent the
tower from encroaching onto adjoining properties of street rights-of-way; and
   (E)   In all cases the fall zone must remain inside the lot lines of the
property on which the tower is located.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.565 SPECIAL EXCEPTION USE.
   (A)   Telecommunications towers in the AB-1, Areawide Business-1 District,
and AB-2, Areawide Business-2 District, are allowed as a special exception,
subject to the provisions of
Subchapter I, Part 9 and the following provisions:
      (1)   The applicant must meet the requirements of §
156.564; and
      (2)   Monopole or stealth applications are preferred over lattice towers.
   (B)   Telecommunications towers for police, fire, public works, utility
companies, and other public or quasi-public service providers are allowed as a
special exception in the PI-1, Public Institutional-1, and PI-2, Public and
Institutional-2, Districts, subject to the provisions of Subchapter I, Part 9
and the following provisions:
      (1)   The applicant must meet the requirements of §
156.564;
      (2)   Monopole or stealth applications are preferred over lattice towers;
and
      (3)   They are provided only in conjunction with a primary facility and
not in a stand-alone capacity.
   (C)   Notwithstanding any contrary provisions of this chapter, including
those of §
156.546, collocations requiring an extension of an existing tower regardless of
zoning district classification may be allowed as a special exception pursuant
to the provisions of
Subchapter I, Part 9.
   (D)   In addition to satisfying the approval criteria listed herein, the
Board of Zoning Appeals must find that the design, location, and height of the
proposed tower will not substantially impact the aesthetic and residential
character of adjoining areas zoned residential, and intended to remain as such
pursuant to adopted land use plans.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.566 ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS.
   (A)   Location, collocation, and construction of new towers require the
issuance of a building permit demonstrating adherence to all applicable
building code requirements, including wind load and seismic requirements.
   (B)   Towers no longer used for communication purposes must be dismantled
and removed within 120 days of the date they are taken out of service.
   (C)   No advertising signage may be placed on any tower.
   (D)   Illumination is only allowed in accordance with the requirements of
the FCC, FAA, or other appropriate regulatory agencies.
   (E)   It is preferred that the color of the tower blend in with its
surroundings.
   (F)   The tower and associated structures are appropriately secured by means
of walls, fences (other than chain link material) or other devices, and are
appropriately screened using existing new evergreen shrubs and trees that will
reach a minimum height of six feet.
   (G)   The use of COWs and CALFs are allowed in any zoning district as
follows:
      (1)   With a special event permit pursuant to the provisions of
Chapter 116;
      (2)   For a period not to exceed 120 days following a natural disaster or
local emergency as declared by competent official authority; and
      (3)   On location by broadcast media on a short-term basis covering an
event or story for the duration of the same.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.567 APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Copy of lease or letter of authorization from the property owner
authorizing the application;
   (B)   Written description and scaled drawings, in plan and elevation view,
of the proposed tower structure, antennas, ground structure, landscape or
bufferyard plantings and fence plan;
   (C)   Graphic representation of the tower's fall zone and certification
letter from a state of South Carolina-licensed, professional engineer, bearing
original signature and seal;
   (D)   Line-of-sight diagram or photo simulation, showing the proposed tower
against the skyline, and viewed from at least four directions from within the
surrounding area;
   (E)   Written justification why location on an existing building or
structure or collocation on an existing tower without extension is not
feasible, to include:
      (1)   Such technical information and other justifications as are
necessary to document why location or collocation is not viable; and
      (2)   A list of all existing structures considered as alternatives to the
proposed location, and an explanation of why the alternatives were unacceptable
due to technical, physical, or financial reasons; and
      (3)   A written agreement acknowledging that additional providers may
collocate on the new tower at the prevailing market rate, subject to the
engineering capabilities of the structure.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.568 APPEALS.
   (A)   Appeals from an administrative decision may be pursued in accordance
with the provisions of
Subchapter I, Part 17.
   (B)   Appeals from the decision of the Board of Zoning Appeals regarding a
special exception application may be pursued in accordance with the provisions
of
Subchapter I, Part 9.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.569 THROUGH 156.579 RESERVED.
SUBCHAPTER D: BUFFERS AND SCREENING
PART 1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 156.580 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   This subchapter generally applies to all lots and regulates both
bufferyards and buffers.
   (B)   Overlay districts may establish different standards for perimeter and
right-of-way bufferyards (see
Subchapter B).
   (C)   
Subchapter C specifies perimeter and right-of-way bufferyard requirements for
certain land uses, such as car washes, that apply in addition to the standards
in this subchapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.581 EXISTING VEGETATION PREFERRED.
   Existing vegetation is preferred over new plantings and may count toward
bufferyard requirements if it achieves the same purpose as the required
plantings and otherwise meets the requirements of this subchapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.582 VEGETATION REMOVAL PROHIBITED.
   (A)   Removal of trees and natural vegetation, except invasive species,
occupying a special right-of-way bufferyard, a scenic highway bufferyard, a
critical area buffer, or an historical and cultural resources buffer is
prohibited.
   (B)   Removal of trees and natural vegetation occupying a perimeter or
right-of-way bufferyard (except a special right-of-way bufferyard or a scenic
highway bufferyard) may be allowed pursuant to §
156.609. Removal of invasive species is required as specified in §
156.583.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.583 INVASIVE SPECIES.
   (A)   Invasive exotic species listed on the South Carolina Exotic Pest
Council Invasive Plant List shall not be planted or used to fulfill any
planting requirements.
   (B)   Where invasive species exist on sites to be developed in part or in
full, they shall be removed by appropriate means so as not to damage desirable
species.
      (1)   Landscape, buffer, and/or site plans, as applicable, for proposed
development shall indicate the presence, if any, of invasive species.
      (2)   Herbicide treatments or other activities necessary to eradicate
invasive species shall begin during the first phase of development (e.g., the
clearing phase) to ensure adequate time for subsequent treatments and the
effective eradication of these species prior to completion and final inspection
of the development project (see A Management Guide for Invasive Plants in
Southern Forests, United States Department of Agriculture, Forest Service,
Southern Research Station).
      (3)   Replacement is not required for removal of invasive species.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.584 MINIMUM PLANT STANDARDS.
   (A)   Minimum size. All planting materials required by this subchapter shall
conform to the minimum size or height standards in Table 156.584-1: Minimum
Plant Size at the time of planting.
   (B)   ANSI standards. All vegetation planted to fulfill the requirements of
this subchapter shall meet or exceed the latest version of American Standard
for Nursery Stock (ANSI Z-60.1).
   (C)   Quality. Planted trees shall be of good structure and high quality.

§ 156.585 PLANT SPECIES.
   (A)   Generally. 
Table 156.585-2: Plant Species List specifies the types of plants that may be
used to satisfy the requirements of this subchapter. Plants not listed may be
approved by staff. Examples of unlisted plants that may be approved include new
varieties of species already listed and species that may now survive in this
geographic area due to warmer temperatures.
   (B)   Native species required. To encourage a diversity in plantings, at
least 50% of the total quantity of canopy and understory trees and at least 25%
of shrubs used to fulfill the requirements of this subchapter shall be native
species.
Table 156.585-2: Plant Species List indicates native species in bold text.
   (C)   Species variety required.
      (1)   To avoid a monoculture and encourage diversity among plantings, a
variety of species are required based on the number of plantings as specified
in
Table 156.585-1: Species Variety.
      (2)   This applies for each type of planting (canopy trees, understory
trees, and shrubs). For example, if six canopy trees, 12 understory trees, and
25 shrubs are planted, the plantings must include at least two different
species of canopy trees, four different species of understory trees, and seven
different species of shrubs.

§ 156.586 REQUIRED VEGETATION IS PROTECTED.
   (A)   All vegetation required by this subchapter is protected and requires
prior approval for the alteration of bufferyard or buffer width or removal of
bufferyard or buffer vegetation.
   (B)   Mitigation for removal is required by replacement or through donation
to the town's tree bank in applicable situations.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.587 IMPACTS FROM AERIAL TRANSMISSION POWER LINES.
   (A)   Where protected trees are mutually considered danger trees by the
power provider and the Zoning Administrator:
      (1)   Their removal request shall be submitted in plan form and may be
granted, with replacement being required, as outlined in
Subchapter E, to be planted on the site of the requested removal. Where buffer
configuration, aerial power line conditions or other circumstances or
conditions do not permit canopy tree replacement, the largest size tree or tall
shrubs may be permitted, with replacement calculations based upon nursery
standards or an equivalent donation made to the tree bank as determined by Town
Council; and
      (2)   Such trees may be pruned only in accordance with town standards and
with the specifications provided in the latest version of ANSI A300. ANSI A300:
Standards for Tree Care Operations specifies acceptable alternatives to topping
that may be considered.
   (B)   Where power line maintenance operations cause violation of
Subchapter E by means such as excessive pruning, based upon pruning standards
referenced in §
156.706, the tree may be considered damaged and require removal and
replacement. Damage to bufferyard or buffer vegetation as a part of any
maintenance activity requires replacement in-kind.
   (C)   Where taller maturing species of trees exist directly under the power
lines, pruning practice would otherwise require a tree to be topped, resulting
in a standing stub without lateral limbs, they may be removed with Zoning
Administrator approval, and may require replacement with more power line-
compatible species.
   (D)   Regular line clearance pruning may be permitted on cyclical events, if
pruning is the minimum legally required.
   (E)   No portions of a bufferyard or buffer shall be maintained by clear
cutting or herbicide applications.
   (F)   Where existing aerial lines are to be placed underground, locations
for ground cabinets should first be sought outside of the bufferyard or buffer.
Where other options do not exist, minimal portions of the bufferyard or buffer
may be cleared to allow for the setting of ground cabinets, with Zoning
Administrator approval of the plans, and replanting required around the
cabinets to screen them and best reestablish all vegetative levels of the
bufferyard or buffer.
   (G)   Where road widening or other road improvements impact existing
bufferyards, a buffer width reduction may occur only when a full buffer width
cannot be accommodated with site adjustments. Where a full bufferyard width
cannot be provided through site adjustments but some additional width can be
accommodated, the width shall be increased to the maximum extent possible.
Required plant quantities, based upon the pre-road improvement buffer width
within impacted buffers, may only be reduced to the extent that plantings
cannot fit within the final approved bufferyard width. The potential to have
plantings within the right-of-way may be considered where plantings on private
property cannot be accommodated.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.588 IMPACTS FROM ROAD IMPROVEMENTS.
   (A)   Where road widening or other road improvements impact existing
bufferyards or buffers, a width reduction may occur only when the full required
width cannot be accommodated with site adjustments.
   (B)   Where a full bufferyard or buffer width cannot be provided through
site adjustments but some additional width can be accommodated, the width shall
be increased to the maximum extent possible. Required plant quantities, based
upon the pre-road improvement buffer width within impacted buffers, may only be
reduced to the extent that plantings cannot fit within the final approved
bufferyard width. The potential to have plantings within the right-of-way may
be considered where plantings on private property cannot be accommodated.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.589 THROUGH 156.599 RESERVED.
PART 2: PERIMETER AND RIGHT-OF-WAY BUFFERYARDS
§ 156.600 PURPOSE.
   (A)   The purpose of this part is to:
      (1)   Separate different land uses from each other, in order to:
         (a)   Eliminate or minimize potential nuisances, such as dirt, litter,
noise, glare of lights, signs, and unsightly buildings or parking areas; and
         (b)   Provide spacing to reduce adverse impacts of noise, odor, or
danger from fires or explosions;
      (2)   Improve air and water quality;
      (3)   Moderate climatic effects;
      (4)   Reduce flooding by slowing, stormwater runoff and increasing
infiltration;
      (5)   Stabilize soils; and
      (6)   Provide habitat for wildlife.
   (B)   Both the amount of land and the type and amount of planting specified
for each bufferyard required by this part are designed to ameliorate nuisances
between adjacent land uses or between a land use and a street. Perimeter and
right-of-way bufferyards are not intended for future location of water, sewer,
or other utility lines.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.601 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   This part applies to
      (1)   All subdivisions subject to the sketch plan process (see §
155.021); and
      (2)   The following types of development in the RM, OP-1, OP-2, NC-1, NC-
2, AB-1, AB-2, ED, LI, WG-C, SCW-W, SCW-H, SCW-N, and PD Districts:
         (a)   All new non-residential developments and buildings;
         (b)   All new mixed use buildings;
         (c)   All new multiplex and apartment complex developments and
buildings;
         (d)   Any change of use from one non-residential use to another non-
residential use;
         (e)   Any change of use from a residential use to a non-residential
use;
         (f)   Any expansion of an existing building, structure, or vehicular
use area by more than 50% of its gross area; and
         (g)   Any renovation of a nonconforming structure or site feature
meeting the threshold in §
156.1538.
   (B)   This part does not apply to lots located in the Old Village Historic
District.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.602 EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   For sites subject to the design review process (see
Subchapter I, Part 12) that include one or more separate lots within a larger
development (such as an "outparcel"), the necessity of whether a bufferyard is
required between the lots within the development, and the specific requirements
thereof, shall be determined during the design review process.
   (B)   Where two non-residential lots share two-way vehicular access (i.e., a
driveway) along a common side or rear lot line, the perimeter bufferyards may
be eliminated where this vehicular access occurs.
      (1)   If the two lots share a fully cohesive (shared), interconnected
parking lot, the perimeter bufferyard may be entirely eliminated along the
common lot line(s) where the parking lot connection exists.
      (2)   Portions of the lots not interconnected are required to provide the
perimeter bufferyard as normally required.
   (C)   Bufferyards do not apply to interior lot lines for lots subdivided
pursuant to the provisions of §
155.047(C)(1)(a). However, perimeter and right-of-way bufferyards are required
along the development perimeter or as prescribed by the design review process.
   (D)   Bufferyards do not apply to lots subdivided pursuant to the provisions
of §
155.047(C)(1)(b).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.603 LOCATION OF PERIMETER AND RIGHT-OF-WAY BUFFERYARDS.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   Perimeter and right-of-way bufferyards are located along the outer
perimeter of a lot, extending to the lot line; and
      (2)   Are not located on any portion of an existing public or private
street or areas encumbered by a recorded easement, except as allowed in
division (E) below.
   (B)   Perimeter bufferyards. Perimeter bufferyards are located along all lot
lines that are not adjacent to a public or private right-of-way.
   (C)   Right-of-way bufferyards. Right-of-way bufferyards are located along
all lot lines that are adjacent to a public or private street right-of-way.
   (D)   Relationship to required setbacks. Where front, side, and rear
setbacks are required by this chapter, perimeter and right-of-way bufferyards
may be established within the setback area.
   (E)   Perimeter and right-of-way bufferyards along utility line easements.
Perimeter and right-of-way bufferyards installed along utility line easements
shall meet one of the following requirements:
      (1)   If utility lines run parallel or near parallel to a lot line that
requires a bufferyard, the required bufferyard must begin at the edge of the
utility easement closest to the proposed development; or
      (2)   The property owner shall obtain a written agreement from the
utility company having control of the easement authorizing the required
plantings to be placed within the easement and to remain within the easement in
perpetuity unless the bufferyard is no longer required. This agreement shall:
         (a)   Specify the agency or person responsible for the maintenance and
replacement of any removed, damaged, or diseased vegetation; and
         (b)   Be submitted with the zoning permit application or preliminary
plat application, as applicable.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.604 PERIMETER AND RIGHT-OF-WAY BUFFERYARD TYPES.
   (A)   Existing plant material. Any existing plant material that otherwise
satisfies the requirements of this part may be counted toward satisfying the
required bufferyard if they are identified on the development plans.
   (B)   Groundcover required. All bufferyard areas shall be covered with mulch
or suitable ground cover, except where other surfaces, such as sidewalks or
recreational trails, are allowed to occur within a bufferyard.
   (C)   Evergreen plant materials. When evergreen (or conifer) plant materials
are used in a perimeter or right-of-way bufferyard, they shall be planted in
clusters.
   (D)   Developments subject to design review. The type and height of the
required structure and exact placement of required plants shall be determined
through the design review process (see
Subchapter I, Part 12) based upon the proposed use of the subject property and
the uses of adjoining properties and, in the case of fence structures, the type
of materials utilized and maintenance issues.
   (E)   Developments subject to Planning Commission review.
      (1)   The type and height of the required structure (if any) and the
number and species of required plants shall be specified on the sketch plan
(see §
155.021). The Planning Commission may require changes based upon the proposed
use of the subject property and the uses of adjoining properties and, in the
case of fence structures, the type of materials utilized and maintenance
issues.
      (2)   The exact placement of required plants shall be determined through
the preliminary plat process (see §
155.023), based upon the proposed use of the subject property and the uses of
adjoining properties.
   (F)   All other developments. For all other developments subject only to the
zoning permit process (see
Subchapter I, Part 7), the applicant shall propose the number, species, and
placement of required plants. However, staff may require changes to help ensure
the plants thrive where planted and effectively buffer the subject property as
intended.
   (G)   Bufferyard illustrations. The illustrations in Figures 156.604-
1 through 156.604-7 graphically indicate the planting requirements for each
bufferyard type. Each illustration depicts the bufferyard to be provided on a
given property, which is a portion of the total bufferyard to be provided
between two adjoining properties or between the subject property and the right-
of-way.
      (1)   The illustrations specify the type and quantity of plant materials
required by each bufferyard type and each bufferyard option.
      (2)   The requirements are stated in terms of the bufferyard width and
the number of plants required per 100 linear feet of bufferyard.
      (3)   The requirements of a bufferyard may be satisfied by any one of the
options illustrated.
      (4)   The plant unit multiplier is a factor by which the basic number of
plant materials required for a given bufferyard is determined, given a change
in the width of that yard.
      (5)   Figure 156.604-7: Required Structures in Perimeter and Right-of-Way
Bufferyards provides specifications for the walls and fences required in
certain bufferyard types.
      (6)   When required, structure type F-1 shall be placed in a bufferyard
within four feet of the lot line, while structure types F-2, F-3, F-4, and F-
5 may be placed anywhere within a bufferyard.

§ 156.605 PERIMETER AND RIGHT-OF-WAY BUFFERYARD SPECIFICATIONS.
   ( A)    Generally. Table 156.605-1: Required Perimeter and Right-of-Way
Buffer Types by Land Use specifies the perimeter and right-of-way bufferyard
types required for proposed development based on land use.
   (B)    Determination of bufferyard requirements. To determine the bufferyard
required between two adjacent lots or between a lot and a street:
      (1)   In the leftmost column of the table, locate the row for the
proposed use of the lot on which development is proposed;
      (2)   For each lot line (or segment thereof), identify the adjacent land
use and locate the applicable column;
      (3)   The table cell where the row and column intersect specifies the
applicable bufferyard type (see §
156.604).
   (C)   Different bufferyard types along a single lot line. Where the required
bufferyard type changes along a lot line because of abutting land uses, the
applicable bufferyard width and plant schedule shall be provided adjacent to
each abutting land use.

§ 156.606 SPECIAL RIGHT-OF-WAY BUFFERYARDS.
   (A)   Purpose.
      (1)   The purpose of this section is to provide enhanced screening along
the specified rights-of-way that helps to:
         (a)   Preserve tree canopy;
         (b)   Minimize the harmful impacts of noise, dust and other debris,
and motor vehicle headlight glare; and
         (c)   Reduce the visual impact of development along the specified
rights-of-way to maintain a more rural appearance.
      (2)   The special right-of-way bufferyard is intended to appear as a
wooded strip, with a mix of canopy and understory trees, shrubs, and
undergrowth.
   (B)   Applicability. This section applies along:
      (1)   Highway 17 North from its intersection with Long Point Road and
with Old Georgetown Road, north/northeast to the municipal boundary;
      (2)   Highway 41 from its intersection with Highway 17 North, north to
the Wando River; and
      (3)   Long Point Road from its intersection with Interstate 526 to its
intersection with Whipple Road and with Lillie and Rebecca Lane.
   (C)   Vegetation removal prohibited. Except as provided in division (F)
below, removal of trees and natural vegetation occupying a special right-of-way
bufferyard is prohibited.
   (D)   Natural, undisturbed bufferyard required.
      (1)   New developments, redevelopments, and lot subdivisions are required
to maintain or establish a bufferyard along each lot’s right-of-way frontage.
      (2)   If the property is vegetated prior to submittal of development
plans, the existing bufferyard shall remain natural and undisturbed, except
that select clearing is allowed as provided in division (F) below. If the
existing bufferyard does not contain at least the minimum plantings required by
Part 6: Lots Without an Existing Buffer, the applicant shall supplement the
existing buffer to meet the requirements of Part 6.
      (3)   If a natural, vegetated bufferyard does not exist on a lot at the
time of submittal of development plans, the applicant shall establish the
bufferyard during the development process as specified in Part 6. In such
cases, all new plantings shall be native species.
   (E)   Minimum bufferyard width. The minimum width for a special right-of-way
bufferyard is 50 feet.
   (F)   Select clearing allowed. Select clearing of trees measuring less than
three inches DBH is allowed in a special right-of-way bufferyard.
      (1)   All trees three inches DBH or greater shall be indicated on a tree
survey.
      (2)   Select pruning of limbs up to eight feet above ground level or half
the height of the tree, whichever is less, is allowed if it meets the pruning
standards as provided in the latest version of American National Standard for
Tree Care Operations – Tree, Shrub, and Other Woody Plant Management - Standard
Practices (Pruning) (ANSI A300).
   (G)   Invasive species. Invasive species shall be removed from a special
right-of-way bufferyard in accordance with §
156.583.
   (H)   Supplemental landscaping. A property owner may supplement existing
vegetation in a special right-of-way bufferyard if the additional landscaping
is comprised of native species and is approved by the Department of Planning,
Land Use and Neighborhoods.
   (I)   Irrigation. Irrigation systems are allowed in a special right-of-way
bufferyard if approved by the Department of Planning, Land Use and
Neighborhoods.
   (J)   Utilities.
      (1)   Cross-penetration of utilities in a special right-of-way bufferyard
is discouraged and, to the extent possible, shall be brought in at other
disturbed areas such as vehicular access points or sidewalk connections.
      (2)   Where cross-penetration of utilities in a special right-of-way
bufferyard is unavoidable, the property owner shall obtain a written agreement
from the utility company having control of the easement in accordance with §
156.603(E).
         (a)   Where a special right-of-way bufferyard is vegetated, utility
cross-penetrations shall be bored under existing vegetation to avoid any
disturbance to the buffer vegetation.
         (b)   In cases where no vegetation exists prior to development,
trenched utility penetrations may occur. However, maintenance or repairs to the
utility line that disturbs vegetation planted as a requirement of the
development process shall be replaced in accordance with §
156.603(E).
   (K)   Prohibited elements. The following elements are prohibited in a
special right-of-way bufferyard:
      (1)   Structures, including fences and walls, unless they are associated
with a use allowed by §
156.608;
      (2)   Amenity features such as tables, seating areas, and fire pits,
whether temporary or permanent; and
      (3)   Natural and synthetic turf grass.
   (L)   Development plans and construction activities.
      (1)   The boundaries of the special right-of-way bufferyard shall be
clearly delineated and identified on all development plans and plats submitted
for approval.
      (2)   Bufferyard limits shall be staked in the field prior to and
throughout construction activities. Bufferyard limits shall be marked with a
stake every 50 feet and at every point where the bufferyard limit pivots or
changes direction.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.607 SCENIC HIGHWAY BUFFERYARDS.
   (A)   Purpose.
      (1)   The purpose of this section is to:
         (a)   Fulfill the intent of the Mathis Ferry Road and Long Point Road
Corridor Management Plans; and
         (b)   Conserve and enhance the natural tree canopy that helps support
the routes’ Scenic Highway designation.
      (2)   To this end, owners of all developed properties are encouraged to
plant trees along their Mathis Ferry Road or Long Point Road frontage to
maintain the tree canopy along these scenic highways.
   (B)   Applicability. This section applies along:
      (1)   Mathis Ferry Road, from its intersection with 7th Avenue to its
intersection with Whipple Road; and
      (2)   Long Point Road, from its intersection with Whipple Road to its
intersection with Highway 17 North.
   (C)   Vegetation removal prohibited. Except as provided in division (F)
below, removal of trees and natural vegetation occupying a special right-of-way
bufferyard is prohibited.
   (D)   Minimum bufferyard width. The minimum width for a scenic highway
bufferyard is based on the type of development proposed.
      (1)   When an existing detached house, duplex, or townhouse dwelling is
improved by 50% or more of its assessed value, a 25-foot bufferyard shall be
maintained or established in accordance with the planting requirements
specified in division (E) below.
      (2)   When an existing non-residential structure, triplex dwelling,
quadplex dwelling, multiplex dwelling, or an apartment complex is improved by
50% or more of its assessed value, a 50-foot bufferyard shall be maintained or
established in accordance with the planting requirements specified in division
(E) below.
      (3)   When an existing residentially-zoned lot is subdivided into two or
more lots, each at least 10,000 square feet in area, a 50-foot bufferyard shall
be maintained or established in accordance with the planting requirements
specified in division (E) below.
      (4)   When an existing residentially-zoned lot is subdivided into two or
more lots, each less than 10,000 square feet in area, a 25-foot bufferyard
shall be maintained or established in accordance with the planting requirements
specified in division (E) below.
      (5)   When an existing lot is developed with any non-residential use, a
triplex dwelling, a quadplex dwelling, a multiplex dwelling, or an apartment
complex, a 50-foot bufferyard shall be maintained or established in accordance
with the planting requirements specified in division (E) below.
      (6)   When an existing lot is developed with a detached house, duplex, or
townhouse dwelling, a 25-foot bufferyard shall be maintained or established in
accordance with the planting requirements specified in division (E) below.
   (E)   Natural, undisturbed bufferyard required.
      (1)   New developments, redevelopments, and lot subdivisions are required
to maintain or establish a bufferyard along each lot’s scenic highway frontage.
      (2)   If the property is vegetated prior to submittal of development
plans, the existing bufferyard shall remain natural and undisturbed, except
that the removal of invasive exotic species and vines is allowed as provided in
division (F) below.
      (3)   If a natural, vegetated bufferyard does not exist on a lot at the
time of submittal of development plans, the applicant shall establish the
bufferyard during the development process as follows:
         (a)   Except as otherwise provided below, the applicant shall remove
existing turf grass, fences, walls, and any other structure located in the
scenic highway bufferyard.
         (b)   If the proposed use of the lot is a detached house dwelling, the
applicant shall replant the scenic highway bufferyard with one 2.5-inch caliper
live oak tree per 30 feet of frontage or portion thereof. Applicants are not
required to remove existing turf grass. If turf grass does not exist, the
applicant shall mulch the scenic highway bufferyard.
            1.   Any existing oak tree in good health located in the bufferyard
may be used to meet this requirement.
            2.   If the lot cannot physically accommodate the required tree(s),
the applicant may pay a fee-in-lieu as provided in §
156.702(M).
         (c)   For all other uses, the applicant shall:
            1.   Mulch and replant the scenic highway bufferyard with the
following number and type of plants for each 200 square feet of bufferyard
area:
               a.   Four three-gallon shrubs and four seven-gallon shrubs
comprised of at least three differing species, with near equal quantities of
each species; and
               b.   Two 1.5-inch caliper understory trees and one 2.5-inch
caliper canopy tree comprised of at least two differing species per tree type.
The result of this requirement is that there are at least two different species
of understory trees and at least two different species of canopy trees.;
            2.   Install plantings that are indigenous to the immediate area;
and
            3.   Arrange the plantings in a natural random pattern.
   (F)   Invasive exotic species and vines.
      (1)   All property owners may remove invasive exotic species and vines
from the scenic highway bufferyard.
      (2)   New construction, additions to existing construction, and
redevelopments are required as part of their construction plans to eradicate
invasive exotic species and vines from their scenic highway bufferyard area.
Herbicide treatments or other activities necessary to eradicate invasive
species shall begin during the first phase of development (e.g., the clearing
phase) to ensure adequate time for subsequent treatments and the effective
eradication of these species prior to completion and final inspection of the
development project (see A Management Guide for Invasive Plants in Southern
Forests, United States Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Southern
Research Station).
      (3)   Property owners along these scenic highway corridors are encouraged
to regularly monitor their buffer and take measures to control vine and
invasive exotic species growth to ensure a healthy, natural buffer.
   (G)   Prohibited elements. The following elements are prohibited in a scenic
highway bufferyard:
      (1)   Structures, including fences and walls, unless they are associated
with a use allowed by §
156.608;
      (2)   Amenity features such as tables, seating areas, and fire pits,
whether temporary or permanent; and
      (3)   Natural and synthetic turf grass.
   (H)   Development plans and construction activities.
      (1)   The boundaries of the scenic highway bufferyard shall be clearly
delineated and identified on all development plans and plats submitted for
approval.
      (2)   Bufferyard limits shall be staked in the field prior to and
throughout construction activities.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.608 USE OF PERIMETER AND RIGHT-OF-WAY BUFFERYARDS.
   (A)   Allowed uses. The uses specified below are the only uses allowed in a
perimeter or right-of-way bufferyard.
      (1)   Multi-use paths.
         (a)   A perimeter or right-of-way bufferyard may accommodate a
publicly accessible multi-use path, if the path:
            1.   Is part of the approved route for Mount Pleasant Way; or
            2.   Is identified as a recommended improvement in the town’s
Bicycle and Pedestrian Master Plan; or
            3.   Creates a new connection between existing disconnected paths
or sidewalks; and
            4.   Is sited in a manner that minimizes impacts to the bufferyard
vegetation; and
            5.   Is shown on the approved site plan for the development.
         (b)   A multi-use path may include boardwalks as well as amenities,
such as benches, bicycle repair stations, and trash cans.
         (c)   Every reasonable effort shall be made to accommodate displaced
plantings elsewhere within the bufferyard.
      (2)   Stormwater control measures. A perimeter or right-of-way bufferyard
may accommodate stormwater conveyance and infiltration, if the proposed
development achieves the Level 2 or Level 3 threshold specified in the town’s
Environmental Guidelines for Land Development.
      (3)   Signs. Freestanding signs are allowed in a perimeter or right-of-
way bufferyard if permitted in accordance with this chapter.
      (4)   Fences and walls. Fences and walls are allowed, and in some
instances are required, within a perimeter or right-of-way bufferyard.
      (5)   Utility ground cabinets. Utility ground cabinets are allowed within
a perimeter bufferyard, but should not be placed in a right-of-way bufferyard.
   (B)   Prohibited elements. The following elements are prohibited in a
perimeter or right-of-way bufferyard:
      (1)   Structures, excluding signs, fences, walls, and utility ground
cabinets, unless they are associated with a use allowed by this section; and
      (2)   Amenity features such as tables, seating areas, and fire pits,
whether temporary or permanent.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.609 ALTERNATIVE COMPLIANCE.
   (A)   Purpose. Project conditions associated with individual sites that are
subject to the Environmental Guidelines for Land Development (see §
155.054(B)) may justify approval of alternative methods of compliance.
Conditions may arise where normal compliance is impractical or impossible, or
where maximum achievement of the purpose and intent of this part can only be
obtained through alternative compliance.
   (B)   Applicability.
      (1)   This section allows alternative methods of meeting the requirements
of this part for perimeter and right-of-way bufferyards for developments that
are subject to the Environmental Guidelines for Land Development (see §
155.054(B)).
      (2)   Requests for alternative compliance review may be submitted in
conjunction with any application for a use or development to which the
perimeter and right-of-way bufferyard requirements apply, when one or more of
the following conditions are met:
         (a)   A higher level of opacity would result from alternative
compliance;
         (b)   Topography, soil, vegetation, drainage, or other site conditions
are such that full compliance is impractical;
         (c)   Existing plant material is unhealthy, invasive, or otherwise
undesirable;
         (d)   Spatial limitations, unusually shaped lots, prevalence of
overhead power lines, unusual servitude requirements, or prevailing practices
in the surrounding neighborhood justify alternative compliance;
         (e)   Public safety considerations make alternative compliance
appropriate; or
         (f)   Public improvement projects make alternative compliance
appropriate.
      (3)   Alternative compliance is not allowed as a way to provide less
landscape material than is otherwise required.
   (C)   Written and graphic documentation required.
      (1)   Requests for alternative compliance shall be accompanied by written
explanation and plan drawings to allow staff evaluation and decision.
      (2)   Documentation and plan drawings shall be prepared and stamped by a
State of South Carolina Registered Landscape Architect.
   (D)   Approval criteria. Staff may approve or approve with conditions an
alternative buffer plan if the proposed bufferyard plan:
      (1)   Is at least equivalent to one that complies with this part in terms
of aesthetics, innovation, and creativity;
      (2)   Incorporates existing vegetation, where present, and topographical
conditions;
      (3)   Functions to buffer different uses of adjacent lots where
appropriate; and
      (4)   Uses a variety of complementary species of trees and shrubs.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.610 THROUGH 156.619 RESERVED.
PART 3: CRITICAL AREA BUFFERS
§ 156.620 PURPOSE AND INTENT.
   (A)   The purpose of the critical area buffer is to:
      (1)   Reduce stormwater pollutants;
      (2)   Improve water quality;
      (3)   Prevent and reduce erosion through undisturbed and stabilized
areas;
      (4)   Preserve wildlife corridors and natural habitats for important
species;
      (5)   Reduce flooding and subsequent damage to property; and
      (6)   Provide a natural privacy barrier.
   (B)   The intent of this part is to prohibit grassed, manicured lawns within
the buffer area.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.621 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   This part applies to all lots located adjacent to the critical area,
as defined in S.C. Code § 48-39-10, or located within 35 feet of the critical
area line.
   (B)   Where a developed lot does not meet the critical area buffer
requirements, the buffer shall be established in accordance with this part if
the principal structure on the lot is improved by 50% or more of its assessed
value.
   (C)   Where a vacant lot does not meet the critical area buffer
requirements, the buffer shall be established in accordance with this part when
the lot is developed.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.622 CRITICAL AREA BUFFER REQUIRED.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   A vegetated buffer shall be maintained or established along areas
designated as the tidally influenced "critical area" by the South Carolina
Department of Environmental Services (SCDES) Bureau of Coastal Management
(BCM).
      (2)   The natural vegetation in the buffer shall remain undisturbed,
except as allowed by §
156.624 and §
156.626. In addition, invasive species shall be removed in accordance with §
156.583.
   (B)   Buffer location.
      (1)   The critical area buffer is located landward of the critical area
line.
      (2)   A critical area buffer is required whether or not the critical area
line is located on the subject lot.
      (3)   Critical areas by their very nature are dynamic systems, subject to
change over time. Because of this, the limits of the critical area buffer are
established by the final plat approved by the town and recorded with the
Charleston County ROD office.
         (a)   The buffer limits shall remain unchanged in perpetuity unless a
new subdivision occurs. At such time, the critical line must be validated by
SCDES-BCM, which will establish the current critical line location and thus the
new buffer area; provided, however, the new critical line location only applies
to the subject lot and not to adjoining lots.
         (b)   In areas where the critical area buffer has been averaged, the
new buffer area shall not result in a reduction in square footage of the former
buffer area previously established.
         (c)   It is the sole responsibility of the property owner to ensure
all construction activity occurs landward of the current SCDES-BCM critical
line, irrespective of the critical line location reflected on the most recent
recorded plat.
   (C)   Buffer width.
      (1)   The width of the critical area buffer is:
         (a)   An average of 35 feet; and
         (b)   A minimum of 20 feet.
      (2)   The minimum and average buffer widths apply to individual lots. The
average buffer width shall not be applied over adjacent lots.
   (D)   Natural, undisturbed buffer required.
      (1)   New developments, redevelopments, and lot subdivisions are required
to maintain any existing buffer in its natural state, except as provided in §
156.624, §
156.625, and §
156.626.
      (2)   If a natural, vegetated bufferyard does not exist on a lot at the
time of submittal of development plans, the applicant shall establish the
bufferyard during the development process as specified in
Subchapter D, Part 6.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.623 PROHIBITED ELEMENTS IN A CRITICAL AREA BUFFER.
   (A)   Impervious surfaces. Impervious surfaces are prohibited within the
critical area buffer, except as provided in §
156.624.
   (B)   Erosion control structures. Erosion control structures or portions of
these structures, such as retaining walls and rip rap, may be located on the
critical line but are prohibited within the critical area buffer.
   (C)   Fences and walls. Fences with masonry elements and walls are
prohibited within the critical area buffer. Fences without masonry elements are
allowed, if materials are brought in without the use of vehicles or heavy
equipment and they are constructed by hand.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.624 ALLOWED USES IN A CRITICAL AREA BUFFER.
   Only the following uses are allowed in the critical area buffer:
   (A)   A pedestrian trail, if the trail is:
      (1)   Publicly accessible;
      (2)   Constructed of pervious material; and
      (3)   Oriented parallel to the critical line;
   (B)   A pedestrian or vehicular boardwalk, if the boardwalk:
      (1)   Leads to a water-dependent use, such as a dock, pier, bridge, or
boat landing;
      (2)   Is elevated above grade to avoid channelization; and
      (3)   Is the minimum width necessary to provide access;
   (C)   Minimum utility line penetrations, as specifically and previously
approved on development plans; and
   (D)   Permitted freestanding signs and utility ground cabinets.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.625 STORMWATER CONTROL MEASURES.
   (A)   Existing lots.
      (1)   Where stormwater control measures must be placed within the
critical area buffer on an existing lot, the property owner shall use swales or
other means, rather than drainage pipes, to convey stormwater.
      (2)   The stormwater control measure(s) must be located within an
existing vision corridor. If a vision corridor does not exist, any clearing of
vegetation required for construction of the stormwater control measures must
meet the requirements in §
156.626.
   (B)   New subdivisions requiring sketch plan approval.
      (1)   Any new subdivision that is not exempt from sketch plan approval
pursuant to §
155.028: Exceptions may use drainage pipes to convey stormwater through the
critical area buffer.
      (2)   Vegetation removal is limited to the minimum required to
accommodate the drainage pipe(s).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.626 VISION CORRIDORS.
   (A)   Generally. Vision corridors may be established through the critical
area buffer on any lot in accordance with this section.
   (B)   Vision corridor defined. A vision corridor is a vertical corridor cut
through the buffer, allowing a view through the critical area buffer. This area
is generally formed by two near perpendicular lines connecting the critical
area line to the upland boundary of the critical area buffer.
   (C)   Vision corridor area.
      (1)   The area of a vision corridor shall not exceed one-third (33%) of
the square footage of the total buffer area.
      (2)   The vision corridor shall be one single uniform unbroken portion,
except on lots where the buffer exceeds 5,250 square feet in area where it may
be broken into multiple vision corridors that each are at least 25 feet in
length.
   (D)   Vegetation removal and pruning.
      (1)   Within the vision corridor, trees of a protected size for the lot
(see Subchapter E) shall not be removed. Smaller trees may be pruned or cut
with hand tools, but the stump must remain in place.
      (2)   Grasses, shrubs, and other smaller vegetation may be pruned and
trimmed, but shall not be removed at the root.
      (3)   Pruning of any vegetation is limited to eight feet above the ground
and must be completed in accordance with the American National Standard for
Tree Care Operations – Tree, Shrub, and Other Woody Plant Management - Standard
Practices (Pruning) (ANSI A300).
      (4)   The use of heavy equipment and herbicides is prohibited in the
buffer.
      (5)   The intent of this division is to ensure the root mass remains
intact to stabilize the ground surface, which prevents soil erosion.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.627 CRITICAL AREA BUFFER AND VISION CORRIDOR DELINEATION AND RECORD.
   (A)   The boundaries of the critical area buffer shall be clearly delineated
and identified on all development plans and plats submitted for approval.
   (B)   If a vision corridor is intended to be established during the
development process, it shall be delineated on the final version of all design
plans.
      (1)   For developments subject to design review, the vision corridor
shall be delineated on the final design review plans.
      (2)   For all other developments, the vision corridor shall be delineated
on the building permit application.
      (3)   Once a building permit application is submitted for a particular
lot, a vision corridor may only be established through a plat revision or deed
restriction on the property on which it is located to act as a record of its
establishment.
      (4)   The distances from rear and side property lines must be shown on
final design plans and revised plats or specified in the deed restriction, as
applicable.
   (C)   Subsequent changes to an established buffer or vision corridor must be
re-approved and re-recorded, with restoration in accordance with Subchapter D,
Part 6 required for any previously disturbed buffer area, if necessary.
   (D)   Buffer and vision corridor limits shall be staked in the field prior
to and throughout construction activities. In addition, the vision corridor
shall have protective barricades (see Figure 156.705-3: Protective Barricade)
along its edges that are approximately perpendicular to the critical line.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.628 VIOLATIONS AND ENFORCEMENT.
   (A)   Violation of this part or failure to comply with any of the
requirements hereof shall be classified as a misdemeanor punishable by a fine
in the amount of up to $500, or imprisonment for not more than 30 days, or
both. However, no penalty shall exceed the penalty provided by state law for a
similar offense.
      (1)   A separate offense shall be deemed committed for:
         (a)   Each tree and/or separate plant or shrub that is removed; and
         (b)   Each day that the violation occurs or continues.
      (2)   Any person, firm, organization, society, association, partnership,
corporation, or like entity, or any agent or representative thereof, who
commits, participates in, or assists in such violation may each be found guilty
of a separate offense and suffer the penalties herein provided.
   (B)   Full restoration to a condition comparable to that which was destroyed
shall be required within a specified period. If restoration is to be
accomplished by the offending party, it shall include posting an acceptable
financial guarantee with the town for the full amount of restoration required
until the same is completed.
   (C)   Failure to comply with the terms stated in this part shall also be
subject to enforcement in a circuit court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.629 THROUGH 156.639 RESERVED.
PART 4: WETLAND BUFFERS
§ 156.640 PURPOSE.
   This part establishes requirements for buffers adjacent to freshwater
wetlands to improve water quality, preserve natural habitat, and reduce
flooding.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.641 APPLICABILITY.
   This part applies to all lots that contain or are located adjacent to
freshwater wetlands delineated by an environmental/wetland professional.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.642 WETLAND BUFFER REQUIRED.
   (A)   Buffer width. A buffer at least 35 feet in width is required adjacent
to all freshwater wetlands delineated by an environmental/wetland professional.
   (B)   Natural, undisturbed buffer required.
      (1)   New developments, redevelopments, and lot subdivisions are required
to maintain any existing buffer in its natural state, except as provided in §
156.644 and §
156.645.
      (2)   If a natural, vegetated bufferyard does not exist on a lot at the
time of submittal of development plans, the applicant shall establish the
bufferyard during the development process as specified in Subchapter D, Part 6.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.643 IMPERVIOUS SURFACES IN A WETLAND BUFFER.
   Impervious surfaces are prohibited within a wetland buffer.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.644 REMOVAL OF INVASIVE SPECIES.
   (A)   The removal of invasive exotic species from a wetland buffer is
required.
   (B)   The use of heavy equipment and herbicides for vegetation removal is
prohibited.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.645 TRAIL SYSTEM.
   (A)   The only use allowed in a wetland buffer is a pervious pedestrian and
bicycle trail system, if no trees greater than three inches DBH are removed.
   (B)   The use of heavy equipment and herbicides for vegetation removal is
prohibited.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.646 THROUGH 156.649 RESERVED.
PART 5: HISTORICAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES BUFFERS
§ 156.650 PURPOSE.
   This part establishes requirements for buffers intended to protect
historical, archaeological, and cultural resources.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.651 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   This part applies to all lots that contain or are immediately adjacent
to an historical, archaeological, or cultural resource. This part does not
apply within the Old Village Historic District.
   (B)   New developments, redevelopments, and lot subdivisions are required to
maintain or establish a buffer adjacent to historical, archaeological, and
cultural resources that are:
      (1)   Individually listed in or eligible for listing in the National
Register of Historic Places;
      (2)   Resources contributing to listed or eligible historic districts;
      (3)   Resources contributing to individual historic properties such as
structures or archaeological sites; or
      (4)   Designated by Town Council or County Council as an historical,
archaeological, or cultural resource.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.652 HISTORICAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES BUFFER REQUIRED.
   (A)   Buffer width. A buffer at least 40 feet in width is required adjacent
to all historically, archaeologically, or culturally significant areas.
   (B)   Natural, undisturbed buffer required.
      (1)   New developments, redevelopments, and lot subdivisions are required
to maintain any existing buffer in its natural state, except as provided in §
156.653 and §
156.654.
      (2)   If a natural, vegetated bufferyard does not exist on a lot at the
time of submittal of development plans, the applicant shall establish the
bufferyard during the development process as specified in
Subchapter D, Part 6.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.653 REMOVAL OF INVASIVE SPECIES.
   (A)   The removal of invasive exotic species from an historical and cultural
resources buffer is required.
   (B)   The use of heavy equipment and herbicides for vegetation removal is
prohibited.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.654 TRAIL SYSTEM.
   (A)   The only use allowed in an historical and cultural resources buffer is
a pervious pedestrian and bicycle trail system, if no trees greater than three
inches DBH are removed.
   (B)   The use of heavy equipment and herbicides for vegetation removal is
prohibited.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.655 THROUGH 156.659 RESERVED.
PART 6: LOTS WITHOUT  AN EXISTING BUFFER
§ 156.660 APPLICABILITY.
   This part applies to the buffers and bufferyards required by:
   (A)   §
156.606;
   (B)   
Subchapter D, Part 3;
   (C)   
Subchapter D, Part 4; and
   (D)   
Subchapter D, Part 5.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.661 PLANTING STANDARDS.
   When a buffer or bufferyard meeting the requirements of this subchapter does
not exist on a lot, the following provisions apply:
   (A)   For special right-of-way bufferyards, all prohibited elements shall be
removed, including impervious surfaces (other than trails and multi-use paths,
if allowed) and existing turf;
   (B)   The buffer or bufferyard shall be mulched and replanted as prescribed
below per 200 square feet:
      (1)   Four three-gallon shrubs and four seven-gallon shrubs comprised of
at least three differing species, with near equal quantities of each species;
and
      (2)   Two one and one-half inch understory trees and one two and one-half
inch caliper canopy tree comprised of at least two differing species per tree
type. The result of this requirement is that there are at least two different
species of understory trees and at least two different species of canopy trees.
   (C)   Plantings shall be:
      (1)   Indigenous to the immediate area;
      (2)   Arranged in a natural random pattern; and
      (3)   In a critical area buffer, selected from the list in Table 156.661-
1: Critical Area Buffer Vegetation List.
