§§ 156.662 THROUGH 156.669 RESERVED.
PART 7: MAINTENANCE
§ 156.670 APPLICABILITY.
   This part applies to landscaping required by
Subchapter H, Part 3, Subpart 3.5 and to bufferyards required by Part 2.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.671 MAINTENANCE RESPONSIBILITY.
   The owner, occupant, tenant, and the respective agent of each, if any, are
jointly and severally responsible for the maintenance of all landscaping and
perimeter and right-of-way bufferyards.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.672 VEGETATION MAINTENANCE.
   (A)   All landscape and bufferyard areas shall be properly maintained so as
to ensure their survival and aesthetic value, and shall be provided with an
irrigation system or a readily available water supply. Failure to monitor such
areas is a violation of this Chapter and may be remedied in the manner
prescribed for other violations (see
Subchapter L).
   (B)   Landscaping shall be maintained in a good condition so as to present a
healthy, neat, and orderly appearance at least equal to the original
development, and shall be kept free of refuse, with dead vegetation promptly
replaced.
   (C)   Courtesy inspections may be coordinated by town staff to ensure proper
maintenance.
   (D)   Any pruning or maintenance that significantly limits a plant's ability
to obtain its natural form and fulfill the intent of the landscaping and
bufferyard requirements will result in the issuance of a citation and/or the
possible replacement of damaged material with replacement equal to or greater
than the damaged material. Replacement greater than the damaged material may be
required when portions of plants are removed or when the landscaping or
bufferyard is nonconforming. Pruning specifications as provided in the latest
version of ANSI A300 shall be used to determine compliance with this division.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.673 LANDSCAPING MAINTENANCE BOND.
   (A)   Prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy or the recording of a
final plat, as applicable, the developer or subdivider shall post a landscaping
maintenance bond or other financial security to ensure the required plantings
survive in a healthy condition.
   (B)   The bond shall be equal to 20% of the cost of installation of all
required landscaping, including plants and labor, and shall be valid for at
least two years from the date of installation.
   (C)   The town will release the maintenance bond two years after
installation of the landscaping if the landscaping has been maintained in a
healthy growing condition and any dead or dying plants have been replaced.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.674 THROUGH 156.699 RESERVED.
SUBCHAPTER E: TREE PROTECTION
§ 156.700 AUTHORITY AND PURPOSE.
   (A)   The citizens of the town recognize the importance of preserving the
natural landscape through the protection of existing trees to:
      (1)   Promote the public health, safety, and general welfare;
      (2)   Lessen air pollution;
      (3)   Increase dust filtration;
      (4)   Reduce noise, heat, and glare;
      (5)   Prevent soil erosion;
      (6)   Improve surface drainage and minimize flooding;
      (7)   Ensure that noise, glare, and other distractions of movement in one
area do not adversely affect activity within other adjacent areas;
      (8)   Beautify and enhance improved and undeveloped land;
      (9)   Preserve and protect both the natural and historic amenities within
the town;
      (10)   Ensure that excessive tree cutting does not reduce property
values; and
      (11)   Minimize the cost of construction and maintenance of drainage
systems necessitated by the increased flow and diversion of surface waters.
   (B)   In furtherance of the above purposes and pursuant to authority
conferred by the South Carolina Local Government Comprehensive Planning and
Enabling Act of 1994, as amended, the Town Council does ordain and enact into
law the following sections:
      (1)   Regulating and restricting the removal of trees from all developed
and undeveloped real property;
      (2)   Providing for replacement of trees;
      (3)   Establishing standards for tree protection during land clearing and
construction;
      (4)   Providing certain exceptions and exemptions;
      (5)   Establishing and defining the approval process, with respect to
these regulations, for developments subject to the design review procedure;
      (6)   Providing appeal procedures and remedies;
      (7)   Providing penalties for violations of this chapter;
      (8)   Providing proper methods for maintenance;
      (9)   Defining certain terms used herein; and
      (10)   For other purposes.
   (C)   The intent of this subchapter is to encourage the protection and
replacement of trees consistent with the economic and healthful enjoyment of
private property. The intent is not punitive, nor to cause hardship to any
individual, private firm, or public agency that uses every care and diligence
to protect trees within the town.
   (D)   The Zoning Administrator shall be an ISA Certified Arborist and shall
be responsible for administration of all provisions of this subchapter. Public
tree management and all aspects of maintenance (see §
156.708) shall be administered by the Public Services Department.
   (E)   No person, firm, organization, society, association, or corporation,
or any agent or representative thereof, shall directly or indirectly destroy or
remove any protected, significant, or historic tree, except as authorized under
the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.701 JURISDICTION AND APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   This subchapter applies to all real property within the corporate
limits of the town.
   (B)   Protected, significant, or historic trees shall not be removed except
in accordance with this subchapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.702 TREE REMOVAL AND REPLACEMENT.
   (A)   Tree removal permit required.
      (1)   Prior to removal of any protected, significant, or historic tree,
the applicant must obtain a tree removal permit issued by the Zoning
Administrator, an approved clearing and grading permit, or any other tree
removal permit, as appropriate.
      (2)   An application for tree removal must be submitted, along with
payment of the required fee. Pending staff review of the request, a replacement
plan may be required which must be submitted and approved prior to issuance of
the tree permit.
      (3)   Where full replacement cannot be accomplished by replanting on the
site, fee in lieu of replacement trees may be considered in accordance with
division (M) below. When fee in lieu of replacement trees is part of an
approved replacement plan, payment must be submitted prior to issuance of the
removal permit.
      (4)   On all properties, the removal of historic trees, except as
otherwise provided in this subchapter, requires approval as specified in this
section or in §
156.704, as applicable.
      (5)   In cases where removal is requested for a boundary tree, all owners
must agree through written consent on removal and replacement prior to approval
and issuance of a tree removal permit.
      (6)   Tree removal permits will not be issued on properties where
outstanding mitigation has not been satisfied.
   (B)   Display of permit. Any permit or document authorizing removal of a
tree shall be clearly displayed in an obvious and noticeable location, such as
a window or storm door, for review during the removal process. Failure to do so
is a violation of this chapter and subject to the provisions of §
156.709.
   (C)   Tree replacement.
      (1)   Removal of each protected, significant, or historic tree, except as
specified elsewhere in this chapter, requires replacement/mitigation in caliper
inches (see ANSI Z60.1 for measuring instructions). The total number of inches
removed from the site is measured as the diameter at breast height (DBH).
      (2)   In the case of developed sites:
         (a)   Tree replacement must be planted within a defined period of time
not to exceed six months from the date of permit issuance; and
         (b)   If the mitigation calculation is greater than or equal to 2.5
inches, one replacement tree of at least 2.5-inch caliper must be planted on-
site.
      (3)   In the case of new construction, replacement trees shall be
installed prior to final inspection of the project. This includes construction
of both principal and accessory structures.
      (4)   Replacement trees must:
         (a)   Be selected from
Table 156.702-1: Tree Mitigation Calculation and have an equal or higher point
value than the designated classification of the tree(s) removed;
         (b)   Be selected in accordance with §
156.585; and
         (c)   Meet the requirements in §
156.584.
      (5)   Replacement is not required for removal of invasive species.
      (6)   Replacement trees shall not conflict with any drainage or utility
features or be located within drainage or utility easements.
   (D)   Tree mitigation calculation. 
Table 156.702-1: Tree Mitigation Calculation will be used to determine the
amount of mitigation required for removal of existing trees.
      (1)   Quality rating. Many local canopy trees have been grouped by their
average quality rating found in July 2005's Southeastern U.S. Tree Species
Rating Guide. For species not listed, find the average quality rating for Zone
8 in this guide available through the Southern Chapter of ISA, and compare to
the quality rating point range in the table below.
      (2)   Health rating. Trees are great complex systems with many unique
characteristics and health concerns and, therefore, health is categorized
broadly.
         (a)   Good. 100% to 75% live crown ratio. Minimal structural defects.
         (b)   Fair. 75% to 50% live crown ratio. Minor or tolerable structural
defects that can be overcome through arborist intervention.
         (c)   Declining. Less than 50% live crown ratio. Severe structural
defects that would classify it as a hazard tree, including insufficient holding
wood.

   (E)   Detached house lots.
      (1)   On individually platted lots for/with detached house dwellings, the
following criteria shall be used to evaluate requests for the removal of
historic and significant trees:
         (a)   The tree location in relation to property boundaries,
infrastructure, existing physical features;
         (b)   The condition of the canopy, overall health, and species;
         (c)   The nature of the request, justification, and reason for
removing the tree; and
         (d)   Whether practical alternatives have been vetted to preserve the
tree.
      (2)   Removal of Category I or II historic trees or pine trees greater
than 24 inches DBH classified as ‘good’ or ‘fair’ shall be decided by the Board
of Zoning Appeals, except as provided in §
156.704.
   (F)   Residential sketch plans.
      (1)   On sketch plans for residential subdivisions requiring approval by
the Planning Commission, trees 16 inches and greater are protected.
      (2)   A minimum of 160 caliper inches of protected trees per developable
acre shall be retained on the site. On sketch plans where the undeveloped
property has less than this amount of inches existing, caliper inches from
planted canopy trees may be used to meet this requirement. Further, each newly
platted lot shall have at least one 2.5-inch canopy tree retained or planted
on-site, preferably in the front yard.
      (3)   Developable acreage does not include wetlands, retention ponds, or
rights-of-way.
      (4)   Removal of historic trees requires replacement, as described
herein, in excess of 160 caliper-inch minimum.
      (5)   In general, lots and infrastructure should not be sited so as to
require the removal of protected trees 16 inches or greater, whenever possible.
However, the Planning Commission may authorize the removal of these protected
trees for that purpose at the time of sketch plan approval, when their
retention becomes inordinately burdensome in developing the property in a
reasonable fashion. The approval for removal shall be judiciously exercised in
consideration of the stated intent of this subchapter, and with due
consideration of the size, quality, and health rating of individual trees as
provided herein. In such cases when the Planning Commission approves removal,
the following standards apply:
         (a)   In the development of a residential subdivision, replacement
trees may be located as follows:
            1.   On homeowners’ association property, if reviewed and approved
by the Zoning Administrator. Trees between 2.5 and 16 inches DBH retained on
the homeowners' association property can count toward required replacement
inches, if surveyed and protected by a recorded covenant agreement; and/or
            2.   Within the public street right-of-way in accordance with an
approved design plan, as provided in §
155.048(F)(21).
         (b)   Replacement trees shall not conflict with any drainage or
utility features or be located within drainage or utility easements.
         (c)   Mitigation trees shall be selected from
Table 156.702-1: Tree Mitigation Calculation. Replacement species shall be
equal to or of higher point value than the designated classification of the
tree(s) removed.
         (d)   Prior to final plat approval, mitigation must be accomplished as
described above or by providing a cash bond for 200% of the tree replacement
cost in accordance with an approved mitigation plan. The cash bond will have a
maximum lifespan of two years from the date of issue; afterwards, the town may
plant the trees or forfeit the cash bond money into the Tree Bank Fund.
   (G)   Townhouse, triplex, quadplex, and multiplex developments. For
townhouse, triplex, quadplex, and multiplex developments, the following
standards apply:
      (1)   Removal of protected and significant tree(s) may be approved by the
Zoning Administrator, if replacement trees are selected from the canopy tree
list in §
156.585.
      (2)   Removal of Category I or II historic trees or pine trees greater
than 24 inches DBH classified as ‘good’ or ‘fair’ shall be decided by the Board
of Zoning Appeals, except as provided in §
156.704.
      (3)   A minimum of 160 caliper inches per acre shall be retained on the
site. On parcels with less than this amount, caliper inches from planted canopy
trees may be used to meet this requirement.
      (4)   Removal of historic trees requires replacement, as described
herein, in excess of the 160 caliper-inch minimum.
   (H)   Properties subject to design review. For properties subject to the
design review procedure (see
Subchapter I, Part 12), the removal of protected, significant, and historic
trees is at the discretion of the designated reviewing authority, exercised
through the site plan approval process.
      (1)   However, the project site design shall endeavor to retain
protected, significant, and historic trees whenever possible, consistent with
the design principles in
Subchapter H and effective utilization of the project site.
      (2)   The removal of protected, significant, and historic trees is not
intended to provide maximum utilization of the site area, but rather reasonable
use of the site based upon the factors stated above.
      (3)   In reviewing requests for removal of protected, significant, and
historic trees, the designated reviewing authority shall consider tree species,
size, and condition, and may require an independent assessment from an ISA
certified arborist to assist in the final determination.
      (4)   In cases where the removal of an historic tree is proposed, the
developer of the property shall be able to demonstrate that efforts to preserve
the tree(s) were made through site planning and that removal of the tree is
necessary to create the best, most cohesive site plan. This information may be
used by the DRB in making any decisions regarding the proposed removal of
historic tree(s).
      (5)   A minimum of 160 caliper inches per acre shall be retained on the
site. On parcels with less than this amount, caliper inches from planted canopy
trees may be used to meet this requirement.
      (6)   Removal of historic trees requires replacement, as described
herein, in excess of 160-caliper-inch minimum.
   (I)   All other land uses. For other land uses not subject to the design
review process, removal of protected, significant, and historic trees is
allowed with approval of the Zoning Administrator, if replacement trees are
selected from the canopy tree list in §
156.585.
      (1)   However, the project site design shall endeavor to retain
protected, significant, and historic trees whenever possible, consistent with
this subchapter’s stated tree protection principles and effective utilization
of the project site.
      (2)   The removal of protected, significant, and historic trees is not
intended to provide maximum utilization of the site area, but rather reasonable
use of the site based upon the factors stated above.
      (3)   In reviewing requests for removal of protected, significant, and
historic trees, the reviewing authority shall consider tree species, size, and
condition, and may require an independent assessment from an ISA certified
arborist to assist in the final determination.
      (4)   In cases where the removal of an historic tree is proposed, the
developer of the property shall be able to demonstrate that efforts to preserve
the tree(s) were made through site planning, and that removal of the tree is
necessary to create the best, most cohesive site plan. This information may be
used by the reviewing authority in making any decisions regarding the proposed
removal of historic tree(s).
      (5)   A minimum of 160 caliper inches per acre shall be retained on the
site. On parcels with less than this amount, caliper inches from planted canopy
trees may be used to meet this requirement.
      (6)   Removal of historic trees shall require replacement, as described
herein, in excess of 160-caliper-inch minimum.
   (J)   Submittal requirements for clearing and grading permit. Table 156.702-
2: Submittal Requirements outlines submittal requirements for obtaining a
clearing and grading permit.

   (K)   Replacement for trees removed without permission.
      (1)   Replacement for trees protected by this subchapter that are removed
without permission shall be calculated by twice the number of inches removed.
      (2)   If the DBH inches of the removed tree cannot be determined,
replacement shall be based on the stump diameter. Where there is no stump to
calculate the diameter of the illegally removed tree, replacement shall be
calculated based on the tree having been 24 inches.
   (L)   Replanting schedule standards. To avoid a monoculture among plantings
and to encourage a diversity, at least 50% of the total quantity of replacement
trees shall be native species. The required planting diversity is based on the
number of replacement trees required.
      (1)   Five to ten trees. Minimum two types of trees to be planted;
      (2)   Ten to 20 trees. Minimum four types of trees to be planted;
      (3)   Twenty to 100 trees. Minimum seven types of trees to be planted;
      (4)   Greater than 100 trees. Minimum ten types of trees to be planted.
   (M)   Fee in lieu of replacement trees.
      (1)   In cases where any or all replacement trees cannot be adequately
accommodated on a site, the developer/owner may have the option of paying a fee
in lieu of replacement trees to the town. This fee shall be two times the
wholesale value per 2.5-inch caliper tree required for mitigation that is not
being planted on site.
      (2)   This money shall be put into the Tree Bank Fund to be used solely
for the planting and/or maintaining of trees for the public good, including the
placement of utility lines underground.
      (3)   The Zoning Administrator shall decide whether to accept the fee or
require the on-site placement of the trees.
   (N)   Relocation of a protected tree. Relocation is accomplished by moving
the protected tree elsewhere on the land to be developed pursuant to the same
development order and under the same ownership. The relocation of a protected
tree shall be coordinated with staff and require Zoning Administrator approval
of a detailed maintenance plan, as appropriate based upon size of relocated
tree.
   (O)   Inspection of protected, relocated, or replaced trees.
      (1)   All relocated or replaced trees shall be inspected by the Zoning
Administrator one year after their planting to ensure they are surviving in a
healthy condition.
      (2)   Trees planted pursuant to this subchapter that are found to be in
declining condition shall be replaced by the owner of the parcel within 30 days
of notification from the Zoning Administrator.
      (3)   If replacement is necessary, there shall be a re-inspection six
months after the replacement planting.
   (P)   Maintenance of protected, relocated, or replaced trees. The owner of
the parcel is responsible for the maintenance of all protected, relocated, or
replaced trees.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.703 EXEMPTIONS.
   (A)   Commercial timber operations.
      (1)   Commercial timber operations are exempt from this subchapter where
management records of timber, in form and content satisfactory to the Zoning
Administrator, can be provided. This does not apply to clearing of unmanaged
natural woods.
      (2)   The town encourages and may enforce for the benefit of the public
health, safety, or welfare, the retention of a 50-foot buffer of existing trees
adjacent to all public rights-of-way on commercial timber operation property.
   (B)   Wetlands mitigation. The mitigation of wetlands pursuant to a permit
or approved plan from, and the requirements of, the South Carolina Department
of Environmental Services Bureau of Water or the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers
are exempt from this subchapter.
   (C)   Commercial tree operations. Trees grown specifically for sale by
commercial nurseries, while on the nursery site, are exempt from this
subchapter.
   (D)   Class IV trees. Trees categorized as Class IV in
Table 156.702-1: Tree Mitigation Calculation are exempt; however, pine trees
greater than 24 inches DBH shall be considered historic trees outside of a
protected buffer.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.704 EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   Tree conditions.
      (1)   In the event that any tree is determined to be severely damaged, of
inferior quality, or in a hazardous condition or location posing a danger to
private property, written authorization may be given by the Zoning
Administrator for tree removal with replacement as specified in this
subchapter. To assist in making the above-mentioned determination, the Zoning
Administrator may require a written assessment by an ISA certified arborist,
ISA TRAQ certified arborist, or registered engineer (in situations involving
actual or potential structural damage), as applicable, describing the condition
of the tree and/or other relevant factors in justification of removal.
      (2)   Should the Zoning Administrator disagree with the written
assessment, they may solicit a second opinion from an ISA certified arborist,
ISA TRAQ certified arborist, or registered engineer (in situations involving
actual or potential structural damage). The administrative decision of the
Zoning Administrator is final, subject to appeal to the Board of Zoning Appeals
in accordance with
Subchapter I, Part 17.
   (B)   Emergencies. During the period of an emergency, such as a tornado,
hurricane, ice storm, flood, or any other act of nature, Town Council or its
assignee may waive the requirements of this subchapter. In such case, the
cutting and removal of fallen and severely damaged trees is permitted until
such time as Town Council deems it necessary.
   (C)   Utility, public service, and transportation projects provided for the
public good, such as water, sewer, stormwater, roadways, multi-purpose trails,
and power installations.
      (1)   Historic trees. In all instances, attempts should be made to
preserve good quality historic trees. If their removal for public projects is
unavoidable due to the requirements of the particular project, historic trees
may be removed in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter.
      (2)   Transportation projects. Tree removal or relocation for
transportation projects, including the removal or relocation of infrastructure
resulting from said transportation projects, sponsored by the town, Charleston
County, or the South Carolina Department of Transportation in contravention to
the provisions of this subchapter is allowed, if the trees proposed for removal
are identified on plans approved by Town Council and the tree removal is
necessary to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public. Replacement
is required in accordance with this subchapter.
      (3)   Aerial power line/buffer impacts; danger trees.
         (a)   Where protected trees located in a required natural buffer or
planted landscaped buffer or otherwise are mutually considered danger trees by
the power provider and the Zoning Administrator, their removal request shall be
submitted in plan form and may be granted with replacement being required, in
accordance with this subchapter, to be planted on the site of the requested
tree removal.
         (b)   Where buffer configuration, aerial power line conditions, or
other circumstances or conditions do not permit canopy tree replacement,
mitigation may be achieved with one of the following methods:
            1.   The largest size tree or tall shrubs may be permitted, with
replacement calculations based upon nursery standards;
            2.   An equivalent donation made to the Tree Bank Fund, as
determined by Town Council; or
            3.   As may be approved in accordance with division (C)(5) below.
         (c)   Where power line maintenance operations cause violation of this
subchapter by means such as excessive pruning, based upon pruning standards
referenced in §
156.706, the tree may be considered damaged and require removal and
replacement. Damage to buffer vegetation as a part of any maintenance activity
requires replacement in-kind.
      (4)   Public projects, maintenance, repair, and installation by the Town
of Mount Pleasant and Mount Pleasant Waterworks.
         (a)   Tree removal for approved projects including town public
infrastructure projects and Mount Pleasant Waterworks projects, including
protected trees located in a required natural buffer or planted landscaped
buffer, is allowed in contravention of the provisions of this subchapter, if:
            1.   The proposed trees to be removed are identified on project
plans approved by the respective governing bodies; and
            2.   A finding is made by the applicable governing body that the
tree removal is necessary to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the
public.
         (b)   Replacement is required in accordance with this subchapter.
Where buffer configuration or other conditions or circumstances do not permit
canopy tree replacement, mitigation may be achieved with one of the following
methods:
            1.   The largest size tree or tall shrubs may be permitted, with
replacement calculations based upon nursery standards;
            2.   An equivalent donation made to the Tree Bank Fund, as
determined by Town Council; or
            3.   As may be approved in accordance with division (C)(5) below.
         (c)   Tree removal, canopy pruning, and root pruning of trees within
boundaries of existing Town or Mount Pleasant Waterworks infrastructure,
easements, and rights-of-way is permitted with approval of the Zoning
Administrator, upon receipt of a written request from the Town Director of
Public Services, the Town Director of Engineering and Development Services, or
the General Manager of Mount Pleasant Waterworks, if the tree is causing damage
or interference with operation, maintenance, or rehabilitation of Town or Mount
Pleasant Waterworks infrastructure or facilities, and where no other corrective
options are determined feasible to protect or access the infrastructure or
facilities. The Zoning Administrator may approve removal and/or pruning with
replacement required in accordance with this subchapter.
      (5)   Tree replacement not otherwise specified under this division.
         (a)   Utility infrastructure providers, including the town and Mount
Pleasant Waterworks, may be entitled to a reduction or alteration of mitigation
requirements by the Town Administrator should the following conditions be met:
            1.   A request is made to the Town Administrator in a manner and
format acceptable to the Town Administrator;
            2.   The request is made by a public or private utility company,
the town, or Mount Pleasant Waterworks;
            3.   Tree removal is necessary for the installation or protection
of utilities; and
            4.   Mitigation is required.
         (b)   The Town Administrator may, at their discretion, elect to reduce
or alter mitigation requirements if the alteration or reduction is in the best
interests of the public. Reduction or alteration of mitigation requirements
shall be based on the value and nature of resources donated to the town by the
utility company. Examples of donated resources include, but are not limited to,
parks, trails, easements, or storage space. The amount or degree of any
reductions or alterations are within the discretion of the Town Administrator.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.705 TREE PROTECTION ZONES (TPZ).
   (A)   Minimum tree protection zone.
      (1)   During the development approval process, a tree protection zone
shall be established around all trees to be saved in accordance with this
subchapter and erected prior to the start of construction.
      (2)   The tree protection zone shall consist of a circular area centered
around the tree, the radius of which is equal to one foot for each inch of DBH
measurement (except as may be modified by division (B) below).
      (3)   The area within the tree protection zone shall remain free of all
building materials, dirt, or other construction materials, debris, vehicles,
and development activities, except as allowed by division (C) below.
      (4)   Impervious surface materials, building foundations, and other
subgrade building elements are prohibited within the tree protection zone.
      (5)   The tree protection zone shall be shown on all site plans,
construction plans, sketch plans, preliminary plats, final plats, and
subsequent recorded plats.
      (6)   Such depiction shall also include an explanation in the appropriate
"note" section of the documents of the treatments.
   (B)   Modifications to tree protection zones. In situations where strict
adherence to the tree protection zone, as defined above, is impossible or
unrealistic (due to site conditions, other town requirements, overlapping tree
protection zones, size or shape of a tree, and the like), the PLAN Department,
through field determination and consultation, may allow or require
modifications to this zone with potential conditions. Particular consideration
should be given to the installation of utilities.
   (C)   Development activities. Development activities within the tree
protection zone shall be in accordance with the following procedures:
      (1)   Grade changes.
         (a)   Moderate fill may be allowed, upon prior approval of the PLAN
Department and with the prior installation of an aeration system.
         (b)   A decrease in grade is prohibited.
         (c)   The grade outside the tree protection zone shall be decreased
only with the use of approved retaining walls or terracing plans. See Figure
156.705-1: Grade Changes.
         (d)   Drainage shall be addressed where grade changes occur around
trees.
Figure 156.705-1: Grade Changes
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13020.png]
 
      (2)   Utility installation.
         (a)   The installation of utilities, by boring and tunneling through
the tree protection zone, may be allowed with prior approval. See Figure
156.705-2: Utility Installation.
         (b)   Trenching is prohibited within the tree protection zone.
Figure 156.705-2: Utility Installation
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13022.png]
 
   (D)   Protective barricades.
      (1)   Protective barricades shall be placed at the perimeter of the tree
protection zone (see
Figure 156.705-3: Protective Barricade) and shall remain in place until
construction activities are complete.
      (2)   Chain link barricades are required in all instances for trees 24
inches and greater (see
Figure 156.705-4: Chain Link Protective Barricade).
      (3)   All tree protection must be accompanied by “Keep Out” or “Tree
Protection Area” signs.
Figure 156.705-3: Protective Barricade
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13024.png]
Figure 156.705-4: Chain Link Protective Barricade
   (E)   Passive tree protection for remote areas. Areas remote from active
land disturbance shall utilize passive forms of tree protection during
development activities.
      (1)   These areas must be completely surrounded with continuous rope or
flagging (heavy mill, minimum two inches wide). See
Figure 156.705-5: Passive Tree Protection.
      (2)   All passive tree protection must be accompanied by "Keep Out" or
"Tree Protection Area" signs.
Figure 156.705-5: Passive Tree Protection
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13026.png]
 
   (F)   Clearing within tree protection zone. Clearing within the tree
protection zone is allowed, if it is done by hand tools or gas-powered, push-
type or walk-behind equipment designed for brush or undergrowth clearing.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.706 REMEDIAL PROCEDURES.
   (A)   Conditions that require remedial procedures.
      (1)   Remedial site reclamation and tree care procedures shall be
implemented when development activities have caused damage to either the tree
or the tree's growing site and that damage is repairable.
      (2)   If encroachment into tree protection zones is anticipated or has
happened, the following practices shall be employed to improve survivability.
   (B)   Canopy pruning.
      (1)   A tree that has suffered root damage becomes stressed as that root
system no longer provides sufficient water and nutrients for the existing
crown.
         (a)   This stress becomes evident with the appearance of "staghorns"
or deadwood within the tree's crown.
         (b)   Once a tree has had construction damage, it is advisable to
delay pruning for one to three years until the deadwood becomes evident.
Pruning for deadwood removal is then recommended.
      (2)   The removal of live plant tissue from a construction-damaged tree
can accelerate the tree's decline.
      (3)   Trees that have not been affected by construction activities can be
pruned for maintenance of the tree's health, appearance, and safety, utilizing
accepted arboricultural practices.
      (4)   Pruning specifications as provided in the latest version of ANSI
A300 shall be used in all pruning cases.
      (5)   The pruning of specimen trees may be subject to PLAN Department
approval.
      (6)   All cabling work and other structural support supplemental systems
shall be installed in accordance with the latest edition of ANSI A300 American
National Standard for Tree Care Operations - Trees, Brush, and Other Woody
Plant Maintenance - Standard Practices on Support Systems and Cabling.
      (7)   Any lightning rod protection shall be installed in accordance with
ANSI A300 American National Standard for Tree Care Operations - Trees, Brush
and Other Woody Plant Maintenance - Standard Practices on Lightning Protection.
   (C)   Root pruning. All roots outside of the protective barricade to be
removed during the development shall be cleanly severed and a two-inch layer of
mulch shall be applied over the surface of exposed roots during development.
   (D)   Fertilization.
      (1)   Fertilizer applications will enhance the vigor of trees stressed by
site disturbances, thereby promoting root development.
      (2)   Information regarding appropriate fertilizers and application rates
may be obtained in the latest edition of ANSI A300 American National Standard
for Tree Care Operations - Trees, Brush and Other Woody Plant Maintenance -
Standard Practices on Fertilization.
   (E)   Soil aeration.
      (1)   A tree's ability for adequate root development, and ultimately its
chances for survival, are improved with reclamation of the growing site.
      (2)   Wherever possible, the soil should be brought back to its natural
grade.
         (a)   Unnecessary fill, compaction, erosion sedimentation, concrete
washout, and construction debris should be removed.
         (b)   When machinery is required for site improvement, it is
recommended that a "Bobcat" or similar lightweight, rubber-tired vehicle be
used so as to minimize soil compaction.
      (3)   Compacted soil within the tree protection zone should be aerated
(see Figure 156.705-6: Soil Aeration).
         (a)   A compressed air gun is used to cut narrow trenches in a spoke
pattern away from the trunk, to a depth of eight to 12 inches or greater if the
soil grade has been raised.
         (b)   Trenches should begin four to six feet from the trunk to avoid
cutting any major support roots and should extend to the dripline.
         (c)   Trenches are then backfilled with topsoil or compost. The air
exchange, nutrient, and water-holding capacities of soils can be improved with
soil amendments. This is best accomplished by backfilling with mineral
amendments such as perlite, vermiculite, isolite, and the like.
Figure 156.705-6: Soil Aeration
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13028.png]
 
   (F)   Mulching. A four- to six-inch layer of mulch material, such as pine
straw, pine bark, or wood chips, spread within the tree protection zone of
trees on construction sites is extremely beneficial.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.707 IRREPARABLE DAMAGE IN TREE PROTECTION ZONES.
   Where the Planning, Land Use, and Neighborhoods (PLAN) Department determines
that irreparable damage has occurred to trees within the tree protection zones,
the trees must be removed and replaced in accordance with the requirements of §
156.702(K).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.708 PUBLIC TREES.
   (A)   Public trees within the town are considered to be a valuable public
resource. In order to appropriately care for and maintain these public
resources, the town shall create inventories and develop work plans as
described in this section.
   (B)   Maintain a current inventory of all public trees. The inventory data
gathered and recorded for each tree shall include, at a minimum, the following
informati on:
      (1)    Location (address or latitude/l ongitude coordinat es);
      (2)   Tree species;
      (3)   DBH;
      (4)   Condition; and
      (5)   Maintenance needs.
   (C)   Develop an annual work plan for the management of public trees
utilizing the tree inventory information. The work plan shall contain the
following plans and schedules:
      (1)   Tree planting;
      (2)   New tree maintenance, including mulching, irrigation, and young
tree training pruning;
      (3)   Tree pruning;
      (4)   Tree mulching; and
      (5)   Tree removal.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.709 NOTICE OF VIOLATION AND PENALTY.
   (A)   If the Zoning Administrator finds that any of the provisions of this
subchapter are being violated, they may issue a stop work order and shall, in
writing, notify the owner of the property and the general building contractor,
if applicable. In order to enforce this subchapter, town staff have the
authority to access private property to investigate and make determinations of
fact related to this section.
      (1)   Written notification shall indicate the nature of the violation and
the action necessary to correct the violation.
      (2)   Such remedial action shall be in accordance with §§
156.700 through
156.707.
   (B)   The issuance of a clearing and grading permit, tree removal permit, or
letter authorizing tree removal, and the failure to substantially erect
building improvements within 12 months that has resulted in tree removal
without replacement shall be deemed violations of this subchapter. Each tree
removed shall be identified as a separate offense.
   (C)   Notwithstanding the penalties designated above, violation of §§
156.700 through
156.707, or failure to comply with any of the requirements hereof, shall be
classified as a misdemeanor punishable by a maximum $500 fine and/or a maximum
of 30 days imprisonment, and/or shall be subject to a civil penalty that shall
not exceed $1,000 not including attorney’s fees and costs to collect and
enforce the civil penalty including, but not limited to, any proceedings to
create a lien on any property owned by the owner of the property for any unpaid
civil penalties.
      (1)   However, no penalty shall exceed the penalty provided by state law
for similar offenses.
      (2)   Each tree removed or destroyed in violation of this subchapter
represents a separate offense.
      (3)   Each day of violation also represents a separate offense.
      (4)   Any person, firm, organization, society, association, or
corporation, or any agent or representative thereof, who commits, participates,
or assists in such violation may each be found guilty of a separate offense and
be subject to the penalties in this section.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.710 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BOUNDARY TREE. A tree located on a property line and, therefore, jointly
owned.
   CALIPER. The diameter of the trunk of a proposed, purchased, or newly-
planted tree, measured six inches above the ground for trees up to four inches
and 12 inches above the ground for trees larger than four inches.
   CANOPY TREE. A woody perennial typically capable of achieving heights
exceeding 30 feet at maturity.
   CONIFER. A tree that produces cones. Typically an evergreen species,
although some deciduous species exist.
   DAMAGE or ABUSE (to vegetation). Any intentional or negligent act that
endangers survivability of a tree or other plant material including, but not
limited to, damage inflicted upon the root system of a tree by application of
toxic substances, the operation of machinery, the change of natural grade by
excavation or filling above the root system or around the trunk of a tree,
pruning, damages from injury or fire inflicted on trees that result in or
permit pest infestation, or actual cutting of the tree.
   DANGER TREE. A live, dead, or structurally compromised tree that could
endanger or interfere with an existing aerial power line. This is linked to
federal regulations pertaining to transmission power lines, generally equal to
or exceeding 100 kV.
   DIAMETER BREAST HEIGHT (DBH). The diameter of a tree, measured at breast
height (4.5 feet) above the ground. If a tree trunk splits at ground level and
does not share a common base, each trunk shall be measured as a separate tree.
If a multi-trunk tree splits below the 4.5-foot mark, all trunks six inches or
larger in diameter at 4.5 feet shall be measured separately and count as one
tree.
   DRIP LINE. An imaginary vertical line that extends downward from the
outermost branches of a tree to the ground.
   EVERGREEN. A plant that keeps its leaves or needles year round for more than
one growing season.
   HAZARD TREE. A tree identified as a likely source of harm.
   HISTORIC TREE. Any tree with diameter breast height (DBH) of 24 inches or
larger, with the following exceptions:
      (1)   Exempt trees, including invasive species, as provided herein; and
      (2)   For the purpose only of requiring a variance for removal of
historic trees or historic tree replacement requirements, non-exempt tree
species (with the exception of live oak trees) containing three or more
separate trunks are considered a significant tree, subject to the applicable
removal and replacement requirements of significant trees. Live oak tree
species with a DBH of 24 inches or larger are considered HISTORIC TREES under
all circumstances.
   INVASIVE EXOTIC. A non-native plant that regularly reproduces in our area
and outcompetes native species. These species are not protected by this
chapter. Includes the term INVASIVE SPECIES.
   ISA CERTIFIED ARBORIST. A professional, certified by the International
Society of Arboriculture, who possesses the technical competence gained through
experience and related training to provide for or supervise the management of
trees and other woody plants in residential, commercial, and public landscapes.
   ISA TRAQ CERTIFIED ARBORIST. A certified arborist who has completed the
International Society of Arboriculture Tree Risk Assessment Qualification
program. This qualification promotes the safety of people and property by
providing a standardized and systematic process for assessing tree risk.
   MITIGATION PLAN. A plan describing the intended mitigation for tree removal.
This can include a planting plan, payment based upon mitigation inches
required, or a combination of the two.
   MITIGATION TREE. See PROTECTED TREE.
   PROTECTED TREE. Any tree with a diameter breast height (DBH) of eight inches
or greater, and any smaller trees protected through special zones or buffers or
as a condition of approval by any of the town’s boards or commissions. This
term also includes trees planted as mitigation.
   PROTECTIVE BARRICADE. A physical structure at least four feet in height,
composed of wood, chain link fencing, or other durable material, limiting
access to protected, significant, and historic trees and their tree protection
zones (TPZ) during the development process, as more fully defined in §
156.705.
   PUBLIC TREE. A tree that grows on town-owned property within the street
right-of-way, parks, public facilities, or other town-owned properties.
   REPLACEMENT TREE. Any tree that is planted in order to replace an existing
tree that has been or will be removed. Replacement trees must be canopy
species, have a minimum size of 2.5 inches in caliper, and meet ANSI Standard
Z60.1. REPLACEMENT TREE includes the terms MITIGATION TREE and REPLACED TREE.
   SHRUB. Typically a woody perennial that does not achieve tree proportions at
maturity. Where referenced for requirements, some herbaceous species such as
ornamental grasses may be counted to fulfill this requirement where they
provide a similar screening purpose.
   SIGNIFICANT TREE. Any tree with a diameter breast height (DBH) of 16 inches
or larger.
   TREE. Any living, self-supporting, woody perennial plant, usually having one
dominant trunk and a mature height greater than 16 feet.
   TREE ASSESSMENT. Information on a site plan that confirms tree species from
the survey critical to the application of this subchapter, grades the
conditions of trees to aid in retaining quality trees, identifies invasive
exotic species on site for removal, confirms the tree survey is complete,
identifies any unique features of trees such as leans or lower canopy heights,
identifies trees just off site that may require design considerations, and
ultimately makes the designer more aware of the site and its character. This
analysis shall be performed by either an ISA certified arborist or a registered
South Carolina landscape architect and submitted with all development
submittals.
   TREE BANK FUND. A special account to be used solely for the beautification
of public lands.
   TREE REMOVAL PERMIT. A permit issued by the town, after review of a
requested tree removal, that defines required mitigation and confers approval
to remove the specified tree.
   TREE REPLACEMENT SCHEDULE. A plan showing the location, species, and size of
all replacement trees; and a table listing removed protected, significant, and
historic trees with total replacement caliper inches required.
   TREE RISK ASSESSMENT. A systematic process used to identify, analyze, and
evaluate tree risk. Performed by an ISA TRAQ certified arborist.
   TREE SURVEY. A survey completed by a registered land surveyor showing the
location, size, and species of all protected trees, including their tree
protection zone. These are required to be no more than one year old for any
formal submittals.
   UNDERSTORY TREE. A woody perennial with a smaller size at maturity than
canopy species, typically with a size between 16 feet and 30 feet at maturity.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.711 THROUGH 156.729 RESERVED.
SUBCHAPTER F: PARKING AND LOADING
PART 1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 156.730 PURPOSE.
   This subchapter sets minimum standards for off-street parking requirements
for new construction and expansion of or changes to existing uses and
structures to:
   (A)   Ensure uses have a minimum level of off-street parking to avoid
congestion on surrounding streets without creating excessive parking; and
   (B)   Provide flexibility to accommodate alternative parking solutions.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.731 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   This subchapter applies:
      (1)   At the time of initial construction of any principal building;
      (2)   At the time of establishment of a principal use, whether a new use
on a previously undeveloped lot or a change in use of a developed lot;
      (3)   Any time a structural alteration or other addition to a principal
building produces an increase in parking demand;
      (4)   Any time the useable seating area of a restaurant or brewpub is
increased; and
      (5)   Any time a use is enlarged to occupy additional floor area or is
altered in another manner that produces an increase in parking demand.
   (B)   Required off-street parking provided for one use shall not be included
as part or all of the required off-street parking for another use, unless
authorized through a shared parking plan (see §
156.774).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.732 LOCATION OF REQUIRED PARKING SPACES.
   (A)   Unless otherwise approved through an alternative parking plan (see
Part 4), all required off-street parking spaces shall:
      (1)   Be located on the same lot with the principal building or use or
uses served;
      (2)   Have direct access to a street or alley; and
      (3)   Be developed and maintained in accordance with
Subchapter F, Part 3 and with
Subchapter H, Part 3, if applicable.
   (B)   On-street parking may be allowed as provided in §
156.773.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.733 THROUGH 156.739 RESERVED.
PART 2: PARKING RATIOS
§ 156.740 MINIMUM OFF-STREET PARKING RATIOS.
   (A)   Minimum number of off-street parking spaces required. §
156.741 establishes the minimum number of off-street parking spaces required
for the land uses listed in
Subchapter C, Part 3, Subpart 3.2.
   (B)   Fractional computations. If the final calculation of the minimum
required number of off-street parking spaces includes a fractional space, the
number of required parking spaces is rounded up to the next highest whole
number regardless of the fraction.
   (C)   Requirements for uses not specifically listed. When the parking space
requirements for a particular use are not listed in §
156.741, the applicant shall submit a parking demand study that complies with §
156.775 to establish the number of parking spaces required.
   (D)   Parking demand studies. When an applicant believes the minimum number
of required parking spaces specified in §
156.741 exceeds the number needed for the proposed use, the applicant may
submit a parking demand study that complies with §
156.775 to establish the number of parking spaces required.
   (E)   Parking spaces for alternative fuel vehicles. Parking spaces for
alternative fuel vehicles, including spaces with electric vehicle charging
stations, count towards the required number of parking spaces for a use, unless
the space is exclusively available for alternative fuel vehicles (through the
use of a sign or other marking).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.741 OFF-STREET PARKING TABLE.
   (A)   The minimum number of required parking spaces shall be calculated on
the basis of the use of the land or principal structure on a lot, according to
the requirements indicated in
Table 156.741-1: Off-Street Parking Table, unless otherwise specified in this
chapter.
   (B)   In the OP-1, OP-2, NC-1, NC-2, AB-1, AB-2, ED, LI, and WG-C zoning
districts, all parking spaces provided above the minimum amount required,
except spaces for alternative fuel vehicles, shall be surfaced with pervious
materials approved by the Zoning Administrator in consultation with the Town
Engineer. The applicant shall provide manufacturer specifications and
construction details for the proposed materials.

§ 156.742 BICYCLE PARKING.
   (A)   Applicability. Bicycle parking and storage is required for multiplex
dwellings, apartment complexes, and commercial developments at the time of the
initial construction of any principal building or when a structural alteration
or other addition to a principal building produces an increase in parking
demand.
   (B)   Minimum number of spaces required.
      (1)   Multiplex dwellings and apartment complexes. Multiplex dwellings
and apartment complexes that contain more than ten dwelling units shall provide
enough secure bicycle parking to accommodate 10% of the units at one space per
unit.
      (2)   Commercial developments. Commercial developments and redevelopments
of 6,000 square feet or more shall provide secure bicycle parking in accordance
with Table 156.742-1: Bicycle Parking for Commercial Developments.
 
Table 156.742-1: Bicycle Parking for Commercial Developments
   Key: min. = minimum required | sf = square feet
Gross Floor Area   Required Number of Bicycle Parking Spaces (min.)
0 to 6,000 sf      1
6,001 to 10,000 sf 2
Over 10,000 sf     1 per each additional 10,000 sf
 
   (C)   Vehicular parking reduction for commercial developments.
      (1)   The required number of off-street vehicular parking spaces for a
commercial development may be reduced by up to 10% if the development provides
indoor bicycle accommodations, in addition to the required number of bicycle
parking spaces.
      (2)   Examples of accommodations include enclosed bicycle lockers,
personal lockers, employee shower facilities, and dressing areas. Examples of
indoor bicycle accommodations are shown in Figure 156.742-1.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13030.png]
 
   (D)   Design and location.
      (1)   The design and location of all bicycle parking is subject to
approval through the design review process.
      (2)   Required bicycle parking shall:
         (a)   Consist of racks or lockers of theft-resistant construction,
which shall be anchored so they cannot be easily removed;
         (b)   Allow both the bicycle frame and the wheels to be locked using a
standard U-lock;
         (c)   Be designed so as not to cause damage to the bicycle;
         (d)   Facilitate easy locking without interference from or to adjacent
bicycles;
         (e)   Be located in convenient, visible, well-lighted areas that are
close to entrances and do not interfere with pedestrian movements;
         (f)   Where provided for residential developments, be protected from
the elements (see Figure 156.742-2: Examples of Protected Bicycle Parking for
Residential Developments); and
         (g)   Where located in commercial parking lots, utilize a paving
material or surface different from the adjacent parking areas and shall include
some means of protection of bicyclists and the bicycle facility from vehicular
conflicts.
      (3)   Figure 156.742-3 provides examples of outdoor bicycle parking for
commercial developments.
