§§ 156.743 THROUGH 156.754 RESERVED.
PART 3: OFF-STREET PARKING SPACE AND LOT DESIGN
§ 156.755 APPLICABILITY.
   This part applies to all uses subject to this subchapter except where
otherwise indicated.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.756 GENERAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Tandem parking. Tandem parking is prohibited, unless specifically
allowed elsewhere in this chapter.
   (B)   Stop signs. Stop signs shall be provided at the transition from a
surface parking area to the public right-of-way.
   (C)   Wheel stops. Wheel stops shall be provided wherever an angled parking
space abuts a curb or sidewalk.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.757 SURFACING.
   (A)   All parking spaces shall be surfaced with a suitable paving material
such as asphalt, concrete, specialty pavers, or pea gravel (but not other types
of gravel or similar material), except as provided in §
156.741(B) and division (B) below.
   (B)   Parking spaces located in the SCW-W, SCW-H, SCW-N Districts and
parking spaces serving detached house dwellings, duplex dwellings, and any
other use that requires or provides six or fewer parking spaces may be surfaced
with other suitable paving material approved by the Zoning Administrator in
consultation with the Town Engineer. The applicant shall provide manufacturer
specifications and construction details for the proposed materials.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.758 PARKING SPACE AND TRAVEL AISLE DIMENSIONS.
   (A)   Parking spaces oriented 90 degrees to the travel aisle shall be at
least nine feet in width and 18 feet in length. However, where parking spaces
abut landscaped areas not required by this chapter, the paved length of the
parking stall may be reduced to 17 feet if curbing or anchored concrete wheel
stops are furnished at the edge of paving to allow the vehicle to overhang the
landscape area.
   (B)   Angled parking spaces positioned at other than 90 degrees to the
travel aisle, parallel parking spaces, and one-way travel aisles shall be
dimensioned in accordance with recognized standard criteria, such as time-saver
standards.
   (C)   The minimum dimensions for a parking space exclude aisles, maneuvering
space, turnaround space, and drives.
   (D)   All two-way travel aisles shall be a minimum of 24 feet in width.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.759 DRIVE-THROUGHS.
   For businesses with drive-through access, parking spaces and travel aisles
shall be arranged in a manner that provides sufficient stacking area from the
public access driveway to prevent vehicles from backing up into the adjacent
roadway.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.760 DESIGN REGULATIONS FOR COMMERCIAL, INSTITUTIONAL, AND APARTMENT
COMPLEX PARKING LOTS.
   (A)   Applicability. This section applies for commercial, institutional, and
apartment complex parking lots located in any zoning district.
   (B)   Lighting. Parking lots and vehicular use areas shall be lighted in
accordance with
Subchapter H, Part 3, Subpart 3.4.
   (C)   Screening. All parking lots and vehicular use areas shall be screened
from all abutting properties and rights-of-way by the minimum requirements of
Subchapter D, Part 2.
   (D)   Parking lot landscaping.
      (1)   Planter islands. Surface parking lots shall contain planter islands
located so as to best relieve the expanse of paving.
         (a)   The end of each parking row shall terminate in a planter island,
outlined by curb and gutter or concrete wheel stops.
            1.   A maximum of 12 parking spaces in a row is allowed without a
planter island.
            2.   However, this requirement may be modified by the Zoning
Administrator when strict application will seriously limit the function of an
area.
         (b)   Planter islands shall have a minimum area of 150 square feet.
            1.   Planter islands shall contain at least one 2.5-inch-caliper
canopy tree with a minimum clean trunk of five feet and a minimum overall
height of eight feet at the time of planting. “Minimum clean trunk” means the
tree does not have limbs or leaves between the ground and the specified height,
which helps maintain a clear line of sight for drivers and pedestrians.
            2.   The remainder shall be landscaped with understory trees,
shrubs, or ground cover.
            3.   As it presents considerable root competition for trees, the
use of lawn within an island should be limited.
            4.   Planter islands with a minimum area less than 250 square feet
shall not include light poles, fire hydrants, manholes, curb inlets/drain
boxes, transformers, and the like.
         (c)   Depth of termination area and height of landscaping shall be
determined by preserving a sight triangle within the parking area formed by a
long leg of 50 feet and a height of eye of three and one-half feet.
      (2)   Planted borders.
         (a)   Where a parking area is not located immediately adjacent to a
perimeter or right-of-way bufferyard, the parking area shall have planted
borders at least five feet in width located parallel to lot lines and rights-
of-way.
         (b)   Planted borders are intended to supplement, not replace,
required bufferyards.
         (c)   Planted border areas shall contain at least one 2.5-inch-caliper
canopy tree, with a minimum clear trunk of five feet and a minimum height of
eight feet, for each 30 linear feet of the border area. The remainder shall be
landscaped with shrubs, lawn, ground cover, or other approved materials.
         (d)   Planted border areas may be interrupted to provide:
            1.   Ingress and egress drives for the property; and
            2.   Sidewalks that are generally perpendicular to the border area
and that are used to connect the parking area to a building.
   (E)   Existing plant material.
      (1)   The natural landscape shall be preserved according to the
provisions of §
156.991.
      (2)   Wherever healthy plant material exists on a site, the standards in
division (D) above may be adjusted to allow credit for such plant material, if
the existing plant material meets the standards in this section.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.761 THROUGH 156.769 RESERVED.
PART 4: ALTERNATIVE PARKING PLANS
§ 156.770 PURPOSE.
   The minimum off-street parking ratios are intended to encourage development
that is economically viable and environmentally sensitive. The standards in
this subchapter are not intended to be so rigid as to require significantly
more parking spaces than a particular use demands, or to inhibit creative
development. Project conditions associated with individual sites may justify
the use of alternative parking plans as provided in this part.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.771 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   Alternative parking plans may be submitted in conjunction with any
application, subject to the requirements in the applicable section of this
part.
   (B)   Alternative parking plans may modify the provisions of §
156.732 or §
156.741, but shall not modify any other provisions of this subchapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.772 OFF-SITE PARKING.
   (A)   Applicability. Off-site parking may be provided for any use, subject
to the provisions in this section.
   (B)   Location.
      (1)   The off-site parking area shall be located no more than 600 feet
from the primary pedestrian entrance of the use(s) served. This distance is
measured from the nearest point of the off-site parking area to the primary
pedestrian entrance of the use served along the shortest designated pedestrian
route.
      (2)   The off-site parking spaces shall not be separated from the use(s)
served by a street right-of-way greater than 80 feet in width.
   (C)   Availability of off-site parking spaces. Off-site parking spaces used
to meet minimum parking requirements must be exclusively available to the users
of the use served by the off-site parking spaces during the duration of use.
   (D)   Off-site parking agreement required. The owner of the lot on which the
off-site parking is located must relinquish, through a covenant agreement with
the town, their development rights over the property until such time as parking
space is provided elsewhere or on the same premises as the principal use or
uses.
      (1)   An agreement ensuring the use of the off-site parking area by the
associated use shall be submitted in conjunction with the application.
      (2)   If an off-site parking agreement is revoked by the parties to the
agreement, off-street parking shall be provided in another location in
accordance with the requirements of this subchapter.
   (E)   Off-site parking in the TH District.
      (1)   In the TH District, required parking may be provided in a community
parking lot or garage, the title to which and/or easement for the use of which
runs with and/or is appurtenant to the title of townhouse.
      (2)   Any such parking lot or garage shall be located 200 feet or less
from the dwelling(s) it serves.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.773 ON-STREET PARKING.
   (A)   Applicability.
      (1)   On-street parking is allowed in Planned Development Districts, if
expressly authorized by the associated rezoning ordinance.
      (2)   On-street parking may be allowed in zoning overlay districts (see
Subchapter B).
      (3)   On-street parking may be provided in any zoning district that is
subject to Subchapter H, if approved through the design review process.
   (B)   Location.
      (1)   Public streets.
         (a)   On-street parking may be located on town-owned rights-of-way.
         (b)   On-street parking on state rights-of-way is subject to review
and approval by the South Carolina Department of Transportation.
         (c)   On-street parking is publicly available and may not be reserved
for private use.
         (d)   On-street parking may not be used for required off-street
parking.
      (2)   Private streets. On-street parking may be located on private
rights-of-way.
      (3)   Access drives. On-street parking may be located on private drives
if the drive is constructed to look like a street. Figure 156.773-1 provides
examples of drives constructed to look like a street.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13036.png]
   (C)   Design.
      (1)   On-street parking spaces. On-street parking spaces shall be:
         (a)   Oriented parallel to the travel lanes, except on private streets
and access drives where they may be parallel or angled;
         (b)   Dimensioned in accordance with recognized standard criteria,
such as time-saver standards;
         (c)   Located at least 50 feet from any street intersection, as
measured from the closest edge of the parking space to the center of the
intersection;
         (d)   Located at least 30 feet from any intersection of two access
drives or an access drive and a street, as measured from the closest edge of
the parking space to the center of the intersection; and
         (e)   Marked in accordance with the latest edition of the Manual on
Uniform Traffic Control Devices.
      (2)   Curb and gutter. Curb and gutter shall be provided.
      (3)   Curb extensions.
         (a)   Curb extensions (or “bulb-outs”) shall be provided between at
least every six on-street parking spaces.
         (b)   A curb extension shall have at least the same dimensions as the
on-street parking spaces.
         (c)   Curb extensions shall be landscaped with trees, shrubs,
groundcover, or a combination of these elements. For developments subject to
the Environmental Guidelines for Land Development (see §
155.054(B)) curb extensions on:
            1.   Private streets or access drives may accommodate low impact
development stormwater control measures; and
            2.   Public streets may accommodate low impact development
stormwater control measures, if approved by the Town Engineer.
   (D)   New on-street parking may constitute up to 50% of required parking.
      (1)   Unless otherwise specified in a PD District ordinance or zoning
overlay district regulations, newly constructed on-street parking spaces may be
used to satisfy up to 50% of the parking spaces required for any use if the on-
street parking is located within:
         (a)   250 feet of any building entrance for a residential use; and
         (b)   600 feet of the primary building entrance for a non-residential
use.
      (2)   All required accessible parking spaces shall be provided off-
street.
   (E)   On-street parking map required.
      (1)   If on-street parking spaces are used to satisfy any portion of the
minimum parking requirement, the applicant shall provide a key map allocating
the provided on-street parking to the lot or tenant utilizing the spaces.
However, on-street parking spaces for a specific use shall not be reserved
exclusively by that use, but must be available for general public use at all
times. Signs or action limiting general public use of on-street spaces is
prohibited.
      (2)   The overlapping of the same on-street parking space(s) for multiple
uses is prohibited.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.774 SHARED PARKING.
   (A)   Applicability. Shared parking may be provided for any two or more
uses, subject to the provisions in this section.
   (B)   Generally.
      (1)   Off-street parking spaces may be shared among more than one use,
whether the uses are on the same lot or on separate lots, if the total number
of off-street parking spaces is at least equal to the sum of the individual
off-street parking space requirements for each use specified in §
156.741, except as provided in division (D) below.
      (2)   Shared parking spaces must be available on an equal basis for all
users. Parking spaces shall not be designated solely for certain uses through
the use of signs or other elements, except that shared parking spaces provided
pursuant to division (D) below may be restricted to specific users during
certain hours.
   (C)   Shared parking agreement required.
      (1)   When off-street parking spaces are shared among more than one use,
a legally sufficient agreement, approved by the Town Attorney prior to
execution, ensuring the perpetual joint usage and maintenance of the shared
parking area(s) shall be recorded with the Charleston County Register of Deeds.
      (2)   The agreement must include provisions for written notice to the
Zoning Administrator prior to expiration, termination, or an amendment to the
agreement.
      (3)   An executed shared parking agreement shall be submitted to the
Zoning Administrator prior to technical review and code compliance or zoning
permit approval, as applicable, and recorded within 30 days of approval.
      (4)   If a shared parking agreement expires, terminates, or is amended in
a manner contrary to this section, off-street parking shall be provided in
another location in accordance with the requirements of this subchapter within
60 days of such action. Unless remediating steps are taken that bring the
property into compliance with parking requirements, the property may be
considered in violation of this chapter.
   (D)   Reduction in required number of off-street parking spaces.
      (1)   Where off-street parking spaces are shared among two or more uses
that have different hours of operation or peak parking demand hours, the Zoning
Administrator may allow a reduction in the total number of required parking
spaces.
      (2)   The reduction shall be based on a shared parking analysis prepared
by a professional engineer or transportation planner that clearly demonstrates
the feasibility of shared parking.
      (3)   In the shared parking analysis, the professional engineer or
transportation planner shall assess:
         (a)   Site-specific elements, including the size and type of the
proposed development and the composition of uses or tenants; and
         (b)   The anticipated rate of parking turnover and the anticipated
peak parking and traffic loads for all uses, using:
            1.   Actual parking counts for uses or combinations of uses that
are the same or comparable to the proposed use(s) in terms of density, scale,
bulk, area, type of activity, and location; and/or
            2.   Relevant data from the Institute of Transportation Engineers
(ITE), Urban Land Institute (ULI) meeting a Level of Service A or B for walking
distances from parking to entrance, or another generally accepted resource for
parking demand data; and/or
            3.   The availability of current or planned public transportation
routes, greenways, and other pedestrian and bicycle connections.
      (4)   If one or more uses change, a new shared parking analysis is
required to demonstrate whether the parking reduction continues to accommodate
the parking demand for each use. If the number of parking spaces provided no
longer accommodates the parking demand generated by each use, parking shall be
provided in accordance with this subchapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.775 PARKING DEMAND STUDIES.
   (A)   Purpose. The purpose of a parking demand study is to demonstrate the
appropriate off-street parking ratio for a proposed use, based on operational
characteristics of the particular use and relevant site-specific factors.
   (B)   Applicability.
      (1)   The applicant for any use where §
156.741 specifies that the minimum number of off-street parking spaces is
established via a parking demand study, or for any use not listed in the table,
shall submit a parking demand study in conjunction with the relevant
application.
      (2)   The applicant for any use may submit a parking demand study in
conjunction with the relevant application if the applicant believes the parking
ratio specified in §
156.741 exceeds the number needed for the proposed use.
   (C)   Documentation of parking demand required.
      (1)   The parking demand study shall be prepared by a professional
engineer or transportation planner.
      (2)   The professional engineer or transportation planner shall provide
documentation verifying parking demand based on:
         (a)   Relevant data for the proposed use, if available, such as number
of employees, hours of operation, and number and frequency of customer or
client visits; and/or
         (b)   Actual parking counts for uses or combinations of uses that are
the same or comparable to the proposed use(s) in terms of density, scale, bulk,
area, type of activity, and location; and/or
         (c)   Data from the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE), Urban
Land Institute (ULI) meeting a Level of Service A or B for walking distances
from parking to entrance, or another generally accepted resource for parking
demand data.
      (3)   The parking demand study shall consider the availability of current
or planned public transportation routes, greenways, and other pedestrian and
bicycle connections.
   (D)   Total number of parking spaces required. The approved parking demand
study shall establish the minimum number of parking spaces required for the
use.
   (E)   Changes affecting the number of parking spaces needed.
      (1)   If changes occur that affect the number of parking spaces needed
for the use, such as building additions, changes to operational characteristics
of the use, or adjustments to hours of operation, then either:
         (a)   A new parking demand study shall be submitted to demonstrate
whether the number of existing parking spaces continues to accommodate the
parking demand for the use; or
         (b)   Parking shall be provided in accordance with the applicable
ratio specified in
Subchapter F, Part 2.
      (2)   If the new parking demand study demonstrates that the number of
existing parking spaces no longer accommodates the parking demand generated by
the use, parking shall be provided in accordance with the new parking demand
study or with the applicable ratio specified in
Subchapter F, Part 2.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.776 THROUGH 156.784 RESERVED.
PART 5: OFF-STREET LOADING
§ 156.785 APPLICABILITY.
   This part applies to:
   (A)   Any building or structure that will be occupied by a use that requires
the receipt or distribution of material or merchandise, but that is not large
enough to necessitate the inclusion of one or more loading docks in the
building or structure design; and
   (B)   Any multi-tenant retail or office building.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.786 OFF-STREET LOADING SPACE REQUIRED.
   (A)   At least one off-street loading space shall be constructed at the time
of the initial construction or alteration or conversion of any building or
structure subject to this part. For multi-tenant buildings, at least one off-
street loading space shall be constructed for every three tenant spaces.
   (B)   Vehicles being loaded or unloaded in connection with normal operations
shall not project into a street or sidewalk.
   (C)   Each loading space shall be at least ten feet in width and 20 feet in
length.
   (D)   Off-street loading spaces do not count towards the minimum parking
required by §
156.740.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.787 THROUGH 156.809 RESERVED.
SUBCHAPTER G: SIGNS
PART 1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 156.810 PURPOSE.
   (A)   Purpose. The purposes of this subchapter are to regulate signs as
follows:
      (1)   To enhance the aesthetics and visual appeal of the town by:
         (a)   Encouraging signs that are of a quality design, pleasing in
appearance, and are appropriate in location, size, materials, and illumination
for the type of activity to which they pertain;
         (b)   Encouraging signs that are compatible with the architectural
style, characteristics, and scale of the building to which they are attached
and encouraging signs that are compatible with adjacent buildings, businesses,
and residents;
         (c)   Preserving and enhancing the natural scenic beauty or aesthetic
features of natural areas visible from highways, streets, and adjacent areas;
and
         (d)   Discouraging signs that contribute to the visual clutter of the
streetscape, such as off-premises signs, oversized signs, and excessive
temporary signs;
      (2)   To promote traffic safety by:
         (a)   Preventing or limiting unreasonable distraction of operators of
motor vehicles;
         (b)   Preventing the obstruction of the vision of operators of motor
vehicles;
         (c)   Discouraging signs that cause traffic hazards or interfere with
ingress/egress; and
         (d)   Preventing confusion with regard to traffic lights, signs, or
signals;
      (3)   To prevent property damage caused by signs improperly constructed
or anchored in times of hurricanes or other storms;
      (4)   To protect citizens’ state and federal constitutional rights to
free speech by:
         (a)   Providing ample opportunities for expression through signs;
         (b)   Avoiding regulatory triggers or distinctions based on a sign's
content; and
         (c)   Providing clear standards for approval of signs.
      (5)   To promote the prosperity, economic well-being, and general welfare
of the town and to preserve property values;
      (6)   To promote safety, convenience, and enjoyment of travel and
protection of the public investment in highways and streets within the town;
      (7)   To ensure light, air, and open space; and
      (8)   To implement the goals and policies of the Comprehensive Plan.
   (B)   Findings. The Town Council finds that the sign regulations in this
subchapter are necessary to preserve aesthetic values, promote traffic safety,
and accomplish the other purposes set out above.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.811 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   This subchapter applies to new and existing signs within the town,
except for the signs exempted from the applicability of this subchapter in §
156.812.
   (B)   This subchapter does not prohibit signs required by local, state, or
federal law and does not authorize signs prohibited by state or federal law.
   (C)   A person may not construct, install, operate, display, change the sign
copy, or otherwise use any sign this subchapter prohibits.
   (D)   A person may not construct, install, operate, display, change the sign
copy, or otherwise use any sign at a time, place, or manner that this
subchapter prohibits.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.812 EXEMPT SIGNS.
   (A)   Government signs. This subchapter does not apply to signs erected,
maintained, or displayed by the state, federal, Charleston County, or town
governments. Government uses in all zoning districts may include signs.
   (B)   Traffic control devices. This subchapter does not apply to traffic
control devices on public or private property that the Manual on Uniform
Traffic Control Devices adopted in this state requires.
   (C)   Required signs. This subchapter does not apply to any sign or device
the state, federal, or county government requires a person to erect, maintain,
or display.
   (D)   Indoor signs. This subchapter does not apply to signs within a
structure that are not visible from any perspective outside of the structure.
   (E)   Signs in an enclosed facility. This subchapter does not apply to signs
in an enclosed facility, such as a fenced or restricted access facility, that
are not visible from any point outside the facility.
   (F)   Signs smaller than one square foot. This subchapter does not apply to
signs with an area of less than one square foot that are located on a platted
lot. Such signs may not be placed in the right-of-way of any public street.
However, multiple small signs that effectively function together as a larger
sign must comply with the standards of this subchapter.
   (G)   Non-residential light pole banners. This subchapter does not apply to
temporary banners affixed to light poles in multi-tenant developments that are
displayed for a period not to exceed 90 days.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.813 PROHIBITED SIGNS.
   The following signs are hereby expressly prohibited unless specifically
otherwise allowed.
   (A)   Off-premises signs. Off-premises signs are prohibited, except as
provided in §
156.828.
   (B)   Signs that move. Signs or portions of signs that move by any means, or
signs that give the appearance of movement in any manner, including feather
signs, except for flags as allowed in this subchapter.
   (C)   Signs on parked vehicles. A vehicle, including trailers or other non-
motorized wheeled vehicles carrying or displaying signs, may not be parked so
that it functions primarily as a sign.
      (1)   Factors. The following factors determine whether a vehicle is used
primarily as a sign:
         (a)   The vehicle is parked at a prominent location on the lot;
         (b)   The vehicle is parked at the same or similar locations for more
than eight consecutive hours during the same day or for more than three
consecutive days during the same week; and
         (c)   A viewer in the right-of-way can read the sign copy.
      (2)   Presumption of use as a sign. While other factors may also
establish a violation of the prohibition of vehicle signs, a vehicle
presumptively violates this provision if the vehicle satisfies the three
factors, and the owner of the vehicle does not provide a compelling reason to
justify the parking location as opposed to another less conspicuous location.
   (D)   Signs that emit sound, odor, or visible matter, such as smoke or
vapor.
   (E)   Any sign or sign structure that obstructs the view of, or may be
confused with, a traffic/directional safety sign.
   (F)   Signs in the right-of-way. Signs may not be located within a state or
county-maintained street, highway, or right-of-way or within any street or
right-of-way that is maintained by the town.
   (G)   Any sign painted on or affixed to trees or other natural features,
utility poles, benches, or other street furniture, such as waste receptacles,
bike racks, drinking fountains, public telephones, and the like.
   (H)   Any sign located on any land subject to periodic inundation by tidal
saltwater.
   (I)   A sign towed behind a vehicle, watercraft, or aircraft.
   (J)   Any sign exhibiting statements, words, or pictures that are of an
obscene or pornographic nature.
   (K)   Inflatable signs or balloons of any type.
   (L)   Banners, flags (except as specifically permitted in this subchapter),
pennants, streamers, balloons, and other gas-filled figures, except as allowed
in
Chapter 116.
   (M)   Marquees.
   (N)   Electronic readerboard signs. However, interactive digital kiosks and
displays are not considered signs.
   (O)   Portable signs, except for A-frame signs, as specifically permitted in
this subchapter.
   (P)   Any other sign not expressly authorized by this subchapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.814 CONTENT NEUTRALITY AND SUBSTITUTION.
   (A)   Content neutrality. Despite any other provision of this subchapter,
the content of a sign’s message does not limit its permissibility under this
subchapter. However, location-based standards such as off-premises sign
regulations do not regulate content and do apply to signs.
   (B)   Substitution allowed. Any sign allowed with a commercial message may
contain any non-commercial message. Any sign with a non-commercial message may
contain any other non-commercial message.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.815 CLASSIFICATION OF SIGN USERS AND INTERPRETATION OF TABLES.
   (A)   Generally. This subchapter classifies sign users in a series of tables
to provide different allowances for area, height, and other features for signs
based on the use and to ensure that the same sign standards apply to similarly
situated users and in cohesive areas.
   (B)   Classifications. For the purposes of the subchapter, the following use
classifications apply:
      (1)   Residential uses. These are the principal uses listed in §
156.338, category for residential uses;
      (2)   Non-residential uses. These are all other principal uses not listed
in §
156.338, category for residential uses and any other non-listed uses, including
mixed-use buildings; and
      (3)   Multi-tenant developments. Where applicable, these are a building
or group of buildings developed for multiple non-residential users or mixed-
uses occupying one development site, such as a shopping center, retail center,
office park, multi-story multi-tenant building, planned development, mixed-use
building, or comprehensive development projects. Exclusively residential
developments are not considered a multi-tenant development.
   (C)   Interpretation of tables. This subchapter presents the allowed
specifications for signs in a series of tables. The subjects addressed by the
tables are described below. Each of the tables is a summary of the dimensional
allowances and features, and additional standards and requirements are included
in the substantive section for each sign type. The tables include the following
standards.
      (1)   Allowed. States whether the sign type is allowed for the use.
      (2)   Permit required. States whether this subchapter requires a permit
for the sign type and use.
      (3)   Sign setback. The distance from any property line that a sign may
be placed, in linear feet.
      (4)   Number. The maximum number of the particular sign on a platted lot
for the use.
      (5)   Sign area. The maximum area allowed for the sign face for the use,
in square feet.
      (6)   Height. The maximum height allowed for sign for the use, in linear
feet.
      (7)   Illumination. States whether illumination is allowed for the sign
type and use.
      (8)   Readerboard. States whether a readerboard is allowed for the sign
type and use.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.816 SIGN FEATURES.
   (A)   Illumination.
      (1)   General standards.
         (a)   Illuminated signs located adjacent to any residential area shall
be controlled by a rheostat, or another acceptable method, so as not to create
excessive glare to properties within the residential district.
         (b)   No illumination-simulating traffic control devices or emergency
vehicles shall be used.
         (c)   All illumination must be from a steady, stationary light source.
      (2)   Internal illumination.
         (a)   Internally illuminated signs must be constructed with opaque
backgrounds so that only letters, numbers, and/or logos are illuminated.
         (b)   Signs shall not have light-reflecting backgrounds or letters.
         (c)   All finishes shall be a matte finish.
      (3)   External illumination.
         (a)   Illumination shall be a steady, stationary light source,
shielded and directed solely at the sign.
         (b)   Light sources to illuminate signs shall neither be visible from
any street right-of-way, nor cause glare hazardous to pedestrians or vehicle
drivers, or so as to create a nuisance to adjacent properties.
         (c)   The intensity of light shall not exceed 20 footcandles at any
point on the sign face.
         (d)   The color of light sources to illuminate signs shall be white.
         (e)   Signs shall not have light-reflecting backgrounds or letters.
   (B)   Readerboards. Readerboards:
      (1)   Must be incorporated into the overall design of the sign;
      (2)   Shall not exceed 25 square feet, which is included in the total
sign square footage;
      (3)   Must have letters that are a minimum of four inches and a maximum
of eight inches in height; and
      (4)   If illuminated, must be constructed with opaque backgrounds so that
only letters, numbers, and/or logos are illuminated.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.817 THROUGH 156.824 RESERVED.
PART 2: SIGN STANDARDS
SUBPART 2.1: NON-RESIDENTIAL SIGNS
§ 156.825 FREESTANDING SIGN STANDARDS.
   (A)   Definition. A freestanding sign is a permanent on-premises sign
supported by a sign structure secured in the ground, wholly independent of any
other support.
   (B)   In general.
      (1)   Sign allowances. All non-residential uses must comply with the
freestanding sign allowances listed in Table 156.825-1.

      (2)   General allowance for all uses. Where

   (C)   Number.
      (1)   Lots with multiple frontages.
         (a)   Properties with a street frontage on two opposing parallel
streets may display one sign per street frontage. One sign shall meet the
standards of
Table 156.825-1. The sign on the secondary frontage shall not exceed 35 sq. ft.
in area and eight feet in height.
         (b)   This additional sign allowance does not apply to corner lots or
lots located at frontage road intersections.
      (2)   Multi-tenant developments.
         (a)   Multi-tenant developments may display the number and size for
freestanding signs as provided in
Table 156.825-1 for the entire development.
         (b)   Each tenant or occupant of a multi-tenant development shall not
display a separate freestanding sign.
   (D)   U.S. Highway 17/Johnnie Dodds Boulevard/Isle of Palms Connector. Non-
residential uses located on lots adjacent to Johnnie Dodds Boulevard or U.S.
Highway 17 and the Isle of Palms Connector (S.C. 517, Clyde Moultrie
Dangerfield Highway) must comply with the special sign allowances set out in
Table 156.825-1.
   (E)   Multi-tenant developments. All multi-tenant developments require a
master sign program approved by the Design Review Board as provided in §
156.861.
   (F)   Pole signs prohibited. All permanent freestanding signs must be
monument signs. Pole signs shall not be used as permanent freestanding signs.
   (G)   Setbacks.
      (1)   Signs must be located on the subject property, must have a minimum
setback of ten feet from the curb and/or street right-of-way, and in no case be
installed within the street right-of-way or project into the vertical plane of
the street right-of- way.
      (2)   Additionally, all sign locations must conform to the State
Department of Transportation's Access and Roadside Management Standards Sight
Distance Formula.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.826 ATTACHED SIGN STANDARDS.
   (A)   Definition. An attached sign is an on-premises sign that is
permanently affixed to a building or structure, including wall signs,
projecting signs, awning and canopy signs, roof signs, and window signs.
   (B)   Sign allowances.
      (1)   All non-residential uses must comply with the attached sign
allowances listed in Table 156.826-1.
Table 156.826-1: Attached Sign Allowances
Standard Freestanding Buildings Occupant 30 ft. Frontage Occupant > 30 ft.
         and Anchor Tenants                              Frontage
Table 156.826-1: Attached Sign Allowances
Standard        Freestanding Buildings Occupant 30 ft. Occupant > 30 ft.
                and Anchor Tenants     Frontage        Frontage
Allowed         Yes                    Yes             Yes
Permit required Yes                    Yes             Yes
Number          N/A                    N/A             N/A
Sign area1      1 sq. ft. per 1 ft. of 30 sq. ft.      1 sq. ft. per 1 ft. of
                frontage                               frontage
Illuminati on   Yes                    Yes             Yes
Readerbo ard    No                     No              No
Notes
1 The non-residential use attached sign area allowance applies cumulatively
for all attached signs. Additional rules and limitations in this section
apply.
 
      (2)   Calculation of sign allowances.
         (a)   The sign allowance for attached signs is determined by the width
of the building frontage for the primary building façade for occupants with a
public entrance at ground level.
         (b)   Buildings with more than one street frontage or where the
building is adjacent to the street with no parking or vehicular access between
the building and street, may qualify for an additional allowance for attached
signs not to exceed 50 square feet, as determined by the Zoning Administrator.
         (c)   Occupants in a multi-tenant development with more than one
street frontage, corner units, or where the buildings are situated along the
street with the development's parking to the rear, may also qualify for
additional attached signs up to an additional 100% of their attached sign
allowance.
         (d)   Regardless of the building façade width, a single sign user may
not exceed 150 square feet of internally illuminated signage per façade.
   (C)   Signs and building types.
      (1)   Freestanding buildings.
         (a)   Freestanding buildings may use any combination of attached sign
types to meet the attached sign allowance.
         (b)   All attached signs must be appropriately scaled to the building
or property as determined by the Commercial Design Review Board or Zoning
Administrator.
      (2)   Multi-tenant developments.
         (a)   All multi-tenant developments require a master sign program
approved by the Design Review Board as provided in §
156.861.
         (b)   Anchor tenants.
            1.   Anchor tenants may use any combination of attached sign types
to meet the attached sign allowance.
            2.   All attached signs must be appropriately scaled to the
building or property as determined by the Commercial Design Review Board or
Zoning Administrator.
            3.   Anchor tenants in multi-story buildings may locate allowed
attached signs near the top of the building.
            4.   To qualify as an anchor tenant, the business must fully occupy
the anchor space, as noted on the site plan provided in the master sign program
and have a minimum 20,000 square feet of area.
         (c)   The wall signs for all other occupants with a ground-level
public entrance are limited to wall signs and must be located in a sign band
pursuant to the provisions of §
156.902.
         (d)   Building occupants without a ground-level public entrance may
not display an attached sign in addition to the signs allowed for the multi-
tenant development.
   (D)   Wall signs.
      (1)   Definition. A sign attached directly to an exterior wall of a
building or dependent upon a building for support, with the exposed face of the
sign substantially parallel to the exterior building wall to which the sign is
attached.
      (2)   Design standards. Wall signs must be mounted flush to the exterior
wall on which they are mounted.
   (E)   Projecting signs.
      (1)   Definition. Any sign attached to, and projecting more than 18
inches from, the face of a building.
      (2)   Design standards.
         (a)   Projecting signs may not project more than five feet from the
building.
         (b)   Projecting signs must have clearance of ten feet from grade, as
illustrated in Figure 156.826-1.
         (c)   The height of the top edge of a projecting sign may not exceed
the lower of:
            1.   Twenty-five feet above grade; or
            2.   The height of the building at the building line.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13038.png]
 
   (F)    Awning and canopy signs.
      (1)    Definition. A permanent sign attached or applied to an awning or
canopy.
      (2)    Design standards. Awnings and canopies that include signs must be
an integral component of the design of a building and fully functional to
protect pedestrians from the elements.
      (3)    Materials. Awnings must be constructed of cloth or canvas and may
not be illuminated.
      (4)    Sign area allowance calculation.
         ( a)   Logos, lettering, and the like on the face and/or sides of the
awning will count towards the attached sign area allowance.
         (b)   However, one row of copy, not exceeding six inches in height,
located on the awning valence will not be included in the attached sign area
calculation.
   (G)   Roof signs.
      (1)   Definition. Any sign erected over or on the roof of a building.
      (2)   Sloped roofs. For sloped roofs, roof signs may not project or
extend above the ridge line of the roof.
      (3)   Flat roofs.
         (a)   For flat roofs with a parapet wall, a roof sign may not extend
above the top edge of the parapet.
         (b)   Buildings with flat roofs without a parapet wall may not display
roof signs.
   (H)   Window signs.
      (1)   Definition. A permanent sign posted, painted, placed, or affixed to
the inside or outside of a window or glass door.
      (2)   Sign area allowance calculation. Window signs and interior store
signs visible to the outside, will be included as part of the attached sign
area calculation.
      (3)   Exception for sign area allowance calculation. However, a single
row of copy, not exceeding six inches in height, located on the top or bottom
of each ground level display window, will not be included in the attached sign
area calculation.
   (I)   Safety standards.
      (1)   Obstructions. Signs may not obstruct any fire escape, or any
window, door, or opening used as a means of ingress or egress for firefighting
purposes or prevent access from one part of a roof to any other part of the
roof.
      (2)   Location of attachment. Signs may not be attached to a fire escape
or be placed in a location that interferes with any opening required for
ventilation.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.827 MURAL STANDARDS.
   (A)   Definition. A mural is a hand-produced work in which paint or tile is
applied by hand directly on an exterior wall of a building or structure. The
town will not review the content of murals.
   (B)   Mural allowances. Table 156.827-1 states the standards for murals for
non-residential uses. One mural or painted wall sign may be displayed on a
secondary wall of a non-residential building in addition to other signs allowed
in this subchapter.
Table 156.827-1: Mural Allowances
Standard Allowance
Table 156.827-1: Mural Allowances
Standard        Allowance
Allowed         Yes
Permit required Yes
Number          1 per building
Sign area       100% of one wall
Height          No taller than existing wall
Illumination    External only
Readerboard     No
 
   (C)   Location and design.
      (1)   Placement on secondary wall. A mural may not be located on an
exterior wall with direct street frontage. Murals are only allowed on side and
rear façades.
      (2)   Materials and design. A mural may not include:
         (a)   Mechanically produced or computer-generated prints or images,
including digitally printed vinyl sheets and wraps;
         (b)   Works containing electrical or mechanical components; or
         (c)   Works that involve changing or moving images or components.
      (3)   Review criteria. The Design Review Board will review all murals.
The review will include a consideration of the following factors but will not
include any consideration of content:
         (a)   The mural uses durable, exterior grade paints and materials and
weatherproof and ultraviolet-protective coatings, if applicable;
         (b)   The mural uses colors that coordinate with the colors of the
building;
         (c)   The mural is directed at and scaled to pedestrians;
         (d)   The mural does not overwhelm or hide the character-defining
features of a building;
         (e)   The mural is placed and sized to reinforce the building’s
architecture and its surroundings; and
         (f)   The mural is placed at a similar height and façade location as
murals on adjacent buildings, if possible, to provide an integrated block
appearance.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.828 OFF-PREMISES SIGN STANDARDS.
   (A)   Definition. A sign that advertises businesses, organizations, goods,
products, or services that are not located, sold, manufactured, or distributed
on or from the premises or facilities where the sign is located. For the
purposes of this definition, premises will be considered to include all
contiguous parcels that are under common ownership, maintenance, operation, or
plan. Nothing contained in this definition shall be construed to apply to limit
noncommercial messages or information placed on any allowed sign.
   (B)   District limitations. Off-premises signs are allowed only in the Light
Industrial District (LI).
   (C)   Off-premises sign allowances. One off-premises sign is allowed per
lot, if it meets the following requirements.
      (1)   Separation distance.
         (a)   Separation of off-premises signs shall be at least 1,000 feet,
measured along any street or thoroughfare from any other off-premises sign or
on-premises sign.
         (b)   However, off-premises signs of 35 square feet or less are
allowed less than 1,000 feet apart from other off-premises or on-premises
signs, if they are on a separate platted lot.
      (2)   Setbacks.
         (a)   Setbacks for off-premises signs shall be at least 20 feet,
measured from the pavement edge of the nearest road surface.
         (b)   Additionally, all sign locations must conform to the State
Department of Transportation's Access and Roadside Management Standards Sight
Distance Formula.
      (3)   Height and area.
         (a)   Height of off-premises signs must not exceed 20 feet above the
roadbed toward which the sign face is directed.
         (b)   The sign area of off-premises signs must not exceed 150 square
feet on one side.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.829 THROUGH 156.834 RESERVED.

   (A)   Sign allowances. All residential uses must comply with the allowances
listed in Table 156.835-1.

2 Special standards apply for residential development signs. Refer to §

   (B)   Residential development signs.
      (1)   Definition. A freestanding sign located near the entrance drive or
road to a residential development or an attached sign located on a multi-family
building. An example of a typical residential development sign is one that
identifies the name of the development or phase of development, sometimes
incorporating architectural or landscape features. The example is provided to
clarify the regulations and does not limit the content of residential
development signs. The town will not review the content of residential
development signs.
      (2)   Number and dimensions for freestanding signs. Residential
developments may have a maximum of two one-sided or one two-sided freestanding
sign per entry drive with vehicle access to the subdivision or development.
These freestanding signs must comply with the allowances in
Table 156.835-1.
      (3)   Location of signs. Where entry drives include or incorporate
decorative features, such as walls, gates, fences, or similar decorative
features, flanking the entrance drive, one sign may be attached to each wall or
other appropriate feature.
      (4)   Alternative wall sign for multi-family buildings. As an alternative
to a freestanding sign provided by this division, an apartment or multiplex
dwelling may display one attached sign, such as a wall, canopy, or projecting
sign. The same sign area allowance applies.
   (C)   Pole signs prohibited. All permanent freestanding signs must be
monument signs. Pole signs may not be used as permanent freestanding signs.
   (D)   Setbacks.
      (1)   Signs must be located on the subject property, must have a minimum
setback of ten feet from the curb and/or street right-of-way, and in no case be
installed within the street right-of-way or project into the vertical plane of
the street right-of- way.
      (2)   Additionally, all sign locations must conform to the State
Department of Transportation's Access and Roadside Management Standards Sight
Distance Formula.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.836 THROUGH 156.844 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.3: INCIDENTAL AND TEMPORARY SIGNS
§ 156.845 INCIDENTAL SIGN STANDARDS.
   (A)   Definition. An incidental sign is a small permanent sign that is
freestanding or attached to a building that is in addition to the primary sign
types for the property, such as wall signs and freestanding signs, and that has
a height and scale that is subordinate to the primary sign types allowed for
the property. Examples of typical incidental signs include house numbers,
occupant directories, directional signs, flags, and parking signs. The list of
examples is provided to clarify the regulations and does not limit the content
of incidental signs. The town will not review the content of incidental signs.
   (B)   Dimension and location standards. Table 156.845-1 states the standards
for incidental signs.

   (C)   Sign setback. This section regulates the location and size of
incidental signs based on a sign setback that varies by use and incidental sign
type.
      (1)   Measurement. The sign setback is the setback from any property line
and regulates the location and size of incidental signs.
Table 156.845-1 defines the applicable setback for each sign type and use.
      (2)   Perimeter signs. Perimeter signs are signs that may be located
between the property line and the applicable sign setback.
      (3)   Interior signs. Interior signs must be located within a platted lot
and may not be located within the sign setback.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13040.png]
 
   (D)   Number and location.
      (1)   Perimeter signs.
         (a)   
Table 156.845-1 defines the maximum number of perimeter incidental signs per
entrance to a public street.
         (b)   All perimeter signs must be located within 15 feet of a driveway
entrance to a public street.
         (c)   Perimeter signs may only be installed at driveway entrances onto
a property when the traffic patterns within the property or site are strictly
limited to one-way traffic.
      (2)   Interior signs. This section provides for two types of interior
signs: small and large interior signs.
         (a)   
Table 156.845-1 defines the maximum allowances for small interior incidental
signs based on the number of signs per acre. Examples of typical small
incidental signs include house numbers, directional signs, and parking signs.
The list of examples is provided to clarify the regulations and does not limit
the content of incidental signs. The town will not review the content of
incidental signs.
         (b)   Large interior signs. 
Table 156.845-1 defines the allowances for large interior incidental signs
based on the number of signs per development. Examples of typical large
incidental signs include occupant directories, drive-thru menus, and
information kiosks. The list of examples is provided to clarify the regulations
and does not limit the content of incidental signs. The town will not review
the content of incidental signs.
            1.   Multi-tenant developments equal to or greater than 40,000
square feet of gross leasable area may have a maximum of two large interior
signs; and
            2.   Multi-tenant developments with less than 40,000 square feet of
gross leasable area may have one large interior sign.
   (E)   Design standards.
      (1)   Appearance. All incidental signs must utilize a uniform background
color and a uniform font/logo color for all sign panels.
      (2)   Illumination. Incidental signs may not be illuminated.
      (3)   Sight distance. All sign locations must conform to the State
Department of Transportation's Access and Roadside Management Standards Sight
Distance Formula.
      (4)   Interior orientation. Interior signs must be oriented internally to
the development.
      (5)   Installation. An incidental sign on a wall shall affix flush
against the wall of the building.
      (6)   Painted signs prohibited. Incidental signs must not be painted on
an exterior wall.
      (7)   Pavement markings. Pavement markings are allowed only as approved
through site plan review by the Design Review Board or designee.
   (F)   Flags.
      (1)   Generally. 
Table 156.845-1 provides the allowances for flags.
      (2)   Number. A maximum of three flags may be displayed at one time.
However, the flags must be flown on one pole.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.846 TEMPORARY SIGN STANDARDS.
   (A)   Definition. A temporary sign is a sign constructed of cloth, canvas,
light fabric, cardboard, wood, wallboard, metal, or other light materials, with
or without frames, that is intended to be displayed for a limited period of
time only. Temporary signs include stake signs, post signs, and A-frame signs.
Examples of common temporary sign uses include political signs, public
demonstrations, grand opening signs, contractor signs, real estate signs, and
signs that announce an event such as a carnival, circus, or similar event. The
list of examples is provided to clarify the regulations and does not limit the
content of temporary signs. The town will not review the content of temporary
signs.
   (B)   Prohibited temporary sign types. §
156.813 prohibits the use of several common temporary sign types, including
banners, streamers, balloons, and other gas-filled figures.
   (C)   Dimension and display standards. Table 156.846-1 states the standards
for temporary signs.
Table 156.846-1: Temporary Sign Allowances
Standard Residential Uses Non-Residential Uses
Table 156.846-1: Temporary Sign Allowances
