   (D)   A-frame signs.
      (1)   Location and use standards.
         (a)   A-frame signs must be located within ten feet of the primary
building entrance.
         (b)   A-frame signs may not be located within the ADA accessible
route, eight-foot-minimum sidewalk, verge, right-of-way, or landscaped areas.
      (2)   Design standards.
         (a)   A-frame signs must employ a high level of traditional design and
material. Examples of high level of design include, but are not limited to, the
illustrations in Figure 156.846-1.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13042.png]
 
         (b)   Figure 156.846-2 illustrates examples of signs that are not
appropriate.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13044.png]
 
         (c)   A-frame signs may not employ readerboard or changeable letter
copy. This design aesthetic prohibition does not preclude the inclusion of
chalkboards. Figure 156.846-3 illustrates examples of readerboards that are not
allowed.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13046.png]
 
         (d)   Plastic or similar material is not allowed. Figure 156.846-
4 illustrates examples of plastic materials that are not allowed.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13048.png]
 
   (E)   All other temporary signs.
      (1)   Number. 
Table 156.846-1 defines the maximum limit for other temporary signs per
occupant or user per parcel.
      (2)   Duration temporary signs may be displayed. Each temporary sign may
only be displayed for 90 days or less. However, the same sign may displayed for
multiple time periods if an additional time allowance is available.
      (3)   Owner consent required. A person must obtain the consent of the
property owner before placing a sign on that person’s property.
      (4)   Hazardous signs prohibited. A person may not place, erect, or
maintain any temporary sign so as to pose a hazard to pedestrian or vehicular
traffic along streets, sidewalks, or at street corners.
      (5)   Display locations for multi-tenant developments. Temporary signs in
multi-tenant developments must be displayed within the occupant’s window.
      (6)   Design standards.
         (a)   Except for A-frame signs, temporary signs should be implanted or
anchored in the ground or affixed to the wall of a building or other permanent
structure.
         (b)   Temporary signs must not be anchored to the ground by measures
such as using sandbags or other weighted objects.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.847 THROUGH 156.859 RESERVED.
PART 3: ADMINISTRATION AND  ENFORCEMENT
§ 156.860 ADMINISTRATION.
   (A)   Non-residential uses.
      (1)   Design review. The provisions of this subchapter applicable to non-
residential uses will be administered by the Design Review Board staff
representative through the design review process.
      (2)   Review authority.
         (a)   The Design Review Board has the authority to review and approve
master sign programs pursuant to this subchapter.
         (b)   Applications not requiring a master sign program may be reviewed
and approved by the Zoning Administrator. Any sign that conforms to an approved
sign program may be approved by the Zoning Administrator. The Zoning
Administrator may also refer a sign proposal to the Design Review Board as
provided in §
156.862. Applicants may choose to pursue staff-level or Design Review Board
approval for this process.
         (c)   Appeals from staff-level decisions in the design review process
will be considered by the Design Review Board. Decisions of the Design Review
Board may be appealed to Circuit Court.
   (B)   Residential uses.
      (1)   Review authority. The provisions of this subchapter applicable to
residential uses will be administered by the Zoning Administrator.
      (2)   Appeals. Appeals from decisions of the Zoning Administrator will be
considered by the Board of Zoning Appeals. Decisions of the Board of Zoning
Appeals may be appealed to Circuit Court.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.861 MASTER SIGN PROGRAM.
   (A)   Purpose. To further the goals of §
156.810 and create a harmonious and aesthetically-pleasing visual environment
within developments.
   (B)   General requirements.
      (1)   A master sign program is required for all multi-tenant
developments.
      (2)   Master sign programs require review and approval through the design
review process.
   (C)   Scope of approval. Approval of architectural plans that include signs
on any portion of the building or property does not constitute approval of
signage. A separate request for signage approval must be submitted for approval
if approval is necessary for the sign type.
   (D)   Review criteria. The reviewing authority may require alterations to
the design, materials, size, or other articles of this chapter, based on the
scale of the building, the proposed location on the property, or other factors,
including the aesthetics or design of the sign.
   (E)   Review authority. The reviewing authority may not alter the
regulations to increase size or circumvent other regulations for the applicant,
except that comprehensive development project signs may be allowed on a lot
outside of the development site provided that the sign must be in as close
proximity to the overall comprehensive development project as possible. For the
purposes of this subchapter, such a sign will not be considered an off-premises
sign.
   (F)   Required information.
      (1)   An accurate site plan of the lot;
      (2)   Location of buildings, parking lots, driveways, and landscaped
areas on the lot;
      (3)   An accurate indication on the site plan of the proposed location of
each proposed and/or existing free-standing sign;
      (4)   A scaled elevation view of the proposed sign locations for attached
signs;
      (5)   Color scheme;
      (6)   Sign style;
      (7)   Lighting;
      (8)   Materials; and
      (9)   Sign dimensions.
   (G)   Procedures.
      (1)   A master sign program is a required condition of approval of any
new signs within a multi-tenant development project.
      (2)   A master sign program shall be a condition of approval of any
planned development, design review, use permit, or other application required
by the town for multi-tenant developments, and shall be processed prior to the
installation of any signs.
      (3)   Approval of a master sign program does not waive the permit
requirements for individual signs.
   (H)   Amendments. A master sign program may be amended by filing a new
master sign program that conforms with all of the requirements of this
subchapter.
   (I)   Existing signs not conforming to master sign program. If any new
master sign program is filed or an existing master sign program on which
existing signs are located is amended, it shall include a schedule for bringing
into conformance all signs not conforming to the proposed or amended program.
   (J)   Binding effect. After approval of a master sign program or amendment
to an existing master sign program, no signs shall be erected, placed, painted,
or maintained, except in conformance with such plan, and such plan may be
enforced in the same way as any provision in this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.862 SIGN PERMITS.
   (A)   Permit required. Except as otherwise provided in this subchapter, no
person shall erect, move, alter, replace, or change sign copy (except on
readerboard signs), without first obtaining a zoning permit as required by this
subchapter. A permit is required for all sign types and uses for which a permit
is required by the tables for each sign type in this subchapter.
   (B)   Permit not required.
      (1)   Exempt signs. Sign permits are not required for exempt signs listed
in §
156.812.
      (2)   Permit requirement in tables. The tables for each sign type in this
subchapter state whether or not a permit is required for the sign types and
use.
      (3)   Maintenance. Sign permits are not required for customary
maintenance of a sign that does not change the dimensions of the sign or the
copy displayed by the sign.
   (C)   Permit applications.
      (1)   Applications for sign permits shall be submitted on forms provided
by the Department of Planning, Land Use and Neighborhoods, and contain all
information required on the forms and any additional information required to
ensure compliance with all applicable sections of the zoning and/or building
codes.
      (2)   If required by the Building Official, the application shall include
a copy of stress sheets and calculations prepared or approved by a state-
licensed registered structural engineer, showing that the sign is designed for
dead load and wind pressure in any direction in the amount required by this and
all other applicable ordinances of the town.
      (3)   The Building Official may also request details of electrical
connection points, construction details, and attachment details.
   (D)   Permit fees.
      (1)   Every application for a sign approval shall be accompanied by a
fee, in an amount specified by the schedule of fees established by Town Council
resolution, and related provisions of the Town Building Code.
      (2)   Whenever a sign permit fee is required by this section and work is
started prior to obtaining a permit, a fine of up to $500 may be imposed for
failure to secure a permit, in addition to other applicable fines.
   (E)   Issuance of permits.
      (1)   Approval.
         (a)   The Zoning Administrator will review all sign permit
applications within ten days of filing. If, upon review, the proposed sign is
complete and in compliance with all of the requirements of this section, and
any other applicable ordinances of the town, the Zoning Administrator shall
issue a permit that may be subject to conditions, and if required, forward the
permit to the Department of Engineering and Development Services for issuance
of a building permit and/or electrical permit, or refer the application to the
Design Review Board as provided below.
         (b)   Sign permits shall be vested for a period of two years, subject
to the rights and restrictions contained within this title.
         (c)   Should the work not be completed within this timeframe, a new
sign permit is required prior to the installation of the sign.
      (2)   Referral to Design Review Board.
         (a)   The Zoning Administrator may refer any application for a
permanent or attached non-residential sign to the Design Review Board for
evaluation.
         (b)   The Design Review Board shall evaluate a sign application
referred by the Zoning Administrator for aesthetics only and may not evaluate
the content or message of the sign.
         (c)   Aesthetic criteria for the Zoning Administrator to consider in
referral and the Design Review Board to consider in the review include:
            1.   The placement of the sign on the building in locations that
detract from or conceal architectural features;
            2.   The effect of contrasting colors used in the sign;
            3.   The extent that the colors of the sign face or support
structure compliment colors of materials used in buildings and other signs on
the site; and
            4.   The proportions of the sign in relationship to the building or
sign band.
         (d)   If the Design Review Board approves or approves subject to
conditions, the Zoning Administrator shall issue the permit, including any
applicable conditions.
      (3)   Denial. If the application request is not in compliance with all
requirements of this section, then the Zoning Administrator will deny the
application. If the Design Review Board recommends denial of a permit, the
Zoning Administrator shall deny the permit.
   (F)   Revocation of permits. On failure of the holder to comply with any
provision of this section or any other applicable statute, ordinance, or
regulation, the Zoning Administrator is authorized and empowered to revoke any
issued permit and order the immediate removal of the sign.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.863 SIGN INSPECTION AND MAINTENANCE.
   (A)   Maintenance required. Every sign and all parts, portions, units, and
materials comprising the same, together with the frame, background, supports,
or anchorage thereof, shall be maintained in proper repair and a proper state
of preservation.
   (B)   Inspections. All signs for which a permit is required shall be subject
to inspection to ascertain compliance.
   (C)   Notification of need for maintenance. In the event that maintenance is
deemed necessary, the sign owner will be notified by letter, in which case the
noted deficiencies shall be corrected within 60 days, unless an extension is
granted for sufficient cause shown for an appropriate amount of time.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.864 ABANDONED SIGNS.
   (A)   Definition. An abandoned sign is any permitted sign or sign structure
that was erected on a premises in conjunction with a particular use that has
been discontinued for a period of 30 days or more, or any permitted temporary
sign for which the allowed display time has expired.
   (B)   Declaration of abandonment. The Zoning Administrator may declare a
sign to be abandoned.
   (C)   Criteria. Evidence of abandonment is a discontinuance of the use,
activity, place, or business that the sign identifies, or a willful lack of
maintenance to the extent that the sign is in obvious disrepair.
   (D)   Removal. A nonconforming sign that has been declared abandoned by the
Zoning Administrator shall be removed within 90 days of written notification
thereof, and shall not thereafter be reestablished, except in conformity with
the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.865 MEASUREMENTS.
   (A)   Height.
      (1)   Freestanding signs. For freestanding signs, height is the distance
from the highest point of the sign to the base of the sign at the ground level.
Figure 156.865-1: General Sign Measurements illustrates this measurement.
      (2)   Below-grade signs. If the site of the sign is below street level,
the height is measured from street level.
Figure 156.865-1: General Sign Measurements
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13050.png]
 
   (B)   Sign area.
      (1)   Generally. The general sign area, measured in square feet (“sq.
ft.”), is the width multiplied by the height of a single rectangle, parallel
with the ground, that contains all sign copy and other illuminated decorative
embellishments that are not an architectural design element of the building or
the base or sign support structure.
Figure 156.865-1: General Sign Measurements illustrates this measurement.
      (2)   Channel letters. The sign area for signs using channel letters is
the sign face width multiplied by the sign face height for the smallest
rectangle that completely encloses all sign copy. It does not include the
background unless the background is internally illuminated. Figure 156.865-2:
Channel Letter Area Measurement illustrates this measurement.
Figure 156.865-2: Channel Letter Area Measurement 
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13052.png]
 
      (3)   For two-sided signs. The sign area of a two-sided sign with
parallel faces of the same size is the measure of the larger sign area of
either of the two sides. Signs with more than two faces and multi-sided signs
or objects are not allowed.
   (C)   Façade width.
      (1)   Measurement. Where this subchapter calculates a sign area allowance
based on the width of a building’s façade facing a street frontage, the width
of the façade is the horizontal distance of the façade at grade on the side of
the building facing a public street. Figure 156.865-3 illustrates this
measurement.
      (2)   Shopping centers and retail centers. For shopping centers and
retail centers with multiple occupants, the width of the façade is the
horizontal distance of the portion of the façade between party walls or tenant
separation partitions for the particular occupant at grade on the side of the
building on which the sign is proposed.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13054.png]
 
   (D)   Setbacks. All setbacks are measured from the foremost plane of a sign
or sign structure.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.866 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ABANDONED SIGN. Any permitted sign or sign structure that was erected on a
premises in conjunction with a particular use that has been discontinued for a
period of 30 days or more, or any permitted temporary sign for which the
allowed display time has expired.
   A-FRAME SIGN. A portable sign capable of standing without support or
attachment.
   ATTACHED SIGN. An on-premises sign that is permanently affixed to a building
or structure; types include wall signs, projecting signs, awning and canopy
signs, roof signs, and window signs.
   AWNING. Any structure made of flexible fabric or similar material covering a
metal frame attached to a building, whether or not the same is so erected as to
permit its being raised to a position flat against the building when not in
use.
   AWNING AND CANOPY SIGN. A permanent sign attached or applied to an awning or
canopy.
   BANNER. A device made of flexible materials designed to attract attention
that is attached to a building or support structure at each corner to prevent
movement in the wind. BANNERS do not include flags and feather signs.
   CANOPY. Any structure, other than an awning, made of flexible or inflexible
material, supported by the ground or sidewalk, and/or partially supported by
the building.
   FEATHER SIGN. A temporary sign made of flexible material in the shape of a
feather, quill, sail, blade or teardrop, mounted along one margin on a solid or
flexible vertical pole, where the height is greater than the width of the sign
face. These are sometimes referred to as QUILL SIGNS or SAIL BANNERS.
   FLAG. A piece of fabric or other flexible material, with distinctive colors
and patterns, customarily mounted on a pole or similar freestanding structure,
or on a pole mounted on a building, where the width is equal to or greater than
the height.
   FREESTANDING SIGN. Any permanent on-premises sign supported by a sign
structure secured in the ground, wholly independent of any other support.
   GOVERNMENT SIGN. A sign installed or maintained by the federal, state,
Charleston County, or town government, and also a sign located on property
owned or leased by the federal, state, Charleston County, or town government.
   GRAPHICS. Any drawing, symbol, picture, motif, or logo displayed on a sign
face.
   ILLUMINATED SIGN. Any sign directly or indirectly lighted by an artificial
light source.
   INCIDENTAL SIGN. A small permanent sign that is freestanding or attached to
a building that is in addition to the primary sign types for the property, such
as wall signs and freestanding signs, and that has a height and scale that is
subordinate to the primary sign types allowed for the property. Examples of
typical incidental signs include house numbers, occupant directories,
directional signs, flags, and parking signs. The list of examples is provided
to clarify the regulations and does not limit the content of incidental signs.
The town will not review the content of incidental signs.
   INFLATABLE SIGN. Any sign that is either expanded to its full dimensions or
supported by gases contained within the sign, or sign parts, at a pressure
greater than atmospheric pressure. Untethered airships are not considered to be
inflatable signs.
   INTERACTIVE DIGITAL KIOSKS AND DISPLAYS. An object or device with a digital
display of not more than four square feet and characters or icons that do not
exceed four inches in height that has the primary purpose of interactive use by
a pedestrian or occupant of a vehicle to submit payments or make donations,
receive items distributed for non-commercial or commercial purposes, place
orders, or use a service. Examples of interactive uses include donation
portals, check-in portals, kiosks that distribute non-commercial or commercial
literature or information, ticket dispensers, automatic teller machines,
restaurant order interfaces for menus, and fuel station pumps. The list of
examples is provided to clarify the regulations and does not limit the content
of interactive digital kiosks and displays. The town will not review the
content of these devices. These devices are not considered signs.
   INTERNALLY ILLUMINATED SIGN. Any sign that has light transmitted outward
through its face or any part thereof.
   MARQUEE SIGN. A roof-like structure or panel attached to a building and
bearing a sign board or sign area designed for changeable copy.
   MASTER SIGN PROGRAM. A coordinated sign plan that includes details of all
signs (not including exempt or temporary signs) that are, or will be, placed on
a site.
   MONUMENT SIGN. A permanent, on-premises ground sign with a low profile that
has a base and support structure with a solid appearance measuring at least
one-half of the width of the widest part of the sign’s face. Fully enclosed
fascia will be included in the measurement of the width of the sign support.
   MULTI-TENANT DEVELOPMENTS. For the purposes of the sign regulations in this
subchapter, a building or group of buildings developed for multiple non-
residential users or mixed-uses occupying one development site, such as a
shopping center, retail center, office park, multi-story multi-tenant building,
planned development, mixed-use building, or comprehensive development projects.
Exclusively residential developments are not considered a multi-tenant
development.
   MURAL. A mural is a hand-produced work in which paint or tile is applied by
hand directly on an exterior wall of a building or structure. The town will not
review the content of murals.
   NONCONFORMING SIGN. A sign lawfully erected and legally existing on the
effective date of this chapter, or of amendments thereto, but which does not
conform to the provisions of this chapter.
   OCCUPANT. For the purposes of the sign regulations in this subchapter, a
distinct user that occupies a portion of a multi-tenant building, lot, or
development, regardless of the legal arrangement allowing occupancy between the
owner of the building, lot, or development and the user.
   OFF-PREMISES SIGN. A sign that advertises businesses, organizations, goods,
products, or services that are not located, sold, manufactured, or distributed
on or from the premises or facilities where the sign is located. For the
purposes of this definition, premises will be considered to include all
contiguous parcels that are under common ownership, maintenance, operation, or
plan. Nothing contained in this definition shall be construed to apply to limit
noncommercial messages or information placed on any allowed sign.
   ON-PREMISES SIGN. A sign that advertises businesses, organizations, goods,
products, or services that are located, sold, manufactured, or distributed on
or from the premises or facilities where the sign is located. For the purposes
of this definition, premises will be considered to include all contiguous
parcels that are under common ownership, maintenance, operation, or plan.
Nothing contained in this definition shall be construed to apply to limit
noncommercial messages or information placed on any allowed sign.
   PERMITTED SIGN. Any sign for which the town has issued a permit.
   POLE SIGN. A permanent ground sign supported by one or more poles or
vertical members that are less than one-half of the width of the widest part of
the sign’s face. Fully enclosed fascia will be included in the measurement of
the width of the sign support.
   PORTABLE SIGN. A sign not permanently attached to the ground or other
permanent structure, or a sign designed to be transported, including signs
designed to be transported by means of wheels, A-frame signs, and balloons.
   PRIMARY BUILDING FAÇADE. For the purposes of the sign regulations in this
subchapter, that façade most clearly articulated as the visual or focal point
of the building, usually associated with the main entrance. The Zoning
Administrator will make this determination for buildings with corner entrances
or with more than one façade facing the street.
   PROJECTING SIGN. Any sign attached to, and projecting more than 18 inches
from, the face of a building.
   READERBOARD SIGN. A sign on which copy is changed manually in the field,
including but not limited to, business directories, church signs, and gas
pricing signs.
   READERBOARD SIGN, ELECTRONIC. A sign with copy that is displayed through the
use of digital screens, electric lights, illumination, or other electronic or
digital format, and that may be changed at will for the purpose of
advertisement or announcement.
   RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT. For the purposes of the sign regulations in this
subchapter, a subdivision for single-family dwellings or a multi-family
building or group of buildings.
   RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT SIGN. A freestanding sign located near the entrance
drive or road to a residential development or an attached sign located on a
multi-family building. An example of a typical residential development sign is
one that identifies the name of the development or phase of development,
sometimes incorporating architectural or landscape features. The example is
provided to clarify the regulations and does not limit the content of
residential development signs. The town will not review the content of
residential development signs.
   ROOF SIGN. Any sign erected over or on the roof of a building.
   SIGN. A visual display of an object or device that includes elements such as
colors, lights, motion, symbols, images, icons, letters, numerals, figures,
characters, or combines any of those elements, that a person intends to
communicate, advertise, identify, announce, direct, inform, or attract
attention. The term SIGN includes a structure used to support or display a
SIGN.
   SIGN FACE. The part of the sign that is or can be used for the display of
any copy or graphics, including any background material, panel, trim, color, or
illumination that differentiates the sign from a facade or sign structure.
   SIGN STRUCTURE. Any supporting structure erected, used, or intended for the
display of any sign, with or without a sign thereon.
   TEMPORARY SIGN. A sign constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric,
cardboard, wood, wallboard, metal, or other light materials, with or without
frames, that is intended to be displayed for a limited period of time only.
TEMPORARY SIGNS include stake signs, post signs, and A-frame signs. Examples of
common TEMPORARY SIGN uses include political signs, public demonstrations,
grand opening signs, contractor signs, real estate signs, and signs that
announce an event such as a carnival, circus, or similar event. The list of
examples is provided to clarify the regulations and does not limit the content
of TEMPORARY SIGNS. The town will not review the content of TEMPORARY SIGNS.
   VEHICLE SIGN. Any permanent or temporary sign, affixed to, painted, or
represented on, or placed in or upon any vehicle.
   WALL SIGN. A sign attached directly to an exterior wall of a building or
dependent upon a building for support, with the exposed face of the sign
substantially parallel to the exterior building wall to which the sign is
attached.
   WINDOW SIGN. A permanent sign posted, painted, placed, or affixed to the
inside or outside of a window or glass door.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.867 THROUGH 156.879 RESERVED.
SUBCHAPTER H: BUILDING AND SITE DESIGN
PART 1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 156.880 PURPOSE.
   (A)   The purpose of the established building and site design standards is
to protect and provide the desired character of the commercial districts and
development areas of the town.
   (B)   By establishing commercial building design standards, the town intends
to:
      (1)   Promote the appearance, character, and economic value of land
located in commercial districts and development areas;
      (2)   Protect the public from the impact of adverse visual nuisances;
      (3)   Assure respect for the character, integrity, and quality of the
built and natural environments of the town;
      (4)   Enhance public safety by defining spaces to influence traffic
movement;
      (5)   Reduce the amount of storm runoff and provide an appropriate and
attractive transition between neighboring properties;
      (6)   Foster civic beauty; and
      (7)   Strengthen the local economy.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.881 TOWN COMMERCIAL AREAS.
   (A)   Purpose. The town’s commercial areas generally include all non-
residential and mixed-use areas under the purview of the Design Review Board.
   (B)   Applicability. The following zoning districts and development types
are subject to this subchapter:
      (1)   Non-residential zoning districts including Limited Office
Professional District (OP-1), Office Professional District (OP-2), Limited
Neighborhood Commercial District (NC-1), Neighborhood Commercial District (NC-
2), Areawide Business-1 District (AB-1), Areawide Business-2 District (AB-2),
Economic Development District (ED), and Light Industrial District (LI);
      (2)   PD, Planned Development District with zoning classifications
containing a non-residential use component, for the non-residential use areas
only, and specifically including entire buildings containing a residential use
located in conjunction with a non-residential use;
      (3)   Overlay districts containing a commercial district zoning
classification or commercial area; however, specifically excluding the
commercially zoned properties located in the Old Village Historic District (OV-
HD);
      (4)   All properties located in the Village-Scale Pedestrian Overlay
District (VSP-OD);
      (5)   All properties located in the Shem Creek Waterfront Districts
(SCWD); and
      (6)   All properties with proposed residential development or
redevelopment consisting of five or more units located in any zoning district.
   (C)   Exemptions. Where detached houses are permitted in zoning districts
subject to this subchapter, they are exempt from the requirements of this
subchapter.
   (D)   Nonconforming buildings and structures. Notwithstanding the provisions
of Subchapter K, minor improvements not exceeding 50% of the reasonable
replacement value of the building or structure shall meet the requirements of
this subchapter; provided, however, that when improvements do not exceed 50% of
the reasonable replacement value of the building or structure, only those
elements proposed for modification are required to comply with this subchapter.
   (E)   Hierarchy of authority. Specific requirements adopted pursuant to
Planned Development District zoning classifications, special design subareas,
and specific requirements of adopted overlay districts take precedence over the
procedures and design requirements in this subchapter, when in conflict with
the same.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.882 DESIGN REVIEW PROCESS REQUIRED.
   The design review process establishes a systematic and uniform review
procedure for proposed construction of all applicable non-residential, mixed-
use, and in some cases multi-family developments to protect and provide for the
desired character of the commercial districts and development areas throughout
the town.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.883 TOWN DESIGN PRINCIPLES.
   (A)   Purpose. The following design principles serve as criteria for staff
and the Design Review Board for decision-making as it relates to Mount Pleasant
vernacular or lowcountry vernacular in the review of proposed development and
redevelopment throughout the town. The goal of the design standards is to
maintain the traditional small village feel of Mount Pleasant as it continues
to grow.
   (B)   Findings. The vernacular buildings of Mount Pleasant are typical of
most small, Atlantic seaboard fishing communities, and can be generally
described as simple and utilitarian in expression of form, design, material,
and detail. Mount Pleasant has historically been a small town. By 1970, the
population had only grown to roughly 6,000 residents. Since that time, the
population has doubled each decade. Buildings were generally small, vernacular
structures. While some buildings with formal styles were constructed, they are
generally few. Therefore, future construction should follow the form and
detailing of the more abundant small, vernacular buildings and utilize
vernacular designs and elements as described herein.
   (C)   Simplicity of massing and form. Traditional buildings are known for
their simple and utilitarian forms. Because traditional structures were built
by hand, elaborate shapes or complex forms were avoided due to labor and cost
implications. Structures must be distilled to a simple massing composed of one
or more rectangular forms.
   (D)   Legible hierarchy and order of elements. Throughout the lowcountry,
features of traditional structures are generally arranged from most to least
important. The most important portions of the building are emphasized and
receive greater attention to detail. The least important portions recede or
receive simpler treatments. Likewise, new buildings must include primary
massing components (i.e., the dominant or central part of a building) and
secondary or tertiary massing components (i.e., areas that flank or link the
main portion of the building are considered less prominent areas).
   (E)   Harmonious proportions. Traditional structures utilize simple
proportions to optimize rationality and constructability. The use of proportion
in new construction must establish harmonious relationships between the massing
of the building and architectural elements. Simple proportional relationships
that contribute to visually pleasing and cohesive whole generally adhere to 1:
1, 3:2, and 5:2 ratios. Vertical orientation, where elements are taller than
they are wide, are preferred because they relate well to human scale and
perception.
   (F)   Consistent arrangement of elements. Traditional architecture arranges
openings, columns, and elements of the building in a manner that is based on
practicality, ease of construction, and time efficiency. Window openings must
be arranged regularly and symmetrical along a building face.
   (G)   Top, middle, and base. Vertical elements must be composed of a clearly
visible top, middle, and base. These three separate concepts are rooted in
classical patterns, provide order, and give articulation to a building.
Building elevations must clearly illustrate a visually pronounced first floor
or base level, a middle ground consisting of all floors above the base level,
and an articulated top consisting of the final floor or top level with defined
cornice or sloped roof profile.
   (H)   Relationship to the street. Traditionally, structures were placed and
arranged so that the most public portion of the building (e.g., the entrance)
orients outward toward the public realm (i.e., a street, park, plaza, or
private courtyard area connecting to a street). The front of buildings must be
arranged to create a strong and discernible connection with the public realm.
   (I)   Relationship to environs. Lowcountry vernacular architecture responds
to and connects with the natural environment and regional climate. Building
placement, orientation to the sun, natural light and ventilation, materiality,
and shading all lend toward developing a strong sense of character that is
unique to Mount Pleasant vernacular. New construction must incorporate elements
that relate well to the natural setting and climate.
   (J)   Materials and detailing. Primary building materials were limited to
those readily available in the area–predominantly wood and some brick. Roofs
generally feature a hipped or gabled roof, often with broad eave overhangs and
exposed rafter tails or fascia trim. Boxed eaves, when present, feature a
traditional pedimented gable or return detail. Roofing materials are
historically metal standing seam or 5-V crimp and later shingles. Windows are
abundant for light and ventilation. Window shapes and panes are taller than
wide. Windows occur as singles, pairs or, in some instances, triples with a
single, wide “picture frame” trim. Decorative trim and detailing is generally
limited to the pedestrian areas of the building, such as display windows and
entry elements, although some simple variations of cornice trim may be found at
the eaves and in the gables. Large porches are common at the primary entries,
with square wood columns that are often chamfered. Simple round Tuscan columns
were sometimes used but are primarily seen as later replacement columns.
   (K)   Vista and view shed. Lowcountry vernacular structures are generally
framed within their settings, often incorporating large trees and roadways into
a visual experience. Where it is reasonably practical, proposed structures
shall not impede scenic views from the main road, from existing structures, or
from natural settings. Structures must strengthen and maintain vistas and view
sheds.
   (L)   Relationship to adjacent structures. Although maximum site densities
and special site requirements defined for particular use districts shall be
preserved, proposed structures shall not dominate, in an incompatible manner,
an adjacent building, nor in surrounding general development substantially in
compliance with this chapter.
   (M)   Cohesive design. Cohesive design elements create harmony through
related massing, scale, proportion, detail, materials, color, site planning,
and landscaping.
      (1)   All elevations of a structure shall be in harmony with one another
in terms of scale, proportion, detail, material, and color. The side and rear
elevations of buildings shall be as visually attractive as the front elevation.
Rooflines and architectural detailing shall present a consistency in quality
design.
      (2)   All buildings and structures within a proposed development,
including canopies, shall utilize a unifying architectural theme and be uniform
in character in order to create a harmonious whole. However, it is not to be
inferred that buildings must look alike to achieve a harmony of style. The
scale of buildings and accessory structures (including canopies) shall be
appropriate to the scale of structures located in the surrounding area.
Canopies designed as domineering or overpowering architectural features are not
allowed.
      (3)   The architecture, landscaping, and building siting must work in
concert to create a unified appearance that contributes to the existing/
developing streetscape.
   (N)   Architectural compatibility.
      (1)   The architectural design and material finish of buildings, signage,
gasoline pump canopies, and other necessary structures shall be compatible with
one another, and with adjacent and surrounding structures where such structures
are substantially in compliance with this section.
      (2)   In reviewing a proposed structure, specific considerations shall be
given to its compatibility with adjacent structures.
      (3)   Proposed structures shall be shown to scale, in a streetscape view
with adjacent buildings, by using elevations or, in certain instances,
photographs, of adjacent structures.
   (O)   Local design quality. Structures that are of symbolic design for
reasons of advertising, corporate identity or corporate continuity shall be
highly discouraged; however, the Design Review Board or staff may work with
applicants to incorporate limited signature design elements into buildings, to
allow recognition of certain corporate or signature identity, while still
retaining the ability to achieve a project design unique to Mount Pleasant.
Similarly, prototype architecture is prohibited; however, the Design Review
Board or staff may work with applicants to incorporate limited signature design
elements into buildings, to allow recognition of certain corporate or signature
identity, while still retaining the ability to achieve a project design unique
to Mount Pleasant.
   (P)   Prohibited architectural styles. Colonial, Classical, Victorian,
Bauhaus, mid-20th Century modern, and/or formal architectural styles and
designs are prohibited. The form may be based on historical models; however,
the formal detailing of the historical period styles should be absent or
extremely simple when present.
   (Q)   Consideration for contemporary architectural treatments. Contemporary
architectural treatments, as demonstrated in Figure 156.883-1: Contemporary Use
of Vernacular Design and Elements below, shall not be prohibited where it
maintains the traditional form, massing, design elements, materials, and
adherence to design principles of Mount Pleasant vernacular or lowcountry
vernacular, and arranges the components in a new and/or modern way such that
the basic nature and form of the traditional architecture is clearly visible
and compatible with surrounding structures and sites. Commercial buildings
should reflect and incorporate traditional characteristics and patterns with
simple modifications made to accommodate emerging market trends and commercial
activities.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13056.png]
 
   (R )   Consideration for taller buildings. Structures that are excessively
wide and tall are not consistent with Mount Pleasant vernacular and lowcountry
vernacular tradition. Vernacular structures were generally no taller than 38 -
40 feet, given the sum of heights of the base, floor-to-floor levels, and roof
of a traditional two-story structure. Therefore, modern buildings generally
taller than three stories and 45 feet should employ traditional design
principles to mitigate excessive massing and scale of building elements and
relate to traditional form and models. Specific design standards that include
parameters for taller buildings are noted in §§
156.892,
156.894, and
156.898(C).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.884 THROUGH 156.889 RESERVED.
PART 2: BUILDING DESIGN STANDARDS
§ 156.890 GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   (A)   Purpose. The architectural compatibility and aesthetic harmony of
commercial buildings within the Town of Mount Pleasant are of critical
importance in protecting and promoting the appearance, character and economic
value of land, in addition to protecting the public from the impact of adverse
visual experienc es. The intent of the design review process is to assure
respect for the character, integrity, and quality of the built and natural
environments of the town; it is not intended to stifle innovative architecture.
   (B)   Applicability. Building design standards apply to all areas described
in §
156.881.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.891 BUILDING SETBACK.
   The setback distances from lot lines having street frontage shall be
determined during the design review process, utilizing a build-to line between
20 and 30 feet, measured from the lot line.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.892 BUILDING STEP-BACK.
   Proposed buildings taller than three stories and 45 feet must provide a
building step-back along the primary street or right-of-way as follows:
   (A)   The building step-back must contain a minimum depth of ten feet and
occur at some point between the first and fourth levels of the building. See
Figure 156.892-1: Building Step-Back.
   (B)   Structures should step-back the upper portions of the building so as
to avoid their becoming the dominant element of the building.
Figure 156.892-1: Building Step-Back
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13058.png]
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.893 PRIMARY FAÇADE AND ENTRY ORIENTATION.
   (A)   All buildings shall have a primary façade, facing the primary street
or right-of-way. See
Figure 156.893-1: Primary Façade.
   (B)   Along primary arterials, such as Highway 17 North, Johnnie Dodds
Boulevard, and Coleman Boulevard, primary building entrances shall be located
facing the primary street and/or at the corner for buildings located at an
intersection. Exceptions may be made in consideration of such conditions as
differences in elevation of the adjacent street and subject property, and the
presence of abutting frontage roads.
   (C)   All buildings located at intersections or corner properties, including
entry drives to shopping centers and/or developments, shall be located at the
corner adjacent to the intersection.
   (D)   Porches or porticos are encouraged to define entryways into buildings
and primary façades.
Figure 156.893-1: Primary Façade
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13060.png]
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.894 TOP, MIDDLE, AND BASE.
   (A)   All buildings shall be composed of distinct base, middle, and top
sections as demonstrated below. See
Figure 156.894-1: Top, Middle, and Base of Buildings.
   (B)   Base.
      (1)   For single-story buildings, the base may be articulated by the
foundation, knee walls, or other architectural features such as bulkheads or
trim used to transition the wall plane to the ground plane.
      (2)   For buildings taller than three stories and 45 feet, the base may
consist of the full first level of the building. The base of such buildings
shall be visually pronounced and clearly delineated from the remaining portions
of the building, distinguished by identifiable features such as but not limited
to a separate building material, portico, shopfront, or separate area with
sloping roof, significant change in vertical proportion of openings.
   (C)   Middle.
      (1)   For single-story buildings, the middle portion of the building
shall consist of the wall plane between the foundation and the roof structure.
      (2)   For buildings taller than three stories and 45 feet, the middle
portion of the building shall consist of upper floor levels between the first
level and top of the building.
   (D)   Top.
      (1)   For single-story buildings, the top shall be articulated by how the
wall plane transitions to the roof structure, including:
         (a)   Wall detailing as described in §
156.896; and
         (b)   Roof form as described in §
156.898
      (2)   For buildings taller than three stories and 45 feet, the upper-most
level of the building shall be considered part of the top and be distinguished
from the lower portions of the building through identifiable design elements,
such as window treatment and wall plane detailing. Buildings taller than three
stories and 45 feet shall include a highly defined cornice or roof profile as
described in §
156.898(C).
Figure 156.894-1: Top, Middle, and Base of Buildings
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13062.png]
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.895 MASSING.
   Buildings and structures shall break down the massing of the building into
simple forms to harmonize with traditional vernacular forms and models. See
Figure 156.895-1: Traditional Vernacular Forms.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13064.png]
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.896 WALL PLANES.
   (A)   Avoid long façades.
      (1)   Long, monotonous façade design, including but not limited to, those
characterized by unrelieved repetition of shape or form, or by unbroken
extensions of a line, are prohibited.
      (2)   Long façades shall break the cornice, parapet, and roof to reduce
massing.
      (3)   Façades shall utilize offsets in wall plane and offsets in building
footprints to differentiate building masses, forms and/or components. Depths of
offsets shall be in proportion to the size of the façade and shall not be
smaller than one foot in depth between adjacent wall planes.
   (B)   Wall plane detailing. Control joints, score lines, gutters and/or
downspouts, or similar building elements or details shall not be used to
express articulation or to differentiate building masses and forms, or to
create sign bands or express other details.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13066.png]
 
   (C)   Parapet walls.
      (1)   Parapet walls must be broken between building elements and/ or
design elements to reinforce the individual building forms and elements, and to
break the horizontal line of the building.
      (2)   Projecting parapets, where allowed, must have return/depth.
      (3)   Refer to Figure 156.896-2: Parapet Walls for examples.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13068.png]
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.897 MATERIALS.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   Material integrity. Materials shall express their function clearly
and honestly and shall not appear as materials that are foreign to the
character of the rest of the building.
      (2)   Consistency of materials. Any building exterior elevation shall
consist of architectural materials that are equal in quality, appearance, and
detail to all other exterior elevations of the same structure.
      (3)   Prohibited materials.
         (a)   No portion of a building may be constructed of unadorned
concrete masonry units or corrugated and/or sheet metal.
         (b)   Paint and/or similar finish is not considered an adornment.
         (c)   Nothing in this section precludes the use of architectural metal
cladding, which may be incorporated into the overall building composition when
used as an architectural accent and when found to meet the intent of this
section. Such architectural cladding will exhibit features, such as quality
architectural materials, a natural or high quality fluoropolymer finish, and
concealed fasteners.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13070.png]
         (d)   However, in areas zoned LI, Light Industrial District, or for LI
District uses located within PD, Planned Development Districts, the above
materials may be used on buildings or portions of buildings that are not
visible from any public right-of-way or from any differently zoned property.
   (B)   Primary building materials.
      (1)   Primary building materials shall be wood.
      (2)   Cementitious and other synthetic materials may be used to
facilitate the appearance of wood lap siding, vertical board and batten siding,
and/or machine sawn shingles. Real wood products may be used when in compliance
with the building code. For the purposes of this division, wood shall refer to
wood, cementitious siding, and other synthetic materials meant to facilitate
the appearance of wood siding as described herein.
      (3)   Stucco may be used as a primary building material only along
primary arterials, such as Highway 17 North, Johnnie Dodds Boulevard, and
Coleman Boulevard, and in Commercial Villages, such as Towne Centre, Irongate
Plaza, The Market at Oakland, and Seaside Farms. Stucco may also be used on
civic structures such as churches and government buildings.
   (C)   Secondary building materials.
      (1)   Buildings taller than three stories and 45 feet may use masonry,
cementitious, or stone material as a secondary building material. See Figure
156.897-2: Use of Stucco-like Material.
      (2)   Stucco or materials similar in appearance or texture may be used in
"voids" or reveals between brick building masses but shall not constitute more
than 50% of the area of a building façade.
      (3)   Stucco or materials similar in appearance or texture may be used
for details such as sills, lintels, and cornice features, including
clerestories.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13072.png]
      (4)   Cast or natural finished stone may be used as decorative detailing
at the base or as lintels and/or sills and cornice features.
      (5)   Materials in the middle and top portions of the building shall
appear lighter than the base material so that heavier materials are located to
the bottom of lighter materials. For example, brick or stone should be provided
below wood or stucco.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13074.png]
   (D)   Base of wooden buildings. The base of wood structures shall consist of
a wooden base trim.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13077.png]
   (E)   Base of masonry buildings. The base of masonry buildings and
structures shall consist of a watertable of the same material, expressed by
either a projecting base or a recessed or projecting beltcourse or stringer
course between the middle and base.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13079.png]
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.898 ROOF FORM.
   (A)   Predominant roof form. Roof forms, including gasoline canopies and all
other structures, shall be simple gable or hip designs.
   (B)   Roof pitch.
      (1)   Roof pitch may be of a moderate, varied, or low slope.
      (2)   Roof pitch shall be proportional to the building design, mass, and
form.
      (3)   Split pitch roofs, or bellcast/flared eaves, may be used where the
lower portion of the roof takes on flatter pitch, in order to cast water
further from the structure.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13081.png]
   (C)   Roof profile of taller structures. Buildings taller than three stories
and 45 feet shall include a highly defined cornice or sloped roof with broad
overhangs, to create a strong and identifiable roof profile as viewed from the
street.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13083.png]
   (D)   Prohibited roof forms.
      (1)   Mansard roofs are prohibited.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13085.png]
      (2)   Unbroken roof lines. Long, monotonous roof design, including but
not limited to, those characterized by unrelieved repetition of shape or form,
or by unbroken extension of line, shall not be permitted.
      (3)   Flat roofs.
         (a)   Flat roofs are prohibited, except when provisions are made for
outdoor mechanical wells and similar types of equipment, as follows.
         (b)   On buildings requiring flat roofs for roof-mounted mechanical
equipment, a flat roof section may be attached to the rear of the building,
with a pitched roof over the front portion of the building so that the flat
roof area appears to be a later addition. Buildings may create a flat roof area
between pitched elements, where the pitched elements completely screen the
mechanical equipment from view. Hipped or gabled roofs with a mechanical roof
well will not be considered mansard roofs, when the roof appears to be a true
hipped or gabled design.
   (E)   Eaves. Gable or hip roofs shall have broad eave overhangs proportioned
to the building.
   (F)   Roof elaborations.
      (1)   Cupolas, widow's walks, and other roof appurtenances, such as
domes, are not allowed; provided, however, that civic buildings, such as
churches, may incorporate these elements when appropriate to the design theme
of the structure.
      (2)   Roof appurtenances, such as dormers, roof monitors, light wells,
and mechanical vents, shall be gabled, hipped, or shed designs, and shall
function as true elements not used for aesthetic purposes only.
      (3)   Tower elements are strongly discouraged. Tower elements may not be
substituted in lieu of, nor considered as, pitched roof elements in order to
meet the requirements of this division.
   (G)   Cornice and eave details.
      (1)   Cornice, eaves, and/or gable trim must have a traditional return.
See Figure 156.898-4: Cornice/Eave Return.
      (2)   Boxed eaves trim are prohibited.
      (3)   Trim or cornice detailing must match at the returns into other
elements.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13087.png]
   (H)   Roof material. Shingles, metal, standing seam, corrugated or 5-
V crimp, or other roofing materials with similar appropriate texture and
appearance shall be utilized.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.899 WINDOWS.
   (A)   Vertical orientation. Windows shall utilize traditional proportions
and be taller than wide.
   (B)   Inset windows. Windows must not be flush with the exterior wall but
must be inset in a traditional manner.
   (C)   Lintel and sill. All windows shall have an expressed lintel and sill;
provided, however, that first floor display, storefront systems, or full-length
windows terminating at building grade or finished floor elevation do not
require a sill.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13089.png]
   (D)   Shopfront windows.
      (1)   Picture and/or display windows are required along the first floor
of retail buildings within every structural bay but shall be no less than every
25 feet along the primary street or right-of-way façade.
      (2)   Window openings shall be greater than 40% of the first-floor wall
area of retail buildings along the primary street or right-of-way façade.
      (3)   However, exceptions may be made, in consideration of such
conditions as differences in elevation of the adjacent street and subject
property,
the presence of abutting frontage roads, and the width of adjacent roadside
buffer, to exempt retail buildings from the 40% first floor window requirement.
Buildings will still need to maintain a primary building façade along the
primary street or right-of-way as required in §
156.893.
      (4)   Picture and/or display windows must always remain open to view from
the exterior, and may not be covered, screened, blocked, or diminished in any
manner for a distance of three feet inside the window. A minimum of 20% of
first floor windows must be picture windows to reveal interior activity.
   (E)   Design of hurricane protection. Hurricane protection of windows shall
be integral to the design of the building or shall utilize subtle attachment
methods that do not detract from its architectural or visual character.
Exterior mounted roll-up hurricane shutters are prohibited. Impact-resistant
glazing is encouraged.
   (F)   Window type specifications.
      (1)   Half-round arched windows shall be prohibited.
      (2)   Segmented, jack, or flat arches may be incorporated when
appropriate to the design of the structure.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13091.png]
      (3)   Spandrel glass is only allowed as glazing in front of interstitial
space on multi-story buildings. Spandrel glass is prohibited on the ground
floor of a structure.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13093.png]
      (4)   Glass shall be clear, grey, or green, and may not be tinted greater
than 30%. Awnings and/or canopies shall be used to shade windows, if shading is
desired.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.900 COLUMNS.
   Columns, including those supporting a gasoline canopy and other canopies and
accessory structures, shall be either square, square with chamfers, square
tapered, or round Tuscan style with entasis, whichever style is most
appropriate for the architectural theme of the structure. Columns shall exhibit
a base and capital, and visibly support an entablature.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.901 AWNINGS, CANOPIES, AND BALCONIES.
   (A)   Awning material. All awnings must be canvas, cloth, or similar
material. Stretched vinyl or materials similar in material, texture, or
appearance are prohibited.
   (B)   Awning attachment.
      (1)   The top of all awning structures must be attached above window
openings so as to protect pedestrians from the elements below.
      (2)   Awnings must project a minimum of three feet from the face of the
building.
      (3)   The bottom of the awning shall not be located higher than ten feet
from grade.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13095.png]
   (C)   Illumination prohibited. Awnings and canopies shall not be
illuminated.
   (D)   Canopy location. Canopies are allowed where appropriate to the design
theme and materials of the structure.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13097.png]
   ( E )    Canopy material. Canopies shall have metal roofing, translucent
roof panels and/or glass roofing, whichever is most appropriate to the design
theme of the structure.
   (F)   Canopy structure.
      (1)   The support structure shall be wood or metal, whichever is most
appropriate to the design theme of the structure.
      ( 2)    Metal suppo rting mem bers shall utilize escutcheons.
   (G)   Protection from elements. Both awnings and canopies shall be designed
to protect pedestrians from the weather and/or provide shade for windows.
   (H)   Arcades. Arcades are prohibited.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13099.png]
   (I)   Balconies. Balconies must function as true, functional balconies, and
shall not be used for aesthetic purposes only.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.902 SIGN BANDS.
   (A)   Sign band area. Sign bands and/or sign areas shall be designed into
the façades of all retail buildings. Sign bands and/or sign areas on other
building types and structures shall be similarly considered and be integral to
the composition of the façade. Building signs shall be limited to the sign band
and/or sign areas of buildings and may not extend beyond the limits of sign
band and/or sign area, where such buildings are in compliance with this
section.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13101.png]
   (B)   Sign location. The location and dimension of wall signs shall be
indicated on the architectural elevations of proposed structures and shall
maintain compatibility with the architectural features of the structure.
   (C)   Sign approval. Approval of architectural plans with signs or sign
areas shown on the building shall not constitute sign approval. A separate
application for a sign permit must be submitted for sign approval as required
by
Subchapter I, Part 7.
   (D)   Symbols. A symbol or symbols attached to a building shall not be
allowed unless it is secondary in appearance to the structure and landscape and
is an aesthetic asset to the building and surrounding area. Where such symbols
are allowed, they shall count towards the allowable sign area of the building.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.903 SCREENING OF MECHANICAL EQUIPMENT.
   (A)   Mechanical equipment, including exhaust hoods and grease traps,
whether ground level, raised or rooftop, shall be shielded and screened from
public view, and designed to be perceived as an integral part of the building.
   (B)    Roof-mounted equipment shall not be located on the primary street or
right-of-way side of a building. All roof-mounted equipment shall be screened
from public view.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.904 COLORS.
   (A)   Color combinations of paints or stains shall be complementary.
   (B)   In no case shall garish colors be permitted.
   (C)   In general, no more than three different colors per building shall be
allowed, not including a neutral trim color.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.905 THROUGH 156.914 RESERVED.
PART 3: SITE DESIGN STANDARDS
SUBPART 3.1: SITING OF BUILDINGS AND PARKING AREAS
§ 156.915 PURPOSE.
   This subpart pertains to general siting of buildings and parking areas and
shall be used to preserve natural vistas and extend viewing corridors through
better design and structure placement.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.916 APPLICABILITY.
   This subpart applies to all areas described in §
156.881.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.917 PARKING LOT AREAS AND FACILITIES.
   (A)   The placement of the major portion of a proposed development's parking
area must be to the rear of a main structure's corridor façade, or within a
vehicular courtyard surrounded on three sides by a proposed structure.
   (B)   The rationale for this standard is to promote proportional and spatial
definition of corridors, to be accomplished through prioritizing placement of
buildings and landscaping over parking areas.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.918 THROUGH 156.924 RESERVED.
SUBPART 3.2: ACCESS AND CONNECTIVITY
§ 156.925 GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   (A)   Purpose. This part pertains to the town’s access management and
overall connectivity and shall be used to ensure public access, accommodate
future transit stops and opportunities, and improve the mobility through
pedestrian and vehicular interconnectivity, including streets, parking lots,
sidewalks, paths, and multi-use trails.
   (B)   Applicability.
      (1)   This subpart applies to all areas described in §
156.881.
      (2)   Land development regulations. §
155.049 applies in addition to the standards in this subpart.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.926 PEDESTRIAN ACCESS, CROSSWALKS, AND SIDEWALKS.
   (A)   New development, subdivisions, and renovations. New developments,
subdivisions, and renovations shall provide appropriate pedestrian access,
either through the construction of concrete sidewalks or pedestrian path/
bikeway systems, or a combination of both. Requirements for pedestrian access
shall be in accordance with the following table.
