   (B)   Non-residential and mixed-use areas.
      (1)   Generally. In all cases, ease of pedestrian access between proposed
developments and adjacent developments shall be demonstrated in the development
of a proposed project's site and circulation plans.
      (2)   Crosswalks and mid-block crossings.
         (a)   Crosswalks shall be prominently designed, and located at street
intersections, the intersection of parking lot entrances with abutting streets,
and in other locations where pedestrians are invited to cross vehicular areas
such as mid-block crossings.
         (b)   The texture and/or color of their paving material shall contrast
with that of the street.
         (c)   Raised pedestrian crosswalks (speed tables) may be utilized and
are encouraged as a traffic-calming device in areas containing both high
pedestrian activity and long, unbroken vehicular straightaways.
         (d)   Crosswalks made of entirely thermoplastic or painted lines are
not allowed unless part of another governmental agency's requirements. However,
thermoplastic may be used as a border to a stamped and painted asphalt product
serving as the field or interior of the crosswalk.
      (3)   Internal crosswalks for commercial projects.
         (a)   Where crosswalks are required within a commercial center,
uninterrupted travel-way sections of more than three lanes shall be avoided.
         (b)   Uninterrupted travel-way sections of more than four lanes shall
not be allowed.
         (c)   Where wider travel-way sections are required, curb bump outs,
medians and other design features shall be employed to ease pedestrian crossing
at intersections.
         (d)   When medians are used to break a travel-way section of four or
more lanes, they shall be at least five feet in width, from back of curb to
back of curb, allowing an adequate and safe resting zone for crossing
pedestrians, and allowing room for canopy tree plantings to contribute to the
streetscape, break the expanse of asphalt, and reduce the scale of the travel-
way.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13103.png]
          (e)    The above provisions shall apply to private streets, access
ways, and portion s of parking lots that functio n as streets.
      (4)    Sidewalks.
          (a)    Sidewalk connect ions are require d between the developm ent
walkway system and the public sidewalk, which shall be strategically placed to
best facilitate movement from the entrance(s) of development building(s) to the
public sidewalk.
         (b)   Commercial projects fronting streets currently without public
sidewalks shall provide a minimum-five-foot sidewalk within the road right-of-
way.
         (c)   Corner developments or those that otherwise front multiple
streets shall provide a public sidewalk in the right-of-way on street(s)
currently without a sidewalk.
         (d)   In unique cases where a sidewalk cannot be in part or fully
provided on the right-of-way, a public sidewalk shall be provided, in part or
in full, on private property with a public access easement provided to cover
that portion of sidewalk on private property.
Figure 156.926-2: Medians
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13105.png]
         (e)    Corner developments or those that otherwise front multiple
streets shall provide a sidewalk connection to all streets.
         (f)   Projects containing multiple buildings on a particular street
frontage shall provide multiple points of connection to the public sidewalk.
      (5)   Shared-use paths. Development and redevelopment on properties
abutting existing or planned shared-use paths must accommodate a minimum of
eight feet in width, with a preferred width of ten feet, for a continuous,
separated facility.
      (6)   Bike lanes and shared lanes. Development and redevelopment on
properties abutting existing or planned bike lanes and shared lanes must
integrate design capacity to support a continuous bike facility.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.927 VEHICULAR ACCESS.
   ( A)    Access drives.
      ( 1)    Acce ss drives include public streets, rights-of-way, private
streets, access ways, and portions of parking lots that function as streets or
thoroughfares.
      (2)   The location of access drives shall be determined through the
encroachment permit process or design review process, whichever is applicable,
with the appropriate right-of-way owner or governing jurisdiction, using the
most current edition of the South Carolina Department of Transportation Access
and Roadside Management Standards (ARMS Manual) or other appropriate standard
as determined by the governing agency.
   (B)   Visibility triangle. Fences, walls, shrubbery, or other obstructions
to travel vision are prohibited.
   (C)   Curb cuts.
      (1)   No more than one curb cut is allowed per 250 feet.
      (2)   Shared access is required when there is less than 250 feet of
frontage.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.928 INTERNAL ACCESS ROADS.
   (A)   In order facilitate the replication of a grid street pattern and
enhance the streetscape appearance for non-residential and mixed-use
developments where no public street is dedicated, internal access roads are
required whenever site design characteristics reasonably allow them on all
larger parcels and smaller parcels that have been aggregated.
   (B)   These roads shall be designed to appear and function as a public
street. Privately owned access roads must be owner-maintained.
   (C)   Sidewalks and on-street parking are required. On-street parking spaces
on internal access roads may count towards required parking. Buildings should
address these internal access roads in the same manner as a public street with
respect to orientation, setbacks, and bufferyard requirements.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.929 ACCESS EASEMENTS.
   (A)   Where interconnectivity is proposed, access easements shall be
provided from a public right-of-way to the property line of the adjacent
property it is meant to serve.
   (B)   Where a final plat is required, easements shall be provided prior to
final plat approval. For developments that do not require a final plat,
easements shall be provided prior to issuance of any building permits for the
development.
   (C)   Easements shall provide for unencumbered access by the adjoining
property owner(s) and the public through the property in perpetuity, or until
such time as the property is redeveloped and the easement is no longer
required.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.930 DRIVE-THROUGH AND DRIVE-UP USES.
   (A)   Drive-through access. Drive-through access shall be integrally
designed with the building, and shall not dominate the design generally or wrap
around the street side(s) of the building; provided, however, that exceptions
may be made in consideration of such conditions as differences in elevation of
the adjacent street and subject property, historic tree location, the presence
of abutting frontage roads, and the width of adjacent roadside buffers; and
further provided that the following provisions hereunder shall apply, except
that drive-through access and parking areas are prohibited in the activity zone
of properties.
   (B)   Banks (or similar financial institutions), post offices, or utility
company offices.
      (1)   Multi-lane, drive-through access is allowed, but is limited to no
more than four lanes, including a by-pass lane.
      (2)   Such uses are encouraged to provide hybrid lanes, which may
accommodate two functions per lane such as a tube and an ATM (See
Figure 156.926-2: Medians).
      (3)   Drive-through medians containing tubes or other equipment shall
extend beyond the canopy above and be left open as planters, with a width no
less than 30 inches wide, as measured between the back of curb on each side, to
provide the opportunity for plant material to serve in place of bollards and
reduce the expanse of asphalt.
      (4)   Paved areas approaching and exiting the drive-through area shall be
narrowed to the best extent possible.
   (C)   Gas stations and similar pump-dispensed uses.
      (1)   Gasoline and other chemical pump dispensers, and any canopies
covering the dispensers, shall be located to the side of, or behind, the
building so that it is between the pumps and the primary street frontage.
      (2)   If located on a corner lot, the building must be situated in the
corner of the lot at the intersection.
      (3)   Drive-through medians containing dispensing pumps or other
equipment shall extend beyond the canopy above and be left open as planters,
with a width no less than 30 inches wide, as measured between the back of curb
on each side, to provide the opportunity for plant material to serve in place
of bollards and to reduce the expanse of asphalt.
      (4)   Accessory buildings, vacuum units, air stations, ice chests and the
like shall be shown on the site plans for approval and shall be sited in such a
way as to allow screening and not disrupt pedestrian flow on sidewalks. In no
case shall they contain garish colors on emblems, stickers, or other visible
means of attracting attention.
   (D)   Pharmacy, fast food restaurant, and similar uses. These uses may
utilize a single drive-through access lane and/or a single row of parking, with
a two-way drive aisle located between the building and the primary street
frontage, pursuant to the following conditions:
      (1)   The drive-through pick-up window shall not be located on the
primary street;
      (2)   The drive-through access isle and parking shall be suitably
screened from view, with a structure such as a pierced-brick wall and/or a
vegetated hedge of single- or double-row vegetation. Because individual
building sites vary and to provide variety in design, these treatments will be
determined during the design review process;
      (3)   The plant unit multiplier shall be 1.5 for required vegetation,
except as stated above, if a hedge screening treatment is utilized, and the
canopy trees utilized shall be from the list as provided in §
156.585;
      (4)   Double- or multi-lane drive-through access is allowed elsewhere on
the site, but not between the building and the primary street frontage;
      (5)   The drive-through lanes and access aisle(s) shall be considered
separately and will not be limited to a 24-foot-total width of paving; and
      (6)   Paved areas approaching and exiting the drive-through area shall be
narrowed to the best extent possible.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.931 THROUGH 156.939 RESERVED.
SUBPART 3.3: SITE COMPONENTS
§ 156.940 GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   (A)   Purpose. This part addresses miscellaneous site elements and
associated design standards.
   (B)   Applicability. This subpart applies to all areas described in §
156.881.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.941 UTILITIES.
   (A)   The necessity for utility connections, meter boxes, and similar
elements should be recognized and integrated with the architectural elements of
the site plan, proposed landscaping, and general site layout.
   (B)   All utility lines, such as electric, telephone, CATV, or similar lines
serving individual sites, as well as all utility lines necessary within the
property, shall be placed underground in accordance with the following
provisions:
      (1)   Existing aerial lines may be maintained in their present location
and configuration, but there shall be no net gain in additional aerial lines
when providing new service.
      (2)   Where development requires existing aerial lines to be relocated,
they will then be required to be placed underground.
      (3)   Properties to be serviced from existing aerial distribution lines
located across a street shall be required to bore beneath roads to reach the
proposed development and shall not cross a street with an aerial line to set a
dip pole to serve the proposed development.
      (4)   In cases of off-site connections, additional survey information is
required to adequately address potential off-site impacts.
   (C)   Where these off-site impacts occur within another jurisdiction, such
as Charleston County, approval of utility installation shall be furnished to
the town prior to receiving approval.
   (D)   All utility pad fixtures and meters shall be shown on the proposed
site plans, and shall include:
      (1)   Method of installation;
      (2)   Location of connection to existing facilities;
      (3)   Size of cabinet or box;
      (4)   Direction of door swings on applicable cabinets;
      (5)   Proposed easements associated with the new utility installation;
and
      (6)   Direction of access to service the fixture.
   (E)   All utility cabinets and other similar aboveground structures shall be
screened with appropriate landscaping, as approved by designated reviewing
authority and the pertinent utility agencies, from all sides that are visible
from a public or private street, access way, and portions of parking lots that
function as streets or thoroughfares.
   (F)   Whenever possible, utility boxes shall be located in areas that will
not require bollards for their protection.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.942 SHOPPING CART STORAGE.
   (A)   Generally. In general, carts are encouraged to be stored inside the
building. However, if outdoor storage of carts is intended, an enclosure is
required that does not impede lateral or direct pedestrian traffic to the
subject building or adjacent buildings.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13107.png]
   (B)   Shopping cart corrals located in parking areas.
      (1)   Typical prefabricated pipe or plastic enclosures placed in a
parking space shall not be allowed; rather, corral enclosures shall be
incorporated into a parking lot planter island, with concrete curbing outlining
the storage area.
      (2)   To the degree possible, the corral shall be designed to retain the
minimum required planter island size and shall be roughly centered in one side
of the island, leaving two narrow peninsular islands forming the sides of the
enclosure.
      (3)   For island configurations of other proportions, the designated
reviewing authority shall have the flexibility to allow other and similar tree
planting requirements as needed to suit the condition.
      (4)   Landscape treatments shall be dictated by the size and
configuration of the planter island parking corral, but in all cases shall
generally correspond to the graphic representation below.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13109.png]
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.943 MAILBOXES, OUTDOOR SALES RACKS, AND SIMILAR ITEMS.
   (A)   Mailboxes, outdoor sales racks, and similar items shall be shown on
site plans and have cut sheets provided to convey the sizes, colors, finishes
and the like of each item.
   (B)   These items shall be placed in areas so as to not impede pedestrian
access or landscape maintenance.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.944 OUTDOOR FURNITURE.
   Outdoor furniture includes benches, water fountains, bicycle racks, refuse
containers, and other forms of outdoor furniture shall be shown on all site
plans, with the number and placement of fixtures evaluated with respect to:
   (A)   Style size, color, material, and finish;
   (B)   Consistency of style within a development; and
   (C)   Strategic locations within the development layout.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.945 BOLLARDS.
   (A)   The use of bollards is strongly discouraged.
   (B)   Alternative methods of structure protection shall be employed wherever
possible, such as:
      (1)   Site redesign to increase distance from the travel aisle to the
structure to be protected; or
      (2)   The use of landscaping and/or other structures, such as trash cans,
benches, steps and the like, that will provide varying levels of protection.
   (C)   In cases where the above remedies are impractical, the following
treatments may be utilized, in order of preference:
      (1)   Decorative concrete bollards, with detail expressed from the
architecture of the building; and to the extent possible, so designed as a site
amenity able to accommodate dual uses, such as seating, incorporation of
plantings, trash enclosures, public art, lighting and the like; or
      (2)   Pipe bollards provided that they are no taller than 36 inches, no
more than five inches in diameter, and painted black or a color to match an
adjacent site or building element.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.946 LOADING AREAS, SERVICE COURTYARDS, AND DUMPSTERS.
   (A)   Structures shall be oriented so that loading areas, service
courtyards, and/or dumpsters are in no manner visible from residential
districts or from existing or planned future public rights-of-way. Loading
areas and service courtyards shall be screened from view by the use of a wall
that is compatible with the overall architectural scheme of the project and
appropriately landscaped.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13111.png]
   (B)   Loading areas may be oriented toward adjoining commercially zoned,
developed properties, or toward adjoining properties eligible for future
commercial development, if they are entirely screened from view by the use of a
wall that is compatible with the overall architectural scheme of the project
and appropriately landscaped.
   (C)   Service areas, vehicle repair, installation facilities, or service
facilities with roll-up or service doors facing an existing right-of-way or
proposed or future street or public right-of-way must use glass doors to create
the appearance of storefront units consistent with the concepts expressed in
Subchapter H, Part 2. Provided, however, that exceptions may be made in
consideration of such conditions as differences in elevation of the adjacent
street and subject property, the presence of abutting frontage roads, and the
width of adjacent roadside buffers.
   (D)   Vehicles, mobile units, and containers which provide a temporary or
permanent service for a business must be screened in accordance with this
section.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.947 SCREENING FOR ENCLOSURES.
   (A)    Screening for dumpster and roll-out trash can enclosure s, HVAC,
generator s, compacto rs, and other similar elements shall be:
      (1)    Clearly indicated on the project site plan; and
      (2)   Screened from view, in an enclosure built entirely of masonry or
wood infill walls between masonry columns, with enclosure detailing to match
the architecture of the building.
   (B)   HVAC units, generators and other similar elements shall be screened
with an appropriate enclosure constructed of materials to match the building.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.948 SATELLITE DISHES.
   (A)   All ground-mounted satellite dishes:
      (1)   Shall be shown on the project site plans;
      (2)   May not be located between building and street; and
      (3)   Shall be completely screened from view from the street or right-of-
way.
   (B)   All building- or structure-mounted satellite dishes shall be shown on
the architectural plans.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.949 TELECOMMUNICATION TOWERS AND ASSOCIATED GROUND-MOUNTED EQUIPMENT.
   (A)   A fence and/or wall is required to screen the equipment. However,
chain link fencing shall not be used to screen the equipment.
   (B)   Unless otherwise required by the Board of Zoning Appeals through
special exception approval, the designated reviewing authority may also require
the installation of 20-foot, Type C perimeter and right-of-way landscape
bufferyards.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.950 FREE-STANDING SIGNAGE.
   (A)   All free-standing signs shall be shown on the site plans and
landscaping adjusted to incorporate and accentuate the sign.
   (B)   The sign design shall have its text at an appropriate height and its
plantings appropriately designed to avoid maintenance conflicts with
landscaping.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.951 TRUNCATED DOMES (DETECTABLE WARNINGS).
   (A)   Prefabricated truncated dome mats are prohibited.
   (B)   Poured-in-place and imprinted concrete are strongly discouraged.
   (C)   Use of prefabricated pavers with truncated domes are preferred where
such detectable warnings are required. Consideration should be given to paver
joints being mortared. Paver color shall contrast with the walking surface
within which they are placed.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.952 THROUGH 156.964 RESERVED.
SUBPART 3.4: EXTERIOR LIGHTING
§ 156.965 PURPOSE.
   (A)   The purpose of this subchapter is to:
      (1)   Reduce the problems created by improperly designed and installed
exterior lighting;
      (2)   Eliminate glare, minimize light trespass and sky glow, and reduce
unnecessary excess exterior lighting by limiting lighting levels and
establishing design standards for all exterior lighting;
      (3)   Provide a safe and secure nighttime environment;
      (4)   Provide safe access into buildings; and
      (5)   Enhance historic or notable features, buildings, or architectural
elements.
   (B)   While intended to provide appropriate lighting levels for commercial
and apartment complex uses, this subchapter also requires that all exterior
fixtures be decorative in design and contribute to the aesthetic quality of the
development.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.966 EXEMPTIONS.
   The following types of exterior lighting are exempt from the requirements of
this subchapter:
   (A)   Lighting used only under emergency conditions;
   (B)   Traffic control signals and devices;
   (C)   Lighting for detached house dwellings, manufactured homes, duplex
dwellings, townhouse dwellings, triplex dwellings, and quadplex dwellings;
   (D)   Lighting solely used for signs;
   (E)   Lighting associated with an approved temporary use;
   (F)   Temporary lighting associated with a development site;
   (G)   Lighting for public monuments and statues;
   (H)   Underwater lighting in fountains, swimming pools, and other water
features;
   (I)   Lighting required pursuant to state and federal laws (e.g., FAA);
   (J)   Lighting required by the Building Code; and
   (K)   Seasonal lighting.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.967 PROHIBITED EXTERIOR LIGHTING.
   The following types of exterior lighting are prohibited:
   (A)   Exterior lighting resembling emergency signals. Exterior lighting that
contains reflectors or glaring, strobe, or rotating lights, beacons, beams, or
flashing illumination resembling an emergency signal.
   (B)   Searchlights, aerial lasers, and beacons. Searchlights, aerial lasers,
or any type of beacon used to attract attention to a property. This does not
prohibit the use of a searchlight by authorized personnel for emergency
purposes.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.968 GENERAL EXTERIOR LIGHTING STANDARDS.
   (A)   Lighting shall enhance the overall aesthetics of the site.
   (B)   Lighting shall be integrated with the architectural design of the
building and shall contribute to the landscaping effect.
   (C)   The type of lamp (e.g., LED, incandescent, fluorescent) selected shall
be consistent throughout the site.
   (D)   Lamps (bulbs) shall not be visible.
   (E)   If parking lots and vehicular use areas are lighted, the lighting must
comply with this subchapter.
   (F)   Security lighting shall be provided, particularly at pedestrian
walkways.
   (G)   Landscape lighting shall be designed to illuminate specific site
features using a concealed light source fixture that does not:
      (1)   Distort colors or structures;
      (2)   Spill over into adjoining properties and roadways; or
      (3)   In any way interfere with the vision of oncoming motorists.
   (H)   Timers, dimmers, or vacancy or motion sensors should be utilized when
continuous lighting is not needed for safety or operational purposes.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.969 UNIFORMITY.
   (A)   Uniformity ratios shall meet those established by the Illuminating
Engineering Society’s Lighting Library Standards, as assigned by activity or
use.
   (B)   When a particular activity or use is unlisted or is sufficiently
unclear, the Zoning Administrator shall assign a uniformity ratio.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.970 LIGHTING COLOR.
   (A)   Blue light emissions can be harmful to flora and fauna, and can result
in decreased nighttime visibility and increased skyglow. In order to minimize
blue light emission, warm spectrum, amber lighting shall be utilized rather
than cool spectrum, blue or white lighting, as specified in division (B) below.
   (B)   The correlated color temperature of all exterior lighting shall be
3,500 Kelvin (4000K) or lower, with tolerance within the ANSI standard C78.377
for LED sources.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.971 LIGHTING HEIGHT.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   Freestanding (ground-mounted) lighting equipment shall not exceed
18 feet in height from the average surrounding grade, except as otherwise
provided in this section.
      (2)   Building-mounted lighting equipment shall meet the height limit
specified in Subchapter B for the district in which the lighting is located.
   (B)   Luminaire mounted on pedestal.
      (1)   A luminaire located in a parking area may be mounted on top of a
pedestal (see example in Figure 156.971-1), if the pedestal is 36 inches or
less in height. The pedestal height is excluded from the height limit specified
in division (A) above.
      (2)   The pedestal must be similar in color and material to the principal
building on the site or as specified through the design review process.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13113.png]
   (C)   Maximum luminaire height in parking areas.
      (1)   Luminaires up to 25 feet in height may be located only in the
central areas of the parking lot; and
      (2)   Decorative luminaires up to 18 feet in height shall be utilized
along the primary vehicular and pedestrian corridors.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.972 BUILDING LIGHTING, BUILDING AREA LIGHTING, AND SERVICE AREA LIGHTING.
   (A)   Applicability. In addition to the general requirements established in
§
156.968, any lighting designed or intended to illuminate any exterior portion
of a building, its immediate surroundings, or service/loading areas shall meet
the requirements in this section.
   (B)   Ground-mounted lighting.
      (1)   Ground-mounted luminaires shall:
         (a)   Be shielded so that all of the light is focused on the building
façade; and
         (b)   Not exceed 100 lumens.
      (2)   Ground-mounted lighting equipment shall be placed no further than
20 feet away from the building.
   (C)   Building-mounted lighting.
      (1)   Lighting intended to illuminate the roof of a structure is strongly
discouraged.
      (2)   The placement of neon banding, string lights, or the like on any
portion of a building is prohibited.
      (3)   Fully-shielded wallpack-style fixtures are allowed in service/
loading areas of properties zoned LI District, except that when the service
area is highly visible from a street or any area with significant pedestrian
and automobile traffic, wallpacks are prohibited.
      (4)   All other lighting placed on the building itself shall:
         (a)   Be decorative in design; and
         (b)   Primarily complement the architecture and design themes
established for the site.
      (5)   The use of fully-shielded luminaires is encouraged for all lighting
placed on the building that is not specifically utilized for service areas.
   (D)   Gas stations, overhead canopies, and drive-through canopies.
      (1)   All lighting housed beneath the canopy shall be recessed or flush-
mounted with the canopy ceiling so that no portion of the light source extends
below ceiling plane.
      (2)   A drop lens is allowed and may extend below the ceiling plane no
further than two inches.
      (3)   The maximum to minimum uniformity ratio for the area beneath the
canopy shall not exceed 2:1.
   (E)   Automatic teller machines (ATMs).
      (1)   Lighting for ATMs shall not exceed IES-recommended levels for
security.
      (2)   Area lighting for ATMs shall extend for a radius not to exceed 50
feet from the face of the machine, or as determined through the design review
process.
      (3)   If the ATM is located under a canopy, the standards in division (D)
above also apply.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.973 POLE-MOUNTED LIGHTING.
   (A)   The light source in a pole-mounted luminaire shall be completely
concealed within an opaque housing, and shall not be visible from any adjacent
lot or public right-of-way.
   (B)   All pole-mounted luminaires shall be flush-mounted to existing grade,
except as provided in division (B)(2) below.
      (1)   Proper pole offsets from parking areas, curbing, and wheel stops
shall be used to prevent automobile and pole conflicts.
      (2)   If the pole cannot be adequately protected through these methods,
it may be mounted on a pedestal or bollard as provided in §
156.971(B).
   (C)   All lighting equipment and poles shall:
      (1)   Be decorative in design;
      (2)   Primarily complement the architecture and design themes established
for the site; and
      (3)   Not be incongruent with other design themes utilized by the
municipality.
   (D)   Pole-mounted lighting within service or loading areas may be required
to provide additional shielding so that the light is contained specifically
within the service or loading area.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.974 LIGHTING ZONES.
   (A)   Generally. §
156.975 regulates the amount of exterior lighting by district. Many zoning
districts have common characteristics for the purposes of exterior lighting
regulations, and this section combines the zoning districts subject to this
subchapter into common lighting zones. Table 156.974-1: Lighting Zones
designates the zoning districts included in each lighting zone.

   (B)   Description of lighting zones.
      (1)   Lighting Zone 1. Lighting Zone 1 (LZ 1) includes areas with low to
moderate ambient lighting levels. These typically include residential areas,
apartment complexes, institutional residential uses, neighborhood commercial
areas, neighborhood-serving recreational and playing fields, and mixed use
development with a predominance of residential uses.
      (2)   Lighting Zone 2. Lighting Zone 2 (LZ 2) includes areas with
moderately high lighting levels. These typically include commercial corridors,
suburban commercial areas, town centers, mixed use areas, industrial uses with
night time activity, high-use recreational and playing fields, car dealerships,
gas stations, and other retail areas active at nighttime.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.975 LIGHTING LEVELS.
   (A)   Individual lighting power allowances for building exteriors are
specified in the International Energy Conservation Code (IECC). The IECC
includes allowances for building entrances and exits as well as uncovered
parking areas, walkways, sales canopies, and outdoor sales areas.
   (B)   The IECC regulates exterior lighting by lighting zone, and generally
describes the types of uses in each lighting zone. §
156.974 establishes lighting zones specific to Mount Pleasant, which are
consistent with the lighting zones established in the IECC.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.976 LIMITS TO OFF SITE IMPACTS.
   (A)   Backlight, uplight, and glare (BUG) ratings.
      (1)   Generally. The three components of BUG ratings are based on the
Illuminating Engineering Society’s Technical Memorandum: Luminaire
Classification System for Outdoor Luminaires. Each component is assigned a
value between zero and five, with lower numbers indicating a luminaire emits
less light in a given direction. A zero value means the luminaire emits no
light in the given direction.
      (2)   Backlight. Backlight creates light trespass onto adjacent lots and
streets.
      (3)   Uplight. Uplight contributes to skyglow.
      (4)   Glare. Glare causes visual discomfort or reduced visibility.
   (B)   Maximum allowable BUG ratings.
      (1)   All luminaires shall be rated and installed according to
Table 156.976-3: Maximum Allowable Backlight, Uplight, and Glare (BUG) Ratings.
      (2)   A luminaire may be used if it is rated for the lighting zone of the
site or is lower in number for all ratings (B, U, and G). Luminaires equipped
with adjustable mounting devices permitting alteration of luminaire aiming in
the field are prohibited.
      (3)   If a luminaire does not have a BUG rating, it shall be fully-
shielded.

(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.977 LIMITATION ON HOURS OF OPERATION.
   (A)   Applicability. This section applies to exterior lighting on sites with
buildings containing more than 40,000 square feet of enclosed floor area. This
section applies whether the exterior lighting was installed before, on, or
after the effective date of this subchapter.
   (B)   Hours of operation. All exterior lighting should be turned off between
11:00 p.m. (local time) and sunrise, except when used for:
      (1)   Commercial and industrial uses (such as sales, assembly, and repair
areas) where business is conducted after 11:00 p.m., but only while the
business is open to the public;
      (2)   Lighting necessary for security purposes or to illuminate walkways
or roadways; and
      (3)   Recreational use that continues after 11:00 p.m., but only for so
long as such use continues.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.978 SPECIAL PURPOSE LIGHTING.
   (A)   Exterior lighting that does not comply with the technical requirements
of this subchapter, but is consistent with its intent, may be installed for the
special uses listed below:
      (1)   Sports facilities including, but not limited to, open courts,
fields, and stadiums. This includes sports facilities located on a school
campus;
      (2)   Outdoor amphitheaters;
      (3)   Parking structures;
      (4)   Ports; and
      (5)   Lots zoned LI or ED that contain uses with unique operational
characteristics.
   (B)   The applicant shall demonstrate in the exterior lighting plan (see §
156.980) that the proposed lighting installation:
      (1)   Has sustained every reasonable effort to mitigate the effects of
light on the environment and surrounding properties, supported by a signed
statement describing the mitigation measures;
      (2)   Only includes luminaires with a backlight rating of zero (B0);
      (3)   Does not create unwarranted glare or skyglow;
      (4)   Employs lighting controls to reduce lighting at a project-specific
curfew time established in the exterior lighting plan. For sports facilities,
this curfew must be no later than one hour after the end of the final game or
match.
   (C)   The mounting height of luminaires associated with:
      (1)   Parking structures shall be 18 feet or less above the top floor of
the structure; and
      (2)   Sports facilities, outdoor amphitheaters, and ports may be up to 70
feet above grade unless otherwise specified by the Board of Zoning Appeals as
part of a special exception use approval.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.979 STREET LIGHTING.
   Lighting used for the principal purpose of illuminating streets and
sidewalks:
   (A)   Is subject to §
156.970, but is not subject to any other provisions of this subchapter; and
   (B)   Must comply with the SCDOT ARMS Manual or town street standards, as
applicable.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.980 EXTERIOR LIGHTING PLAN REQUIRED.
   (A)   An exterior lighting plan demonstrating compliance with this
subchapter shall be submitted as a component of the design review application
in accordance with
Subchapter I, Part 12.
   (B)   The exterior lighting plan shall:
      (1)   Have a minimum scale of one inch equals 20 feet;
      (2)   Be integrated with the required landscaping plan; and
      (3)   Include:
         (a)   Location and mounting information for each luminaire;
         (b)   A graphic representation of each type of luminaire;
         (c)   A fixture schedule listing fixture design, type of lamp, lumens,
correlated color temperature, and BUG rating for each luminaire;
         (d)   Manufacturer's photometric data for each type of luminaire;
         (e)   COMcheck Exterior Lighting Compliance Certificate or other
verification that the proposed exterior lighting complies with the IECC
individual lighting power allowances for building exteriors (see §
156.975); and
         (f)   Illumination calculations showing:
            1.   Light levels in footcandles at points located on a ten-foot
center grid; and
            2.   Uniformity ratio.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.981 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subpart, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BACKLIGHT. For an exterior luminaire, lumens emitted in the quarter sphere
below horizontal and in the opposite direction of the intended orientation of
the luminaire. For luminaires with symmetric distribution, backlight will be
the same as front light.
   CORRELATED COLOR TEMPERATURE (CCT). A numerical figure used to describe the
apparent color of white or nearly white light sources such as LEDs or metal
halide.
   DIRECT LIGHT. Light emitted directly from the lamp, off of the reflector or
reflector diffuser, or through the refractor or diffuser lens of a luminaire.
   EXTERIOR LIGHTING. The illumination of an outside area or object by any
human-made device located outdoors that produces light by any means.
   FIXTURE. The assembly that houses the lamp or lamps, and can include all or
some of the following parts: a housing, a mounting bracket or pole socket, a
lamp holder, a ballast, a reflector or mirror, or a refractor or lens.
   GLARE. Lighting entering the eye directly from luminaires or indirectly from
reflective surfaces that causes visual discomfort or reduced visibility.
   LAMP. The component of a luminaire that produces the actual light. A generic
term for a source of optical radiation (i.e., “light”), often called a “bulb”
or “tube.” Examples include incandescent, fluorescent, high-intensity discharge
(HID) lamps, and low pressure sodium (LPS) lamps, as well as light-emitting
diode (LED) modules and arrays.
   LANDSCAPE LIGHTING. Lighting equipment powered at less than 15 volts with
luminaires having a rated initial luminaire lumen output of 525 lumens or less.
   LIGHT TRESPASS. Light that falls beyond the boundaries of the property it is
intended to illuminate.
   LIGHTING EQUIPMENT. Equipment specifically intended to provide gas or
electric illumination, including but not limited to, lamps, luminaires,
ballasts, poles, posts, lenses, and related structures, electrical wiring, and
other necessary or auxiliary components.
   LUMEN. The unit of measure used to quantify the amount of light produced by
a lamp or emitted from a luminaire (as distinct from “watt,” a measure of power
consumption).
   LUMINAIRE. A complete lighting unit (fixture), consisting of a lamp, or
lamps and ballast(s) (when applicable), together with the parts designed to
distribute the light (reflector, lens, diffuser), to position and protect the
lamps, and to connect the lamps to the power supply.
   LUMINAIRE, FULLY-SHIELDED. A luminaire constructed and installed in such a
manner that all light emitted by the luminaire, either directly from the lamp
or a diffusing element, or indirectly by reflection or refraction from any part
of the luminaire, is projected below the horizontal plane through the
luminaire's lowest light-emitting part. Any structural part of the luminaire
providing this shielding must be permanently affixed and part of the luminaire,
not part of any surrounding building or architectural elements.
   LUMINAIRE, HEIGHT OF. The vertical distance from the ground directly below
the centerline of the luminaire to the lowest, direct, light-emitting part of
the luminaire.
   MOUNTING HEIGHT. See LUMINAIRE, HEIGHT OF.
   SEASONAL LIGHTING. Temporary lighting installed and operated in connection
with holidays or traditions.
   SECURITY LIGHTING. The minimum amount of exterior lighting necessary to
illuminate building entrances, exits, and other possible points of entry;
exterior walkways; and/or outdoor storage areas.
   SKYGLOW. The brightening of the nighttime sky that results from scattering
and reflection of artificial light by moisture and dust particles in the
atmosphere. SKYGLOW is caused by light directed or reflected upwards or
sideways and reduces one's ability to view the night sky.
   UNIFORMITY. A description of the smoothness of the lighting pattern or the
degree of intensity of light and dark areas in the area to be lighted.
   UNIFORMITY RATIO. A measurement of the relative difference between the
average footcandles of illumination on the area to be lighted and the
footcandles at the point of minimum illuminance on the area to be lighted. The
lower the ratio, the more uniform the lighting design. A UNIFORMITY RATIO of 3:
1 means the average footcandles value on the area to be lighted is three times
the footcandles value at the point of least illuminance on the area to be
lighted.
   UPLIGHT. For an exterior luminaire, flux radiated in the hemisphere at or
above the horizontal plane.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.982 THROUGH 156.989 RESERVED.
SUBPART 3.5: LANDSCAPING
§ 156.990 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of these landscaping requirements is to:
   (A)   Reduce the visibility of paved areas from adjacent properties and
streets;
   (B)   Moderate climatic effects;
   (C)   Minimize noise and glare;
   (D)   Provide habitat for wildlife;
   (E)   Reinforce a sense of place with use of indigenous lowcountry plants;
   (F)   Enhance public safety by defining spaces that influence efficient
traffic movement; and
   (G)   Enhance the character, value, and attractiveness of new development
and surrounding properties.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.991 GENERAL LANDSCAPING STANDARDS.
   (A)   Existing vegetation. Existing vegetation of any type, size, or origin
shall not be altered or removed, unless it satisfies the requirements of this
part;
Subchapter D, Part 2;
Subchapter E; and §
156.760.
   (B)   Integral design. Landscape design and planning shall be integrated
with the overall project design concept and shall not be considered as merely
an afterthought.
   (C)   Natural landscape.
      (1)   The natural landscape character shall be preserved in every
reasonable instance.
      (2)   Trees measuring three inches DBH or larger shall not be felled
except where authorized by this chapter.
   (D)   Included in landscape. In applying landscaping to complement natural
conditions, factors to be included in the integral design of development
projects include:
      (1)   Trees and plantings;
      (2)   All vegetative cover and ornamentation;
      (3)   Paving;
      (4)   All the items of exterior furniture, including pedestrian benches;
      (5)   Fountains;
      (6)   Fences;
      (7)   Mailboxes;
      (8)   Light fixtures; and
      (9)   Shopping cart return stalls.
   (E)   Types and selection of landscaping.
      (1)   All items of the landscape are to be selected for both their
functional and aesthetic value, and must complement the whole.
      (2)   Plants must be selected in accordance with §
156.585 and meet the requirements in §
156.584.
Figure 156.992-1
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13119.png]
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.992 LANDSCAPE DESIGN.
   (A)   Landscape plan required. A comprehensive landscaping program for each
individual lot subject to this part is essential for protecting and promoting
the appearance, character, and economic value of land. As such, a landscape
plan is required for all projects.
   (B)   Low impact development features. Landscaping will reduce the amount of
stormwater runoff and provide transition between neighboring properties. The
use of bio-swales, rain gardens, and other low impact development (LID)
features in required landscape areas is allowed and encouraged.
   (C)   Landscaping between buildings and parking areas. Landscaping is
required between buildings and parking areas to:
      (1)   Soften the appearance of structures and parking lots from the road;
      (2)   Screen vehicular headlight glare on- and off-site;
      (3)   Lessen spillover light from on-site lighting; and
      (4)   Enhance the aesthetics of the site.
   (D)   Landscaping between buildings and sidewalks or curbs and between
parking lots and driveways. Landscaping is required between buildings and
sidewalks and/or buildings and curbing and between parking lots and driveways.
      (1)   Such landscaping shall include understory and canopy trees, as
approved by the designated reviewing authority.
      (2)   The scale of the proposed landscaping and landscape areas shall be
in proportion to the building.
      (3)   Landscape areas shall be appropriately sized for required
plantings.
   (E)   Landscaping at buildings or in planters immediately fronting a
building.
      (1)   Proposed landscaping shall consider architectural features in order
to avoid immediate or future conflict with projecting elements. See examples in
Figure 156.992-1: Landscaping Along Building Frontage.
      (2)   Proposed landscaping shall consider building sign locations to
avoid adverse pruning for sign visibility.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.993 EVALUATION CRITERIA.
   (A)   Emphasis shall be placed upon landscaping as a means of achieving
beauty in the community and, in some areas, it will be the primary tool
available.
   (B)   Toward this end, proposed landscaping will be evaluated in relation
to:
      (1)   Existing natural landscape that may be used as a "plant palette"
for the given site;
      (2)   Existing or proposed buildings; and
      (3)   Existing and proposed landscaping, including that existing on
adjacent properties and street rights-of-way, to provide consistent street tree
plantings.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.994 CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY.
   All landscaping required by this part shall be shown on all development site
plan(s) and shall be installed in accordance with specified species, height,
spread, density, and quality prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.995 DESIGN REVIEW PROCESS.
   For buildings, structures, and developments subject to the design review
process (see
Subchapter I, Part 12), alteration of existing vegetation or landscaping
treatments is prohibited without prior approval through the design review
process.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.996 MAINTENANCE.
   Landscaping required by this part shall be maintained in accordance with
Subchapter D, Part 7.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.997 THROUGH 156.1009 RESERVED.
PART 4: SPECIAL DESIGN SUBAREAS
SUBPART 4.1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 156.1010 SPECIAL DESIGN SUBAREAS.
   Special design subareas are areas of town that exhibit a type of development
pattern that varies from the town’s building and site design standards. Each of
the special design subareas outline standards in order to produce a desired
outcome for a given area.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1011 HIERARCHY OF AUTHORITY.
   (A)   All standards applicable to special design subareas take precedence
over town commercial area standards.
   (B)   The town commercial area standards apply for any standard not
addressed in the subarea standards.
   (C)   All codified development criteria otherwise required by the town
applies in addition to these standards.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1012 THROUGH 156.1019 RESERVED.
SUBPART 4.2: COMMERCIAL VILLAGE SPECIAL DESIGN SUBAREA
§ 156.1020 GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   (A)   Purpose. The Commercial Village concept shares certain similarities
with standard enclosed malls in terms of business types, but its land use
patterns differ considerably.
      (1)   Where enclosed malls are surrounded by large, streetless seas of
asphalt, which, in turn, are surrounded by numerous developed outparcels devoid
of pedestrian linkages; the Commercial Village will assimilate various uses on
a unified street system capable of continued evolution.
      (2)   Structures, including buildings, utility buildings, and parking
decks, will display a high degree of architectural integrity to appeal to and
attract people, and promote the appearance, character, and economic value of
the property.
      (3)   Development patterns are encouraged to have office or residential
uses above retail uses. Design elements will include excellence in the
architecture of structures, unified scale and proportionality shared by
buildings, street furniture, lighting standards, streets and parking lots, the
use of window displays, and convenience of parking relative to sidewalks, as
described by standards herein.
      (4)   The accommodation of automobiles, though utterly essential, will
not dominate land use patterns or design quality.
   (B)   Applicability. This subpart applies to developments consisting of
shopping centers, strip centers, super centers, malls, and other combined
commercial projects totaling more than 100,000 square feet, including
outparcels.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1021 SUPPLEMENTAL BUILDING DESIGN STANDARDS.
   (A)   Building setback. Buildings will follow a generally uniform setback
along the street. Variations may be allowed to accommodate architectural
features.
   (B)   Primary façade and entry orientation. Building façades facing parking
lots shall be considered the same as street-front façades and shall be designed
as a primary façade.
   (C)   Structures.
      (1)   Individuality in the design of each building is encouraged.
         (a)   Unity between buildings shall rely primarily on proportional
relationship and composition of material.
         (b)   Regardless of height, buildings must relate to one another by
exactly or closely approximating each other's cornice and fenestration lines.
      (2)   The establishment of a successful relationship between the scale of
structures is critical.
         (a)   Regardless of height or size, buildings must relate to one
another's scale, particularly where large buildings abut small buildings.
         (b)   Therefore, large buildings must avoid wide, flat expanses by
using architectural treatments to reduce the visual effect of width.
      (3)   Proportional height-to-width ratios are expected to be provided by
project architects and applied to all structures and the development area. Tall
structures that contain only one floor must use architectural treatments to
infer a second story.
      (4)   Structures designed solely to promote standardized corporate images
are prohibited.
      (5)   All structures are to be specifically designed for their particular
sites and in consideration of the character of the entire development.
   (D)   Parking lot areas and facilities.
      (1)   Generally.
         (a)   Parking lot areas must be designed to accommodate pedestrians
and landscaping, as well as vehicles.
         (b)   Parking lot areas must be designed to reduce lateral parking
space requirements and increase the amount of landscaped and/or buildable area.
      (2)   Location of parking lot.
         (a)   Parking lots must be positioned to the rear or side of
buildings.
         (b)   Where this is not required as a result of the design review
process and where they abut streets, parking lots must be shielded from view by
the use of walls and landscaping that contribute to the streetscape of the
adjacent built environment.
         (c)   Entrances to parking areas must be evident through the use of
landmark entrance treatments.
      (3)   Spatial requirements.
         (a)   Parking areas must be located within a reasonable safe walking
distance from destinations no further than 400 feet from the entrance to a
commercial building.
         (b)   Each individual parking lot area will measure no larger than 400
by 400 feet.
         (c)   All parking lots will provide pedestrian linkages to the
buildings they serve. In order to channel foot traffic to appropriate entrances
and exits, clearly marked pedestrian sidewalks and pathways are required within
large parking lots accommodating more than 100 vehicles.
         (d)   Parking lot areas must be clearly delineated by the use of
borders around the perimeter.
            1.   Borders may be created by landscape strips, buildings, walls,
or fences.
            2.   When walls and fences are utilized, the landscaped strip may
be reduced to five feet.
            3.   Otherwise, landscaped borders shall be ten feet wide.
            4.   Curbing is required within parking lots, unless suitable
substitutes are approved through the design review process.
      (4)   Planter islands at ends of parking rows. Canopy trees shall be
planted between every 12 parking places.
      (5)   Excess parking areas. Excess parking may be provided if it is
composed of porous or semi-porous material and with an approved alternative
parking plan.
   (E)   Internal access roads.
      (1)   A system of interconnecting, predominantly linear streets is
required.
      (2)   All streets must include sidewalks on each right-of-way.
         (a)   The width of the sidewalks shall be determined by the estimated
amount of pedestrian traffic.
         (b)   In most instances, where buildings abut sidewalks, an eight- to
ten-foot width will be necessary.
      (3)   Angled and/or parallel parking shall be provided along streets
where it can be safely accommodated.
      (4)   Street trees shall line every street to contribute to the
definition of the streetscape, and will be selected to create a street canopy
that provides effective shade for pedestrians and vehicles. They will be
planted to provide separation of the sidewalk from the street curb.
      (5)   Buildings must be separated from street sidewalks by narrow,
planted earth islands, landscaped boxes, or other landscaped features.
      (6)   All streets shall have standing curbs.
      (7)   Street furniture, particularly in the form of benches, kiosks,
drinking fountains, and trash receptacles, shall be strategically placed for
the benefit of pedestrians.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1022 THROUGH 156.1034 RESERVED.
SUBPART 4.3: VILLAGE-SCALE PEDESTRIAN SPECIAL DESIGN SUBAREA
§ 156.1035 APPLICABILITY.
   In addition to the requirements of the town’s commercial design standards
described in Parts 2 and 3 of this subchapter, the design standards in this
subpart apply for all development within the Village-Scale Pedestrian Overlay
District (VSP-OD).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1036 ACTIVITY ZONE.
   (A)   Description. The activity zone is a quasi-public space that may be
used for pedestrian circulation, placement of required canopy trees, planters,
benches, trash receptacles, and other street furnishings, in addition to the
uses described herein.
   (B)   Location. Because the activity zone is specifically defined as the
area between the street right-of-way line and build-to line, this means that an
activity zone is not allowed where a setback is required.
      (1)   On Coleman and Ben Sawyer Boulevards, activity zones are expressly
prohibited where a setback is required, as specified in
Table 156.254-1: Coleman Boulevard Development Standards.
      (2)   On Johnnie Dodds Boulevard, activity zones are expressly prohibited
on the following neighborhood streets: Lansing Drive, Tall Pine Road, Dragoon
Drive, Pine Hollow Road, Cottingham Drive, Williamson Drive, and the western
side of Bowman Road between Johnnie Dodds Boulevard and Mathis Ferry Road.
      (3)   On Chuck Dawley Boulevard, activity zones are allowed only on Chuck
Dawley Boulevard. Activity zones are expressly prohibited on all side streets.
   (C)   Permitted uses. All uses in the activity zone shall be conducted
outside of the street right-of-way. Design review approval is required prior to
establishing any use and/or installing any street furnishings within the
activity zone. Allowed uses are limited to the following:
      (1)   Streetside dining;
      (2)   Outdoor merchandise display, which must be related to the business
in front of which it is located;
      (3)   Non-amplified music performers or entertainers, subject to the
town's noise ordinance;
      (4)   Pushcarts; and
      (5)   A-frame signs in accordance with the requirements of
Subchapter G.
   (D)   Activity zone design standards.
      (1)   Awnings and balconies.
         (a)   Awnings may cover the entire activity zone area not utilized for
canopy tree placement and as defined for streetside dining.
         (b)   Awnings must be at least five feet in depth, measured
horizontally from face of building.
         (c)   Awnings shall be a maximum of eight feet in height, measured
from the bottom of an awning and/or valence to the sidewalk adjacent to
building. This measurement may be adjusted for grand, multi-story windows.
         (d)   Balconies may project over the activity zone, but in no instance
shall they extend over the right-of-way.
         (e)   Support structures for awnings and balconies are prohibited in
the activity zone.
      (2)   Raised planters. In order to enhance the pedestrian-oriented theme
of development, planters are required as a design element to soften the
building exterior and enhance the streetscape.
      (3)   Street furniture. Street furniture shall be utilized to enhance and
facilitate the pedestrian experience and shall not be utilized as additional
signage.
      (4)   Pedestrian access to remain unimpeded. In all cases, permanent or
temporary design features or activities shall not impede pedestrian access on
the public sidewalk.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1037 TERMINAL VISTAS.
   (A)   Properties that terminate views down streets shall be identified
during the design review process, and will be held to a higher architectural
standard along this visible façade.
   (B)   Such identified properties are those across from side streets that
intersect the primary boulevard and terminate or intersect and continue at a
different angle.
   (C)   Properties that are at the end of a straightaway on the boulevard
shall also meet this requirement.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1038 COLEMAN BOULEVARD STANDARDS.
   (A)   Active ground floor use.
      (1)   For buildings with frontage on Coleman Boulevard, within the area
located between Live Oak Street and the intersection of Coleman, Ben Sawyer,
and Chuck Dawley Boulevards, a minimum of 60% of the ground floor street
frontage shall be utilized for retail, restaurant, or entertainment use, as
allowed by the base zoning district (see §
156.338). Such retail, restaurant, or entertainment space shall be of a
meaningful depth so as to create a functional, usable commercial space that
addresses the activity zone and creates interest and activity in the public
realm.
      (2)   The remaining 40% of first floor level area may be devoted to
office or residential use.
   (B)   Bufferyards and street trees.
      (1)   Three canopy trees of a minimum-four-inch caliper are required for
each 100 linear feet of road frontage, using species southern red oak, live
oak, willow oak, elm varieties, and American beech. These tree types must be
consistent along each block and evenly spaced, with exceptions made for curb
cuts, utilities, and other obstructions. On side streets, the required street
trees shall be located in an area behind the sidewalk.
      (2)   Internal side and rear (non-street frontage) bufferyards shall be
provided in accordance with
Table 156.254-1: Coleman Boulevard Development Standards.
      (3)   Sabal palmettos shall be planted in the public right-of-way
adjacent to lots on Coleman Boulevard, at approximately 30 feet on center.
Additional low shrub or groundcover plantings, including grass, may be required
between the Sabal palmettos in the verge.
   (C)   Parking lot islands. Parking lot islands, which must include four-inch
caliper or larger canopy trees of a species approved during the design review
process, must be provided at a minimum of every 12 spaces when adjacent to rear
or side property lines. Internal parking lot islands either shall be provided
at a minimum of every 12 spaces or only at the end of parking rows.
   (D)   Sidewalks and landscaping.
      (1)   There shall be a public sidewalk, either within the right-of-way or
within a pedestrian easement on private property, on both sides of all streets.
The sidewalk shall be at least five feet wide on side streets and internal
access roads and at least eight feet wide on boulevard streets.
      (2)   On boulevard streets, sidewalks shall typically be separated from
traffic by a grassed verge, which shall be at least three feet wide, measured
from the back of curb, and planted with palmettos at approximately 30 feet on
center. However, where on-street parking is utilized, the palmettos may be
planted in openings of three feet by three feet, with eight-foot-wide sidewalks
serving the parallel parking areas. See Figures 156.1038-1, 156.1038-2, and
156.1038-3.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13123.png]
 
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
