[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13127.png]
 
   (E)   Lot frontage.
      (1)   On Coleman Boulevard between its intersection with Lansing Drive
and its intersection with Chuck Dawley Boulevard, the minimum building frontage
on properties of less than 100 feet is 100% of its frontage, except for
adequate allowance for one curb cut. The total required building frontage may
be accomplished through a phased development plan.
      (2)   For properties with more than 100 feet of frontage on the
boulevards, a minimum of 70% building frontage is required. The total required
building frontage may be accomplished through a phased development plan.
      (3)   Pocket parks, plazas, and other civic open spaces that are
integrated into the overall design of a project count for up to 20% of the
required building frontage.
      (4)   The minimum allowable size of a pocket park or other suitable civic
open space is 12 feet of frontage and 300 square feet of overall area.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1039 JOHNNIE DODDS BOULEVARD STANDARDS.
   (A)   Bufferyards.
      (1)   Scenic Highway Buffer (Mathis Ferry Road). See §
156.607.
      (2)   Right-of-way bufferyard. Three canopy trees of a minimum-four-inch
caliper are required for each 100 linear feet of street frontage, using species
such as southern red oak, live oak, willow oak, elm varieties, and American
beech. These trees must be consistent along each block and evenly spaced, with
exceptions made for curb cuts, utilities, and other obstructions.
      (3)   Perimeter bufferyards.
         (a)   In general, perimeter bufferyard requirements on individual lots
are specified in Subchapter D, Part 2. However, contingent upon approval
through the design review process, development utilizing an integrated site
plan involving multiple parcels may forgo perimeter bufferyards along lot
lines, except when commercial uses abut residential uses lying outside the VSP-
OD. In the latter case, a minimum ten-foot, Type C bufferyard, with an F3
fence, is required in all instances. This buffer may overlap with the required
side and/or rear yard setback.
         (b)   Perimeter bufferyards are not required where common wall
construction to adjacent properties spanning property lines is utilized in
accordance with applicable Building and Fire Code requirements.
   (B)   Pedestrian trails.
      (1)   A key component of the VSP-OD in the Johnnie Dodds Boulevard area
is the provision of an integrated pedestrian and bicycle access plan through
sidewalks and trails. This system is graphically depicted in Figure 156.1039-1:
Pedestrian Trails.
      (2)   Dedication of easements and construction for sidewalks and
pedestrian trails on development parcels may be required in the approval
process to implement this pedestrian and bicycle access system.
      (3)   In addition to the pedestrian trail system, Figure 156.1039-1:
Pedestrian Trails illustrates areas suitable for open space and parks.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13129.png]
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1040 CHUCK DAWLEY BOULEVARD STANDARDS.
   (A)   Right-of-way bufferyards. Three canopy trees of a minimum four-inch
caliper are required for each 100 linear feet of street frontage, using species
such as southern red oak, live oak, willow oak, elm varieties, and American
beech. These trees must be consistent along each block and evenly spaced, with
exceptions made for curb cuts, utilities, and other obstructions.
   (B)   Perimeter bufferyards.
      (1)   In general, perimeter bufferyard requirements on individual lots
are specified in
Subchapter D, Part 2. However, contingent upon approval through the design
review process, developme nt utilizing an integrated site plan involving
multiple parcels may forgo perimeter bufferyard s along lot lines, except when
commercia l uses abut residential uses lying outside the VSP-OD. In the latter
case, a minimum ten-foot, Type C bufferyard, with an F3 fence, is required in
all instances. This buffer may overlap with the required side and/or rear yard
setback.
      (2)   Perimeter bufferyards are not required where common wall
construction to adjacent properties spanning property lines is utilized in
accordance with applicable Building and Fire Code requirements.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1041 SUPPLEMENTAL BUILDING DESIGN STANDARDS.
   (A)   Primary façade and entry orientation.
      (1)   Primary entry. For buildings with frontage on the boulevards or
frontage roads, the primary entry must be from Coleman Boulevard, Ben Sawyer
Boulevard, Johnnie Dodds Boulevard frontage road, or Chuck Dawley Boulevard.
Rear of buildings shall not be designed to appear as fronts. Display windows
are required on all street facades for retail buildings. Other commercial or
office buildings shall adhere to the requirements of §
156.899(D)(4). Second floor and above, with a separate entrance from the first
floor, shall have primary entrance from the primary street, when feasible.
Buildings, businesses, and residences facing side streets should have entrances
from the side street.
      (2)   Secondary entry. Secondary entrances from the rear of a store may
be allowed; however, this area may not be treated as a storefront in detailing
or pedestrian amenities.
   (B)   Elevated buildings. In order to project a pedestrian-friendly
streetscape, it is highly recommended that alternatives to elevating commercial
buildings located in "A" flood zones be pursued. This may be accomplished by
flood proofing or altering the elevation of the finished floor inside the
building. However, in the event that these techniques are not feasible and the
building must be elevated, such elevation may not exceed the minimum elevation
required plus one foot of additional freeboard; provided further, that this
provision does not apply to a parking garage located in a flood zone.
   (C)   False second floors. False second floors are not allowed for buildings
in which multiple stories are required. However, a mezzanine comprising one-
third of the area of the floor below, or an atrium located between the floor
and ceiling equivalent to two-story spaces, may be utilized to fulfill this
requirement.
   (D)   Parking lot areas and facilities.
      (1)   Parking lot requirements for multi-family, mixed use, and non-
residential uses.
         (a)   Ground level parking in buildings and parking structures is
permitted, if the street level frontage of the building complies with the
requirements outlined in this subsection.
         (b)   In no case shall ground level parking lots occupy more than one-
third of a lot’s frontage along a pedestrian street or street segment;
excluding primary and secondary entries.
         (c)   Parking and exterior loading areas shall be buffered from any
adjacent pedestrian way by planting canopy trees and providing a landscaped
area with a continuous row of high shrubs, or a fence or seating wall, subject
to the design review process.
         (d)   On private property, pervious materials, other than loose rock
or gravel, may be utilized for required parking spaces and parking drive
aisles, subject to the design review process.
      (2)   Parking structures. When possible, parking structures (garages)
shall be placed in the center of the block and may utilize ground floor
parking. See Figure 156.1041-1: Parking Structure Location.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13131.png]
   ( E)    Access and connectivity.
      (1 )   R esident ial uses, including detached single-family dwellings,
duplex dwellings, and townhouse dwellings.
         (a)   Units on the second floor and above must have a direct access to
the street. This access may be created through the use of a single or multiple
lobby(ies) that access the street level.
         (b)   Where duplex or townhouse dwellings may be approved along any
boulevard streets, requirements for sidewalks and street tree plantings shall
be in accordance with the specifications of the respective sub-area.
         (c)   Parking in structures not located mid-block shall be above the
ground floor or behind the storefront or residential uses, if located on the
ground floor as described below.
            1.   If located to the side of a building, the parking structure
must be set back from the front of that building and have an architectural
façade.
            2.    Slopi ng floor s shall not be visible from primary streets.
            3.   Retail storefronts, residences, or other business uses on
street level shall be required on street frontages of parking structures to
provide vitality.
            4.   Vehicular access shall be from side streets or alleys wherever
possible, and not directly from the primary street.
      (2)   Incentive for parking structures. There shall be no maximum parking
requirements for commercial uses if a parking structure is utilized on site.
      (3)   Parking for outdoor dining. Parking for outdoor dining shall be
determined by the minimum number of off-street parking spaces required for
restaurant use in
Subchapter F, Part 2 and not based upon square footage of outdoor use area.
   (F)   Vehicular access.
      (1)   Access points to the boulevards shall look like streets, with
identifiable features including pavement markings, sidewalks and crosswalks,
planting strips, and canopy trees, distinguishable from parking lot entrances,
as illustrated in the figures below.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13133.png]
 
      (2)   Shared vehicular access is encouraged; the benefit is more frontage
and more developable land on parcels.
      (3)   Residential uses, including detached single-family dwellings,
duplex dwellings, and townhouse dwellings. In cases where single-family lots
are subdivided with access to an existing public street, access for parking
must be located to the rear of the lots (alley-fed). Driveways for individual
dwelling units may not be located on existing public streets.
   (G)   Drive-through uses.
      (1)   Because driving culture is not compatible with the walkability
goals of the Village Scale Pedestrian area, drive-through facilities are
generally discouraged, and may need to be located internal to sites, behind
other road-front buildings that meet the goals of the standards.
      (2)   Drive-through lanes are prohibited within the activity zone.
      (3)   Drive-through lanes shall not present impediments to the smooth and
orderly flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic to or within the site.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1042 THROUGH 156.1054 RESERVED.
SUBPART 4.4: SHEM CREEK WATERFRONT  SPECIAL DESIGN SUBAREA
§ 156.1055 APPLICABILITY.
   In addition to the requirements of the town’s commercial design standards
described in
Subchapter H, Part 2 and Part 3, the design standards in this subpart apply for
all development within the Shem Creek Waterfront Districts.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1056 SUPPLEMENTAL BUILDING DESIGN STANDARDS.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   Buildings shall front on Shem Creek;
      (2)   Avoid monolithic massing and create visual variety;
      (3)   Provide variation in cornice and/or eave height along Shem Creek;
      (4)   Vary building elevation, using step-backs or other changes in
building massing to limit continuous repetitive facades; and
      (5)   Vary building height, roof slope, and roof details.
   (B)   Building edge and massing.
      (1)   The building edge must be maintained for at least 75% of any
frontage on Shem Creek; and
      (2)   Continuous repetitive facades must be limited to 50 feet along
building fronts.
   (C)   View plane.
      (1)   A view plane for Shem Creek or marsh frontages shall be defined,
beyond which no building element shall penetrate, determined by maximum
allowable façade height at the minimum building setback line, starting at a
height of 25 feet along this line, at an angle of 30 degrees upward from the
horizontal.
      (2)   Building façades shall be no closer to Shem Creek than the minimum
setback defined below in this section and no further than 15 feet beyond the
resulting minimum building setback.
   (D)   Rooflines.
      (1)   Roofs must maintain a sloped or gabled design.
      (2)   However, a flat roof may be provided at the center of a structure
solely for the purpose of housing required mechanical equipment and associated
services areas not accessible by the public.
      (3)   Roofing materials shall be metal standing seam, terne metal,
corrugated or 5-V crimp metal.
   (E)   Materials.
      (1)   Primary building materials. Primary building materials shall be
wood. For the purposes of this division, wood shall refer to wood, cementitious
siding, and other synthetic materials meant to facilitate the appearance of
wood siding as described herein.
      (2)   Secondary building materials. Secondary building materials shall be
wood except as provided below:
         (a)   Limited use of 5-V crimp, corrugated, standing seam terne metal,
or standing seam copper architectural metal cladding, may be incorporated into
the overall building composition when used as an architectural accent and when
found to meet the intent of this section. Such architectural cladding will
exhibit features, such as quality architectural materials, a natural finish,
and concealed fasteners.
         (b)   Metal cladding shall not constitute more than 50% of any façade.
   (F)   Elevated buildings.
      (1)   Buildings in flood zones.
         (a)   In order to project a pedestrian-friendly streetscape, it is
highly recommended that alternatives to elevating commercial buildings located
in “AE” flood zones be pursued. This may be accomplished by floodproofing or
altering the elevation of the finished floor inside the building. However, in
the event that these techniques are not feasible, and the building must be
elevated, such elevation may not exceed the minimum elevation required by Town
of Mount Pleasant flood damage prevention regulations.
         (b)   All elevated buildings shall utilize traditional building design
elements such as doors and window openings to give the appearance of a
traditional ground floor where those façades are most visible from the public
view to the extent allowed by Town of Mount Pleasant flood damage prevention
ordinances.
         (c)   Where flood damage prevention ordinances prohibit or severely
limit the use of architectural treatments to create the appearance of a ground
floor, landscaping should be used to screen the ground floor area.
      (2)   Open space and parks. Passive parks, plazas or public gathering
spaces should be utilized to facilitate a vibrant, pedestrian-friendly
streetscape between the street and building façade of elevated buildings.
      (3)   Street furniture. Street furniture shall be utilized in passive
parks, plazas, or public gathering spaces between the street and building
façade of elevated buildings to enhance and facilitate the pedestrian
experience.
      (4)   Parking design standards.
         (a)   Stand up curbing will not be required within parking lots;
however concrete wheel stops shall be used to border and define drive aisles,
where determined necessary. Alternative curbing substitutes shall be reviewed
through the design review process.
         (b)   Diamond-shaped planter islands (minimum 36-inch width), which
must include Sabal palms or single-stem Crape myrtles, shall be placed every 36
feet within a row of parking, both internally and when adjacent to rear and
side property lines. The planter will be placed in the center of the
intersection of four parking spaces. The equidistant placement of this planter
will provide vegetation in the parking area, without detracting from parking
counts. See Figure 156.1056-1: Diamond-Shaped Planter Island.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13135.png]
         ( c)   Planter islands are not required to terminate parking rows.
         ( d)   Gravel parking is permitted as a suitable material. However,
accessible parking stalls must meet IBC standards in which gravel is not
permitted.
      (5)    Buffer and landscaping vegetation requirements.
         ( a)   Natural habitats. As the Shem Creek area is a noted habitat
containing wetlands and estuaries housing migratory birds, required landscaping
shall be native or bird-friendly species, with an intention to create or
augment habitat areas.
         (b)   Perimeter buffers only. In the interest of meeting the
district's intent of both pedestrian interconnectivity and accommodation of
parking, internal buffers will not be required between neighboring properties
within the districts, except for the following conditions.
            1.   A five-foot A-type bufferyard (two canopy trees, three
understory, five shrubs per 100 feet linear) with native or bird-friendly
vegetation shall be required around the outer perimeter of each district and
along the following district streets: Coleman Blvd., Mill St., and Haddrell.
            2.   If a conflict in application of requirements exists, the
district's specific buffer requirements shall apply first; Planned Development
district zoning specific requirements second; and requirements of Subchapter D
third.
      (6)   Site furnishings and miscellaneous.
         (a)   Bike racks will be required to be installed at each commercial
establishment in conjunction with any site or building additions, renovations,
or remodels.
         (b)   Mobile raised planters are encouraged to help define outdoor
activity space within the perimeter of a property. Planters are not permitted
to obstruct pedestrian interconnectivity or prohibit interaction with the
public realm as approved through the design review process.
   (G)   Parking. The applicant must propose a parking design plan for
consideration as part of the design review process.
      (1)   No more than 10% of surface parking areas shall be covered by
impervious surfaces, as defined in Subchapter N.
      (2)   For the uses listed below, the following requirements apply:
         (a)   Restaurant: 1.25 parking spaces per 100 square feet.
         (b)   Lodging: one parking space per room
         (c)   Office: one parking space per 200 square feet.
         (d)   Except as provided in division (G)(2)(f) below, kayak and
paddleboard rentals:
            1.   One parking space per four individual watercrafts available
for use by customers; and
            2.   One parking space per two full time employees
         (e)   Except as provided in division (G)(2)(f) below, charter boats,
water taxis, and other excursions:
            1.   One parking space per four individual passenger capacity
available for use by customers; and
            2.   One parking space per two employees.
         (f)   Kayak and paddleboard rentals, charter boats, water taxis, and
other water-related excursions land uses may satisfy the above requirements by
either:
            1.   Providing shuttle services to all customers; or
            2.   Providing required parking on an adjacent parcel, which may be
separated by a local road.
         (g)   For all other land uses, minimum parking provided must be as
specified in Subchapter F, Part 2.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1057 THROUGH 156.1074 RESERVED.
SUBCHAPTER I: PROCEDURES
PART 1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 156.1075 PURPOSE.
   The purposes of this subchapter are to:
   (A)   Consolidate the procedures and outline clear standards for filing and
processing applications for zoning approvals required by this chapter; and
   (B)   Allow applicants, town officials, and the public to quickly and
efficiently ascertain the steps involved in obtaining zoning approvals.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1076 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   This subchapter establishes the procedures for the initiation, review,
and decision for all zoning permits or approvals required by this chapter.
   (B)   This subchapter establishes the procedures for the administration of
this chapter and amendments to this chapter.
   (C)   
Chapter 157: Development Agreement Code sets forth the procedures for
establishment and amendment of Development Agreements.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1077 SUMMARY OF PROCEDURES.

established in this subchapter.

§ 156.1078 GENERAL PROCEDURAL REQUIREMENTS AND AUTHORITY.
   (A)   General requirements.
      (1)   Application forms. All applications shall be made on forms
maintained for each permit or approval by the PLAN Department, which are
available online or in-person at Town Hall.
      (2)   Submittal requirements. Applications filed under this subchapter
must include the information required by
Subchapter I, Part 2,
including all information required on the application checklist maintained by
the PLAN Department for the particular permit or approval.
      (3)   Application fees. The applicant shall pay all applicable fees at
the time of the application (see §
156.1101).
   (B)   Concurrent applications. Except where this subchapter allows submittal
of concurrent applications, only one application at a time can be considered
for a particular lot.
   (C)   Conformance with application and submitted plans. Zoning permits and
other approvals issued on the basis of plans and applications approved under
this chapter authorize only the use, arrangement, and construction set forth in
the approved plans and applications, and do not authorize any other use,
arrangement, or construction.
   (D)   Written findings.
      (1)   Unless otherwise specifically provided in this chapter, written
findings are not required for a final decision on any application.
      (2)   At the request of an applicant or a party with standing to
challenge an application under the South Carolina Local Government
Comprehensive Planning Enabling Act of 1994, codified as S.C. Code Title 6,
Chapter 29, or on its own initiative, the approving authority may make a
decision subject to the subsequent adoption of written findings. In those
cases, the decision is not final until the written findings are adopted.
   (E)   Workflow summary. This subchapter sets up rules for procedures, such
as pre-application meetings, notices, and public hearings. It then describes
the process for specific zoning-related decisions. The procedures generally
share a common workflow and description, as specified in
Table 156.1078-1: Procedure Workflows.
Table 156.1078-1: Procedure Workflows
Element Meaning
Table 156.1078-1: Procedure Workflows
Element           Meaning
Purpose           Explains the reasons for a particular procedure.
Applicability     Identifies the type of development or situation that is
                  subject to the process.
Initiation        Describes how the applicant begins the process, including
                  which department or official receives the application.
Completeness      Describes how the town determines the application has
                  sufficient information to be processed.
Notice            Describes the type of notice required and how it is provided.
Decision          States who approves the application and the type of
                  proceeding that leads to the decision.
Review criteria   Specifies the standards that apply to the application.
                  Identifies the activities the application authorizes. For
Scope of approval example, some approvals send the applicant to the next step
                  in the overall process, while others authorize construction
                  or use.
                  If an application is denied or withdrawn, some processes have
Reapplication     a waiting period before that type of application can be re-
                  filed for the property.
Appeals           Provides a way to review an application that is denied or an
                  approval that has conditions the applicant disagrees with.
                  Some procedures have specific requirements for maintaining
Recordkeeping     records of applications and actions, which are included in
                  this subchapter. Town record retention policies govern other
                  recordkeeping requirements.
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1079 PRE-APPLICATION MEETING.
   (A)   Applicability.
      (1)   Pre-application meetings are required for the following types of
applications:
         (a)   Zoning map amendments (rezonings), if the application is filed
by the property owner or their agent;
         (b)   Special exception use permits;
         (c)   Impact assessments;
         (d)   Certificates of appropriateness; and
         (e)   Variances.
      (2)   Pre-application meetings for all other procedures are voluntary. An
applicant may request a pre-application meeting for any type of procedure
established by this subchapter.
      (3)   PLAN Department staff may waive the pre-application meeting
requirement upon finding the applicant has sufficient familiarity with the
approval process that a pre-application meeting would not serve a valid
purpose.
   (B)   Timing.
      (1)   The pre-application meeting must occur prior to application
submittal.
      (2)   Prior to the scheduled pre-application meeting, the applicant shall
submit to the PLAN Department a copy of plans and information relevant to the
application.
   (C)   Meeting location. Pre-application meetings may occur in-person, by
telephone, or by other remote meeting technology.
   (D)   Topics for meeting.
      (1)   The pre-application meeting is for informational purposes for the
applicant and PLAN Department staff, and no formal decisions are made.
      (2)   The applicant shall provide a brief overview of the project,
including proposed location, uses, densities, project layout, design features,
and other information relevant to the application.
      (3)   PLAN Department staff will provide information and comments at the
pre-application meeting but will not take formal action on the application. In
addition to providing verbal information, PLAN Department staff may provide a
pre-application meeting checklist.
      (4)   The applicant’s and PLAN Department staffs’ comments are for
purposes of information but are not binding on either the town or the
applicant.
      (5)   A submittal checklist item may be waived as part of this review if
determined to be unnecessary, already known, or needed at a future stage.
      (6)   The pre-application meeting may include the following:
         (a)   Discussion of the extent to which the proposed application
conforms to this chapter and other applicable regulations;
         (b)   A discussion of technical studies, plans, and other information
deemed relevant to the specific application request;
         (c)   A discussion regarding possible modifications to the
application, if warranted;
         (d)   Discussion of the anticipated level of citizen interest;
         (e)   Identification of public hearing or meeting requirements, if
applicable; and
         (f)   A discussion of the general project consistency with the
Comprehensive Plan.
      (7)   PLAN Department staff may request input on the proposed application
from other town departments, state agencies, utility providers, and other
reviewing agencies.
   (E)   Documentation. PLAN Department staff may record in writing (paper or
electronic) any pertinent information concerning the proposed application
described by the applicant, as well as a brief record of written or verbal
guidance provided by town staff or other reviewing agencies.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1080 COMPLETENESS REVIEW.
   (A)   When applications deemed complete.
      (1)   The town will not process incomplete applications.
      (2)   An application is not complete until the applicant submits all
required items (see
Subchapter I, Part 2).
      (3)   PLAN Department staff will review applications for completeness and
determine whether the application is complete.
         (a)   If staff determines an application is incomplete, staff may:
            1.   Reject the application and require the applicant to resubmit a
new application; or
            2.   Specify those parts of the application that are incomplete,
indicate how such parts can be made complete, and specify a date by which the
applicant must provide the missing information in order for the application to
be considered.
         (b)   Staff and the other review and decision-making bodies are not
obligated to further review the application until the required information is
provided.
      (4)   A time period required by this chapter to process an application
does not commence until PLAN Department staff determines the applicant has
submitted a complete application. Review for completeness of the application is
solely to determine whether preliminary information required for submission
with the application is sufficient to allow further processing. It does not
constitute a decision as to whether an application complies with this chapter.
      (5)   If the applicant elects not to pursue an application for any
reason, the application expires 180 days after the application filing date and
the applicant must re-file an application (including payment of any applicable
fees) for any further consideration.
      (6)   The regulations provided in
Subchapter I, Part 20 and Part 19 modify the completeness review provisions of
this section.
   (B)   Application and submittal deadlines.
      (1)   The PLAN Department or the review and decision-making bodies may
provide submission deadlines for materials required in support of any
application provided for in this chapter. These deadlines are typically
published annually on the boards and commissions meeting schedule.
      (2)   Compliance with those deadlines required by the PLAN Department or
the review and decision-making bodies must occur for the application to be
placed on an agenda to be heard by the review or decision-making body.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1081 PRELIMINARY STAFF REVIEW.
   (A)   Some application types, such as impact assessments and planned
development district text amendments, require preliminary staff review.
   (B)   The purpose of preliminary staff review is to provide an opportunity
for staff to review and provide comments on more complex applications, and for
the applicant to address staff’s comments prior to submittal of the application
for board or commission review. Preliminary staff reviews do not result in an
approval or disapproval of the application or create a vested right.
   (C)   The applicant must submit a complete application for preliminary staff
review on or before the next board or commission application deadline date
specified on the annual meeting schedule.
   (D)   Department of Planning, Land Use, and Neighborhoods staff will review
the proposed application and provide written comments to the applicant prior to
the next board or commission application deadline. Staff may also schedule a
meeting with the applicant to review these written comments, with such meeting
to occur prior to the next board or commission application deadline.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1082 NOTICE PROVISIONS.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   This section establishes various requirements for public notice of
applications. This section does not address general notice requirements for
board and commission meetings, which are specified in S.C. Code § 30-4-80:
Notice of meetings of public bodies.
      (2)   Table 156.1082-1: Type and Description of Notice, describes the
various types of notice and its contents. More specific notice requirements are
located in each procedural section.
 
Table 156.1082-1: Type and Description of Notice
Type of Notice Description
               PLAN Department staff will mail the required notices. Regular
Mail           mail is sufficient unless certified mail is required by a
               specific process or state law. Notices to property owners will
               be mailed to the owner listed in Charleston County tax records.
               PLAN Department staff will post at least one sign on the subject
Posted         lot(s) visible from each public street the lot abuts when
               required by state or local ordinance.
Publication    PLAN Department staff will place a notice in a newspaper of
               general circulation in the town.
 
   (B)   Posted notice.
      (1)   Posting by town. If posted notice is required, town staff will post
at least one notice sign in a conspicuous location on the subject lot(s)
visible from each public street the lot abuts.
      (2)   Maintenance by applicant.
         (a)   Once notice is posted on the subject property or properties by
town staff, the property owner or applicant is responsible for maintaining the
signs up until the hearing.
         (b)   If the sign or signs are removed, become damaged and unreadable,
or are not visible from each street that abuts the property after posting by
town staff for the advertised hearing date, the hearing may be postponed upon
motion and affirmative vote of the decision-making body to postpone, at which
time the hearing must be re-advertised at the expense of the applicant. The
application shall not be rescheduled until the applicant has reimbursed the
town for this cost.
   (C)   Written notification policy. The PLAN Department shall maintain a
written notification policy that may be amended from time to time. This policy
may include additional notice requirements that exceed minimum South Carolina
statutory requirements and the requirements of this code.
   (D)   Substantial compliance. All notice provisions require substantial
compliance.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1083 REMOVAL OF APPLICATIONS FROM A MEETING AGENDA.
   Staff may remove an application from a meeting agenda, even if the
application was complete and submitted on time, if:
   (A)   The application is missing information that could significantly change
the proposed development plan; or
   (B)   A variance or special exception use permit is necessary to accommodate
the proposed use or development plan.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1084 PUBLIC HEARINGS.
   (A)   Purpose. A public hearing gives interested parties an opportunity to
be heard. Public hearings are distinct from public meetings. A public meeting
is open to the public but does not necessarily include an opportunity for the
public to provide input.
   (B)   Public input and recordkeeping. If an application requires a public
hearing:
      (1)   The review or decision-making body, as applicable, shall allow the
applicant and all other interested members of the public a reasonable and fair
opportunity to be heard.
      (2)   The review or decision-making body’s Recording Secretary shall make
an accurate written summary of the proceedings.
   (C)   Rules of procedure for public hearings. The Town Council, Board of
Zoning Appeals, Planning Commission, and Historic District Preservation
Commission may adopt rules of procedure for public hearings by resolution or
bylaws.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1085 MODIFICATIONS TO APPROVED APPLICATIONS.
   (A)   Proposed modifications require review. When an applicant proposes a
modification to an application approved under this subchapter, the Zoning
Administrator shall determine whether the modification is minor and can be
administratively approved or is major and must be reviewed through the
applicable procedure in this subchapter.
   (B)   Modifications to Planned Development District ordinances. Any
modification to a Planned Development District ordinance requires review
through the same procedure as the original application (see
Subchapter I, Part 6).
   (C)   Modifications to all other applications.
      (1)   For all other application types, a major modification includes:
         (a)   A change to the site that affects the number of primary
structures, building location, or location of required site design elements
such as parking, open space, or site access;
         (b)   A change in height of the building(s) by more than ten feet or
one story;
         (c)   A 10% or greater change to the building footprint, density, or
intensity of uses;
         (d)   A 5% or greater change to lot coverage;
         (e)   A change in the architecture, exterior elevation of the building
(s), or type or style of dwelling units proposed to be constructed in a
particular area or block; and
         (f)   A change of more than 5% to areas devoted to open space or the
relocation of such areas.
      (2)   Major modifications require review through the same procedure as
the original application.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1086 BUILDING PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (A)   A building permit is required prior to the construction of any
building, including accessory buildings.
   (B)   Prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy:
      (1)   Clearing and repair of public facilities, including all stormwater
storage facilities, site work, and permanent erosion control features, shall be
reviewed for satisfactory completion and conformance with the approved site
plan and permit requirements;
      (2)   Easements disturbed without approval during the construction
process shall be restored to pre-permit conditions.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1087 REVIEW OF DECISIONS AND INTERPRETATIONS.
   (A)   The Zoning Administrator shall provide an annual report to the Town
Council on decisions of the Board of Zoning Appeals under Subchapter I, Part 17
and code interpretations rendered under
Subchapter I, Part 16.
   (B)   The report shall include any recommendations for amendments to this
chapter needed for consistency with these decisions.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1088 MORATORIA.
   (A)   Generally. A moratorium on development is justified in certain
circumstances and can be implemented to prevent property owners from hindering
and/or circumventing the zoning process.
   (B)   Authorization. The town may implement a moratorium using the process
specified in S.C. Code § 6-1-110, if deemed necessary and proper by Town
Council.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1089 THROUGH 156.1094 RESERVED.
PART 2: SUBMITTAL REQUIREMENTS
§ 156.1095 PURPOSE.
   This part establishes the information that applications must include in
order to be considered complete for review under this subchapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1096 FORMAT OF APPLICATIONS.
   (A)   Digital copies required. The applicant shall submit one complete
digital copy of all application materials.
   (B)   Paper copies may be required by staff. The applicant shall also
provide up to four complete paper copies of all application materials if
requested by PLAN Department staff.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1097 AUTHORIZATION OF AGENT.
   All applications for consideration by a board or commission shall include a
signed property owner acknowledgement form for applications to boards and
commissions authorizing the agent to act on the owner’s behalf, if an agent of
a lot owner submits an application on the owner’s behalf.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1098 APPLICATION CHECKLISTS.
   (A)   The PLAN Department maintains application submittal requirements
checklists for each type of procedure described in this subchapter. Each
application must include all elements required by this chapter and the
applicable checklist.
   (B)   This subchapter specifies additional submittal requirements for
certain procedures, such as impact assessments.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1099 RECORDED RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS.
   (A)   Pursuant to the provisions of S.C. Code § 6-29-1145, the applicant for
a development approval (permit) shall confirm that the activity for which
approval has been requested is not restricted by any recorded covenant that is
contrary to, conflicts with, or prohibits the activity, by signing a
development approval application (permit): recorded covenant affidavit or, for
online applications, indicating that fact where required on the application
form.
   (B)   If it has actual notice of the existence of a recorded covenant that
is contrary to, conflicts with, or prohibits the activity for which approval
has been requested, either from information in the affidavit, from materials or
information submitted by the applicant, or from any other source, including
other property holders, the town shall immediately cease processing the
application, request, or permit, and shall not approve the same unless
confirmation from the applicant is received that the restrictive covenant has
been released, by action of the appropriate authority or property holders, or
by court order.
   (C)   As used in this section:
      (1)   ACTUAL NOTICE is not constructive notice of documents filed in the
local offices concerning the property, and does not require the town to conduct
searches in any records offices for filed restrictive covenants;
      (2)   PERMIT does not mean an authorization to build or place a structure
on a tract or parcel of land, and expressly applies only to applications or
requests for approval of the following:
         (a)   Zoning map amendments;
         (b)   Variances;
         (c)   Special exception use permits; and
         (d)   Impact assessments.
      (3)   RESTRICTIVE COVENANT does not mean a restriction concerning a type
of structure that may be built or placed on a tract or parcel of land.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1100 PERMITS REQUIRED BY OTHER AGENCIES.
   (A)   Proof of permits to be provided with application. The applicant for
any permit under this chapter shall submit one complete digital (PDF) copy of
all final approvals required from any other local, state, and/or federal
permitting agencies. All approvals must be demonstrated to be up-to-date and in
effect.
   (B)   Permit not issued at time of application. In cases where the final
permitting agency approval has not been rendered at the time a town application
is submitted, the applicant shall provide one complete digital (PDF) copy of
the application submitted to other permitting agencies. Once final approval is
received, the applicant shall provide one complete digital (PDF) copy of the
permit to town staff prior to the start of operations.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1101 FEES.
   (A)   Fees established. The Department of Planning, Land Use, and
Neighborhoods Fee Schedule establishes fees for all applications required by
the Zoning Code and is updated when Town Council adopts new fees.
   (B)   Fees required. All applicable fees must be paid for an application to
be considered complete for review.
   (C)   Fee for re-advertising a public hearing.
      (1)   The applicant must pay the expense for posting the property and
publication to re-advertise the public hearing if:
         (a)   The applicant requests a deferral or delay of a public hearing;
or
         (b)   A public hearing does not proceed because the posted notice
signs have been removed, became damaged and unreadable, or were not visible
from each street that abuts the property after posting by town staff for the
advertised hearing date.
      (2)   The application may not be rescheduled until the applicant has
reimbursed the town for this cost.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1102 THROUGH 156.1109 RESERVED.
PART 3: ANNEXATION AND INITIAL ZONING
§ 156.1110 PURPOSE.
   This part describes how lots in unincorporated areas are annexed into the
Town of Mount Pleasant.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1111 APPLICABILITY.
   This part applies to any petition to expand the town’s municipal boundary.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1112 INITIATION.
   (A)   Annexation. An annexation petition is initiated in accordance with the
applicable requirements of S.C. Code Title 5, Chapter 3.
   (B)   Initial zoning.
      (1)   If the annexation petition is not accompanied by an application for
initial zoning:
         (a)   The initial zoning is applied in accordance with the procedure
in this part;
         (b)   The lot(s) proposed for annexation shall be zoned R-1,
Residential District, except as specified in division (B)(2) below; and
         (c)   The lot(s) proposed for annexation shall be incorporated into
any applicable overlay district, unless the applicant explicitly requests
exclusion of the lot(s) from the overlay district. In such cases, Town Council
decides whether to include or exclude the lot(s) from the overlay district.
      (2)   If the annexation petition is not accompanied by an application for
initial zoning and the future land use map designation of the lot(s) is:
         (a)   Rural Residential (Rural Neighborhoods in the text), then the
lot(s) shall be zoned RR, Rural Residential District;
         (b)   Settlement Community, then the lot(s) shall be zoned CC,
Community Conservation District;
         (c)   Recreation Open Space, then the lot(s) shall be zoned CR-O,
Conservation- Recreation-Open Space District; or
         (d)   Conservation, Marsh, and Wetlands (Conservation Open Space in
the text), then the lot(s) shall be zoned CO, Conservation-Open Space District.
All marsh, marsh islands, and other islands annexed into the town shall be
zoned CO, Conservation-Open Space District.
      (3)   If the annexation petition is accompanied by an application for
initial zoning:
         (a)   The initial zoning request follows the procedure specified in
Subchapter I, Part 6;
         (b)   The proposed zoning district should be in accordance with the
Comprehensive Plan; and
         (c)   The initial zoning application should include a request for the
lot(s) to be included in any applicable overlay districts; however, the
applicant may request exclusion of the lot(s) from the overlay district(s).
Town Council decides whether to include or exclude the lot(s) from the overlay
district(s).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1113 COMPLETENESS.
   See §
156.1080.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1114 NOTICE.
   (A)   Public notice may be required for an annexation petition, as specified
in S.C. Code Title 5, Chapter 3.
   (B)   Public notice is required for the initial zoning associated with an
annexation petition in accordance with Table 156.1114-1: Required Notice for
Initial Zoning.
 
Table 156.1114-1: Required Notice for Initial Zoning
   Key: N/A = not applicable
Type         Required To Whom        When
Mail         No       N/A            N/A
Posted       Yes      General public At least 15 days prior to public hearing
Publicatio n Yes      General public At least 15 days prior to public hearing
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1115 DECISION.
   (A)   Public hearing on initial zoning only.
      (1)   The Planning Commission shall hold a public hearing on the initial
zoning associated with an annexation petition. Since the initial zoning is
automatically applied in accordance with §
156.1112(B)(1) and (B)(2), the Planning Commission does not provide a
recommendation on the initial zoning.
      (2)   The Planning Commission does not hold a public hearing or make a
recommendation on the annexation petition.
   (B)   Town Council decision.
      (1)   Following the Planning Commission’s public hearing, Town Council
shall approve or disapprove the annexation petition. If Council approves the
annexation petition, the initial zoning automatically applies as provided in §
156.1112(B)(1) and (B)(2) unless the applicant has submitted an initial zoning
application as allowed by §
156.1112(B)(3).
         (a)   If Town Council feels the circumstances of the case warrant a
second public hearing, then it may vote to hold one.
         (b)   Town Council may defer the matter for further consideration or
remand the matter back to its Planning and Development Committee or Planning
Commission for further study and recommendation.
      (2)   Town Council may amend the Zoning Map to provide for initial zoning
of an annexed lot through the procedures specified in Chapter 30 of the Mount
Pleasant Code of Ordinances.
      (3)   After a period of six months, if readings of the annexation
petition and initial zoning are not finalized, the petition becomes null and
void, rescinding any Town Council action on the request. Resubmission of the
petition shall be processed as a new application with prescribed fees and all
other requirements met.
   (C)   Postponement requests and application withdrawals.
      (1)   Withdrawal of an annexation petition and initial zoning prior to
the advertisement for its initial public hearing or posting of the property is
considered as a termination of the petition. Resubmission of the petition shall
be processed as a new application with prescribed fees and all other
requirements met.
      (2)   A postponement request or withdrawal of an annexation petition and
initial zoning that occurs between the time of published advertisement of the
public hearing or posting of the property and the public hearing proceedings
shall be treated as a request denial. Reapplication is subject to a one-year
waiting period, unless granted a waiver by Council, as specified in §
156.1343.
      (3)   In either case, amendment processing shall terminate upon receipt
of written notice from the applicant or owner.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1116 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   In making its decision, Town Council shall consider the following factors:
   (A)   The relationship of the proposed annexation to the Comprehensive Plan;
   (B)   The fiscal impact of providing municipal services;
   (C)   Consideration of the annexation area’s existing conditions and
potential future needs for expansion or improvement of utility and
transportation infrastructure;
   (D)   Whether the town can efficiently and effectively provide services,
such as police and fire protection and trash collection;
   (E)   Whether annexation will create a tax burden or measurably reduce the
level of service(s) provided to existing citizens and property owners;
   (F)   Whether the proposed annexation creates new enclaves of unincorporated
area surrounded by the municipality; and
   (G)   Any other factors Town Council deems appropriate.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1117 SCOPE OF APPROVAL.
   (A)   Approval of an annexation petition and initial zoning becomes
effective immediately upon final reading by Town Council and the lot(s) is
subject to all laws and regulations of the Town of Mount Pleasant.
   (B)   Approval of an annexation petition and initial zoning does not
authorize development. Any development that occurs after annexation requires
additional approval, which may include site plan or subdivision plat approval,
if applicable, and building permits and certificates of occupancy.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1118 REAPPLICATION.
   (A)   When Town Council disapproves an annexation petition, the petition may
not be initiated on the same parcel or any part thereof for a period of 12
months, irrespective of change(s) in ownership;
      (1)   However, after receipt of written petition by the property owner(s)
or other body authorized to submit an annexation petition stating how
conditions have changed substantially in the community since prior
consideration of the annexation petition so as to justify another review, Town
Council may, on a case-by-case basis, waive the waiting period requirements by
a vote of a majority of members present and voting in favor, and direct PLAN
Department staff in writing to process the application.
      (2)   Denial of the petition is final. The one-year waiting period shall
be met before further consideration of a change in zoning district
classification.
   (B)   Resubmittal of an annexation petition shall be processed as a new
application with all fees specified in §
156.1101.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1119 APPEALS.
   This chapter does not authorize new rights to an appeal from or remedies for
adverse decisions by Town Council, but interested parties may pursue existing
remedies from the Circuit Court.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1120 RECORDKEEPING.
   (A)   Annexation petitions shall be assigned a file number and recorded in
the zoning GIS layer (see §
156.022). The initial zoning for the annexed lot(s) shall be depicted on the
Zoning Map.
   (B)   The Zoning Administrator shall maintain a record of all annexation
petitions and related materials.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1121 THROUGH 156.1124 RESERVED.
PART 4: COMPREHENSIVE PLAN ADOPTION
§ 156.1125 PURPOSE.
   This part describes how the town adopts a new Comprehensive Plan.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1126 APPLICABILITY.
   This part applies to the adoption of a new Comprehensive Plan. S.C. Code §
6-29-510(E) requires the town to update all elements of the Comprehensive Plan
at least every ten years. See
Subchapter I, Part 5 for the procedure to amend the current Comprehensive Plan
and Future Land Use Map.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1127 INITIATION.
   (A)   The process to create a new Comprehensive Plan may be initiated by:
      (1)   The Town Council, by adoption of a motion;
      (2)   The Planning Commission, by adoption of a motion; or
      (3)   Recommendation of the PLAN Department.
   (B)   Once the town has initiated the process to create a new Comprehensive
Plan, it may develop the plan as it deems appropriate. This may include the use
of advisory committees as authorized by S.C. Code § 6-29-520(A).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1128 COMPLETENESS.
   The town initiates this procedure without an application, so §
156.1080 does not apply.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1129 NOTICE.
   The notice specified in Table 156.1129-1 is required for adoption of the
Comprehensive Plan.
 
Table 156.1129-1: Required Notice for   Comprehensive Plan Adoption
   Key: N/A = not applicable
Type         Required To Whom        When
Mail         No       N/A            N/A
Posted       No       N/A            N/A
Publicatio n Yes      General public At least 30 days prior to public hearing
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1130 DECISION.
   (A)   Planning Commission.
      (1)   Recommendation of the Comprehensive Plan or any element must be by
resolution of the Planning Commission, carried by the affirmative votes of at
least a majority of the entire membership. The resolution must refer expressly
to maps and other descriptive matter intended by the Planning Commission to
form the whole or element of the recommended plan.
      (2)   The Planning Commission may recommend the adoption of the plan as a
whole or elements of the plan. The elements shall correspond with the major
geographical sections or divisions of the planning area or with functional
subdivisions of the subject matter of the Comprehensive Plan, or both.
      (3)   The Planning Commission Secretary shall provide a copy of the
recommended Comprehensive Plan or element to the Town Council and all other
legislative or administrative agencies affected by the Plan.
   (B)   Town Council.
      (1)   The Town Council shall conduct a public hearing on the
Comprehensive Plan or element, as applicable, prior to adoption.
      (2)   The Town Council may adopt the Comprehensive Plan as a whole by a
single ordinance or elements of the plan by successive ordinances. The elements
shall correspond with the major geographical sections or divisions of the
planning area or with functional subdivisions of the subject matter of the
Comprehensive Plan, or both.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1131 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   Adoption of a new Comprehensive Plan is not subject to specific review
criteria. The Comprehensive Plan establishes the community’s long-term vision
for Mount Pleasant and establishes policies related to land use, housing,
transportation, economic development, natural and cultural resources, community
facilities, public infrastructure and facilities, and community resilience.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1132 SCOPE OF APPROVAL.
   Adoption of the Comprehensive Plan is a formal statement of town policy. It
does not authorize or require specific actions as a result.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1133 REAPPLICATION.
   The town initiates this procedure without an application, so this section
does not apply.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1134 APPEALS.
   This chapter does not authorize new rights to an appeal from or remedies for
adverse decisions by the Town Council, but interested parties may pursue
existing remedies from the Circuit Court.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1135 RECORDKEEPING.
   (A)   When the Town Council adopts a new Comprehensive Plan, it shall
maintain at least one physical copy at Town Hall for public review and shall
post a digital copy on the town website.
   (B)   When the Town Council adopts a new Future Land Use Map, the PLAN
Director works with the Information Technology Division of the Finance and
Corporate Services Department to update the Future Land Use GIS layer.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1136 THROUGH 156.1139 RESERVED.
PART 5: COMPREHENSIVE PLAN AND FUTURE LAND USE MAP AMENDMENTS
§ 156.1140 PURPOSE.
   This part describes how the town makes changes to the Comprehensive Plan.
For example, an applicant may use this procedure to ask the town to change the
future land use category designated on the Future Land Use Map for a specific
lot. Also, S.C. Code § 6-29-510(E) requires the Planning Commission to review
the Comprehensive Plan or elements of it as often as necessary, but at least
once every five years, to determine whether changes in the amount, kind, or
direction of development of the area or other reasons make it desirable to
amend the plan.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1141 APPLICABILITY.
   This part applies to any request to amend the Comprehensive Plan, including
amendments to the Future Land Use Map.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1142 INITIATION.
   (A)   The process to amend any part of the adopted Comprehensive Plan may be
initiated by:
      (1)   The Town Council, by adoption of a motion;
      (2)   The Planning Commission, by adoption of a motion; or
      (3)   Recommendation of the PLAN Department.
   (B)   The process to amend the Comprehensive Plan Future Land Use Map may be
initiated by any of the agencies specified in division (A) above, or by any
property owner in the Town of Mount Pleasant.
      (1)   A property owner may only request a change in the Future Land Use
Map designation of their lot(s).
      (2)   When a property owner submits a Future Land Use Map Amendment
application, the property owner may concurrently submit a zoning map amendment
(rezoning) application (see Subchapter I, Part 6) for consistency with the
proposed Future Land Use Map amendment, if the current zoning is inconsistent
with the proposed Future Land Use Map designation.
   (C)   An application for a Comprehensive Plan or Future Land Use Map
amendment is filed with the PLAN Department.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1143 COMPLETENESS
   When a property owner submits a Future Land Use Map amendment application, §
156.1080 applies.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1144 NOTICE.
   The notice specified in Table 156.1144-1 is required for a Comprehensive
Plan or Future Land Use Map amendment application.
 
Table 156.1144-1: Required Notice for  Comprehensive Plan and Future Land
Use Map Amendments
   Key: N/A = not applicable
Type        Required To Whom        When
Mail        No       N/A            N/A
Posted      No       N/A            N/A
Publication Yes      General public At least 30 days prior to public hearing
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1145 DECISION.
   (A)   Planning Commission.
      (1)   The Planning Commission shall consider the request and provide a
recommendation.
      (2)   For Comprehensive Plan amendments, the Commission shall provide a
recommendation for approval, approval with modifications, or disapproval of the
proposed amendment.
      (3)   For Future Land Use Map amendments, the Commission shall provide a
recommendation for approval or disapproval of the proposed amendment.
      (4)   Recommendation of a Comprehensive Plan amendment must be by
resolution of the Planning Commission, carried by the affirmative votes of at
least a majority of the entire membership.
   (B)   Town Council.
      (1)   The Town Council shall conduct a public hearing on the proposed
amendment prior to adoption.
      (2)   For Comprehensive Plan Amendments, the Town Council shall approve,
approve with modifications, or disapprove the proposed amendment.
      (3)   For Future Land Use Map amendments, the Town Council shall approve
or disapprove the proposed amendment.
      (4)   The Town Council may, on its own motion or at the applicant’s
request, defer its decision and table the request for not more than 60 calendar
days from the date of the public hearing to consider other information that may
have a direct bearing on the decision.
      (5)   If the Town Council elects to table the request, the tabling shall
specifically state the meeting date at which the proposed amendment shall
reappear on the Town Council agenda. Further notice is not required.
      (6)   Approval of a Comprehensive Plan or Future Land Use Map amendment
requires a supermajority (75%) of voting members of Town Council. When
calculating the number of votes required to achieve a 75% supermajority, any
fraction is rounded up to the next highest whole number.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1146 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   In considering any Comprehensive Plan or Future Land Use Map amendment
application, the Planning Commission and Town Council shall consider the
following criteria:
   (A)   Whether the proposed amendment is consistent with other policies and
recommendations in the Comprehensive Plan;
   (B)   Whether the proposed amendment is consistent with other adopted town
plans and policies relevant to the application;
   (C)   Whether the amendment is consistent with sound planning principles;
and
   (D)   Any other factors the Commission or Council deem appropriate.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1147 SCOPE OF APPROVAL.
   A Comprehensive Plan or Future Land Use Map amendment is a formal change in
town policy. It does not authorize or require specific actions as a result.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1148 REAPPLICATION.
   When Town Council disapproves a Comprehensive Plan or Future Land Use Map
amendment application, the same amendment may not be initiated for a period of
12 months.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1149 APPEALS.
   This chapter does not authorize new rights to an appeal from or remedies for
adverse decisions by the Town Council, but interested parties may pursue
existing remedies from the Circuit Court.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1150 RECORDKEEPING.
   (A)   When the Town Council approves changes to the text of the
Comprehensive Plan, the PLAN Director updates the Comprehensive Plan to include
these changes or adds the changes as an appendix to the Plan, as appropriate.
   (B)   When the Town Council approves changes to the Future Land Use Map, the
PLAN Director updates the Future Land Use GIS layer.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1151 THROUGH 156.1154 RESERVED.
PART 6: ZONING MAP AMENDMENTS (REZONINGS)
§ 156.1155 PURPOSE.
   This part describes the way the town changes the zoning classification of a
lot.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1156 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   This part applies to any proposal to amend the Zoning Map, including
any proposal to establish a new Planned Development (PD) District. In
accordance with S.C. Code § 6-29-740, any request involving the establishment
of a PD District or is considered an amendment to this chapter.
   (B)   Amendments to existing PD Districts follow the procedure specified in
Subchapter I, Part 18.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1157 INITIATION.
   (A)   Applicant eligibility. A Zoning Map amendment application may be
initiated by:
      (1)   Town Council by adoption of a motion;
      (2)   Planning Commission by adoption of a motion;
      (3)   The owner of the subject property, or their agent; and
      (4)   The Zoning Administrator.
   (B)   Pre-application meeting. A pre-application meeting is required, if the
application is filed by the property owner or their agent (see §
156.1079).
   (C)   Application requirements.
      (1)   A Zoning Map Amendment application is filed with the PLAN
Department on or before the Planning Commission application deadline specified
on the annual meeting schedule. Applications may be filed electronically.
      (2)   Only one Zoning Map amendment application pertaining to the same
property shall be considered at a time.
   (D)   Zoning Map amendments for Planned Development Districts.
      (1)   Planned Development District Zoning Map amendment applications are
first submitted for preliminary staff review (see §
156.1081).
      (2)   Following preliminary staff review, the Planned Development
District text amendment application is submitted in accordance with §
156.1337(B)(1).
      (3)   If a proposed Planned Development District text amendment
application involves the text of a development agreement proposed or adopted
pursuant to the provisions of
Chapter 157, the applicant must submit the complete application at least 56
days prior to the meeting at which the Planning Commission will consider the
amendment.
   (E)   Town-initiated rezoning.
      (1)   When the Town Council or the Planning Commission initiates a
rezoning, PLAN Department staff will notify the owners of the property by
written notice by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested. The
letter must be mailed at least 21 days prior to the Planning Commission public
hearing on the rezoning.
      (2)   If the addressee of any required notice under this section fails or
refuses to accept or sign a return receipt for the notice, or the notice is
returned undelivered, the notice may be served by regular mail, deposited in
the United States mail, properly stamped, to the address used by the addressee
for tax purposes, or the notice may be served in any manner permitted under
Rule 4 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, and an affidavit of the
official required to give the notice, setting forth the time and manner of
service of the notice, will be conclusive evidence of the giving of the notice
under this section.
      (3)   Posted notice on each affected parcel is not required for town-
initiated rezoning for large areas. Notice for rezoning of large areas will be
posted at prominent locations and intersections.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1158 COMPLETENESS.
   See §
156.1080.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1159 NOTICE.
   The notice specified in Table 156.1159-1 is required for a Zoning Map
amendment application.
 
Table 156.1159-1: Required Notice for Zoning Map Amendments
   Key: N/A = not applicable
Type        Required To Whom        When
Mail        No       N/A            N/A
Posted      Yes      General public At least 15 days prior to public hearing
Publication Yes      General public At least 15 days prior to public hearing
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1160 DECISION.
   (A)   Planning Commission review and recommendation.
      (1)   The Planning Commission shall review all Zoning Map amendment
applications and prepare a report and recommendation, stating its findings and
its evaluation of the proposed amendment. In making its report, the Commission
shall consider the criteria specified in §
156.1161.
      (2)   The Planning Commission shall hold a public hearing. From the
closing date of the public hearing, the Commission has 30 days in which to
submit its report and recommendation to Town Council. A public hearing by the
Commission shall not be extended for more than a period of 30 days. Once a
public hearing begins, it must be closed no later than 30 days from the
commencement date.
      (3)   If the Commission fails to submit its report to Town Council within
the required 30 days, it is deemed to have recommended approval of the
proposal.
   (B)   Town Council decision.
      (1)   Town Council may amend the Zoning Map through the procedures
specified in Chapter 30 of the Mount Pleasant Code of Ordinances.
      (2)   Following the recommendation of the Planning Commission, Council
shall approve or disapprove the proposed amendment. In rendering its decision,
Town Council shall consider, but is not bound by, the recommendation of the
Planning Commission.
         (a)   If Town Council feels the circumstances of the case warrant a
second public hearing, then it may vote to hold one.
         (b)   Town Council may defer the matter for further consideration or
remand the matter back to its Planning and Development Committee or Planning
Commission for further study and recommendation.
      (3)   No change in or departure from the Zoning Map Amendment as
recommended by the Planning Commission may be made pursuant to the hearing
unless the change or departure is first submitted to the Planning Commission
for review and recommendation.
      (4)   After a period of six months from the Planning Commission
recommendation, if readings of the Zoning Map Amendment application are not
finalized, the application becomes null and void, rescinding any Town Council
action on the request. Any further Council action on the same request that has
been denied or expires requires a public hearing by the Planning Commission
before Town Council acts upon subsequent readings of the amending ordinance.
   (C)   Postponement requests and application withdrawals.
      (1)   Withdrawal of a Zoning Map amendment application prior to the
advertisement for its initial public hearing or posting of the property is
considered as a termination of the application. Resubmission of applications
shall be processed as a new application with prescribed fees and all other
requirements met.
      (2)   A postponement request or withdrawal of a Zoning Map amendment
application that occurs between the time of published advertisement of the
public hearing or posting of the property and the public hearing proceedings
shall be treated as a request denial. Reapplication is subject to a one-year
waiting period, unless granted a waiver by Council, as specified in §
156.1343.
      (3)   In either case, amendment processing shall terminate upon receipt
of written notice from the applicant or owner.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1161 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   (A)   As a matter of policy, Town Council shall not approve a Zoning Map
amendment application, except:
      (1)   Where necessary to implement the Comprehensive Plan;
      (2)   To correct an original mistake, a manifest error in the
regulations;
      (3)   To recognize substantial change or changing conditions or
circumstances in a particular locality; or
      (4)   To recognize changes in technology, the style of living, or manner
of doing business.
   (B)   In making its decision, Town Council shall consider the following
factors, as applicable:
      (1)   The relationship of the proposed Zoning Map amendment application
to the Comprehensive Plan and Future Land Use Map;
      (2)   Whether the request supports or contradicts the Comprehensive Plan;
      (3)   The relationship of the proposed Zoning Map amendment to other
relevant plans adopted by the town;
      (4)   Whether the uses allowed by the proposed change would be
appropriate in the area concerned;
      (5)   Whether adequate public school facilities, roads, and other public
services exist or can be provided to serve the needs of the development likely
to take place as a result of such change, and the consequences of such change;
      (6)   Whether the proposed change is in accordance with any existing or
proposed plans for providing public water supply and sanitary sewers to the
area;
      (7)   The amount of vacant land currently classified for similar
development in the vicinity and elsewhere in the town, and any special
circumstances that may make a substantial part of such vacant land unavailable
for development;
      (8)   Whether the proposed Zoning Map amendment is consistent with
Chapter 155;
      (9)   Whether the proposed Zoning Map amendment is consistent with best
practices for community planning and design; and
      (10)   Whether public necessity, safety, or general welfare justifies the
Zoning Map amendment.
   (C)   When a Zoning Map amendment application includes property located
within the boundaries of an overlay district, the application will be
considered in context with the purpose of the overlay district.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1162 SCOPE OF APPROVAL.
   (A)   A Zoning Map Amendment becomes effective immediately upon final
reading by Town Council.
   (B)   Approval of a Zoning Map amendment application does not authorize
development. Any development that occurs after the Zoning Map amendment is
adopted requires additional approval, which may include site plan or
subdivision plat approval, if applicable, and building permits and certificates
of occupancy.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1163 REAPPLICATION.
   (A)   When Town Council disapproves a Zoning Map amendment application, the
same amendment may not be initiated on the same parcel or any part thereof for
a period of 12 months, irrespective of change(s) in ownership;
      (1)   However, after receipt of written petition by the property owner(s)
or other body authorized to submit a Zoning Map amendment application stating
how conditions have changed substantially in the community since prior
consideration of the Zoning Map amendment application so as to justify another
review, Town Council may, on a case- by-case basis, waive the waiting period
requirements by a vote of a majority of members present and voting in favor,
and direct PLAN Department staff in writing to process the application.
      (2)   Denial of the petition is final. The one-year waiting period shall
be met before further consideration of a change in zoning district
classification.
   (B)   Resubmittal of a Zoning Map amendment application shall be processed
as a new application with all fees specified in §
156.1101.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1164 APPEALS.
   This chapter does not authorize new rights to an appeal from or remedies for
adverse decisions by Town Council, but interested parties may pursue existing
remedies from the Circuit Court.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1165 RECORDKEEPING.
   (A)   Zoning Map amendments shall be assigned a file number and recorded in
the zoning GIS layer (see §
156.022).
   (B)   The Zoning Administrator shall maintain a record of all Zoning Map
amendment applications and related materials.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1166 THROUGH 156.1169 RESERVED.
PART 7: ZONING PERMITS
§ 156.1170 PURPOSE.
   The zoning permit procedure allows the Zoning Administrator to review new
uses, structures, activities, and developments prior to establishment of the
use or commencement of development activities to ensure they:
   (A)   Comply with the standards in this chapter;
   (B)   Have appropriate design and infrastructure; and
   (C)   Comply with any conditions of approval required by other procedures,
such as design review, special exception use permits, and variances.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1171 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   This part applies to an application for zoning permit approval. Unless
elsewhere exempted by this chapter, an applicant shall obtain a zoning permit
prior to:
      (1)   Clearing, excavating, or filling of any lot for any site
improvements;
      (2)   Constructing any building, or commencing construction of any
building on an already prepared lot;
      (3)   Commencing the moving or alteration of any building;
      (4)   Establishing a new principal use, including conditional uses and
special exception uses;
      (5)   Changing one existing principal use to another;
      (6)   Reestablishing a use after a period of non-use of 180 days or more;
      (7)   Establishing a new accessory use, including conditional accessory
uses;
      (8)   Establishing a temporary use;
      (9)   Removing a protected tree on a developed lot;
      (10)   Removing vegetation other than invasive species or initiating land
disturbance activity of any kind in a critical area buffer, wetland buffer, or
historical and cultural resources buffer;
      (11)   Erecting, moving, altering, replacing, or changing copy on (except
on readerboard signs) any sign;
      (12)   Issuance of a building permit, if applicable; and
      (13)   Issuance of a business license, if applicable.
   (B)   Zoning permit applications for communications towers or small wireless
facilities are subject to the requirements in this part and in Subchapter I,
Parts 19 and 20, as applicable.
   (C)   This part does not apply to the construction of fences seven feet in
height or less, unless they are:
      (1)   Constructed of brick, stone, or concrete; or
      (2)   Located on a corner lot along one or more lot lines adjacent to a
street right-of-way.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1172 INITIATION.
   (A)   Applicant eligibility. A zoning permit application may be initiated
by:
      (1)   The property owner or tenant of the subject property; or
      (2)   An agent of the property owner or tenant of the subject property.
   (B)   Application requirements.
      (1)   Generally. A zoning permit application is filed with the PLAN
Department. Applications may be filed electronically or in-person.
      (2)   Site plan.
         (a)   A site plan with adequate detail of features such as building
layout, setbacks, easements, parking, circulation systems, tree protection
zones, and buffers must be submitted in conjunction with the zoning permit
application.
         (b)   An application filed without an adequate site plan is considered
incomplete, unless the Zoning Administrator determines a site plan is not
necessary for the particular proposal. The Zoning Administrator may make such
determination when the applicant can demonstrate compliance with this chapter
through other means.
   (C)   Concurrent applications. A zoning permit application may be filed
concurrently with a building permit application.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1173 COMPLETENESS.
   See §
156.1080.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1174 NOTICE.
   Notice is not required for a zoning permit.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1175 DECISION.
   The Zoning Administrator reviews and approves or disapproves a zoning permit
application.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1176 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   (A)   The Zoning Administrator shall review the zoning permit application
for compliance with applicable provisions of the Zoning Code.
   (B)   When a zoning permit application includes two or more lots proposed
for development as a single, unified site, all setback and screening
requirements apply only to the exterior lot lines of the unified development
site and not to internal lot lines within the unified site, unless otherwise
required by another procedure.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1177 SCOPE OF APPROVAL.
   Approval of a zoning permit application authorizes:
   (A)   The Building Official to issue a building permit for the proposed
construction, if applicable;
   (B)   The Business License Official to issue a business license for the
proposed use, if applicable; and
   (C)   The applicant to proceed with the use or development described in the
approved zoning permit application.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1178 REAPPLICATION.
   There is no time limit on refiling a withdrawn or disapproved zoning permit
application.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1179 APPEALS.
   The Zoning Administrator’s decision on a zoning permit application may be
appealed to the Board of Zoning Appeals in accordance with
Subchapter I, Part 17.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1180 RECORDKEEPING.
   The Zoning Administrator shall maintain a record of all zoning permit
applications and related materials.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1181 THROUGH 156.1184 RESERVED.
PART 8: SHORT-TERM RENTAL PERMITS
