§ 156.1185 CROSS-REFERENCE TO APPLICABLE PROCEDURE.
   The procedure for establishment of a short-term rental is specified in
Subchapter C, Part 6.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1186 THROUGH 156.1199 RESERVED.
PART 9: SPECIAL EXCEPTION USE PERMITS
§ 156.1200 PURPOSE.
   Some land uses, buildings, or structures are not appropriate under all
circumstances in a given zoning district but may be appropriate if adequate
precautions are taken to assure compatibility with surrounding uses, public
need, and the town as a whole. This part allows such uses through a special
exception use permit.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1201 APPLICABILITY.
   This part applies to an application for a special exception use permit. An
applicant shall obtain a special exception use permit before changing a use to
or establishing a new use that is designated as a special exception use for the
zoning district, as shown in §
156.338.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1202 INITIATION.
   (A)   Applicant eligibility. A special exception use permit application may
be initiated by:
      (1)   The property owner or tenant of the property proposed for the use;
or
      (2)   An agent of the property owner or tenant of the property proposed
for the use.
   (B)   Pre-application meeting. A pre-application meeting is required (see §
156.1079).
   (C)   Application requirements.
      (1)   A special exception use permit application is filed with the PLAN
Department on or before the Board of Zoning Appeals application deadline
specified on the annual meeting schedule. Applications may be filed
electronically or in-person.
      (2)   A conceptual site plan with adequate detail of features such as
building layout, setbacks, easements, parking, circulation systems, and buffers
must be submitted in conjunction with the special exception use permit
application. An application filed without an adequate conceptual site plan is
considered incomplete.
   (D)   Effect on other proceedings. A special exception use permit request
that would correct a zoning violation stays all legal proceedings by the town
on the zoning violation, unless the Zoning Administrator certifies to the Board
of Zoning Appeals, after the special exception use permit application has been
filed, that a stay would cause an imminent peril to life and property. In cases
where there is an imminent peril to life and property, proceedings will not be
stayed unless a restraining order is granted by the Board or by a court of
record on application.
   (E)   Consideration for Planning Commission and Town Council procedures. As
a matter of process and procedure, proposed developments involving applications
for special exception uses that also require separate review by the Planning
Commission and/or separate Town Council approval, shall not be considered by
the Board of Zoning Appeals until the referenced review and/or approval is
completed.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1203 COMPLETENESS.
   See §
156.1080.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1204 NOTICE.
   (A)   The notice specified in Table 156.1204-1 is required for a special
exception use permit application.
   (B)   If the Board remands a special exception use permit request to the
Zoning Administrator for further review, the Board may set a hearing without
further public notice for a time certain within 60 days unless otherwise agreed
to by the parties. The Board must maintain a list of persons who express an
interest in being informed when the remanded matter is set for rehearing, and
notice of the rehearing must be mailed to these persons before the rehearing.
 
Table 156.1204-1: Required Notice for Special Exception Use Permit
Applications
   Key: N/A = not applicable
Type         Required To Whom             When
Mail         Yes      Parties in interest Due notice
Posted       Yes      General public      Prior to public hearing
Publicatio n Yes      General public      At least 15 days prior to public
                                          hearing
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1205 DECISION.
   (A)   The Board of Zoning Appeals will hear all applications for special
exception use permits and will render a decision in each matter.
   (B)   The Board will hear a special exception use request within 60 days of
the date the application is deemed complete.
   (C)   At the hearing, any party may appear in person or by agent or by
attorney.
   (D)   The burden of proof for the relief sought is upon the applicant.
   (E)   Based on the hearing and probable impact of the proposed use on
surrounding uses and conditions, the Board may approve, approve with
conditions, or disapprove the request. The Board may approve a special
exception use permit application subject to such reasonable terms and
conditions as it may consider necessary to accomplish the intent of this part
and this entire Zoning Code.
   (F)   On its own motion or the motion of a party, the Board may remand a
special exception use permit request to the Zoning Administrator if the Board
determines the record is insufficient for review. special exception use permit
applications that are remanded must be rescheduled for hearing within 60 days
unless the parties agree on an extension.
   (G)   The Board will issue a written decision within 45 days of the final
hearing on the matter.
   (H)   All final decisions or orders of the Board will be delivered to
parties-in-interest by certified mail.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1206 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   (A)   In considering an application for a special exception use permit, the
Board shall:
      (1)   Apply the standards for the proposed special exception use as set
out in
Subchapter C, Part 3, Subpart 3.3; and
      (2)   Use the following general criteria for judging the compatibility of
the proposal with the surrounding area:
         (a)   Adequate provision is made for such items as setbacks, fences,
and buffer or planting strips to protect adjacent properties from the possible
adverse influence of the proposed use, such as noise, vibration, dust, glare,
odor, traffic congestion, and similar factors;
         (b)   Vehicular traffic and pedestrian movement on adjacent roads is
not hindered or endangered;
         (c)   Off-street parking and loading areas and the entrance(s) and
exit(s) of these areas are adequate in terms of location, amount, design, and
construction to serve the proposed use; and
         (d)   The proposed use is compatible with existing uses to the extent
that such use will not adversely affect the level of property values, general
character, or general welfare of the nearby area.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1207 SCOPE OF APPROVAL.
   (A)   Generally. An approved special exception use permit application does
not authorize construction or development. All special exception uses also
require zoning permit approval, following approval by the Board of Zoning
Appeals and prior to the establishment of the use.
   (B)   Approval based on submitted plans.
      (1)   Unless specifically modified by the Board's approval, the special
exception use must be established in accordance with the specific plans
submitted with the application.
      (2)   Minor changes to the approved plans that do not affect the approval
granted may be allowed in order to meet other code requirements, if approved by
the Zoning Administrator.
      (3)   Routine repairs and maintenance may be made to a structure
constructed pursuant to special exception use permit approval as required to
preserve it in sound condition. Any proposed changes to the structure shall be
presented to the Board Secretary for a determination as to whether a new
application is required.
   (C)   Vested rights.
      (1)   In order to complete additional applications and receive the
necessary permits for construction, special exception use permits are vested
for a period of two years, subject to the rights and restrictions contained
within this title.
      (2)   Failure to receive the necessary permits within the prescribed
timeframe renders the special exception use permit approval void and of no
force or effect.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1208 REAPPLICATION.
   (A)   For a period of 12 months, the Board shall not accept a special
exception use permit application for a matter upon which it has rendered a
final decision, except as provided in the Board’s rules of procedure.
   (B)   Prior to the lapse of the 12-month timeframe and upon a majority vote
ascertaining changed facts or circumstances, the Board may accept such a
special exception permit application for consideration.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1209 APPEALS.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   A person who may have a substantial interest in any decision of the
Board of Zoning Appeals, or an officer or agent of the Town of Mount Pleasant,
may appeal from a decision of the Board to the Circuit Court of Charleston
County, by filing with the Clerk of Court a petition, in writing, setting forth
plainly, fully, and distinctly why the decision is contrary to law. The appeal
must be filed within 30 days after the decision of the Board is mailed.
      (2)   A property owner whose land is the subject of a decision of the
Board of Zoning Appeals may appeal either:
         (a)   As provided in this division (A); or
         (b)   By filing a notice of appeal with the Circuit Court, accompanied
by a request for pre-litigation mediation in accordance with S.C. Code § 6-29-
825. Any notice of appeal and request for pre-litigation mediation must be
filed within 30 days after the decision of the Board is postmarked.
   (B)   Notice of appeal and transcript. Upon the filing of the appeal, the
Clerk of the Circuit Court shall give immediate notice of it to the Secretary
of the Board and, within 30 days from the time of the notice, the Board shall
file with the Clerk a certified copy of the proceedings held before the Board
of Zoning Appeals, including a transcript of the evidence heard before it, if
any, and the decision of the Board, including its findings of fact and
conclusions.
   (C)   Supersedeas. The filing of an appeal in the Circuit Court from a
decision of the Board shall not ipso facto act as a supersedeas, but the judge
of the Circuit Court may, at their discretion, grant a supersedeas upon such
terms and conditions as may seem reasonable and proper.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1210 RECORDKEEPING.
   (A)   The Board will keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of
each member upon each question, or if absent or failing to vote, indicating the
fact.
   (B)   The Board will issue a written decision to all parties involved in the
matter.
   (C)   All final decisions and orders of the Board must be in writing and
permanently filed in the PLAN Department office as a public record. All
findings of fact and conclusions of law must be separately stated in final
decisions or orders of the Board, which must be delivered to parties of
interest by certified mail.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1211 THROUGH 156.1214 RESERVED.
PART 10: IMPACT ASSESSMENTS
§ 156.1215 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of an impact assessment is to provide a basis for assessing a
proposed major development project's favorable or unfavorable impact on the
town's overall environment and infrastructure, with an emphasis on
transportation, drainage, and service provision.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1216 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   Minimum thresholds. Impact assessments are required for new
development and redevelopment that meet the following minimum thresholds:
      (1)   New development of land.
         (a)   An impact assessment is required when one or more of the
following conditions are met:
            1.   The proposed development is comprised of residential uses that
are projected to generate more than 75 peak hour vehicle trips; or
            2.   The proposed development is comprised of 40,000 square feet or
more of non-residential area, and is projected to generate more than more than
75 peak hour vehicle trips; or
            3.   The proposed development is comprised of a combination of
residential and non-residential uses such that the residential component only
is projected to generate more than 75 peak hour vehicle trips, and the non-
residential component consists of 40,000 square feet or more of area.
         (b)   Projected peak hour vehicle trips are determined by the Zoning
Administrator in consultation with the Director of Engineering and Development
Services.
         (c)   Calculations of total square footage of open venues for
entertainment, recreation, and civic uses, such as playing fields,
amphitheaters, or concert lawns, shall include the open area square footage.
      (2)   Redevelopment of improved property. An impact assessment is
required for redevelopment projects when the net increase in both peak hour
vehicle trips and building square footage meets the threshold requirements
specified in division (A)(1)(a) above. The impacts assessed shall be predicated
only upon the net increase of peak hour vehicle trips and building square
footage.
   (B)   Project phasing.
      (1)   The subdivision of a project into development phases, or any
staging proposals (irrespective of ownership), or subdivision of a larger
parcel into smaller parcels for sale or development, does not void the
requirement of an impact assessment for the overall project.
      (2)   In phased development projects, additional impact assessments may
be required, if the proposed development phase meets any of the minimum
threshold requirements.
      (3)   The determination of whether additional impact assessments are
required is made by the Zoning Administrator at the time of the developer's
additional plan approval request.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1217 INITIATION.
   (A)   Pre-application meeting. An applicant initiates the Impact Assessment
procedure by attending a pre-application meeting with staff from the PLAN
Department and the Department of Engineering and Development Services.
      (1)   During the pre-application meeting, the developer must identify the
type of development and size; access requirements; land use types and
densities; project phasing; and the anticipated build-out year for the proposed
development. The developer shall also present any available construction plans,
concept drawings, or figures of the proposed development.
      (2)   The developer shall also request any needed clarifications of the
remaining process. Town staff shall provide guidance concerning the
transportation impact assessment process (see §
156.1218(F)) and assist in identifying any additional information that is
required.
      (3)   It is not necessary for the applicant to complete the
transportation impact assessment data form (see §
156.1218(F)(3)) prior to the pre-application meeting, but having the requested
information readily available will make the meeting more productive.
   (B)   Transportation impact assessment process. The transportation impact
assessment process is initiated in accordance with §
156.1218(F)(2), which requires a pre-application meeting as specified in
division (A) above.
   (C)   Transportation impact assessment data form. Following the pre-
application meeting, the applicant must submit a complete transportation impact
assessment data form (see §
156.1218(F)(3)) at least eight weeks prior to the Planning Commission meeting
at which the impact assessment is anticipated to be considered.
   (D)   Preliminary staff review. Submittal of an impact assessment for
preliminary staff review (see §
156.1081) is required. Impact assessments submitted for preliminary staff
review are not required to include a complete traffic study, but traffic
summaries and anticipated mitigation should be provided for review.
   (E)   Impact assessment application submittal. Once the applicant has
completed the preliminary impact assessment review, they may submit a complete
impact assessment application for consideration by the Planning Commission and
Town Council. The application must be submitted on or before the Planning
Commission application deadline specified on the annual meeting schedule.
   (F)   Zoning requests.
      (1)   Requests for zoning of property proposed for annexation or rezoning
requests for property located within the municipal limits and for which no
specific development plan is contemplated do not require submittal for impact
assessment approval in conjunction with the zoning/rezoning request.
      (2)   However, if a specific development plan is contemplated that will
require impact assessment approval, the impact assessment may be submitted in
conjunction with the zoning/rezoning request.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1218 SUBMITTAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   Generally. The impact assessment shall be prepared by qualified
professionals pursuant to checklist forms devised and provided by the
Department of Planning, Land Use, and Neighborhoods, and shall include, but is
not limited to, the information specified in this section.
   (B)   Conceptual plan. The impact assessment shall be submitted with a
conceptual plan, the requirements of which are compiled in a checklist by the
Department of Planning, Land Use, and Neighborhoods, and may be subject to
alteration from time to time, as deemed necessary.
   (C)   General description of proposed major development project. Provide a
general written description of the proposed major development project. Include
in this description the proposed phases of development or operation and
facility utilization, target dates for each of these, and date of completion.
In addition:
      (1)   Indicate the site size, development staging, and appropriate
descriptive measures of the proposed project;
      (2)   Describe the relationship of the proposed development to the town
Comprehensive Plan's objectives and policies;
      (3)   Indicate the relationship to existing or proposed plans for public
facilities, such as parks and recreation, schools, transportation, wastewater
treatment, and the like; and
      (4)   Describe the relationship of the proposed project to any of the
town's special area management plans.
   (D)   Specific impacts on public facilities – water supply, and wastewater
management. Identify projected average daily potable water demands at the end
of each development phase. Specify any consumption rates that have been assumed
for the project. Provide a description of the volume and characteristics of
effluents.
   (E)   Specific impacts on public facilities – drainage. Provide the
following minimum requirements to adequately determine the impacts from changes
to the stormwater characteristics of the land:
      (1)   Current drainage pattern of the property, which shall include
topographic information represented with one-foot contours;
      (2)   Sub-watershed map identifying significant drainage features within
the nearest receiving waterbody drainage basin;
      (3)   When repetitive flood losses have been documented on FEMA reporting
forms within the sub-watershed basin, provide a hydrology analysis that
demonstrates no change in conditions upstream or downstream from the proposed
development;
      (4)   Water quality plan describing how the impairment will be addressed
during and after construction, when the receiving waterbody contains a total
maximum daily loading (TMDL) restriction, or when an impaired monitoring
station that is identified on the South Carolina Department of Environmental
Services Bureau of Water 303d list.
   (F)   Specific impacts on public facilities – transportation. The following
procedures shall be used to identify traffic impacts and mitigation strategies
associated with the proposed development project and may be referred to as the
“transportation impact assessment process.”
      (1)   Purpose.
         (a)   The purpose of this division (F) is to establish a process
allowing town staff and officials to better understand the relationship between
new development and the existing and proposed transportation infrastructure.
         (b)   It will provide a highly detailed analytical tool for the
identification of transportation deficiencies and corresponding mitigation
strategies addressing the impacts related to new development.
         (c)   The described analysis and resulting mitigation strategies are
predicated upon an accepted operational Level of Service D for suburban
population areas, as recommended in the town's adopted Transportation Plan as
included in the current Comprehensive Plan. It is not intended to provide
justification for the denial of individual development projects, per se, based
solely upon the inability to provide an operational Level of Service D to all
roadway segments identified as the transportation influence area described
herein.
      (2)   Transportation impact assessment process initiation. To engage in
the formal transportation impact assessment review process, the developer must
obtain a transportation impact assessment application package from the
Department of Engineering and Development Services, schedule a pre-application
meeting (see §
156.1217), and ultimately complete the application. The package will contain a
description of the review process, a checklist of required information, and a
transportation impact assessment data form.
      (3)   Transportation impact assessment data form.
         (a)   Once the pre-application meeting (see §
156.1217) is complete, the developer must submit a complete transportation
impact assessment data form to town staff. The purpose of the transportation
impact assessment data form is to provide town staff with sufficient
information regarding the proposed development to determine whether an impact
assessment is required, and what the general impact of the development may be
on the transportation system. The impact assessment data form will include, at
a minimum, the following information:
            1.   Name, address, and phone number of the owner, agent, and
developer of the property;
            2.   Name, address, and phone number of the qualified
transportation professional conducting the transportation impact assessment;
            3.   Name of the proposed development;
            4.   The location of the development (including a location map
clearly showing the roadways adjacent to the proposed project);
            5.   A description of the proposed project, including a site plan,
total developed area, types of land uses, and land use densities (i.e., gross
square footage of building space, dwelling units, employees);
            6.   A brief narrative describing the project, including phasing of
the project, anticipated build-out year, and access requirements; and
            7.   Trip generation characteristics.
         (b)   The layout and content of the form may be periodically modified
to ensure that town staff is requesting and obtaining the data necessary for
preliminary impact assessment review.
         (c)   Town staff shall determine whether the transportation impact
assessment data form is complete and notify the applicant appropriately. Only
proposed developments that have submitted complete transportation impact
assessment data forms at least eight weeks prior to the anticipated Planning
Commission meeting will be carried forward in the current batch of projects.
      (4)   Preliminary transportation impact assessment review.
         (a)   Review process.
            1.   For those projects carried forward in the process, town staff
shall conduct a preliminary review of the proposed development and provide the
applicant with the results.
            2.   Applicants will not only receive the preliminary review
results from their own proposal, but also those for other proposals currently
under review.
            3.   This will enable applicants to address the impacts of other
proposals currently under review in their transportation impact assessment
reports.
         (b)   Travel demand models and capacity spreadsheets. Town staff shall
use travel demand models and capacity spreadsheets in conducting the
preliminary impact reviews, using the travel demand modeling computer program
known as “QRS.”
         (c)   Travel demand modeling process.
            1.   Using QRS travel demand models, town staff shall estimate
traffic volume changes on the surrounding road network resulting from each
proposed development. The surrounding roadway network is comprised of the major
transportation facilities, as identified in the adopted Transportation Plan,
and consists of 76 separate roadway segments.
            2.   Using the land use densities (i.e., dwelling units, square
footage, employment data) and/or estimated vehicle trips included with the
transportation impact assessment data form, town staff shall modify the travel
demand model to include the proposed development.
            3.   Staff shall have QRS estimate the number of trips based on
socioeconomic data or, if data is provided on the transportation impact
assessment data form, define the proposed development as a point generator and
enter the total number of trips originating from that point.
            4.   Based on the location of the proposed development, staff shall
modify the data for the appropriate Traffic Analysis Zone (TAZ) within the
model. The model can then estimate the number of trips and distribute/assign
the trips onto the surrounding road network.
            5.   Once staff has modified and run the travel demand models,
modeled volumes will be imported into a capacity analysis spreadsheet. The
capacity spreadsheets indicate the maximum capacity of roadway segments and
track the consumption of capacity by existing volumes and volumes attributable
to approved or proposed developments. Maximum capacities shall be calculated
using Highway Capacity Manual methodology.
            6.   Volumes used for capacity evaluation are calculated by
applying modeled growth percentages to existing counts. Modeled volumes for the
most recent year for which counts are available shall serve as the base values
for estimating modeled growth percentages.
            7.   To assess the impacts of proposed development on the road
network, it is necessary to compare modeled volumes to those estimated for
developments that have been approved but not yet constructed. Growth
percentages shall be calculated for two conditions, approved projects and
proposed projects. (Proposed developments that are pending approval by the
Planning Commission or Town Council will be considered as approved for reviews
of the group of projects undergoing preliminary impact assessment reviews.)
            8.   The percent growth in modeled volumes shall then be applied to
existing traffic counts and converted to p.m. peak hour volumes, using existing
peak hour factors and directional splits. These volumes will then be compared
to existing roadway capacities in order to identify any potential roadway
deficiencies resulting from the proposed development.
            9.   After reviewing the results of the capacity analysis
spreadsheets, town staff will define the minimum area of influence to be used
in conducting a detailed traffic impact study for the proposed development. The
minimum area of influence shall be defined by identifying all road segments
with volumes attributable to the development exceeding 2% of the road segment's
available LOS D capacity.
            10.   Staff will notify the developer as to the limits of the
traffic impact study area, and any other analysis requirements to be included
in the traffic impact study prepared by the developer. An example of other
analysis requirements could include a.m. peak period analysis in the vicinity
of a school site to address operational and safety concerns, such as signal
provision/coordination or turn lane additions.
      (5)   Traffic impact study.
         (a)   Study area/minimum requirements.
            1.   The traffic impact study area shall be comprised of all areas
with adverse links. ADVERSE LINKS are defined as roadway segments in which the
projected trips added to the existing volume and committed trips (E + C) exceed
the LOS D capacity for that link.
            2.   Based on the limits of the traffic impact study area and any
other requirements specified by town staff, the developer shall conduct a
detailed traffic impact study for the proposed development.
            3.   The methodology and procedures used in the traffic impact
study must be in accordance with accepted engineering practices of the state
and approved by town staff. At a minimum, the traffic impact study must include
a summary of the trips the development will generate, capacity analysis of the
intersections and roadway segments contained within the study area,
identification of any roadway deficiencies caused by the development, and
proposed improvements for mitigating transportation network deficiencies, if
applicable.
         (b)   Application timeframe.
            1.   Once the traffic impact study has been completed, it shall be
submitted, along with other required documentation, to the town as part of the
transportation impact assessment application package.
            2.   The transportation impact assessment application package will
not be accepted earlier than 14 days from the time staff provides reports from
the preliminary impact assessment review.
      (6)   Transportation impact assessment application.
         (a)   The transportation impact assessment application package must
include a completed transportation impact assessment data form, site plan/
construction drawings, a description of land use types and densities, access
requirements, the traffic impact study report, and other information discussed
in the pre-application meeting.
            1.   Application packages will be reviewed in the order they are
received, based on time stamps that will be applied upon confirmation of
receipt of a complete package.
            2.   Town staff shall determine whether the developer has submitted
a complete application package.
            3.   Only proposed developments that meet established deadlines for
completed application packages will be carried forward in the current batch of
projects.
            4.   Projects that meet deadlines for the transportation impact
assessment data form, but fail to meet application package deadlines, shall
begin the impact assessment process from the start.
         (b)   A complete application package will include estimates of the
number of trips generated by the proposed development, including, if
appropriate, the estimated amount of vehicle trips generated by the proposed
development for each phase of the development and at build-out. The estimated
number of vehicle trips must be calculated for total daily and p.m. peak hours,
using the procedures outlined in the ITE Trip Generation Handbook.
            1.   Vehicle trips will be estimated using either ITE trip rates or
formulas contained in the latest edition of the ITE Trip Generation Manual.
            2.   Any other methods used for estimating vehicle trips must be
approved by the Director of Engineering and Development Services prior to
submitting the application package.
         (c)   The application package must include:
            1.   A detailed summary of the proposed land use types and
associated densities, ITE land use codes, and ITE trip rates/formulas;
            2.   A table summarizing the total daily and p.m. peak hour
vehicles trips generated by the proposed development by phase and build-out;
            3.   A distribution of the number of vehicle trips entering and
exiting the development for the p.m. peak hour;
            4.   A table summarizing assumed internal trip capture rates and
pass-by trips, if applicable; and
            5.   A brief narrative describing any assumptions made regarding
the estimation of vehicle trips, distribution, internal capture, and pass-by
trips.
      (7)   Staff review period.
         (a)   While town staff shall estimate the impacts of proposed
developments individually during the preliminary impact assessment review,
recommendations to local officials shall be based on the aggregate effects of
all projects in the current group of projects under review. (For the aggregate
analysis, only projects that have been previously approved by the Planning
Commission are considered “approved.”) Staff recommendations must be developed,
considering the information contained in the completed application packages and
the analysis of the aggregate impacts.
         (b)   Town staff must analyze the current proposed projects as a
group, using QRS models and capacity spreadsheets, according to the following
significance and adversity testing methodology.
            1.   Significance. The significance level is defined by the general
use of 2% of LOS D capacity for a given roadway link. When projected trips on
any given link exceed the 2% threshold, trips on the link are considered
significant. Provided, however, that trips on a link that already exceed the
LOS D capacity shall be exempt from consideration for mitigation, other than
site-specific safety and operational features, such as the provision of turn
lanes and/or signalization improvements.
            2.   Adverse. Adversity on any given roadway link is achieved when
project trips added to the existing volume and committed trips (E+C) exceed LOS
D for that link.
            3.   Mitigation. Mitigation will be considered when project trips
are both significant and adverse with respect to each affected roadway link, as
illustrated in the following scenarios:
               a.   Scenario 1. Project trips do not exceed the 2% threshold,
but with the addition of project trips the link becomes adversely affected.
This represents adversity, but not significance. This will likely happen when a
link is already very close to the LOS D capacity with the E+C trips. Mitigation
is not recommended;
               b.   Scenario 2. Project trips exceed the 2% threshold, but
adding them to the E+C trips does not exceed the LOS D capacity. This
represents significance, but not adversity. Mitigation is not recommended;
               c.   Scenario 3. Project trips exceed the 2% threshold
(significance). The E+C trips do not exceed the LOS D capacity, meaning the
link is currently not adverse with existing plus committed trips. However, when
project trips are added to the E+C trips, the LOS D capacity is exceeded and
the link becomes adverse due to the project trips. Mitigation is recommended;
               d.   Scenario 4. Project trips exceed the 2% threshold
(significance). The E+C trips already exceed the LOS D capacity, meaning the
link is already adverse with existing plus committed trips. Mitigation shall be
limited to site-specific safety and operational features (such as the provision
of turn lanes and/or signalization improvements).
            4.   Other mitigation circumstances. It is important to emphasize
that, since the analysis is predicated upon each link in the roadway network,
it may be that certain links in the area of influence are already deficient
(LOS E or F) and may only require mitigation to remedy site-specific
operational and safety concerns, but at the same time, other links in the area
of influence may become deficient as a direct result of additional project
trips and, therefore, require additional mitigation improvements.
         (c)   Town staff shall review the application and present
recommendations to the Planning Commission. Staff shall review the traffic
impact study and compare it to the results of its own analyses. Based on their
review, staff will determine if any additional analysis is required. If the
town determines that additional analysis is required, the developer may be
requested to revise the application and/or the traffic impact study
accordingly. Once town staff has completed their review, they will evaluate the
need for mitigation projects to address impacts as a result of the development.
      (8)   Mitigation projects.
         (a)   Based on staff's review of the development and recommendations
contained in the traffic impact study, town staff may recommend transportation
improvements necessary to mitigate identified negative impacts.
            1.   If improvements are required, town staff can provide a list of
roadway segments that were identified as being below LOS D due to the proposed
development. The town will enter negotiations with the developer to identify
transportation system improvements that mitigate the impact of the proposed
development on the identified set of roadway segments.
            2.   Site-specific mitigation efforts, such as additional turn
lanes or storage modifications, may also be required, even though the project
may not cause a LOS failure on roadway segments.
         (b)   On individual roadway links where existing volumes currently
exceed the Level of Service D capacity, or on individual roadway links where
existing and committed demand volumes exceed the Level of Service D capacity,
mitigation improvements shall be limited to remedy site-specific safety and
operational concerns.
         (c)   The provision of all or a portion of mitigation improvements
shall be limited to the proportionate share of demand generated by the proposed
development. When mitigation embodies improvements identified in the town's
current Transportation Capital Improvement Plan, an appropriate credit will be
given towards the development project's transportation impact fee.
         (d)   If town staff and the developer agree on a set of improvements,
such agreements will be documented and included in the application package.
            1.   If an agreement cannot be reached regarding what improvements
should be implemented with the development, the developer may request to
present the development proposals to the Planning Commission.
            2.   Town staff will also present their recommendations and
findings to the Planning Commission.
      (9)   Provisions for phasing required improvements. Include a description
of how phased improvements will occur during the development process,
identifying when specific improvements will be accomplished and the entity
responsible for the same.
      (10)   Graphic illustration of process.
         (a)   Figure 156.1218-1 illustrates the Transportation Impact
Assessment approval process.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13145.png]
 
         (b)   The graphic illustrates the anticipated approval timeframe for
the transportation impact assessment process.
            1.   Submittal deadlines for complete transportation impact
assessment data forms and impact assessment applications must be met to keep
the review process on schedule.
            2.   Staff review timeframes are predicated upon best estimates,
but are tentative and may be extended, based upon such factors as project size,
complexity of analysis, and similar factors. The rationale is that the
applicant controls the scope of development, and staff must be allowed
sufficient time to conduct and review analysis and mitigation alternatives.
   (G)   Specific impacts on police, fire, recreation, and public services. The
impact assessment shall:
      (1)   Describe how the proposed project will affect basic town services
in general;
      (2)   To the extent possible, relate service provisions to appropriate
standards (i.e., personnel, service area, facilities, and equipment) and the
relationship to adopted plans (e.g., Recreation Master Plan), if applicable.
Examples include such analysis as police officers per 1,000 population, nearest
fire station, the necessity for additional garbage trucks to serve the
development, and the like; and
      (3)   Indicate the method of solid waste collection, either public or
private, in text, and describe pertinent factors such as aggregated individual
receptacles or common collective receptacles. Graphically depict location on
Conceptual Plan and address applicable access requirements.
   (H)   Specific impacts on education. Provide an assessment of impact on the
school system, to include projection of school age children in the proposed
development by type of school and attendance zone.
   (I)   Specific impacts on cultural, archeological, and environmental
resources.
      (1)   Describe the impact of the proposed development on relevant
cultural, archeological, and environmental resources, particularly as it
relates to displacement or alteration of the same as a result of drainage
improvements and land disturbance for development.
      (2)   Indicate proposed tree removal on Conceptual Plan.
   (J)   Fiscal/economic considerations.
      (1)   Provide an analysis of the estimated average annual ad valorem tax
yield from the proposed project during each phase of development. Indicate
assumptions and standards utilized, including but not limited to, assessed
value, exemptions, millage rate, and the like.
      (2)   Provide an analysis of the estimated cost for the town to serve the
proposed development. Staff may develop a process and/or calculation method
that applicants must use.
      (3)   Provide totals for other applicable fees, such as impact fees,
permit fees, and plan review fees.
   (K)   Housing. Provide a breakdown of the proposed residential units, by
price or rental range; and the type of unit, such as detached house, duplex,
townhouse, and the like; and assess the potential of the proposed development
to meet local housing needs.
   (L)   Infrastructure. For impact assessments involving new residential
subdivisions that are subject to the preliminary and final plat process, the
application must include a master drainage plan, a master sanitary sewer plan,
and a master potable water distribution plan (see §
155.029)
   (M)   Letters of coordination. Based upon the necessity of addressing
particular concerns of a given project, letters of coordination from various
town departments, agencies, or other entities referenced herein may be required
to adequately assess specific impacts. This determination will be made by PLAN
staff at the pre-application meeting.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1219 COMPLETENESS.
   (A)   The PLAN Director shall review the impact assessment application and
all supporting data for accuracy, verification, and completeness. Toward this
end, they may conduct field investigations and “in-house” studies, including
verification of pertinent material by independent consultants, if deemed
appropriate.
   (B)   Upon a finding that the required data and information are complete,
accurate, and in proper form, the PLAN Director shall refer the assessment for
further consideration by the Planning Commission and the Town Council.
   (C)   If the PLAN Director finds the impact assessment is incomplete with
respect to data and information requirements or that the data and information
submitted contains significant errors of fact, they shall return the Assessment
to the applicant with an itemized statement of the deficiencies and/or
inaccuracies to be corrected.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1220 NOTICE.
   Notice is not required for an impact assessment application.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1221 DECISION.
   (A)   Planning Commission. The Planning Commission shall consider the
request and provide a recommendation for approval, approval with conditions, or
disapproval of the proposed impact assessment.
   (B)   Town Council. The Town Council shall consider the request and approve,
approve with conditions, or disapprove the proposed impact assessment.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1222 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   (A)   Acceptable impact.
      (1)   The finding of an acceptable impact is a prerequisite to approval
of an impact assessment.
      (2)   This finding shall be noted on the approved Conceptual Plan.
   (B)   Unacceptable negative impact.
      (1)   Where negative impacts are identified, the Town Council shall, upon
the report and recommendation of the Planning Commission, determine whether,
given the goals of the Comprehensive Plan, these impacts are acceptable and in
the public interest.
      (2)   The Council may request the developer mitigate negative impacts
that are deemed to be unacceptable.
      (3)   If satisfactory mitigation cannot be achieved, the town may
disapprove the impact assessment application as submitted.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1223 SCOPE OF APPROVAL.
   (A)   Generally. Approval of an impact assessment enables an applicant to
proceed with any other application required by this chapter,
Chapter 155, or other chapters of the Town Code for the proposed development,
including special exception use permit applications and zoning permit
applications.
   (B)   Development approvals and construction/denial. Development approvals
and construction shall be in accordance with division (C) below, and the
following:
      (1)   Once Town Council approves the impact assessment, the developer
will follow established town development procedures for construction projects,
including obtaining permits.
      (2)   Development approvals may be contingent upon the developer making
certain transportation improvements.
         (a)   In order to obtain a building permit, the developer may post a
financial guarantee suitable to the town, in an amount of one and one half
times the amount of the cost of construction of the improvements.
         (b)   The certificate of occupancy may be withheld until all
contingent transportation improvements are completed.
   (C)   Time limitation.
      (1)   Vested rights. Approved impact assessments are vested for a period
of two years, subject to the rights and restrictions contained within this
title. Should the property owner fail to exercise these provisions or allow the
vested right to otherwise lapse, the following provisions may apply.
      (2)   Residential developments. Approval of an impact assessment for
residential construction shall become null and void if site work predicated
upon an approved preliminary plat has not commenced within the two-year
timeframe, or if the preliminary plat approval authorizing the installation of
improvements becomes void pursuant to division (E) below.
      (3)   Non-residential and multiplex developments. Approval of an impact
assessment for commercial, mixed use, or multiplex development shall become
null and void if a building permit predicated upon an approved site plan has
not been issued within the two-year timeframe. The issuance of a building
permit, in and of itself, shall not be deemed to fulfill the time limitation
requirement, but must be followed by construction progressing in a timely
manner toward project completion.
      (4)   Relationship to valid wetlands disturbance permit. Notwithstanding
the provisions of divisions (C)(2) and (C)(3) above, if a valid wetlands
disturbance permit that has been filed with the proper authorities, pursuant to
and at the approximate same time as impact assessment approval, is pending a
final decision, the time limitation shall be tolled until the final decision
has been rendered.
      (5)   Lapse in construction. If construction improvements lapse for a
consecutive period of six months or more from the initial date of commencement,
the PLAN Director may require an update of the impact assessment. The duration
of a lapse in construction improvements shall be determined by the PLAN
Director.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1224 REAPPLICATION.
   There is no time limit on resubmitting a withdrawn or disapproved impact
assessment application.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1225 APPEALS.
   This chapter does not authorize new rights to an appeal from or remedies for
adverse decisions by the Town Council, but interested parties may pursue
existing remedies from the Circuit Court.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1226 RECORDKEEPING.
   The PLAN Director shall maintain a record of all impact assessment
applications and related materials.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1227 THROUGH 156.1229 RESERVED.
PART 11: TECHNICAL REVIEW AND CODE COMPLIANCE
§ 156.1230 PURPOSE.
   The technical review and code compliance process ensures certain types of
applications meet applicable regulations prior to the decision-making body’s
review of and action on the application. This streamlines the review process
and helps ensure timely and accurate review for all applicants.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1231 APPLICABILITY.
   Technical review and code compliance (TRCC) is required for:
   (A)   Design review applications, including applications for minor projects
as defined in §
156.1247(C);
   (B)   Sketch plan applications (see §
155.021); and
   (C)   Town projects involving site alterations that impact drainage and/or
transportation systems.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1232 INITIATION.
   (A)   A pre-application meeting, used to assess the feasibility of a
proposed project, is highly encouraged but not required.
   (B)   The TRCC process is triggered upon submittal of a complete design
review or sketch plan application. For town projects, the department project
manager initiates the TRCC process.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1233 COMPLETENESS.
   See §
156.1080.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1234 NOTICE.
   Notice is not required for a TRCC application.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1235 DECISION.
   (A)   The Development Review Team (see
Subchapter J, Part 2, Subpart 2.3) will establish a process(es) and timeline(s)
for its review of all applications subject to this part.
   (B)   As part of its review process, the Development Review Team (DRT)
provides comments to applicants and may require changes to submitted
applications and plans to ensure compliance with applicable regulations.
   (C)   The TRCC review process does not result in a decision. After the
applicant successfully addresses the DRT’s comments, the DRT forwards the
complete application to the Design Review Board or Planning Commission, as
applicable, for review and action. Comments are considered “successfully
addressed” based upon written confirmation by the TRCC Program Manager.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1236 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   The DRT ensures applications comply with all regulations applicable to the
proposed development, including:
   (A)   
Chapter 51;
   (B)   
Chapter 76;
   (C)   
Chapter 152;
   (D)   
Chapter 153;
   (E)   
Chapter 155;
   (F)   
Chapter 156;
   (G)   
Chapter 158;
   (H)   International Building Code, Chapter 11: Accessibility;
   (I)   International Fire Code, Appendix D: Fire Apparatus Access Roads; and
   (J)   SCDOT Access and Roadside Management Standards Manual.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1237 SCOPE OF APPROVAL.
   (A)   Following its compliance review, the DRT forwards complete
applications to the Design Review Board or Planning Commission, as applicable.
The DRT does not forward an application unless it fully complies with minimum
Code requirements.
   (B)   The TRCC and DRT do not approve or disapprove applications or
development plans. As such, the TRCC review process does not confer vested
rights for any application.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1238 REAPPLICATION.
   Reapplication is subject to the time limits specified for the applicable
application type.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1239 APPEALS.
   The TRCC procedure does not result in a decision; therefore, there is no
appeal process.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1240 RECORDKEEPING.
   The TRCC Program Manager maintains a record of all applications submitted
for TRCC review and the status of each application.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1241 THROUGH 156.1244 RESERVED.
PART 12: DESIGN REVIEW
§ 156.1245 PURPOSE.
   This part describes how to obtain approval for building and site design for
certain types of new construction and for improvements to certain types of
existing structures and sites.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1246 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   Generally. Design review is required for:
      (1)   All land uses and zoning districts subject to Subchapter H; and
      (2)   Site improvements and building exteriors, but not for building
interiors.
   (B)   Activities requiring design review. Design review approval is required
prior to undertaking the following activities:
      (1)   New construction. Construction of new buildings and structures
(including walls, fences, light fixtures, steps and pavement, or other
appurtenant features), above-ground utility structures, and any type of outdoor
signs;
      (2)   Alteration, restoration, or relocation. Alteration of, addition to,
or relocation of existing buildings and structures (including walls, fences,
light fixtures, steps and pavement, or other appurtenant features), above-
ground utility structure, or any type of outdoor sign;
      (3)   Landscaping. Landscaping for new construction sites and for
existing developed sites, including the alteration of existing landscaping;
      (4)   Construction on public property. Private construction of porches,
steps, posts, fences, walks, walls, landscaping, or other improvements on
public property, which also requires an encroachment permit from the property
owner.
   (C)   Maintenance and repair.
      (1)   Nothing in this part prevents the ordinary maintenance or repair of
any exterior architectural feature that does not involve a change in its
design, material, color, or outer appearance.
      (2)   Nothing in this part prevents the construction, reconstruction,
alteration, restoration, or demolition of any feature the Building Official or
similar official certifies is required for public safety because of an unsafe
or dangerous condition.
   (D)   Design review process for properties zoned ED, Economic Development
District.
      (1)   At the applicant's choosing, either Department of Planning, Land
Use, and Neighborhoods staff or the Design Review Board (DRB) will review a
proposed development located on a lot(s) zoned ED, Economic Development
District.
      (2)   This includes lots zoned for Economic Development use within a
Planned Development District; provided, however, that the choice of review
process is only available for the economic development use as specified in the
use table when other permitted uses are also allowed on the parcel.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1247 INITIATION.
   (A)   Applicant eligibility. A design review application may be initiated
by:
      (1)   The property owner or tenant of the subject property; or
      (2)   An agent of the property owner or tenant of the subject property.
   (B)   Application requirements.
      (1)   A design review application is filed with the PLAN Department on or
before the DRB application deadline specified on the annual meeting schedule.
Applications may be filed electronically or in-person.
      (2)   Submitting a complete design review application triggers the
technical review and code compliance and process (see
Subchapter I, Part 11).
   (C)   Minor projects.
      (1)   Applicants may request review and approval of minor projects by
Department of Planning, Land Use, and Neighborhoods staff by including a
written request attached to the application.
      (2)   The written request shall include confirmation from the applicant
that the proposed project construction cost, excluding improvements or
renovations to building interiors, does not exceed $250,000. The proposed cost
shall include all phases of the proposed project.
      (3)   The determination of whether a project is minor and that the
written confirmation of project cost is reasonable is within the discretion of
the Zoning Administrator. The Zoning Administrator may consult with the
Building Official for projects involving building improvements.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1248 COMPLETENESS.
   (A)   See §
156.1080.
   (B)   In addition, design review applications, which require review through
the TRCC procedure (see
Subchapter I, Part 11), are not considered complete until all TRCC Team
comments are addressed.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1249 NOTICE.
   Notice is not required for a design review application.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1250 DECISION.
   (A)   Minor projects.
      (1)   The DRB Secretary shall approve or disapprove applications for
minor projects, as defined in §
156.1247(C).
      (2)   The DRB Secretary shall forward a minor project application to the
DRB for review and action if the application proposes to modify one or more of
the design standards specified in
Subchapter H, Part 2.
      (3)   The DRB Secretary may forward a minor project application to the
DRB for review and action if the proposed project:
         (a)   Is located along a major street;
         (b)   Is located adjacent to or across a street from a residential
zoning district or use;
         (c)   Is located on a lot with a maximum height limit 20 feet or
greater than that of an adjacent lot or a lot across a street; or
         (d)   Includes fuel dispensing, drive-through, and/or drive-in
facilities.
   (B)   DRB review and action.
      (1)   Generally. The DRB shall approve, approve with conditions, or
disapprove the application.
      (2)   Review process.
         (a)   The design review process may include conceptual, preliminary,
and/or final plan reviews.
         (b)   DRB approval of the conceptual and/or preliminary plan does not
guarantee approval of the final plan.
         (c)   An approval of the final plan, but not the conceptual or
preliminary plans, results in a vested right.
      (3)   Modification of design standards. The DRB may modify the design
standards in
Subchapter H, Parts 2 and 3 as deemed appropriate for the particular project in
consideration of its individual circumstances.
      (4)   Projects approved with conditions. For projects approved with
conditions, the DRB may direct the DRB Secretary to conduct a final review of
the plans in order to ensure compliance with the conditions of approval.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1251 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   The DRB or the DRB Secretary, as applicable, shall act on a design review
application based upon the standards in Subchapter H and other applicable
provisions of the Zoning Code, in addition to the following criteria:
   (A)   Ease of pedestrian access between proposed developments and adjacent
developments is considered in the proposed development's site and circulation
plans;
   (B)   The architecture, landscaping, and building siting works in concert to
create a unified appearance that contributes to the existing/developing
streetscape;
   (C)   The proposed development avoids excessive or unsightly grading,
indiscriminate earth moving or clearing, and removal of trees and vegetation
that could cause disruption of natural water courses or disfiguration of
natural land forms;
   (D)   The proposed development is located and configured in a visually
harmonious manner with the terrain and vegetation of the subject parcel and
with that of surrounding parcels; and
   (E)   When a proposed development includes multiple phases, the application
includes a phasing plan that demonstrates how future phases will connect and
relate to the current phase.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1252 SCOPE OF APPROVAL.
   (A)   Approval of a design review application authorizes the applicant to
undertake the work specified in the approved plans once a building permit is
issued for the same.
   (B)   Design review approvals are vested for a period of two years, subject
to the rights and restrictions contained within this title.
   (C)   Routine repairs and maintenance may be made to a structure approved
for construction through the design review process, as required to preserve it
in sound condition. Any proposed changes to the structure as approved through
the design review process shall be presented to the DRB Secretary for
determination whether a new application is required.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1253 REAPPLICATION.
   There is no time limit on refiling a withdrawn or disapproved design review
application.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1254 APPEALS.
   (A)   Appeal of DRB decision. Any aggrieved party may appeal a decision of
the Design Review Board to the circuit court, pursuant to the provisions of
S.C. Code §§ 6-29-900 et seq.
   (B)   Appeal of administrative decision.
      (1)   Any person aggrieved (or any officer, department, board, or bureau
of the Town of Mount Pleasant) may appeal to the DRB from actions of the Zoning
Administrator or other administrative official in matters within the
jurisdiction of the Board pursuant to S.C. Code §§ 6-29-880 and 6-29-890.
      (2)   The appeal must be filed within 30 days after the affected party
receives actual notice of the decision, by filing with the officer from whom
the appeal is taken and with the DRB notice of appeal specifying the grounds of
the appeal.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1255 RECORDKEEPING.
   (A)   The DRB Recording Secretary will keep minutes of the DRB’s
proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question, or if absent
or failing to vote, indicating the fact.
   (B)   All records of the DRB’s actions are filed in the PLAN Department
office as a public record.
   (C)   The DRB Secretary shall maintain a log of administrative actions on
minor projects.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1256 THROUGH 156.1259 RESERVED.
PART 13: CERTIFICATES OF  APPROPRIATENESS
§ 156.1260 PURPOSE.
   This part describes how to obtain approval for improvements to structures
and sites located in the Old Village Historic District.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1261 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   Activities requiring a certificate of appropriateness. Unless
otherwise stated within the Old Village Historic District Guidelines, a
certificate of appropriateness (COA) is required prior to:
      (1)   Partial or total demolition (including demolition by neglect);
      (2)   Exterior alteration or addition;
      (3)   New construction;
      (4)   Site alteration;
      (5)   Installation of hardscaping, including walkways, driveways, and
patios;
      (6)   Installation of fences, walls, and docks; and
      (7)   The moving of any building into, out of, or within the historic
district.
   (B)   Requirements of municipal and publicly regulated utilities.
      (1)   The town and all publicly regulated utility companies are required
to go before the Historic District Preservation Commission (HDPC) in accordance
with this part;
Subchapter B, Part 4, Subpart 4.3;
Subchapter J, Part 3, Subpart 3.5; and the HDPC Rules of Procedure, prior to
initiating any changes in the character of street paving, sidewalks, trees,
utility installations (excluding traffic-control devices), lighting, walls,
fences, structures and buildings on property, easements, or widening or
constricting of streets owned or franchised by the town or public utility
companies.
      (2)   Nothing in this chapter prevents municipal or publicly regulated
utilities from the orderly maintenance of their systems or the services they
provide.
   (C)   Exceptions following a disaster or in a state of emergency.
      (1)   In the event of a natural disaster or when state of emergency is
declared, the HDPC or HDPC Secretary may authorize temporary disaster-related
repairs in order to weatherproof or stabilize a damaged building/structure
(waiver shall not relieve the applicant/property owner of making permanent
repairs that meet the established guidelines).
      (2)   The immediate restoration or maintenance of any existing above-
ground utility structure is hereby authorized as long as repair results in no
exterior change from the appearance before the disaster or state of emergency.
      (3)   The HDPC may waive all application deadline and notification
requirements pertaining to disaster-related repairs.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1262 INITIATION.
   (A)   Applicant eligibility. A COA application may be initiated by:
      (1)   The property owner of the subject property; or
      (2)   An agent of the property owner of the subject property.
   (B)   Pre-application meeting required. Prior to acceptance of a COA
application, a pre-application meeting is required with the HDPC Secretary (see
§
156.1079).
   (C)   Preliminary review.
      (1)   Prior to final approval for a COA, applicants may, but are not
required to, request a preliminary review by the HDPC. Preliminary review
requests may be appropriate for new construction or complex or large scale
projects, or projects involving major work to historic properties.
      (2)   Preliminary reviews do not result in approval or disapproval of the
application, and do not create a vested right.
      (3)   Preliminary reviews do not require the same level of detail as a
COA application, and are designed to establish the intent and scope of the
proposed project and to review any plans provided. The HDPC may provide the
applicant with comments regarding the request and any items that need to be
addressed prior to a submittal for final COA approval.
   (D)   Application requirements. A COA application is filed with the PLAN
Department on or before the HDPC application deadline specified on the annual
meeting schedule. Applications may be filed electronically.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1263 COMPLETENESS.
   See §
156.1080.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1264 NOTICE.
   The notice specified in Table 156.1264-1 is required for a COA, except that
minor work applications subject to review by the HDPC Secretary do not require
public notice.

   Key: N/A = not applicable

Publicatio n N/A      N/A            N/A
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1265 DECISION.
   (A)   Minor work reviewed by staff.
      (1)   An application consisting entirely of minor work may be reviewed
and approved or disapproved by the HDPC Secretary.
      (2)   A list of work items designated by the HDPC as minor work is
available from the HDPC Secretary. The list may be changed or updated as
necessary by a majority of the HDPC.
      (3)   The HDPC Secretary shall review all minor work applications within
ten business days of receipt of a complete application.
      (4)   At each regularly scheduled meeting, the HDPC Secretary shall
provide a report of all staff-level approvals granted within the month.
   (B)   HDPC review and action.
      (1)   The HDPC will review and approve, approve with conditions, or
disapprove a COA application.
      (2)   The COA process may include conceptual, preliminary, and/or final
plan reviews. HDPC approval of the conceptual and/or preliminary plan does not
guarantee approval of the final plan. An approval of the final plan, but not
the conceptual or preliminary plans, results in a vested right.
      (3)   The HDPC will take final action upon a complete and fully
documented COA application within a reasonable amount of time.
      (4)   The HDPC may postpone the issuance of a COA for demolition for 90
days in order to find an alternative to the demolition or to find an entity
willing to save the building or salvage architectural materials.
      (5)   When the HDPC approves a COA application subject to conditions, the
HDPC Secretary shall verify the applicant has met the conditions prior to
issuance of a certificate of occupancy.
   (C)   Substantial economic hardship exemption.
      (1)   Circumstances. A property owner may apply for an exemption based on
the substantial hardship of maintaining the property according to the design
guidelines. Substantial hardship shall be considered by the HDPC where one or
more of the following unusual and compelling circumstances exist:
         (a)   The property cannot reasonably be maintained in the manner
dictated by the design guidelines due to economic constraints;
         (b)   There are no other reasonable means of saving the property from
deterioration or collapse; or
         (c)   The property is owned by a nonprofit organization and it is not
feasible, financially or physically, to achieve the charitable purposes of the
organization while appropriately maintaining the property.
      (2)   Evidence. If the property owner wishes to make a claim of
substantial economic hardship (as defined herein) owing to the effects of this
chapter, the property owner must submit evidence describing the circumstances
of hardship. Evidence may include:
         (a)   Nature of ownership (individual, business, or nonprofit) or
legal possession, custody, and control;
         (b)   Financial resources of the owner and/or parties in interest
(such as tax returns for the past two years);
         (c)   Cost of repairs;
         (d)   Assessed value of the land and improvements;
         (e)   Real estate taxes for the past two years;
         (f)   Amount paid for the property, date of purchase, and party from
whom purchased, including a description of the relationship between the owner
and the person from whom the property was purchased, or other means of
acquisition of title, such as by gift or inheritance;
         (g)   Annual debt service, if any, for previous two years;
         (h)   Any listing of the property for sale or rent, price asked, and
offers received, if any;
         (i)   Annual gross income from the property for the previous two years
(if the property is income-producing);
         (j)   Itemized operating and maintenance expenses for the previous two
years, including proof that adequate and competent management procedures were
followed (if the property is income-producing); and
         (k)   Annual cash flow, if any, for the previous two years (if the
property is income-producing).
      (3)   In the event the HDPC finds substantial economic hardship in
meeting the guidelines, the finding shall be accompanied by a recommended plan
to relieve the economic hardship. This plan may include loans or grants from
public, private, or nonprofit sources, acquisition by purchase or eminent
domain, or relaxation of the provisions of this chapter sufficient to mitigate
substantial economic hardship.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1266 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   The Historic District Preservation Commission or the HDPC
Secretary, as applicable, shall approve or disapprove a COA application based
upon the specific criteria in Subchapter B, Part 4, Subpart 4.3 and the Old
Village Historic District Guidelines.
      (2)   The HDPC, or HDPC Secretary in the case of minor work, shall not
consider:
         (a)   The use of the building;
         (b)   The interior of the building; or
         (c)   Vegetative landscaping, except living fences.
      (3)   The HDPC, or HDPC Secretary in the case of minor work, shall not
impose conditions on an application except to prevent developments that are not
in harmony with the prevailing character of the streetscape or the district in
general, or are obviously incongruous with the character, integrity, or style
of a building or site.
   (B)   Disapproval of a COA application.
      (1)   A COA application shall be disapproved if the demolition or partial
demolition, alterations and/or additions to existing structures, erection of
new structures, alteration of site, or other factors listed within are
considered in violation of the specific criteria in
Subchapter B, Part 4, Subpart 4.3 or the Old Village Historic District
Guidelines, as applicable.
      (2)   Reasons for disapproval of an application shall be clearly listed
in the motion to disapprove the COA. The motion shall cite the exact section(s)
of the ordinance or design review guidelines the application violates.
      (3)   In the case of staff disapproval, staff shall provide a written
explanation citing the exact section(s) of the ordinance or design review
guidelines the application violates.
   (C)   Demolition. Permits for full demolition without replacement are only
allowed for accessory structures and are allowed for primary structures. The
HDPC shall review all requests for demolition based on the following criteria:
      (1)   Historic buildings and structures. Historic properties comprised of
buildings and structures designated through nomination by inclusion in a survey
or survey update, or by individual nomination, shall be afforded the highest
degree of preservation. Demolition may only be allowed if one or more of the
following conditions are met, with the burden of proof falling upon the
applicant:
         (a)   Where the public safety and welfare requires the removal of the
building;
         (b)   If the building or structure cannot be economically
rehabilitated on the site to provide a reasonable income or residential
environment compared to other structures in the general area; or
         (c)   A finding of substantial economic hardship (see §
156.1265(C)) is established by the HDPC.
      (2)   Buildings and structures lacking historic designation status. In
the case of buildings or structures lacking historic property designation, the
HDPC may, at its discretion, first make a determination that the building or
structure is worthy of individual designation as an historic property pursuant
to the provisions of §
156.1477(B). If no such determination is made, demolition may then be allowed
if one or more of the following conditions are met, with the burden of proof
falling upon the applicant:
         (a)   Where the public safety and welfare requires the removal of the
building;
         (b)   The structure cannot be economically rehabilitated on the site
to provide a reasonable income or residential environment compared to other
structures in the general area;
         (c)   A finding of substantial economic hardship is established by the
HDPC; or
         (d)   Where the proposed new development is more compatible with the
surrounding area, considering such factors as location and exterior design.
      (3)   Accessory buildings and structures. In the case of accessory
buildings and structures, demolition shall be allowed if one of the following
conditions is met, with the burden of proof falling upon the applicant:
         (a)   Where the building or structure is determined not to have any
historical significance; or
         (b)   Where the public safety and welfare requires the removal of the
building or structure.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1267 SCOPE OF APPROVAL.
   (A)   Generally. Approval of a COA application authorizes the applicant to
undertake the work specified in the COA once a building permit is issued for
the same.
   (B)   What COA does not authorize.
      (1)   The COA does not approve tree protection zone modification,
removal, relocation, or replacement. Tree protection zone modification,
removal, relocation, or replacement are granted by the appropriate staff or
board as stated in §§
156.1476 and
156.1477.
      (2)   The COA does not approve stormwater and drainage management plans.
Stormwater and drainage management plans are reviewed by the appropriate staff
pursuant to
Chapter 152.
   (C)   Demolition.
      (1)   Where full demolition requests were granted as a result of new
construction plans or where the applicant intends to request new construction
plans in the future, the permit for demolition shall not be issued until new
construction plans have been approved by the HDPC and submitted for a building
permit.
      (2)   During demolition, nearby sites, structures, and, in the case of
partial demolitions, connecting structures, shall be protected. After
demolition, the site shall be cleared and cleaned.
   (D)   Validity. The COA is valid for a period of two years from the date of
approval by the HDPC or HDPC Secretary, as applicable, and thereafter for the
time prescribed by this title.
      (1)   At any time during the two-year period, or any subsequent vested
rights extensions, the Building Official may grant a building permit to the
applicant.
      (2)   Should the COA expire at any time prior to the application for a
building permit, a building permit shall not be issued until the applicant
provides a current COA.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1268 REAPPLICATION.
   (A)   There is no time limit on resubmitting a withdrawn COA application.
   (B)   If a COA application is disapproved, a new application affecting the
same property may be submitted only if substantial change is made in the plans
for the proposed work.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1269 APPEALS.
   (A)   Appeal of HDPC decision. Any aggrieved party may appeal a decision of
the HDPC to the Courts of South Carolina pursuant to S.C. Code §§ 6-29-900 et
seq.
   (B)   Appeal of administrative decision.
      (1)   Any person aggrieved (or any officer, department, board, or bureau
of the local government) may appeal to the HDPC from actions of the Zoning
Administrator, or other administrative official, in matters within the
jurisdiction of the Board pursuant to S.C. Code §§ 6-29-880 and 6-29-890.
      (2)   The appeal must be filed within 30 days after the affected party
receives actual notice of the decision, by filing with the officer from whom
the appeal is taken and with the HDPC notice of appeal specifying the grounds
of the appeal.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1270 RECORDKEEPING.
   (A)   Generally. The HDPC Secretary shall maintain a record of all COA
applications and related materials.
   (B)   Approved COA applications.
      (1)   The COA is a standardized form signed by the HDPC Secretary. The
COA states the specific changes that will result from the proposed work for
which the application has been made, and shall state that those changes are
approved by the HDPC or HDPC Secretary, in the case of minor work.
      (2)   The HDPC Secretary shall provide the COA and draft minutes of the
hearing of the application to the applicant within ten days of approval of the
plans.
   (C)   Disapproved COA applications. The HDPC Secretary shall mail or email
the draft minutes of the hearing of the application to the applicant within 20
business days of disapproval of the COA application.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1271 THROUGH 156.1274 RESERVED.
PART 14: DEMOLITION BY NEGLECT
§ 156.1275 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this procedure is to prevent demolition of buildings in the
historic district(s) through neglect of the property.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1276 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   This part applies when five or more residents or property owners in an
historic district believe a building located within the historic district is
effectively being demolished by means of neglect and bring forward a petition
to the Historic District Preservation Commission (HDPC), with the goal to bring
the building into compliance with current historic district design guidelines.
   (B)   Nothing in this part diminishes the town's power to declare a building
unsafe or in violation of the minimum housing code.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1277 INITIATION.
   (A)   All charges of demolition by neglect are initiated by a petition
signed by five residents or property owners in the historic district in which
the subject building is located.
   (B)   Residents or property owners residing at the same address count only
once toward the total number of signatures.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1278 COMPLETENESS.
   Petitions for a finding of demolition by neglect must include:
   (A)   A written description and photographic evidence of said neglect; and
   (B)   A summary of the detrimental effect upon the character of the historic
district as a whole or the life and character of the property itself.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1279 NOTICE.
   The notice specified in Table 156.1279-1 is required for a petition for
demolition by neglect.
 
Table 156.1279-1: Required Notice for a Petition for Demolition by Neglect
   Key: N/A = not applicable
Type         Required To Whom        When
Mail         Yes      Property owner 30 to 45 days prior to the public hearing
