Posted       No       N/A            N/A
Publicatio n No       N/A            N/A
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1280 DECISION.
   (A)   Generally. The HDPC shall consider the petition and other evidence at
a public hearing, and render a decision as to whether the building is being
demolished by means of neglect.
   (B)   Substantial economic hardship.
      (1)   If the property owner wishes to make a claim of substantial
economic hardship, they must submit evidence describing the circumstances of
hardship. Evidence may include the items listed in §
156.1265(C)(2).
      (2)   In the event the HDPC finds substantial economic hardship, the
finding shall be accompanied by a recommended plan to relieve the economic
hardship. This plan may include loans or grants from public, private, or
nonprofit sources, acquisition by purchase or eminent domain, or relaxation of
the provisions of this chapter sufficient to mitigate substantial economic
hardship.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1281 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   The HDPC may declare a building to be in a condition of demolition by
neglect if one or more of the following conditions exist:
   (A)   Any fault, defect, or condition in the building that renders it
structurally unsafe or not properly watertight;
   (B)   Building components that may fall and injure the public;
   (C)   Defective or deteriorated floor supports, walls, ceiling, roofs,
chimneys, or vertical or horizontal supports that split, lean, list, buckle,
sag, or split; or
   (D)   Deteriorated or inadequate foundation.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1282 SCOPE OF APPROVAL.
   (A)   If, pursuant to the hearing, the HDPC finds that a building within the
limits of the historic district is being demolished by means of neglect, the
HDPC shall contact the property owner to instruct them to bring the building
into compliance with the current historic district regulations and design
guidelines.
   (B)   If the property owner does not respond, apply for a certificate of
appropriateness, or initiate repair not requiring a COA within 90 days of the
HDPC's issuance of notification, the HDPC shall report to the Zoning
Administrator that the building is in violation of the design guidelines,
providing their findings for such violation(s). The Zoning Administrator may
then take appropriate enforcement action.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1283 REAPPLICATION.
   If the HDPC does not approve the petition for a finding of demolition by
neglect, it shall not hear a petition concerning the same building for at least
12 months from the date of the decision.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1284 APPEALS.
   Any aggrieved party may appeal a decision of the Commission to the courts of
South Carolina pursuant to S.C. Code §§ 6-29-900 et seq.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1285 RECORDKEEPING.
   The Zoning Administrator shall maintain a record of all petitions for
demolition by neglect and related materials.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1286 THROUGH 156.1289 RESERVED.
PART 15: VARIANCES
§ 156.1290 PURPOSE.
   This part establishes a procedure to avoid unnecessary hardships that could
result from a strict application of this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1291 APPLICABILITY.
   This part applies to an application for a variance. An applicant shall
obtain variance approval to construct, develop, or make a material change in
any lot, building, or structure that does not comply with the standards of this
chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1292 INITIATION.
   (A)   Applicant eligibility. A variance application may be initiated by:
      (1)   The property owner or tenant of the subject property; or
      (2)   An agent of the property owner or tenant of the subject property.
   (B)   Pre-application meeting. A pre-application meeting is required (see §
156.1079).
   (C)   Application requirements.
      (1)   A variance application is filed with the PLAN Department on or
before the Board of Zoning Appeals application deadline specified on the annual
meeting schedule. Applications may be filed electronically or in-person.
      (2)   A conceptual site plan with adequate detail of features such as
building layout, setbacks, easements, parking, circulation systems, and buffers
must be submitted in conjunction with the special exception permit application.
An application filed without an adequate conceptual site plan is considered
incomplete.
   (D)   Effect on other proceedings. A variance application that would correct
a zoning violation stays all legal proceedings by the town on the zoning
violation, unless the Zoning Administrator certifies to the Board of Zoning
Appeals, after the variance application has been filed, that a stay would cause
an imminent peril to life and property. In cases where there is an imminent
peril to life and property, proceedings will not be stayed unless a restraining
order is granted by the Board or by a court of record on application.
   (E)   Consideration for Planning Commission and Town Council procedures. As
a matter of process and procedure, proposed developments involving variance
applications that also require separate review by the Planning Commission and/
or separate Town Council approval, shall not be considered by the Board of
Zoning Appeals until the referenced review and/or approval is completed.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1293 COMPLETENESS.
   See §
156.1080.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1294 NOTICE.
   (A)   The notice specified in Table 156.1294-1 is required for a variance
application.
   (B)   If the Board remands a variance application to the Zoning
Administrator for further review, the Board may set a hearing without further
public notice for a time certain within 60 days unless otherwise agreed to by
the parties. The Board must maintain a list of persons who express an interest
in being informed when the remanded matter is set for rehearing, and notice of
the rehearing must be mailed to these persons before the rehearing.
 
Table 156.1294-1: Required Notice for Variance Applications
   Key: N/A = not applicable
Type        Required To Whom             When
Mail        Yes      Parties in interest Due notice
Posted      Yes      General public      Prior to public hearing
Publication Yes      General public      At least 15 days prior to public
                                         hearing
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1295 DECISION.
   (A)   The Board of Zoning Appeals will hear all applications for variances
and will render a decision in each matter.
   (B)   The Board will hear a variance request within 60 days of the date the
application is deemed complete.
   (C)   At the hearing, any party may appear in person or by agent or by
attorney.
   (D)   The burden of proof for the relief sought is upon the applicant.
   (E)   Based on the hearing and probable impact of the proposed use on
surrounding uses and conditions, the Board may approve, approve with
conditions, or disapprove the request. The Board may approve a variance
application subject to conditions regarding the location, character, or other
features of the proposed building, structure, or use as the Board may consider
advisable to protect established property values in the surrounding area or to
promote the public health, safety, or general welfare.
   (F)   On its own motion or the motion of a party, the Board may remand a
variance application to the Zoning Administrator if the Board determines the
record is insufficient for review. Variance applications that are remanded must
be rescheduled for hearing within 60 days unless the parties agree on an
extension.
   (G)   The Board will issue a written decision within 45 days of the final
hearing on the matter.
   (H)   All final decisions or orders of the Board will be delivered to
parties-in-interest by certified mail.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1296 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   (A)   The Board may grant a variance in an individual case of unnecessary
hardship, if the Board makes and explains, in writing, all of the following
findings:
      (1)   There are extraordinary and exceptional conditions pertaining to
the particular piece of property;
      (2)   These conditions do not generally apply to other property in the
vicinity;
      (3)   Because of these conditions, the application of the code to the
particular piece of property would effectively prohibit or unreasonably
restrict the utilization of the property; and
      (4)   The authorization of a variance will not be of substantial
detriment to adjacent property or to the public good, and the character of the
district will not be harmed by the granting of the variance.
   (B)   The Board shall not grant a variance, the effect of which would be to:
      (1)   Allow the establishment of a use not otherwise permitted in a
zoning district;
      (2)   Extend physically a nonconforming use of land; or
      (3)   Change the zoning district boundaries shown on the Zoning Map.
   (C)   The fact that property may be utilized more profitably if a variance
is granted shall not be considered grounds for a variance.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1297 SCOPE OF APPROVAL.
   (A)   Generally. An approved variance application does not authorize
construction or development. Any construction or development that occurs after
approval of a variance application requires zoning permit approval, following
approval by the Board of Zoning Appeals.
   (B)   Approval based on submitted plans.
      (1)   Unless specifically modified by the Board's approval, relief
granted as the result of an appeal shall be in accordance with the specific
plans submitted with the application.
      (2)   Minor changes to the approved plans that do not affect the relief
granted may be allowed in order to meet other code requirements, if approved by
the Zoning Administrator.
      (3)   Routine repairs and maintenance may be made to a structure
constructed pursuant to relief granted by the Board as required to preserve it
in sound condition. Any proposed changes to the structure shall be presented to
the Board Secretary for determination whether a new application is required.
   (C)   Vested rights.
      (1)   In order to complete additional applications and receive the
necessary permits for construction, variances are vested for a period of two
years, subject to the rights and restrictions contained within this title.
      (2)   Failure to receive the necessary permits within the prescribed
timeframe renders the variance approval void and of no force or effect.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1298 REAPPLICATION.
   (A)   For a period of 12 months, the Board shall not accept a variance
application for a matter upon which it has rendered a final decision, except as
provided in the Board’s rules of procedure.
   (B)   Prior to the lapse of the 12-month timeframe and upon a majority vote
ascertaining changed facts or circumstances, the Board may accept such a
variance application for consideration.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1299 APPEALS.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   A person who may have a substantial interest in any decision of the
Board of Zoning Appeals, or an officer or agent of the Town of Mount Pleasant,
may appeal from a decision of the Board to the Circuit Court of Charleston
County, by filing with the Clerk of Court a petition, in writing, setting forth
plainly, fully, and distinctly why the decision is contrary to law. The appeal
must be filed within 30 days after the decision of the Board is mailed.
      (2)   A property owner whose land is the subject of a decision of the
Board of Zoning Appeals may appeal either:
         (a)   As provided in §
156.1209(A); or
         (b)   By filing a notice of appeal with the Circuit Court, accompanied
by a request for pre-litigation mediation in accordance with S.C. Code § 6-29-
825. Any notice of appeal and request for pre-litigation mediation must be
filed within 30 days after the decision of the Board is postmarked.
   (B)   Notice of appeal and transcript. Upon the filing of the appeal, the
Clerk of the Circuit Court shall give immediate notice of it to the Secretary
of the Board and, within 30 days from the time of the notice, the Board shall
file with the Clerk a certified copy of the proceedings held before the Board
of Zoning Appeals, including a transcript of the evidence heard before it, if
any, and the decision of the Board, including its findings of fact and
conclusions.
   (C)   Supersedeas. The filing of an appeal in the Circuit Court from a
decision of the Board shall not ipso facto act as a supersedeas, but the judge
of the Circuit Court may, at their discretion, grant a supersedeas upon such
terms and conditions as may seem reasonable and proper.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1300 RECORDKEEPING.
   (A)   The Board will keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of
each member upon each question, or if absent or failing to vote, indicating the
fact.
   (B)   The Board will issue a written decision to all parties involved in the
matter.
   (C)   All final decisions and orders of the Board must be in writing and
permanently filed in the PLAN Department office as a public record. All
findings of fact and conclusions of law must be separately stated in final
decisions or orders of the Board, which must be delivered to parties of
interest by certified mail.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1301 THROUGH 156.1304 RESERVED.
PART 16: ZONING CODE INTERPRETATIONS
§ 156.1305 PURPOSE.
   A Zoning Code interpretation is a written decision issued by the Zoning
Administrator regarding the interpretation of any provision set forth in the
Zoning Code. It is intended to clarify ambiguities in the Zoning Code and to
resolve any ambiguities in future amendments.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1306 APPLICABILITY.
   This part applies to requests for a decision by the Zoning Administrator to:
   (A)   Interpret a possible ambiguous standard in this chapter;
   (B)   Clarify a standard in this chapter;
   (C)   Clarify conditions of approval pursuant to this chapter;
   (D)   Clarify standards approved for Planned Development Districts; or
   (E)   Address the categorization of a land use (“use determination”),
building, or structure that is not specifically addressed by this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1307 INITIATION.
   (A)   Applicant eligibility. Any person may submit a written request for a
Zoning Code interpretation to the Zoning Administrator.
   (B)   Application requirements. A request for a Zoning Code interpretation
shall be filed with the PLAN Department. At a minimum, the request for a code
interpretation shall be in writing and include:
      (1)   The section of the Zoning Code, standard, or condition that is
allegedly ambiguous or needing clarification;
      (2)   The subject matter or nature of the request; and
      (3)   A statement of facts relevant to the nature of the request.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1308 COMPLETENESS.
   See §
156.1080.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1309 NOTICE.
   Notice is not required for a Zoning Code interpretation.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1310 DECISION.
   (A)   The Zoning Administrator may approve a request by issuing a written
decision regarding the interpretation of any provision set forth in the Zoning
Code or standard identified in §
156.1306.
   (B)   The Zoning Administrator may reject the request through a written
response to the applicant explaining why there is no ambiguity or need for the
requested clarification.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1311 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   (A)   The Zoning Administrator may approve a request if there is an
ambiguity or need for the clarification requested by the applicant.
   (B)   The Zoning Administrator may disapprove or reject the request if there
is no ambiguity or need for the clarification requested by the applicant.
   (C)   The Zoning Administrator shall render only one interpretation per
issue. If an interpretation is requested on an issue previously addressed, the
Zoning Administrator shall provide a copy of the previous interpretation.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1312 SCOPE OF APPROVAL.
   (A)   A Zoning Code interpretation becomes effective upon execution by the
Zoning Administrator.
   (B)   A Zoning Code interpretation does not authorize development. Any
development that occurs after the Zoning Code interpretation has been issued is
subject to all applicable requirements of this chapter, as revised by the
interpretation.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1313 REAPPLICATION.
   An applicant shall not resubmit a Zoning Code interpretation application
once the Zoning Administrator has rendered a determination.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1314 APPEALS.
   The Zoning Administrator’s decision on a Zoning Code interpretation may be
appealed to the Board of Zoning Appeals in accordance with
Subchapter I, Part 17.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1315 RECORDKEEPING.
   The Zoning Administrator shall maintain records of all interpretations made
under this part.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1316 THROUGH 156.1319 RESERVED.
PART 17: APPEALS OF  ADMINISTRATIVE DECISIONS
§ 156.1320 PURPOSE.
   This part provides a process for applicants to request the review and
correction of decisions by administrative officials that they believe are in
error.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1321 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   This part applies to appeals of an order, requirement, decision, or
determination made by the Zoning Administrator or any other administrative
official in the enforcement of this chapter, except as provided in divisions
(B) and (C) below.
   (B)   Administrative decisions on design review applications are heard by
the Design Review Board in accordance with §
156.1254.
   (C)   Administrative decisions on COA applications are heard by the Historic
District Preservation Commission in accordance with §
156.1269.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1322 INITIATION.
   (A)   Applicant eligibility. An administrative decision appeal application
may be initiated by any person aggrieved or by any officer, department, board,
or bureau of the Town of Mount Pleasant.
   (B)   Application requirements.
      (1)   An administrative decision appeal application must be filed within
30 days from the date the appealing party receives actual notice of the action
from which the appeal is taken, by filing with the officer from whom the appeal
is taken and with the Board of Zoning Appeals notice of appeal specifying the
grounds for appeal.
      (2)   The officer from whom the appeal is taken immediately shall
transmit to the Board all the documents and files constituting the record upon
which the action appealed from was taken.
      (3)   Applications may be filed electronically or in-person.
   (C)   Effect on other proceedings. An appeal application that would correct
a zoning violation stays all legal proceedings by the town on the zoning
violation, unless the Zoning Administrator certifies to the Board of Zoning
Appeals, after the Appeal application has been filed, that a stay would cause
an imminent peril to life and property. In cases where there is an imminent
peril to life and property, proceedings will not be stayed unless a restraining
order is granted by the Board or by a court of record on application.
   (D)   Consideration for Planning Commission and Town Council procedures. As
a matter of process and procedure, proposed developments involving appeal
applications that also require separate review by the Planning Commission and/
or separate Town Council approval, shall not be considered by the Board of
Zoning Appeals until the referenced review and/or approval is completed.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1323 COMPLETENESS.
   See §
156.1080.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1324 NOTICE.
   (A)   The notice specified in Table 156.1324-1 is required for appeals of
administrative decisions.
   (B)   If the Board remands an appeal application to the Zoning Administrator
for further review, the Board may set a hearing without further public notice
for a time certain within 60 days unless otherwise agreed to by the parties.
The Board must maintain a list of persons who express an interest in being
informed when the remanded matter is set for rehearing, and notice of the
rehearing must be mailed to these persons before the rehearing.
 
Table 156.1324-1: Required Notice for Appeals of Administrative Decisions
   Key: N/A = not applicable
Type        Required To Whom             When
Mail        Yes      Parties in interest Due notice
Posted      Yes      General public      At least 15 days prior to public
                                         hearing
Publication Yes      General public      At least 15 days prior to public
                                         hearing
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1325 DECISION.
   (A)   The Board of Zoning Appeals will hear all appeal applications and will
render a decision in each matter.
   (B)   The Board will hear an appeal application within 60 days of the date
the application is deemed complete.
   (C)   At the hearing, any party may appear in person or by agent or by
attorney.
   (D)   The burden of proof for the relief sought is upon the applicant.
   (E)   On its own motion or the motion of a party, the Board may remand an
appeal application to the Zoning Administrator if the Board determines the
record is insufficient for review. Appeal applications that are remanded must
be rescheduled for hearing within 60 days unless the parties agree on an
extension.
   (F)   The Board will issue a written decision within 45 days of the final
hearing on the matter.
   (G)   All final decisions or orders of the Board will be delivered to
parties-in-interest by certified mail.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1326 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   In considering an appeal of an administrative decision, the Board shall
apply the standards of this chapter, other applicable law, and previous
interpretations of this chapter by the Board.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1327 SCOPE OF APPROVAL.
   An approved appeal application does not authorize development. Any
development that occurs after the decision on the appeal is subject to all
applicable requirements of this chapter, as amended by the Board of Zoning
Appeals’ decision, if applicable.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1328 REAPPLICATION.
   (A)   For a period of 12 months, the Board shall not accept an appeal
application for a matter upon which it has rendered a final decision, except as
provided in the Board’s rules of procedure.
   (B)   Prior to the lapse of the 12-month timeframe and upon a majority vote
ascertaining changed facts or circumstances, the Board may accept such an
appeal application for consideration.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1329 APPEALS.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   A person who may have a substantial interest in any decision of the
Board of Zoning Appeals, or an officer or agent of the Town of Mount Pleasant,
may appeal from a decision of the Board to the Circuit Court of Charleston
County, by filing with the Clerk of Court a petition, in writing, setting forth
plainly, fully, and distinctly why the decision is contrary to law. The appeal
must be filed within 30 days after the decision of the Board is mailed.
      (2)   A property owner whose land is the subject of a decision of the
Board of Zoning Appeals may appeal either:
         (a)   As provided in §
156.1209(A); or
         (b)   By filing a notice of appeal with the Circuit Court, accompanied
by a request for pre-litigation mediation in accordance with S.C. Code § 6-29-
825. Any notice of appeal and request for pre-litigation mediation must be
filed within 30 days after the decision of the Board is postmarked.
   (B)   Notice of appeal and transcript. Upon the filing of the appeal, the
Clerk of the Circuit Court shall give immediate notice of it to the Secretary
of the Board and, within 30 days from the time of the notice, the Board shall
file with the Clerk a certified copy of the proceedings held before the Board
of Zoning Appeals, including a transcript of the evidence heard before it, if
any, and the decision of the Board, including its findings of fact and
conclusions.
   (C)   Supersedeas. The filing of an appeal in the Circuit Court from a
decision of the Board shall not ipso facto act as a supersedeas, but the judge
of the Circuit Court may, at their discretion, grant a supersedeas upon such
terms and conditions as may seem reasonable and proper.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1330 RECORDKEEPING.
   (A)   All final decisions and orders of the Board must be in writing and
permanently filed in the office of the Board as a public record.
   (B)   All findings of fact and conclusions of law must be separately stated
in final decisions or orders of the Board, which must be delivered to parties
of interest by certified mail.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1331 THROUGH 156.1334 RESERVED.
PART 18: TEXT AMENDMENTS
§ 156.1335 PURPOSE.
   This part describes the way the town changes the text of this Zoning Code or
the regulations pertaining to an existing Planned Development (PD) District.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1336 APPLICABILITY.
   This part applies to any proposal to amend the text of this chapter and any
proposal to amend the text and/or map of a PD District ordinance. In accordance
with S.C. Code § 6-29-740, any request involving changes to an existing PD
District ordinance is considered an amendment to this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1337 INITIATION.
   (A)   Applicant eligibility.
      (1)   A text amendment application may be initiated by:
         (a)   The Town Council by adoption of a motion;
         (b)   The Planning Commission by adoption of a motion; and
         (c)   The Zoning Administrator.
      (2)   The process to amend the text of a Planned Development District
ordinance may be initiated by any of the bodies specified in division (A)(1)
above, or by any property owner whose property is subject to the provisions of
the Planned Development District ordinance.
   (B)   Application requirements.
      (1)   A text amendment application is filed with the PLAN Department on
or before the Planning Commission application deadline specified on the annual
meeting schedule. Applications may be filed electronically or in-person.
      (2)   Only one text amendment application pertaining to the same subject
matter may be considered at a time.
   (C)   Planned Development District text amendments.
      (1)   Planned Development District text amendment applications are first
submitted for preliminary staff review (see §
156.1081).
      (2)   Following preliminary staff review, the Planned Development
District text amendment application is submitted in accordance with division
(B)(1) above.
      (3)   If a proposed Planned Development District text amendment
application involves the text of a development agreement proposed or adopted
pursuant to the provisions of
Chapter 157, the applicant must submit the complete application at least 56
days prior to the meeting at which the Planning Commission will consider the
amendment.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1338 COMPLETENESS.
   See §
156.1080.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1339 NOTICE.
   The notice specified in Table 156.1339-1 is required for a text amendment
application.
 
Table 156.1339-1: Required Notice for Text Amendments
   Key: N/A = not applicable
Type         Required                 To Whom        When
Mail         No                       N/A            N/A
             Yes, for a Planned                      At least 15 days prior to
Posted       Development District     General public public hearing
             Ordinance text amendment
Publicatio n Yes                      General public At least 15 days prior to
                                                     public hearing
 
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1340 DECISION.
   (A)   Planning Commission review and recommendation.
      (1)   The Planning Commission shall review all text amendment
applications and prepare a report and recommendation, stating its findings and
its evaluation of the proposed amendment. In making its report, the Commission
shall consider the criteria specified in §
156.1341.
      (2)   The Planning Commission shall hold a public hearing. From the
closing date of the public hearing, the Commission has 30 days in which to
submit its report and recommendation to Town Council. A public hearing by the
Commission shall not be extended for more than a period of 30 days. Once a
public hearing begins, it must be closed no later than 30 days from the
commencement date.
      (3)   If the Commission fails to submit its report to Town Council within
the required 30 days, it is deemed to have recommended approval of the
proposal.
   (B)   Town Council decision.
      (1)   Town Council may amend the Zoning Code through the procedures
specified in
Chapter 30 of the Mount Pleasant Code of Ordinances.
      (2)   Following the recommendation of the Planning Commission, Council
shall approve, approve with modifications, or disapprove the proposed
amendment. In rendering its decision, Town Council shall consider, but is not
bound by, the recommendation of the Planning Commission.
         (a)   If Town Council feels the circumstances of the case warrant a
second public hearing, then it may vote to hold one.
         (b)   Town Council may defer the matter for further consideration or
remand the matter back to its Planning and Development Committee or Planning
Commission for further study and recommendation.
      (3)   No change in or departure from the text amendment as recommended by
the Planning Commission may be made pursuant to the hearing unless the change
or departure is first submitted to the Planning Commission for review and
recommendation.
      (4)   After a period of six months, if readings of the text amendment
application are not finalized, the application becomes null and void,
rescinding any Town Council action on the request.
      (5)   Any further Council action on the same request that has been denied
or expires requires a public hearing by the Planning Commission before Town
Council acts upon subsequent readings of the amending ordinance.
   (C)   Postponement requests and application withdrawals.
      (1)   Withdrawal of a text amendment application prior to the
advertisement for its initial public hearing or posting of the property is
considered as a termination of the application. Resubmission of applications
shall be processed as a new application with prescribed fees and all other
requirements met.
      (2)   A postponement request or withdrawal of a text amendment
application that occurs between the time of published advertisement of the
public hearing or posting of the property and the public hearing proceedings
shall be treated as a request denial. Reapplication is subject to a one-year
waiting period, unless granted a waiver by Council, as specified in §
156.1343.
      (3)   In either case, amendment processing shall terminate upon receipt
of written notice from the applicant or owner.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1341 REVIEW CRITERIA.
   (A)   As a matter of policy, Town Council shall not approve a text amendment
application, except:
      (1)   Where necessary to implement the Comprehensive Plan;
      (2)   To correct an original mistake, a manifest error in the
regulations;
      (3)   To recognize substantial change or changing conditions or
circumstances in a particular locality; or
      (4)   To recognize changes in technology, the style of living, or manner
of doing business.
   (B)   In making its decision, Town Council shall consider the following
factors, as applicable:
      (1)   The relationship of the proposed text amendment application to the
Comprehensive Plan and Future Land Use Map;
      (2)   Whether the request supports or contradicts the Comprehensive Plan;
      (3)   The relationship of the proposed text amendment to other relevant
plans adopted by the town;
      (4)   Whether the uses allowed by the proposed text amendment would be
appropriate in the area concerned;
      (5)   Whether adequate public school facilities, roads, and other public
services exist or can be provided to serve the needs of the development likely
to take place as a result of such change, and the consequences of such change;
      (6)   Whether the proposed text amendment is in accordance with any
existing or proposed plans for providing public water supply and sanitary
sewers to the area;
      (7)   The amount of vacant land currently classified for similar
development in the vicinity and elsewhere in the town, and any special
circumstances that may make a substantial part of such vacant land unavailable
for development;
      (8)   Whether the proposed text amendment is consistent with Chapter 155;
      (9)   Whether the proposed text amendment is consistent with best
practices for community planning and design; and
      (10)   Whether public necessity, safety, or general welfare justifies the
text amendment.
   (C)   When a Planned Development District is located within the boundaries
of an overlay district, the PD District text amendment application will be
considered in context with the purpose of the overlay district.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1342 SCOPE OF APPROVAL.
   (A)   A text amendment is effective as directed in the ordinance adopting
the amendment by Town Council and as provided in
Chapter 30 of the Mount Pleasant Code of Ordinances.
   (B)   Approval of a text amendment does not authorize development. Any
development that occurs after the text amendment is adopted is subject to all
applicable requirements of this chapter and the Planned Development District
ordinance (if applicable), as revised by the text amendment.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1343 REAPPLICATION.
   (A)   Zoning Code text amendments. When Town Council disapproves a Zoning
Code text amendment application, the same proposed amendment may not be
initiated for a period of 12 months.
   (B)   Planned Development District text amendments. When Town Council
disapproves a Planned Development District text amendment application, the same
proposed amendment may not be initiated for the Planned Development District
for a period of 12 months, irrespective of change(s) in ownership.
      (1)   However, after receipt of written petition by the property owner(s)
or other body authorized to submit a text amendment application stating how
conditions have changed substantially in the community since prior
consideration of the text amendment application so as to justify another
review, Town Council may, on a case-by-case basis, waive the waiting period
requirements by a vote of a majority of members present and voting in favor,
and direct PLAN Department staff in writing to process the application.
      (2)   Denial of the petition is final. The one-year waiting period shall
be met before further consideration of the amendment.
   (C)   Resubmittal. Resubmittal of a text amendment application shall be
processed as a new application with all fees specified in §
156.1101.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1344 APPEALS.
   This chapter does not authorize new rights to an appeal from or remedies for
adverse decisions by Town Council, but interested parties may pursue existing
remedies from the Circuit Court.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1345 RECORDKEEPING.
   (A)   When the Town Council approves changes to the text of the Zoning Code,
those changes will be reflected in the Mount Pleasant Code of Ordinances as
provided in Chapter 30.
   (B)   When the Town Council approves changes to the text of a Planned
Development District ordinance, those changes shall be assigned a file number
and recorded in the zoning GIS layer (see §
156.022).
   (C)   The Zoning Administrator shall maintain a record of all text amendment
applications and related materials.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1346 THROUGH 156.1349 RESERVED.
PART 19: SMALL WIRELESS FACILITIES  APPLICATIONS
§ 156.1350 CROSS-REFERENCE TO APPLICABLE PROCEDURE.
   The procedure for establishment of small wireless facilities is specified in
Subchapter C, Part 7, Subpart 7.1.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1351 THROUGH 156.1369 RESERVED.
PART 20: TELECOMMUNICATIONS TOWERS  APPLICATIONS
§ 156.1370 CROSS-REFERENCE TO APPLICABLE PROCEDURE.
   The procedure for establishment of telecommunications towers is specified in
Subchapter C, Part 7, Subpart 7.2.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1371 THROUGH 156.1389 RESERVED.
SUBCHAPTER J: REVIEWING AND DECISION-MAKING BODIES
PART 1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 156.1390 PURPOSE.
   (A)   This subchapter formally establishes commissions, boards, and
administrative officials, or recognizes existing commissions, boards, or
administrative officials, that administer this chapter.
   (B)   This subchapter establishes the composition of those reviewing and
decision-making bodies, their jurisdiction, and related administrative matters.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§
156.1391 THROUGH
156.1394 RESERVED.
PART 2: ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW AND  DECISION-MAKING BODIES
SUBPART 2.1: DEPARTMENT OF PLANNING, LAND USE, AND NEIGHBORHOODS
§ 156.1395 DIRECTOR OF PLANNING, LAND USE, AND NEIGHBORHOODS.
   In addition to the duties specified in §
31.081, the Director of Planning, Land Use, and Neighborhoods has the following
duties in the administration and enforcement of this chapter:
   (A)   Advise applicants for permits concerning the provisions of
Chapter 156 and assist applicants in preparing applications;
   (B)   Receive, file, and forward to the Planning Commission all complete
applications that require its review, pursuant to
Subchapter I;
   (C)   Provide public notice as required by
Subchapter I;
   (D)   Perform field inspections for individual applications to verify
compliance with this chapter;
   (E)   Provide public information relative to this chapter;
   (F)   Maintain permanent and current records of matters pertaining to this
chapter, including:
      (1)   All original and current zoning maps;
      (2)   Zoning Code text and map amendments; and
      (3)   Comprehensive Plan text and Future Land Use map amendments.
   (G)   Execute any and all reports as the Town Council may require; and
   (H)   Coordinate with other town departments and outside agencies as needed
in the execution of these duties.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1396 ZONING ADMINISTRATOR.
   (A)   As specified in §
31.081, the Zoning Administrator shall be the Director of Planning, Land Use,
and Neighborhoods, unless the Director specifically designates another
individual, in writing, to act as same.
   (B)   The Zoning Administrator has the following specific duties in the
administration and enforcement of this chapter:
      (1)   Advise applicants for permits concerning the provisions of
Chapter 156 and assist applicants in preparing applications;
      (2)   Receive, review, and act on zoning permit applications (see
Subchapter I, Part 7);
      (3)   Receive, file, and forward to the Board of Zoning Appeals all
complete applications that require its review, pursuant to
Subchapter I;
      (4)   Receive, file, and forward to the Design Review Board all complete
applications that require its review, pursuant to Subchapter I;
      (5)   Receive, file, and forward to the Historic District Preservation
Commission all complete applications that require its review, pursuant to
Subchapter I: Procedures;
      (6)   Coordinate the activities of the Historical Commission (see
Subchapter J, Part 3, Subpart 3.6);
      (7)   Review applications for building permits, as needed, to verify
compliance with the Zoning Code;
      (8)   Develop interpretations of ambiguities in this chapter and other
issues in accordance with
Subchapter I, Part 16;
      (9)   Provide public notice as required by
Subchapter I;
      (10)   Provide public information relative to this chapter;
      (11)   Conduct inspections and perform field inspections as needed for
individual applications to verify compliance with this chapter;
      (12)   Maintain permanent and current records and files of any and all
matters referred to them;
      (13)   Execute any and all reports as the Town Council may require;
      (14)   Investigate Zoning Code violations; issue citations, warnings, or
notices where such violations exist; follow up on violations until the
situation has been properly remedied; and attend court hearings and testify
concerning Zoning Code violations;
      (15)   As appropriate, report to the Town Council any violation or
proposed violation of the Zoning Code;
      (16)   Order discontinuances of illegal use of land, buildings, or
structures; removal of illegal buildings or structures of illegal additions,
alterations, or structural changes; discontinuance of any illegal work being
done; or any other action authorized by this chapter to ensure compliance with
or to prevent violation of its provisions (see
Subchapter L);
      (17)   Coordinate with other town departments and outside agencies as
needed in the execution of these duties; and
      (18)   Other general requirements the town deems necessary to administer
this chapter.
   (C)   It shall also be the duty of all officers and employees of the town to
assist the Zoning Administrator by reporting to them new construction or new
land uses and apparent violations of this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1397 THROUGH 156.1404 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.2: ENGINEERING AND  DEVELOPMENT SERVICES DEPARTMENT
§ 156.1405 DIRECTOR OF THE ENGINEERING AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES DEPARTMENT.
   The Director of the Engineering and Development Services Department has the
following duties in the administration and enforcement of this chapter:
   (A)   Designate a Program Manager for the Technical Review and Code
Compliance procedure; and
   (B)   Review for compliance with intersection sight distance requirements
any application referred by the PLAN Director or Zoning Administrator.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1406 DEPUTY DIRECTOR OF THE ENGINEERING AND ENVIRONMENTAL DIVISION.
   The Deputy Director of the Engineering and Environmental Division of the
Engineering and Development Services Department has the following duties in the
administration and enforcement of this chapter:
   (A)   Administer the tree protection regulations in Subchapter E for
detached house dwellings;
   (B)   Review proposals to redesignate critical area buffers on existing lots
(see §
156.622);
   (C)   Review proposals to establish new critical area buffer vision
corridors (see §
156.626); and
   (D)   Participate on the Technical Review and Code Compliance Team and/or
designate one or more staff members to serve on the TRCC.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1407 THROUGH 156.1414 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.3: TECHNICAL REVIEW AND  CODE COMPLIANCE TEAM
§ 156.1415 COMPOSITION.
   (A)   Staff members.
      (1)   Technical Review and Code Compliance (TRCC) is administered by the
Design Review Team (DRT) which may be composed of staff members from the
following departments:
         (a)   Department of Planning, Land Use, and Neighborhoods;
         (b)   Engineering and Development Services Department;
         (c)   Fire Department;
         (d)   Police Department; and
         (e)   Public Services Department.
      (2)   Staff from other departments or outside agencies may be consulted
on a case-by-case basis, depending on the complexity of the proposed project.
   (B)   Program Manager.
      (1)   The Director of the Engineering and Development Services Department
shall designate a Program Manager.
      (2)   The Program Manager:
         (a)   Reviews incoming DRB and Planning Commission applications to
determine which qualify for TRCC review; and
         (b)   Coordinates the DRT members and TRCC review process.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1416 MEETINGS.
   The DRT meets for TRCC on a monthly or as-needed basis.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1417 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   The TRCC process reviews all:
      (1)   Design review applications (see
Subchapter I, Part 12); and
      (2)   Sketch plan applications (see §
155.021).
   (B)   The TRCC determines whether applications and associated development
plans comply with the town Code of Ordinances.
   (C)   As part of the TRCC review process, the DRT provides comments to
applicants and may require changes to submitted applications and plans to
ensure compliance with town ordinances.
   (D)   Following TRCC review, the DRT forwards complete applications to the
Design Review Board or Planning Commission, as applicable. The DRT does not
forward an application unless it fully complies with minimum code requirements.
   (E)   TRCC does not approve or disapprove applications or development plans.
As such, the TRCC review process does not confer vested rights for any
application.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1418 THROUGH 156.1429 RESERVED.
PART 3: APPOINTED REVIEW AND  DECISION-MAKING BODIES
SUBPART 3.1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 156.1430 APPLICABILITY.
   This subpart applies to the Planning Commission, Board of Zoning Appeals,
Design Review Board, Historic District Preservation Commission, and Historical
Commission.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1431 TERM OF OFFICE.
   (A)   Term length.
      (1)   Unless otherwise specified in this subchapter, all seats on all
appointed boards and commissions have a three year term.
      (2)   Terms begin on the date of appointment. Members shall assume their
duties at the first regular meeting after their appointment.
      (3)   Each member shall serve until Town Council appoints their
successor.
   (B)   Number of terms. Each person appointed may serve up to three
consecutive terms on a particular board or commission.
   (C)   Term expiration. Upon the expiration of a term, the Town Council shall
act promptly to make appointments in order to avoid vacant seats, the continued
service of members with expired terms, or the clustering of more than three
term expirations on any one board or commission in a given year.
   (D)   Implementation of new terms.
      (1)   The Zoning Code revision in 2025 implemented universal three-year
terms. To implement this change, each current board or commission member serves
the remainder of their current term. The three-year term commences with each
subsequent appointment or reappointment.
      (2)   Each member may serve up to three consecutive terms on a particular
board or commission, regardless of the number of years in each term.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1432 ATTENDANCE, REMOVAL, AND VACANCIES.
   (A)   Attendance.
      (1)   Members that have served less than one year of their appointed term
shall attend at least 75% of all called meetings. This is measured on the first
of every month for the preceding year. Attendance at fewer than 75% of meetings
is cause for removal.
      (2)   Members that have served one year or more of their appointed term
may be absent from up to four called meetings per year on a 12-month rolling
basis. The fifth absence is cause for removal.
   (B)   Removal.
      (1)   Any member of a board or commission may be removed by the Town
Council or Town Administrator, as specified below, for just cause. Neglect of
duty, no longer being a resident of the town, or misconduct in office
constitutes just cause.
      (2)   If removal for cause, except due to attendance, appears imminent,
the Chairperson of the respective board or commission shall contact the member
and ascertain whether removal should be considered by the Town Council. The
Chairperson shall then make a recommendation to Council, prior to Council
action on the matter.
      (3)   If removal due to attendance is necessary, the Town Administrator
shall remove the member from the board or commission prior to the next
scheduled meeting and shall notify Town Council.
   (C)   Vacancies.
      (1)   A vacancy in the term of office occurs whenever a member resigns,
is unable to serve for any reason, or is removed in accordance with the
provisions of this section.
      (2)   Any vacancy in the membership shall be filled, as soon as may
reasonably be accomplished by the Town Council, in the same manner as the
original appointment.
      (3)   Members appointed to fill a vacancy shall serve a full three-year
term, as specified in §
156.1431, regardless of the amount of time left in the previous member’s term.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1433 CHAIRPERSONS, VICE-CHAIRPERSONS, AND SECRETARIES.
   (A)   Chairpersons and vice-chairpersons.
      (1)   At the first regular meeting of each calendar year, each board or
commission shall elect a Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson by secret ballot.
      (2)   The term of office of the Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson is a
period of one year.
      (3)   If a vacancy occurs in an office prior to the expiration of the
full term, another election to fill the remainder of the term of office shall
be conducted at the first meeting thereafter.
      (4)   The Chairperson shall be a voting member and shall:
         (a)   Call special meetings;
         (b)   Preside at meetings and hearings;
         (c)   Swear in witnesses when applicable;
         (d)   Act as spokesperson for the board or commission; and
         (e)   Perform other duties approved by the board or commission.
      (5)   The Vice-Chairperson shall exercise the duties of the Chairperson
in the absence, disability, or disqualification of the Chairperson.
      (6)   In the absence of the Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson, the members
present shall elect an acting Chairperson.
   (B)   Secretaries.
      (1)   The PLAN Director shall designate staff members of the Planning,
Land Use, and Neighborhoods Department to serve as Secretary and Recording
Secretary of each board or commission.
      (2)   The Secretary shall:
         (a)   Coordinate with board/commission members to schedule meetings;
         (b)   Provide proper notice for all meetings;
         (c)   Create meeting agendas;
         (d)   Distribute meeting materials;
         (e)   See that the property involved is properly posted, as
applicable;
         (f)   Serve board or commission decisions on parties, as applicable;
         (g)   Maintain records of the board’s or commission’s actions as a
public record;
         (h)   Attend to board or commission correspondence;
         (i)   Advise the board/commission as needed; and
         (j)   Undertake other duties as specified in the board’s or
commission’s rules of procedure.
      (3)   The Recording Secretary shall:
         (a)   Keep minutes of the board’s or commission’s proceedings, showing
the vote of each member upon each question or, if absent or failing to vote,
indicating such fact;
         (b)   Assist with meeting room setup;
         (c)   Ensure recording and audio/video equipment are available and set
up as needed;
         (d)   Serve as support staff to the Secretary; and
         (e)   Other duties as specified in the board’s or commission’s rules
of procedure.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1434 MEETINGS AND QUORUMS.
   (A)   Meetings of each board or commission shall be held regularly, as
specified on the annual meeting schedule, at the call of the Chairperson, and
at such other times as the Chairperson or board/commission determine.
   (B)   All meetings of the board or commission shall be open to the public.
   (C)   Public notice for all board and commission meetings shall be provided
in accordance with the requirements outlined in S.C. Code, Title 30, Chapter 4,
also known as the Freedom of Information Act, and S.C. Code Title 6, Chapter
29, also known as the South Carolina Local Government Comprehensive Planning
Enabling Act of 1994.
   (D)   A majority of the members appointed and currently serving constitute a
quorum for conducting business, including members who have recused themselves
for conflict of interest, pursuant to S.C. Code § 8-13-700(B). In no case shall
a quorum exist if the number of members currently serving on the board or
commission is less than the minimum number of members allowable under
applicable state law.
   (E)   Decisions shall be made by a majority vote of a quorum of members.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1435 RULES OF PROCEDURE.
   (A)   Each board and commission shall adopt rules of procedure at its first
meeting of each calendar year.
   (B)   Rules of procedure for each board and commission are available on the
town’s website.
   (C)   Robert's Rules of Order governs the conduct of meetings, except as
otherwise provided by the board’s or commission’s rules of procedure.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1436 LIABILITY OF MEMBERS.
   (A)   Any member of a board or commission acting within the powers granted
by this subchapter is relieved from all personal liability for any damage and
shall be held harmless by the town.
   (B)   Any suit brought against any member of a board or commission within
their official capacity shall be defended by a legal representative furnished
by the town until the termination of the procedure.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1437 THROUGH 156.1444 RESERVED.
SUBPART 3.2: PLANNING COMMISSION
§ 156.1445 ESTABLISHMENT AND MEMBERSHIP OF THE PLANNING COMMISSION.
   (A)   Establishment. Pursuant to S.C. Code §§ 6-29-310 et seq., this part
establishes a Planning Commission, composed of nine members appointed by the
Mayor and Town Council.
   (B)   Membership.
      (1)   It is the declared policy of the Town Council that it will consider
and appoint only those persons who:
         (a)   Are residents of the town and have been so for a period of at
least one year prior to the appointment; and
         (b)   Have demonstrated their professional expertise, knowledge of the
community, and concern for the future welfare of the total community and its
citizens.
      (2)   Members shall represent a broad cross-section of interests and
concerns within the town.
      (3)   Members of the Commission shall:
         (a)   Regularly attend meetings and public hearings of the Commission;
and
         (b)   Serve without compensation, except for reimbursement for
authorized expenses related to the performance of their duties.
      (4)   While serving on the Commission, a member shall not hold any public
office or position in the Town of Mount Pleasant or Charleston County.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1446 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   The Planning Commission has all the powers, duties, and
responsibilities as set forth herein and in S.C. Code §§ 6-29-310 et seq.
   (B)   It is the function and duty of the Planning Commission to undertake a
continuing planning program for the physical, social, and economic growth,
development, and redevelopment of the area within its jurisdiction.
      (1)   The plans and programs must be designed to promote public health,
safety, morals, convenience, prosperity, or the general welfare, as well as the
efficiency and economy of its area of jurisdiction.
      (2)   Specific planning elements must be based upon careful and
comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions and probable future
development, and include recommended means of implementation.
      (3)   The Planning Commission may make, publish, and distribute maps,
plans, and reports and recommendations relating to the plans and programs and
the development of this area of jurisdiction to public officials and agencies,
public utility companies, civic, educational, professional, and other
organizations and citizens.
      (4)   All public officials shall, upon request, furnish to the Planning
Commission, within a reasonable time, such available information as it may
require for its work.
      (5)   The Planning Commission, its members, and its employees, in the
performance of its functions, may enter upon any land with consent of the
property owner or, after ten days' written notification to the owner of record,
make examinations and surveys, and place and maintain necessary monuments and
marks on them, provided, however, that the Planning Commission shall be liable
for any injury or damage to property resulting therefrom.
      (6)   In general, the Planning Commission has the powers as may be
necessary to enable it to perform its functions and promote the planning of its
political jurisdiction.
   (C)   In the discharge of its responsibilities, the Planning Commission has
the power and duty to:
      (1)   Prepare and revise periodically plans and programs for the
development and redevelopment of its area, as provided herein;
      (2)   Prepare and recommend for adoption to the Town Council as a means
for implementing the plans and programs in its area:
         (a)   Zoning ordinances to include zoning district maps and
appropriate revisions thereof, as provided herein;
         (b)   Regulations for the subdivision or development of land, and
appropriate revisions thereof, and to oversee the administration of the
regulations that may be adopted, as provided herein;
         (c)   An official map and appropriate revision on it showing the exact
location of existing or proposed public street, highway, and utility rights-of-
way, and public building sites, together with regulations to control the
erection of buildings or other structures or changes in land use within the
rights-of-way, building sites, or open spaces within its political jurisdiction
or a specified portion of it, as set forth herein;
         (d)   A landscaping ordinance setting forth required planting, tree
preservation, and other aesthetic considerations for land and structures;
         (e)   A capital improvements program setting forth projects required
to implement plans that have been prepared and adopted, including an annual
listing of priority projects for consideration by the governmental bodies
responsible for implementation prior to preparation of their capital budget;
and
         (f)   Policies or procedures to facilitate implementation of planning
element; and
      (3)   Name or rename streets within the town.
   (D)   The Planning Commission may purchase equipment and supplies, and may
employ or contract for such staff and such experts as it considers necessary
and consistent with funds appropriated.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1447 THROUGH 156.1454 RESERVED.
SUBPART 3.3: BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS
§ 156.1455 ESTABLISHMENT AND MEMBERSHIP OF THE BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS.
   (A)   Establishment. Pursuant to S.C. Code §§ 6-29-780 et seq., this part
establishes a Board of Zoning Appeals (BOZA), composed of seven members
appointed by the Mayor and Town Council.
   (B)   Membership.
      (1)   It is the declared policy of Town Council that it will consider and
appoint only those persons who:
         (a)   Are residents of the town and have been so for a period of at
least one year prior to the appointment; and
         (b)   Have demonstrated their general knowledge of the community and
concern for the welfare of the total community and its citizens.
      (2)   Members shall represent a broad cross-section of interests and
concerns within the town.
      (3)   Members of the Board shall:
         (a)   Regularly attend meetings; and
         (b)   Serve without compensation, except for reimbursement for
authorized expenses related to the performance of their duties.
      (4)   While serving on the Board, a member shall not hold any other
public office or position in the Town of Mount Pleasant or Charleston County.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1456 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   Powers and duties. The Board of Zoning Appeals has all of the powers,
duties, and responsibilities set forth in S.C. Code §§ 6-29-780 through 6-29-
860, as amended, unless otherwise stated herein. Specifically, the Board has
the following powers:
      (1)   To hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is error in an
order, requirement, decision, or determination made by an administrative
official in the enforcement of the Zoning Code (see
Subchapter I, Part 17);
      (2)   To hear and decide appeals for variance from the requirements of
the Zoning Code when strict application of the provisions of the Code would
result in unnecessary hardship (see
Subchapter I, Part 15);
      (3)   To permit uses by special exception, (see
Subchapter I, Part 9); and
      (4)   To remand a matter to an administrative official upon motion by a
party or the Board's own motion, if the Board determines the record is
insufficient for review.
         (a)   A party's motion for remand may be denied if the Board
determines the record is sufficient for review.
         (b)   The Board must set a rehearing on the remanded matter without
further public notice for a time certain within 60 days, unless otherwise
agreed to by the parties.
         (c)   The Board must maintain a list of persons who express an
interest in being informed when the remanded matter is set for rehearing, and
notice of the rehearing must be mailed to these persons prior to the rehearing.
   (B)   Exercise of powers and duties.
      (1)   In exercising the above powers and duties, the Board of Zoning
Appeals may:
         (a)   In conformity with the provisions of this chapter, reverse or
affirm, wholly or in part, or modify the order, requirements, decision,
determination, and to that end shall have all the powers of the officer from
whom the appeal is taken;
         (b)   Issue or direct the issuance of a permit;
         (c)   Subpoena witnesses; and,
         (d)   In case of contempt by a party, witness, or other person before
the Board of Zoning Appeals, may certify this fact to the circuit court having
jurisdiction. The judge of the court, in open court or in chambers, after
hearing, may impose a penalty as authorized by law.
      (2)   The Chairperson or, in their absence, the Vice-Chairperson may
administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses by subpoena.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1457 FINANCING.
   The Town Council may:
   (A)   Appropriate such monies, otherwise unappropriated, as it considers fit
to finance the work of the Board of Zoning Appeals and to generally provide for
the enforcement of any zoning regulations and restrictions authorized hereunder
that are adopted; and
   (B)   Accept and expend grants of money for those purposes from either
private or public sources, whether local, state, or federal.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1458 THROUGH 156.1464 RESERVED.
SUBPART 3.4: DESIGN REVIEW BOARD
§ 156.1465 ESTABLISHMENT AND MEMBERSHIP OF THE DESIGN REVIEW BOARD.
   (A)   Establishment. Pursuant to S.C. Code §§ 6-29-870 et seq., this part
establishes a Design Review Board (DRB), composed of seven members appointed by
the Mayor and Town Council.
   (B)   Membership.
      (1)   It is the declared policy of the Town Council that it will consider
and appoint only those persons who:
         (a)   Are residents of the town and have been so for a period of at
least one year prior to the appointment;
         (b)   Have demonstrated their professional expertise, knowledge of the
community, and concern for the welfare of the total community and its citizens;
and
         (c)   Have a demonstrated interest in, competence in, and knowledge
of, architecture, landscape architecture, and urban design.
      (2)   At least one member of the DRB shall be a state-licensed architect
and at least one member shall be a state-licensed landscape architect.
      (3)   To the extent there are local resources, membership priority may be
given, in Council’s sole discretion, to state-licensed landscape architects,
state-licensed architects, licensed professional engineers, and licensed
general building contractors.
      (4)   Members of the DRB shall:
         (a)   Regularly attend meetings of the DRB; and
         (b)   Serve without compensation, except for reimbursement for
authorized expenses related to the performance of their duties.
      (5)   While serving on the DRB, a member shall not hold any other public
office or position in the Town of Mount Pleasant or Charleston County.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1466 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   The DRB has all the powers, duties, and responsibilities as set forth
herein and in S.C. Code §§ 6-29-870 et seq.
   (B)   It is the duty and power of the DRB to:
      (1)   Protect and promote the appearance, character, and economic value
of commercial development located within the commercial districts and
development areas of the town and of apartment complex developments located in
residential and mixed use areas of the town;
      (2)   Review and approve or deny all applications submitted to it for
proposed new commercial developments located within the commercial districts
and development areas of the town and for proposed new apartment complex
developments;
      (3)   Review and approve or deny all applications submitted to it for
major alterations and/or additions to existing commercial developments located
within the commercial districts and development areas of the town and for
proposed new apartment complex developments;
      (4)   Review and approve or deny all applications submitted to it for
landscape plans proposed by the town or any other public or state agency for
public rights-of-way or for publicly-owned property located within the
commercial districts and development areas of the town;
      (5)   Review and approve or deny all applications submitted to it for
architectural plans for facilities to be located within designated commercial
districts and development areas proposed by the town or any other public or
state agency;
      (6)   Foster civic beauty; and
      (7)   Strengthen the local economy.
   (C)   In order to accomplish the above, the DRB has the authority to adjust
or modify the building and site design standards of Subchapter H, Parts 2 and 3
as deemed appropriate to the particular project and its individual
circumstances.
   (D)   The DRB’s area of purview is more fully described in Subchapter H.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1467 THROUGH 156.1474 RESERVED.
SUBPART 3.5: HISTORIC DISTRICT PRESERVATION COMMISSION
§ 156.1475 ESTABLISHMENT AND MEMBERSHIP OF THE HISTORIC DISTRICT PRESERVATION
COMMISSION.
   (A)   Establishment. Pursuant to S.C. Code §§ 6-29-870 et seq., as amended,
the Historic District Preservation Commission (HDPC), composed of five members
appointed by the Mayor and Town Council, was established by Ordinance No.
19062, passed November 12, 2019; having replaced and superseded the previous
Old Village Historic District Commission, which was established by Ordinance
No. 06052, passed June 21, 2006; having replaced and superseded the previous
Town Appearance Commission, which was established by ordinance passed May 5,
1986.
   (B)   Membership.
      (1)   It is the declared policy of the Town Council that it will consider
and appoint only those persons who:
         (a)   Have been residents of the town for a period of at least two
years prior to appointment;
         (b)   Reside in the historic districts, except that a member in one of
the five seats is not required to reside within an historic district. Each
Historic District shall have at least one resident on the HDPC;
         (c)   Have demonstrated their general knowledge of the community and
concern for the welfare of the total community and its citizens; and
         (d)   Have a demonstrated interest and knowledge of the historic
district.
      (2)   At least one member of the HDPC shall be a professional in
architectural history, preservation, history, archaeology, building arts, or
any other area of knowledge that would benefit the mission of the Commission
and meet the membership requirement of the certified local government program.
      (3)   In general, and to the extent that there are local resources in the
community, members shall be knowledgeable in architecture, architectural
history, planning, archeology, history, building arts, and any other areas of
knowledge that would benefit the mission of the Commission and community.
      (4)   Members of the Commission shall:
         (a)   Regularly attend meetings; and
         (b)   Serve without compensation, except for reimbursement for
authorized expenses related to the performance of their duties.
      (5)   While serving on the Board, a members shall not hold any other
public office or position in the Town of Mount Pleasant or Charleston County.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1476 JURISDICTION.
   The HDPC shall oversee the Old Village Historic District (see Subchapter B)
and any future historic districts established by the town.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1477 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   Survey and inventory.
      (1)   Pursuant to the town's historic district Certified Local Government
(CLG) status, the Commission may request funding for and authorize a new survey
and inventory of properties, or update of a prior inventory, provided that such
survey or update is conducted in accordance with professional standards under
qualified supervision; and is coordinated with and complementary to those
standards of the State Historic Preservation Office; and follows procedures
described in the South Carolina State Historic Preservation Program: Survey
Manual.
      (2)   The Commission shall maintain a local survey and inventory of
buildings, structures, and sites. These records shall be available to the
public.
      (3)   In addition to maintaining CLG status, the survey and inventory may
be used to:
         (a)   Record the historic architecture of the town;
         (b)   Study a given area in order to evaluate eligibility for the
National Register of Historic Places or district status; or
         (c)   Monitor change to the architectural fabric of Mount Pleasant.
      (4)   The 2010 comprehensive survey of the district entitled "A Historic
Resources Survey of the Old Village Historic District" shall be the survey
referenced for any of the uses listed above.
   (B)   Designation of historic properties.
      (1)   The Commission shall review the local survey and inventory and make
recommendations for historic designation to the Town Council, based on any of
the following criteria:
         (a)   A property, be it a structure or site, may be designated
historic if it was built at least 50 years before the current year, and:
            1.   Has inherent character, interest, or value as part of the
development or heritage of the community, state, or nation;
            2.   Is the site of an event significant in history;
            3.   Has an association with a person or persons who contributed
significantly to the culture and development of the community, state, or
nation;
            4.   Exemplifies the cultural, political, economic, social, ethnic,
architectural, archeological, or historic heritage of the community, state, or
nation;
            5.   Embodies distinguishing characteristics of a type, style,
period, or specimen in architecture or engineering;
            6.   Is the work of a designer whose work has significantly
influenced the development of the community, state, or nation;
            7.   Contains elements of design, detail, materials, or
craftsmanship that represent a significant innovation;
            8.   Is part of or related to a distinctive element of community
planning;
            9.   Represents an established and familiar visual feature of the
neighborhood, waterfront, or community;
            10.   Represents an archeological site, be it a prominent land
feature with significance to the development of the historic districts, a
prehistory site, or other culturally significant place important to the history
of Mount Pleasant, the historic districts, the state, or the nation; or
            11.   Embodies distinguishing characteristics of a type of land
development character through the prevailing patterns of existing lots,
densities, spacing of homes, lot sizes and shapes, and other characteristics
that exemplify the culture, traditions, beliefs, practices, lifeways, arts,
crafts, and social institutions that constitute the heritage of the community;
         (b)   Ordinarily structures that have been moved from their original
locations, reconstructed historic buildings, properties primarily commemorative
in nature, and properties that have achieved significance within 50 years
before the current year shall not be considered eligible for historic
designation. However, such properties may be recommended if they fall within
the following categories:
            1.   A building or structure removed from its original location,
but that is significant primarily for architectural value, or that is the
surviving structure most importantly associated with a historic person or
event;
            2.   A reconstructed building, when accurately executed in a
suitable environment and presented in a dignified manner as part of a
restoration master plan, and when no other building or structure with the same
association has survived;
            3.   A property primarily commemorative in intent if design, age,
tradition, or symbolic value has invested it with its own historical
significance; or
            4.   A property achieving significance within 50 years before the
current year if it is of exceptional importance;
      (2)   The Commission may review properties for historic designation at
its discretion or when prompted when a structure or site has achieved 50 years
since construction.
      (3)   Owners of properties recommended for designation shall be provided
notice and an opportunity for a public hearing before the Town Council prior to
a final decision. Specifically, the owners shall be notified in writing, via
certified mail, 30 days before the Town Council's review of the recommendation,
and may appear before Town Council to support or oppose the proposed historic
designation.
      (4)   Upon approval of the Town Council, designated districts, district
extensions, buildings, structures, and sites shall be preserved and protected
under the regulations of this Chapter and the design guidelines referenced in
division (G) below.
      (5)   Property owners who wish to appeal the decision of the Town Council
may do so before the courts of the state, as provided in South Carolina Code of
Laws.
   (C)   Creation of new historic districts and the reduction or elimination of
existing historic districts.
      (1)   The Commission has the power to recommend to the Town Council the
creation of new historic districts and the reduction or elimination of existing
historic districts. The recommendation shall be based upon the properties
within the district meeting the criteria specified in division (B) above.
      (2)   Owners of properties to be included in new or expanded districts or
those eliminated from districts shall be notified in writing, via certified
mail, 30 days prior to consideration by the Town Council. Owners may appear
before the Town Council to voice their opinion on the designation, and may
object to the decision of the Town Council to designate their property by
filing suit before the courts of the state, as provided in the South Carolina
Code of Laws.
      (3)   Upon approval by the Town Council, newly created historic districts
shall be treated as new zoning overlay districts, with regulations and
guidelines appropriate for that district and area of the town and shall be
under the authority of the HDPC.
   (D)   Nominations to the National Register of Historic Places.
      (1)   The Commission may nominate buildings, structures, sites, objects,
or districts to the National Register of Historic Places, according to the
criteria and registration requirements set forth by the National Park Service
which oversees the National Register of Historic Places.
      (2)   The Commission shall have first review and evaluation of all
proposed nominations to the National Register of Historic Places within its
jurisdiction, including any that may have been submitted to the State Historic
Preservation Office. Owners of properties to be reviewed by the Commission
shall be notified in writing, via certified mail, 30 days prior to the
Commission's review.
      (3)   The Commission shall forward all reviewed nominations to the State
Historic Preservation Office, with recommendations for consideration by the
State Board of Review.
      (4)   The Commission does not have the authority to nominate properties
directly to the National Register of Historic Places; only the State Board of
Review and the State Historic Preservation Office has this final review
authority.
   (E)   Identification of historic properties and districts.
      (1)   The Secretary shall maintain a map illustrating all historic
properties as defined herein, which may be amended from time to time as allowed
within these provisions.
      (2)   All locally designated historic districts shall be clearly shown
through a written description and map located within each Historic Overlay
District.
   (F)   Design review.
      (1)   It is the duty of the Commission to review applications regarding
moving, demolition, new construction, exterior alteration, building additions,
site alterations, hardscaping, walkways, driveways, patios, walls, fences, and
docks in the Old Village Historic District.
      (2)   This review shall follow established criteria (see
Subchapter I, Part 13) in accordance with approved design guidelines (see
division (G) below).
   (G)   Design guidelines.
      (1)   In order to accomplish the design review as provided in division
(F) above, the Commission shall adopt design guidelines.
      (2)   Such design guidelines, and any subsequent amendments thereto,
shall be published and made available to the public. The Old Village Historic
District Guidelines are available on the town’s website.
      (3)   Amendments to design guidelines take effect at the second regularly
scheduled monthly meeting of the HDPC following the approval.
      (4)   The Commission shall readopt design guidelines at their first
regularly scheduled meeting of each year.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1478 PROFESSIONAL ADVISOR.
   (A)   The Commission may consult with an architect, architectural historian,
a person with an expertise in the building arts, or any other professional on
an as-needed basis to receive professional advice.
   (B)   This advisor may be appointed by Town Council at the request of the
Commission.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1479 THROUGH 156.1484 RESERVED.
SUBPART 3.6: HISTORICAL COMMISSION
§ 156.1485 ESTABLISHMENT AND MEMBERSHIP OF THE HISTORICAL COMMISSION.
   (A)   Establishment.
      (1)   This part establishes a Historical Commission, composed of seven
members appointed by the Mayor and Town Council.
      (2)   The Historical Commission was originally created on January 10,
1989 and was reconstituted in accordance with the South Carolina Local
Government Comprehensive Planning Enabling Act of 1994.
   (B)   Membership. It is the declared policy of Town Council that it will
consider and appoint only those persons who:
      (1)   Are residents of the town and have been so for a period of at least
one year prior to the appointment; and
      (2)   Have demonstrated their general knowledge of the community and
concern for the welfare of the total community and its citizens.
      (3)   Members of the Commission shall:
         (a)   Regularly attend meetings; and
         (b)   Serve without compensation, except for reimbursement for
authorized expenses related to the performance of their duties.
      (4)   While serving on the Commission, a member shall not hold any other
public office or position in the Town of Mount Pleasant or Charleston County.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1486 PURPOSE.
   The Historical Commission’s purpose is to:
   (A)   Promote local history and historical areas through educational
programs and activities.
   (B)   Preserve, protect, and promote the integrity of properties significant
