in local history, architecture, archaeology, engineering, economics,
transportation, and culture; and
   (C)   Initiate, encourage, and maintain local historical preservation
efforts in coordination with community desires and the Comprehensive Plan.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1487 JURISDICTION.
   The Commission's jurisdiction applies to all real property within the
municipal limits of the town, including all future annexations.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1488 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   In furtherance of §
156.1486, the Commission has the following powers and duties:
   (A)   Official map. To prepare and maintain revisions of an official map,
locating the position of historical and cultural sites within the town;
   (B)   Public educational programs and promotion of historical areas. To
promote local history and the use and enjoyment of historical areas through
lectures, exhibits, publications, special events and programs;
   (C)   Historical marker program. To promote local sites, events, and persons
through the historical marker program;
   (D)   Mount Pleasant special collection. To establish a special collection
for the purpose of collecting, cataloging, and preserving information about the
history of the town and its residents; and
   (E)   History-related tourism. To provide advice, recommendations, and
assistance regarding history-related tourism.
   (F)   Monuments and memorials. To evaluate and recommend the approval or
denial of applications for non-town-sponsored and town-sponsored large
memorials and monuments at town parks or on town property, in accordance with §
43.02.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1489 THROUGH 156.1494 RESERVED.
SUBPART 3.7: SPECIAL PURPOSE AND  ADVISORY COMMISSIONS
§ 156.1495 ESTABLISHMENT AND MEMBERSHIP.
   (A)   Establishment. This subpart recognizes that, from time to time, it may
be desirable or necessary to establish commissions for special purposes,
composed of members appointed by the Mayor and Town Council. These special
purpose or advisory commissions may be established by resolution of the Town
Council
   (B)   Membership. The number of members and any special composition of
membership shall be specified in the resolution creating the Advisory or
Special Purpose Commission.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1496 PURPOSE.
   The purpose shall be specified in the resolution creating the Advisory or
Special Purpose Commission.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1497 GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   Unless otherwise specified in the resolution creating the Advisory or
Special Purpose Commission, the term of office and other general provisions
shall be consistent with
Subchapter J, Part 3, Subpart 3.1 for as long as the Advisory or Special
Purpose Commission is authorized.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1498 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The powers and duties shall be specified in the resolution creating the
Advisory or Special Purpose Commission.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1499 THROUGH 156.1514 RESERVED.
SUBCHAPTER K: NONCONFORMITIES
PART 1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 156.1515 PURPOSE.
   Nonconformities in the use and development of structures, land, and
buildings are to be avoided, or eliminated where now existing, wherever and
whenever possible, except when necessary to:
   (A)   Preserve property rights established prior to the official date of
these regulations;
   (B)   Promote the general welfare; and
   (C)   Protect the character of surrounding property.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1516 BURDEN OF PROOF.
   (A)   The burden of proof to determine whether a lawfully established
nonconformity exists and was compliant with the zoning, subdivision, building,
and other development regulations in effect at the time the use, building,
structure, site feature, sign, or exterior lighting equipment was created is
placed upon the property owner and not the Town of Mount Pleasant.
   (B)   Appropriate evidence must be provided to the Zoning Administrator to
be able to establish a valid nonconformity. Upon receipt of adequate proof, the
Zoning Administrator shall acknowledge such proof in writing and decide on the
validity of the claim.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1517 PRINCIPAL STRUCTURES LEGALLY CONSTRUCTED PRIOR TO AUGUST 13, 1979.
   Principal structures legally constructed prior to adoption of the Zoning
Code on August 13, 1979, are considered to have been constructed in conformity
with setback, height, and building coverage regulations in place at the time of
construction.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1518 NONCONFORMITIES CREATED BY GOVERNMENT ACTION.
   In situations where a nonconformity is created on a private property due to
government action to provide public amenities, utilities, or infrastructure,
the nonconformity is considered as a legal conforming situation and the
property owner held harmless and relieved of the need to remedy the
nonconformity.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1519 THROUGH 156.1524 RESERVED.
PART 2: NONCONFORMING LOTS
§ 156.1525 CONTINUANCE OF NONCONFORMING LOTS.
   (A)   Subject to all limitations in this section, any nonconforming lot may
continue without change in boundaries and may be utilized or developed, if the
uses and development are otherwise authorized by this chapter.
   (B)   The front, side, and rear yard setbacks of a lot that is nonconforming
with respect to dimensional standards (area, width, or depth) may be reduced by
up to 20%. If a variance greater than 20% is required to accommodate the
proposed use of the lot, a request for relief from the requirements of this
section must be filed with the Board of Zoning Appeals.
   (C)   When an undeveloped split-zoned lot is proposed for development or
when the principal structure on a split-zoned lot is proposed to be improved by
more than 50% of its taxable/use value of improvement as determined by
Charleston County, the lot must be rezoned or subdivided to eliminate the split
zoning. This provision does not apply to split-zoned lots where the zoning
district boundary line generally separates marsh/water areas from high ground
areas.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1526 DISCONTINUANCE OF NONCONFORMING LOTS.
   Any lot that is made conforming by combining with other lots, by subdividing
or re-subdividing, or by rezoning thereafter shall be recognized as a
conforming lot, and shall fully comply with this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1527 THROUGH 156.1534 RESERVED.
PART 3: NONCONFORMING STRUCTURES,  USES, AND SITE FEATURES
§ 156.1535 PURPOSE.
   Where structures, uses, or site features legally existing on the effective
date of this chapter, or any subsequent amendment thereto, do not conform with
the provisions of this chapter, it is the intent and purpose of this section
to:
   (A)   Declare such structures, uses, and site features to be nonconforming
and detrimental to the orderly development of the town; and
   (B)   Eliminate such nonconformities consistent with the rights of the
owners and users thereof, for the purpose of protecting the public health,
safety, and general welfare.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1536 CONTINUING EXISTING NONCONFORMITIES.
   (A)   Any structure, use, or site feature that does not conform with the
provisions of this chapter for the district in which it is located is deemed to
be nonconforming and may continue only as specified in this section if the
condition was:
      (1)   Legally existing at the time of the enactment of this chapter;
      (2)   Applied for or approved by the town under previous regulations in
effect before the effective date of this chapter, if the condition conformed
with the previous regulations; or
      (3)   For annexed parcels, legally existing on the effective date of the
annexation into the town.
   (B)   Provided, however, that this section does not apply to any structure,
use, or site feature established in violation of the Zoning Ordinance
previously in effect in the town, unless such structure, use, or site feature
now conforms with this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1537 DETERMINATION OF VALUE.
   (A)   Principal structures. The total market value as determined by
Charleston County is used to determine the value of existing principal
structures.
   (B)   Accessory structures. The value of accessory structures is based on
the average per square foot cost of construction for accessory structures as
established by the most current adopted version of the International Code
Council (ICC) building valuation. For unlisted structures, the reasonable
replacement value is used. The Zoning Administrator may consult with
appropriate town officials, such as the Building Official and Town Engineer, to
provide, apply, and interpret the ICC building valuation or determine
reasonable replacement value.
   (C)   Site features. The reasonable replacement value is used to determine
the value of existing site features. The Zoning Administrator may consult with
appropriate town officials, such as the Building Official and Town Engineer, to
determine reasonable replacement value.
   (D)   Property tax exemption. Properties that have been approved for
property tax exemption by the South Carolina Department of Revenue and have a
Charleston County total market value of $0 may provide an appraisal of the
structure and land. The appraisal must have been completed by an appraiser
licensed by the Real Estate Appraisers Board of the South Carolina Department
of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation within one year prior to the date of
application for repairs, alterations, renovations, maintenance, improvements,
or replacement.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1538 REPAIRS, ALTERATIONS, AND MAINTENANCE.
   (A)   Ordinary repairs, alterations, or maintenance of nonconforming
structures. Ordinary nonstructural repairs, alterations, or maintenance may be
made to a nonconforming structure as required to keep it in sound condition.
      (1)   Alterations or repairs of a structural nature to a nonconforming
structure are prohibited, except when :
         (a)   Required by law or ordinance; or
         (b)   The structural alterations or repairs are made to a
nonconforming residential structure used for residential purposes.
      (2)   Nothing in this chapter prevents the strengthening or restoring to
a safe condition of any part of any structure declared unsafe by proper
authority.
   (B)   Improvements to nonconforming principal structures.
      (1)   Any nonconforming principal structure that is renovated, repaired,
altered, or otherwise improved by more than 50% of its total market value as
determined by Charleston County at the time of renovation, repair, or
alteration shall be brought into conformance with all applicable sections of
this Zoning Code. This includes the upgrading of the site to meet landscaping,
buffering, parking, stormwater, and other applicable requirements.
      (2)   When a nonconforming principal structure is improved by less than
50% of its total market value as determined by Charleston County, the
improvements must comply with this subchapter.
   (C)   Improvements to nonconforming site features.
      (1)   Any nonconforming site feature that is renovated, repaired,
altered, or otherwise improved by more than 50% of its reasonable replacement
cost at the time of renovation, repair, alteration, or improvement shall be
brought into conformance with all applicable sections of this Zoning Code. This
includes the upgrading of the site to meet landscaping, buffering, parking,
stormwater, and other applicable requirements.
      (2)   When a nonconforming site feature is improved by less than 50% of
its reasonable replacement cost, the improvements must comply with this
subchapter.
   (D)   Improvements to nonconforming accessory structures.
      (1)   A nonconforming accessory structure may be maintained within its
current height and footprint but shall not be expanded nor improved by more
than 50% of the International Code Council (ICC) building valuation.
      (2)   In order to expand a nonconforming accessory structure or improve
it by more than 50% of its ICC building valuation, it must be brought into
compliance with all applicable requirements of this chapter.
   (E)   Phasing of improvements. Applicants shall not phase improvements to
circumvent compliance with this subchapter. The town calculates the percentage
of improvements over a rolling five-year period.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1539 CHANGE OF USE.
   A nonconforming land use shall not be changed to another nonconforming use.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1540 ABANDONMENT OF USE.
   (A)   A use shall be deemed to have been abandoned when it has been
discontinued, whether temporarily or permanently, with the intent to abandon
the use.
   (B)   Evidence of abandonment includes but is not limited to :
      (1)   Lack of use;
      (2)   Vacancy for at least 12 consecutive months or for 18 accumulated
months in a two-year period; and
      (3)   Substituting a conforming use.
   (C)   A nonconforming use of a structure or land that has been declared
abandoned shall not thereafter be reestablished, except in conformity with this
chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1541 RESTORATION OF DAMAGED STRUCTURES.
   (A)   Damage due to neglect, deferred maintenance, or normal wear and tear.
Any nonconforming structure damaged to more than 50% of its taxable/use value
of improvement at the time of damage, either through neglect, deferred
maintenance, or normal wear and tear over a period of time, shall not be
reconstructed and used as before such happenings.
      (1)   If less than 50% damaged, it may be repaired, if the repair is
started within six months of such happenings.
      (2)   The foregoing restrictions do not apply to duplex, triplex,
quadplex, or multiplex units that are nonconforming solely on the basis of
residential density requirements. These units may be replaced, but such
replacement units must comply with all other applicable requirements of the
Zoning Code.
   (B)   Damage or destruction due to unforeseen hazards. Any nonconforming
principal structure damaged or destroyed due to natural or human-made hazards
such as fire, flood, or other catastrophic event beyond the control of the
property owner, may undergo an in-kind replacement or reconstruction in
accordance with the limitations and exceptions in this section.
      (1)   Increase in nonconformity limited. In general, except as otherwise
allowed by these provisions, the degree of nonconformity may not be increased.
      (2)   Replacement or reconstruction limitations. Structures may be placed
in the same location on the lot within the confines of the structure footprint
and with no greater height, total habitable floor area, or total number of
dwelling units as the most recent structure(s) existing on the lot prior to
such damage.
      (3)   Exception for increased elevation. An increase in the elevation of
a building above the maximum allowed height to comply with minimum floodplain
regulations in Chapter 152 is allowed. The building may only be raised to meet
the minimum design flood elevation required by Chapter 152. Any increase in
height above the minimum design flood elevation requires a variance from the
Board of Zoning Appeals.
      (4)   Time limit for reconstruction or repair.
         (a)   Except when Town Council might declare a special emergency to
suspend certain aspects of this chapter, a building permit for any
reconstruction or repair under this section shall be issued within 12 months of
the date of damage. Further, a certificate of occupancy for such repaired or
restored building shall be secured within 24 months of the date of the building
permit issuance.
         (b)   These time limits may be extended upon written request from the
property owner with appropriate documentation to justify an extension, such as:
            1.   Other approvals required by different levels of government or
other agencies are in progress;
            2.   The property is the subject of litigation; or
            3.   The property is under dispute for an insurance settlement due
to the event.
   (C)   Phasing of repairs. Applicants shall not phase repairs to circumvent
compliance with this subchapter. The town calculates the percentage of repairs
over a rolling five-year period.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1542 EXTENSIONS OF NONCONFORMITIES.
   (A)   A nonconforming structure or use of land shall not be enlarged,
intensified, or extended in such a way as to displace a conforming use or
structure.
   (B)   A nonconforming structure or use of land shall not be extended to
occupy additional land area or height not utilized for such nonconformity as of
the effective date of this chapter.
   (C)   In cases where a structure is nonconforming solely as a result of a
setback encroachment, additions to the structure are allowed, if the new
addition does not project into the setback. If a proposed addition would
encroach into the same setback that already had been encroached upon, the
addition is allowed if it projects no further into the setback than the
existing structure and in no way extends past the line of the existing
structure.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1543 CONSTRUCTION APPROVED PRIOR TO CHAPTER.
   (A)   This subchapter does not require any change in plans, construction, or
designated use of a structure for which the land owner can establish that they
have a vested right to continue such use though it does not conform to this
chapter.
   (B)   Such structure shall be deemed to be a nonconforming use and shall
thereafter be subject to the regulations in this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1544 CESSATION.
   The nonconforming uses of land listed below shall be discontinued and the
nonconforming structures listed below shall be torn down, altered, or otherwise
made to conform with the provisions of this chapter within the following
periods of time:
   (A)   Nonconforming objects that impede vision at intersections.
Nonconforming fences, hedges, shrubbery, and signs impeding vision at
intersections shall be brought into compliance by removal, relocation, or
alteration within 90 days of written notice to the property owner;
   (B)   Nonconforming manufactured housing units.
      (1)   Nonconforming manufactured housing units or manufactured housing
unit sales facilities shall not be replaced if they are vacated for six
consecutive months.
      (2)   An existing nonconforming manufactured housing unit shall not be
replaced with another manufactured housing unit, except in the HNB-VR-OD and
SB-OD.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1545 INSUFFICIENT AUTOMOBILE PARKING FACILITIES.
   Where the automobile parking facilities are insufficient to meet the
standards set forth in this chapter, or where no such parking facilities have
been provided for structures constructed prior to the effective date of this
chapter, such structures may not be altered, change use, nor may any additional
facilities be provided within such structures, until after the requirements for
off-street parking shall have been satisfied for those facilities thus added or
enlarged.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1546 NONCONFORMING BUILDING OR IMPERVIOUS SURFACE COVERAGE.
   (A)   When a lot exceeds the maximum allowable building coverage or
impervious surface coverage, as applicable, the buildings or impervious
surfaces that create the nonconformity shall not be removed and replaced with
other elements that perpetuate the nonconformity.
   (B)   For example, if the maximum impervious surface limit is 40% and a lot
is 60% covered by impervious surfaces, the property owner cannot remove the
driveway and add a swimming pool and maintain the 60% impervious surface
coverage.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1547 HISTORIC PROPERTIES.
   (A)   Notwithstanding any of the preceding provisions of this subchapter,
historic properties may be considered conforming to this code with respect to
any height, setback, yard, area, or other dimension found by the Historic
District Preservation Commission to be of historic significance.
   (B)   In this regard, these existing conditions may supersede any
conflicting standard set forth in the zoning district in which the structure is
located, and may be applied to the structure and the site in making future
determinations of conformity as to the existing structure or any changes
consistent with an approved certificate of appropriateness.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1548 EXCEPTION FOR INCREASED ELEVATION.
   (A)   An increase in the elevation of a building above the maximum allowed
height to comply with minimum floodplain regulations in Chapter 152 is allowed.
   (B)   The building may only be raised to meet the minimum design flood
elevation required by
Chapter 152.
   (C)   Any increase in height above the minimum design flood elevation
requires a variance from the Board of Zoning Appeals.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1549 THROUGH 156.1554 RESERVED.
PART 4: NONCONFORMING SIGNS
§ 156.1555 GENERALLY.
   A nonconforming sign is a sign that does not meet the requirements of this
chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1556 CONTINUATION OF EXISTING SIGNS.
   (A)   Permanent signs.
      (1)   Nonconforming permanent signs may continue in existence as provided
in this section if they were:
         (a)   Legally existing on the effective date of this chapter;
         (b)   Applied for or approved by the town under previous regulations
in effect before the effective date of this chapter, if the sign conformed with
the previous regulations; or
         (c)   For annexed parcels, legally existing on the effective date of
the annexation into the town.
      (2)   Nonconforming permanent signs shall only be repaired, altered, or
replaced in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
   (B)   Temporary signs. All nonconforming temporary signs must be removed
within 90 days of the effective date of this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1557 REPAIR, ALTERATION, AND MAINTENANCE OF SIGNS.
   (A)   Maintenance. Ordinary nonstructural repairs or maintenance may be made
to a nonconforming sign as required to keep it in good condition, appearance,
and function.
   (B)   Replacement of sign face.
      (1)   The sign face of a nonconforming sign may be replaced so long as:
         (a)   The sign features or materials are not changed to be
nonconforming; and
         (b)   The changes do not expand or extend any existing nonconformity.
      (2)   The sign face may be replaced pursuant to this division due to
changes of ownership or use.
   (C)   Repair or alteration of signs.
      (1)   The repair or alteration of a nonconforming sign is allowed so long
as:
         (a)   The cost of the repair or alteration does not exceed 50% of the
replacement cost of the sign;
         (b)   The sign features or materials are not changed to be
nonconforming; and
         (c)   The changes do not expand or extend any existing nonconformity.
      (2)   The repair or alteration of a is not allowed if the cost of the
alteration or repair exceeds 50% of the replacement cost of the sign,
regardless of the reason or cause for the repair or alteration.
   (D)   Relocation of signs. Nonconforming signs required to be moved because
of public right-of-way or utilities improvements may be re-established so long
as:
      (1)   The sign features or materials are not changed to be nonconforming;
and
      (2)   The changes do not expand or extend any existing nonconformity.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1558 ABANDONMENT.
   Nonconforming signs declared abandoned pursuant to §
156.864 must be removed or brought into full compliance with this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1559 THROUGH 156.1564 RESERVED.
PART 5: NONCONFORMING EXTERIOR LIGHTING
§ 156.1565 CONTINUATION OF EXISTING EXTERIOR LIGHTING.
   Any exterior lighting existing on the effective date of this chapter that
does not conform with the provisions of this chapter is a nonconforming
exterior lighting design, and may be continued only as specified in this
section.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1566 REPAIRS, ALTERATIONS, AND MAINTENANCE.
   (A)   Ordinary repairs or maintenance may be made to a nonconforming pole-
mounted luminaire or other exterior lighting equipment, as required to keep it
in sound condition.
   (B)   Repairs requiring the removal or replacement of pole-mounted
luminaires or other exterior lighting equipment are prohibited, except as
required by law or ordinance or authorized by the Zoning Administrator.
   (C)   A nonconforming pole-mounted luminaire or other exterior lighting
equipment shall not be moved, altered, enlarged, or replaced except in
conformity with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1567 ABANDONMENT OF USE.
   (A)   A nonconforming pole-mounted luminaire or other exterior lighting
equipment that the Zoning Administrator has declared to be abandoned shall be
removed within 90 days of written notification and shall not thereafter be
reestablished, except in conformity with the provisions of this chapter.
   (B)   Evidence of abandonment is demonstrated by a discontinuance of the
use, activity, place, or business on the site, or willful lack of maintenance
to the extent that the luminaire is in obvious disrepair.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1568 RESTORATION OF DAMAGED NONCONFORMING EXTERIOR LIGHTING.
   (A)   Any nonconforming exterior lighting damaged by more than 50% of its
reasonable replacement cost at the time of damage assessment, either through
neglect, deferred maintenance, or normal wear and tear over a period of time,
or by fire, flood, explosion, wind, earthquake, war, riot, or other event
outside the control of the property owner, shall not be restored or
reconstructed and used as before such happenings, unless in conformity with the
provisions in this chapter.
   (B)   If less than 50% damaged, the exterior lighting may be repaired and
used as before, if such repair is started within six months of the date on
which the damage occurred.
   (C)   The percentage of damage is calculated by dividing the estimated cost
of restoring the exterior lighting to its pre-damaged condition by its
reasonable replacement cost.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1569 THROUGH 156.1574 RESERVED.
SUBCHAPTER L: ENFORCEMENT
§ 156.1575 PURPOSE.
   This subchapter establishes the procedures to enforce compliance with this
chapter and to mandate corrections for violations of this chapter or conditions
of an approval or permit issued under this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1576 VIOLATIONS.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   When any building is erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered,
repaired, or converted, or any building or land is used in violation of this
chapter, the Zoning Administrator is authorized and directed to institute any
appropriate action to put an end to such violation.
      (2)   Pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, more specific penalties
are prescribed for violations of the tree protection regulations (see
Subchapter E) and the critical area buffer (see
Subchapter D, Part 3).
   (B)   Types of violations. The following activities, acts, failures to act,
and conditions are violations of this chapter and will be enforced using the
penalties and remedies provided by this Subchapter, the Mount Pleasant Code,
and any requirements or limitations of South Carolina law:
      (1)   Development or use without permit or approval. Any activity that is
not authorized by the acquisition of all required permits, approvals,
certificates, and authorizations required by this chapter;
      (2)   Development or use of land inconsistent with this chapter. Any
activity that is inconsistent with any zoning, development, landscaping, sign,
or general regulation of this chapter or any amendment to it;
      (3)   Development or use inconsistent with conditions of approval. Any
activity that is inconsistent with any term, condition, or qualification placed
by the town upon a required permit, certificate, rezoning, plan approval, or
other form of authorization granted by the town to allow the use, development,
placement of signs, or other activity upon land or improvements of land;
      (4)   Making a lot or yard nonconforming. Reducing or diminishing any lot
area, lot width, lot depth, or setback so that the lot or yard is smaller than
prescribed by the requirements of this chapter;
      (5)   Increasing impervious surface coverage. Increasing the impervious
surface coverage on a lot so that it exceeds the maximum allowed by this
chapter;
      (6)   Increasing the intensity of use. Increasing the intensity or
density of use of any land or structure, except in accordance with the
procedural and substantive requirements of this chapter;
      (7)   Deficient landscaping and site improvements. Failing to install or
maintain any landscaping, screening, or site improvements required by this
chapter;
      (8)   Removal of vegetation in buffers and bufferyards. The unauthorized
removal or disturbance of vegetation from required buffers or bufferyards,
except in accordance with the provisions of
Subchapter D;
      (9)   Removal of protected trees. The unauthorized removal or disturbance
of protected trees, except in accordance with the provisions of
Subchapter E;
      (10)   Disrupting notice. Removing, defacing, obscuring, or interfering
with any notice posted or made pursuant to this chapter;
      (11)   Failure to comply with a stop work order. Continuing construction
or other site work on any development, building, or structure on any land or
site after service of a stop work order issues by the town pursuant to this
subchapter;
      (12)   Displaying a temporary sign longer than permitted. Displaying a
temporary sign for a period of time in excess of that stated in the approval;
      (13)   Unauthorized changes to Zoning Map. Any change in zoning district
boundaries on the Zoning Map that is not made in conformance with the
procedures set forth in
Subchapter I; and
      (14)   Other acts. Any other act that is prohibited by this chapter or
the failure to do any act that is required by this chapter is a violation under
this section and is punishable under this chapter.
   (C)   Each day constitutes a separate offense. Each day that any violation
of any provision of this chapter continues constitutes a separate offense.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1577 PENALTIES.
   (A)   Generally. In case any building, structure, or land is or is proposed
to be used in violation of this chapter, the Zoning Administrator or any
adjacent or neighboring property owner who would be damaged by such violation,
may, in addition to other remedies as provided by law, institute injunction,
mandamus, or other appropriate action or proceedings to prevent such unlawful
erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, conversion, maintenance, or
use, or to correct or abate the violation, or to prevent the occupancy of the
building, structure, or land.
   (B)   Violation is a misdemeanor.
      (1)   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter by performing
an act prohibited by it or by failing to perform an act required by it is
guilty of a misdemeanor under the laws of the State of South Carolina.
         (a)   Upon conviction thereof, an offender shall be liable for a fine
of not more than $500 or imprisonment for not more than 30 days, or both.
         (b)   However, the penalty shall not exceed the penalty provided by
state law for similar offenses.
      (2)   The Town Council, Town Attorney, Zoning Administrator, or Planning
Director, or their designee, may institute all necessary proceedings in any
court having jurisdiction or other appropriate venue to prosecute violations
under this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1578 ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURES.
   (A)   Notice of violation.
      (1)   In the case of violations of this chapter involving continuing
construction or development or any emergency situation, the Zoning
Administrator shall provide written notification to the person responsible for
the violation, indicating the nature of the violation and ordering the action
necessary to correct it.
      (2)   In the case of violations of this chapter not involving continuing
construction or development or any emergency situation, the Zoning
Administrator shall give written notice of the nature of the violation to the
owner, occupant, or agent of the property at the last known address.
      (3)   The contents of the notice shall describe the nature of the
violation in terms that would reasonably allow the property owner or other
responsible person, representative, or tenant to determine the nature of the
violation to allow for self-abatement and shall mandate a minimum 15 business
day time to cure before further enforcement action will be taken.
      (4)   The person to whom notice is directed shall correct the violation
or be subject to further enforcement action.
      (5)   The notice shall be personally served or sent by certified mail,
return receipt requested. Failure to sign for the certified mail or failure to
pick up the notice from the post office is not deemed a lack of notice under
this chapter where delivery was attempted, and a record of this attempt was
provided as required by procedures for restricted mail.
   (B)   Immediate enforcement.
      (1)   If the Zoning Administrator determines that an emergency situation
exists or continuing construction is occurring in violation of this chapter,
the town may immediately use the enforcement powers and remedies available to
it pursuant to §§
156.1577 and
156.1579.
      (2)   No other notification procedures are required as a prerequisite to
an immediate enforcement action.
   (C)   Action by Zoning Administrator. The Zoning Administrator may:
      (1)   Follow up on violations until the situation is properly remedied;
      (2)   Order discontinuances of illegal use of land, buildings, or
structures;
      (3)   Order the removal of illegal buildings or structures or illegal
additions, alterations, or structural changes;
      (4)   Order the discontinuance of any illegal work being done; and
      (5)   Take any other action authorized by this chapter and governing law
to ensure compliance with or to prevent violation of its provisions.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1579 REVOCATION OF PERMIT OR APPROVAL.
   (A)   Basis for revocation. A permit or approval may be revoked by the
Zoning Administrator at any time prior to the completion of the use, building,
structure, development, site improvement, or subdivision for which the permit
was issued, when the Zoning Administrator determines that one or more of the
following conditions is present:
      (1)   There is departure from the plans, specifications, or conditions as
required under the terms of the permit;
      (2)   That the permit was procured by materially incorrect information;
      (3)   That the permit was issued in error; or
      (4)   That any of the provisions of this chapter are being violated.
   (B)   Notice. Written notice of the revocation shall be served upon the
owner, the owner's agent or contractor, or any person employed in the building
or structure for which the permit was issued or shall be posted in a prominent
location on the lot. Where notice of revocation is served or posted, all
further construction, use, or development of the lot shall cease.
   (C)   Appeal of revocation. Any revocation of a permit may be appealed to
the Board of Zoning Appeals as provided in
Subchapter I, Part 17.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1580 THROUGH 156.1589 RESERVED.
SUBCHAPTER M: RULES OF INTERPRETATION AND MEASUREMENT
PART 1: RULES OF INTERPRETATION
§ 156.1590 GENERAL RULES OF INTERPRETATION.
   (A)   This part, §
10.02, and §
10.06 establish rules for interpreting provisions in this chapter.
   (B)   In their interpretation and application, the regulations in this
chapter, including the various zoning district regulations, are the minimum
requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, and
welfare.
   (C)   For purposes of interpreting this chapter, the following definitions
of word use apply:
      (1)   Words used in the present tense include the future tense;
      (2)   Words used in the singular include the plural and words used in the
plural include the singular;
      (3)   Words of one gender include the other genders and firms,
partnerships, and corporations;
      (4)   The word “person” includes a corporation, firm, company,
partnership, association, organization, or public or private authority, as well
as an individual;
      (5)   The words "shall" and "must" are mandatory;
      (6)   The words "may," "should," and “encouraged” are permissive;
      (7)   The word “used” or “occupied” as applied to any land or building
shall be construed to include the words “intended, arranged, or designed to be
used or occupied.”
      (8)   The phrase "used for" includes "designed for," "intended for,"
"maintained for," and "occupied for;"
      (9)   The words “such as,” “includes,” “including,” and “for example”
mean “including, but not limited to” or “by way of example and not limitation,”
unless otherwise provided;
      (10)   The term "structure" includes the term "building;" and
      (11)   The word “lot” includes the words “plot” or “parcel.”
   (D)   This chapter contains tables, illustrations, and graphics, which are
designed to assist the reader in understanding the provisions of this chapter.
However, to the extent that there is any inconsistency between the text of this
chapter and any tables, illustrations, or graphics, the text controls.
   (E)   Where this chapter permits or requires an act on the part of an
"owner," "lot owner," or “property owner” and a particular lot or tract of land
is owned by several persons, whether in indivision, partnership, joint venture,
or other form of joint ownership, the act shall be taken on behalf of, and with
the express consent of, all such persons.
   (F)   Any reference to a statute, provision of the Mount Pleasant Code of
Ordinances, other laws or regulations, reference documents, technical manuals,
or other documents refer to the most recent versions of those documents,
including any amendments or updates to the statute, Town Code, law, regulation,
or other document.
   (G)   In computing any period of time, refer to §
10.06(C) unless specifically provided in this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1591 INTERPRETATION OF ZONING MAP.
   (A)   Unless expressly stated otherwise in the associated rezoning
ordinance, the boundaries of zoning districts extend to the centerline of all
adjacent rights-of-way.
   (B)   Where uncertainty exists with respect to the boundaries of districts
shown on the Zoning Map, the following rules of interpretation apply:
      (1)   Boundaries indicated as approximately following corporate area
lines, shall be construed as following the corporate area lines;
      (2)   Boundaries indicated as approximately following lot lines shall be
construed as following the lot lines;
      (3)   Where the boundary of a district follows a stream, lake, or other
body of water, the boundary line is deemed to be at the limit of the
jurisdiction of the town, unless otherwise indicated; and
      (4)   Where a district boundary line divides a lot, the town may require
a survey to establish the precise location of the district boundary line. The
regulations for each district apply to the portion of the lot located in that
district.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1592 CONFLICTING PROVISIONS.
   (A)   Zoning district hierarchy.
      (1)   When base or floating zoning district and overlay zoning district
provisions conflict, the provisions of the overlay zoning district control.
      (2)   When planned zoning district and overlay zoning district provisions
conflict, the provisions of the planned zoning district control.
   (B)   Conflicts between zoning code standards. When generally applicable
standards in this chapter conflict, the more restrictive standard controls.
   (C)   Stricter standards in this chapter. In accordance with S.C. Code § 6-
29-960, where this chapter imposes a greater width or size of yards, courts, or
other spaces; a lower height of buildings or smaller number of stories; a
greater percentage of lot to be left unoccupied; or otherwise imposes higher
standards than are required in any other state statute or local ordinance or
regulation, the provisions of this chapter control.
   (D)   Stricter standards in state statutes or local ordinances or
regulations. When the provisions of any state statute or local ordinance or
regulation require more restrictive standards than required by the regulations
of this chapter, the provisions of such statute govern.
   (E)   Conflicts with private restrictions.
      (1)   It is not intended by this chapter to interfere with, abrogate, or
annul any easements, covenants, or other agreements between parties.
      (2)   Where this chapter is more restrictive or imposes higher standards
than a private restriction, this chapter controls.
      (3)   Where a private restriction is more restrictive or imposes higher
standards than this chapter, the private restriction controls if properly
enforced by a person having the legal right to enforce the restrictions. The
town does not enforce private restrictions.
      (4)   However, the town may cease processing an application if it has
actual notice of the existence of a recorded covenant that is contrary to,
conflicts with, or prohibits the activity for which an applicant requests
approval (see §
156.1099).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1593 THROUGH 156.1599 RESERVED.
PART 2: RULES OF MEASUREMENT
SUBPART 2.1: GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 156.1600 PURPOSE.
   This part establishes rules for measurement or calculation of Zoning Code
standards, such as lot area and height.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1601 THROUGH 156.1604 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.2: BUILD-TO LINE
§ 156.1605 GENERALLY.
   This subpart describes how to measure a build-to line, which is regulated in
Subchapter B and
Subchapter H.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1606 HOW TO MEASURE BUILD-TO LINES.
   (A)   A build-to line is a set building line on a lot where a building
façade must be located. In certain instances, the build-to line is expressed as
a range (e.g., between 20 feet and 30 feet from the front lot line) within
which the building façade must be located.
   (B)   A build-to line is located parallel to the adjacent street right-of-
way.
   (C)   A build-to line is measured from the back of the curb to the face of
the building. If a curb is not present, a build-to line is measured from the
edge of the pavement.
   (D)   Awnings and canopies may encroach beyond a build-to line.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1607 THROUGH 156.1609 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.3: BUILDING COVERAGE
§ 156.1610 GENERALLY.
   This subpart describes how to calculate building coverage, which is
regulated in
Subchapter B and
Subchapter C.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1611 HOW TO CALCULATE BUILDING COVERAGE.
   (A)   Measurement. Building coverage is:
      (1)   Expressed as a percentage of lot area; and
      (2)   Calculated by dividing the total area (in square feet) of all
building footprints within a lot by the total lot area (in square feet), and
multiplying the result by 100.
   (B)   Exceptions. The calculation of building coverage excludes buildings
that are located completely below the finished lot grade, such as subgrade
basements.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1612 THROUGH 156.1614 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.4: DENSITY
§ 156.1615 GENERALLY.
   (A)   This subpart describes how to calculate residential density, which is
regulated in
Subchapter B and
Subchapter C.
   (B)   Density for residential uses is expressed in dwelling units per acre
of land.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1616 HOW TO CALCULATE MAXIMUM DENSITY.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   The calculation of maximum density:
         (a)   Is based on the gross area of all land within the boundaries of
a residential project, including land designated for support of the
development; that is, all areas for lots, parking areas, drives, roads,
drainage and utility easements, rights-of-way, sign easements, entrance
structure easements, and lands designated for private recreation;
         (b)   Includes freshwater wetlands; and
         (c)   Does not include tidally influenced saltwater wetlands.
      (2)   Other land area located within a parcel's boundaries, but outside
of the residential project boundaries not used for residential use, shall not
be included for the purpose of calculating residential density except as
provided in division (A)(3) below.
      (3)   In mixed use projects where non-residential uses are provided in
conjunction with, and are functionally integrated into, the residential uses,
the total area within the project boundaries of all such uses may be used to
calculate density.
   (B)   Accessory dwelling units. Accessory dwelling units are not included in
the calculation of density.
   (C)   Calculation. To calculate the maximum number of dwelling units or
bedrooms, as applicable, allowed in a development, multiply the gross lot area
by the maximum density standard for the zoning district. See Table 156.1616-1:
Example Calculation of Maximum Density (Dwelling Units per Acre).
   (D)   Rounding. When density calculations result in a fraction, the allowed
number of dwelling units or bedrooms, as applicable, is rounded down to the
next lowest whole number.
Table 156.1616-1: Example Calculation of Maximum Density (Dwelling Units per
Acre)

Acre)

(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1617 THROUGH 156.1619 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.5: GROSS FLOOR AREA
§ 156.1620 GENERALLY.
   This subpart describes how to calculate gross floor area, which is regulated
in
Subchapter B and
Subchapter C.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1621 HOW TO CALCULATE GROSS FLOOR AREA.
   (A)   Gross floor area (GFA):
      (1)   Is measured from the inside perimeter of the exterior walls of the
structure, without deduction for the thickness of internal walls;
      (2)   Includes the total horizontal area of all floors of a structure,
including interior balconies, mezzanines, corridors, stairways, ramps, closets,
columns, and other features; and
      (3)   Excludes shafts with no openings and interior courts. A “court” is
an open, uncovered space, unobstructed to the sky, bounded on three or more
sides by exterior building walls or other enclosing devices.
   (B)   The floor area of a structure or portion thereof without exterior
walls is the useable area under the horizontal projection of the roof or floor
above.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1622 THROUGH 156.1624 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.6: HEIGHT
§ 156.1625 GENERALLY.
   (A)   This subpart describes how to measure building and structure height
and allows exceptions for certain structures or elements.
   (B)   Unless necessary to meet drainage or other applicable requirements of
this code, lots shall not be filled in order to artificially increase building
height.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1626 HOW TO MEASURE HEIGHT.
   (A)   Height regulated in feet. Where this chapter regulates height in feet,
the height of a structure is the vertical distance measured from grade plane to
the average height of the highest roof surface.
   (B)   Height regulated in stories. Height, where not regulated in feet, is
regulated in stories.
      (1)   A story is measured:
         (a)   From top to top of two successive finished floor surfaces; and
         (b)   For the topmost story, from the top of the highest finished
floor to the top of the ceiling joists or to the top of the roof rafters if
there is no ceiling.
      (2)   An attic counts as a story if it contains habitable attic space, as
defined by the Building Code.
      (3)   To be considered a half-story, as defined in
Subchapter N, the floor area with head room of five feet or more shall not
exceed 50% of the total floor area of the story below it.
      (4)   The ground level component of an elevated building is considered a
story if it is at least seven feet in height, as specified in the definition of
“story” in
Subchapter N.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1627 EXCEPTIONS.
   (A)   The purpose of this section is to allow a certain category of features
to exceed the maximum height limitation for buildings and structures that would
otherwise be unreasonably restrictive. These features shall not accommodate
human occupancy and shall be the minimum necessary to achieve a specified
purpose.
   (B)   The following projections are exempt from the height limitations of
this chapter to the extent established below:
      (1)   Any chimney or antenna on a building;
      (2)   Church spires or the sanctuary portion of a building associated
with a place of worship;
      (3)   Belfries, cupolas, and domes not intended for human occupancy;
      (4)   Smokestacks;
      (5)   Aerials;
      (6)   The judicious application of portions of a building containing or
shielding from view electrical or mechanical equipment;
      (7)   Elevator penthouses;
      (8)   Masts;
      (9)   Construction cranes or ships; and
      (10)   Other similar elements, such as decorative railings.
   (C)   These projections may be constructed in accordance with other
regulations or ordinances of the Town of Mount Pleasant or of other
jurisdictions, such as the Federal Aviation Administration.
   (D)   Telecommunications towers are subject to the height limits specified
in
Subchapter C, Part 7, Subpart 7.2.
   (E)   Any areas intended for human occupancy, such as rooftop decks,
pergolas, and the like shall not exceed the height limitations of this chapter,
unless otherwise specified in this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1628, 156.1629 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.7: IMPERVIOUS SURFACE COVERAGE
§ 156.1630 GENERALLY.
   This subpart describes how to calculate impervious surface coverage, which
is regulated in
Subchapter B and
Subchapter C.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1631 HOW TO CALCULATE IMPERVIOUS SURFACE COVERAGE.
   (A)   Impervious surface coverage is:
      (1)   Expressed as a percentage of lot area; and
      (2)   Calculated by dividing the total area of all impervious surfaces
within a lot by the total lot area, and multiplying the result by 100.
   (B)   When a lot contains tidally influenced saltwater wetlands/marsh or
open water beyond the delineated SCDES-BCM critical line, impervious surface
coverage is calculated using only the "high ground" of the lot and specifically
excluding the wetlands/marsh or open water.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1632 THROUGH 156.1634 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.8: LOT AREA, WIDTH,  AND DEPTH
§ 156.1635 GENERALLY.
   This subpart describes how to measure lot area, lot width, and lot depth.
Subchapter B and
Subchapter C regulate these metrics.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1636 HOW TO CALCULATE LOT AREA.
   (A)   The area of a lot:
      (1)   Is calculated in square feet by multiplying the lot depth by the
lot width; and
      (2)   Does not include any portion of a road right-of-way.
   (B)   When a lot is irregularly shaped, the calculation method varies based
on the lot shape and the information available (see www.mathopenref.com/
polygonirregulararea.html)
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1637 HOW TO MEASURE LOT WIDTH.
   (A)   Measurement.
      (1)   The width of a lot is the horizontal distance between the side lot
lines, measured:
         (a)   Parallel to the front lot line; or
         (b)   In the case of a curvilinear street, parallel to the chord of
the arc between the intersection of the side lot lines and the front lot line.
      (2)   The zoning district minimum lot width must be met at the front lot
line, except as specified in division (B) below.
   (B)   Lots on cul-de-sacs. For lots located on a cul-de-sac, the zoning
district minimum lot width must be met at the front setback for the district.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1638 HOW TO MEASURE LOT DEPTH.
   The depth of a lot is the average horizontal distance between the front and
rear lot lines, measured generally parallel to the side lot lines.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1639 THROUGH 156.1644 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.9: SETBACKS AND YARDS
§ 156.1645 GENERALLY.
   (A)   Purpose. This subpart describes how to measure yards and setbacks.
Subchapter B and
Subchapter C regulate these metrics.
   (B)   Required yards cannot overlap. Required yards provided for one
structure shall not be used to meet yard requirements for another structure.
   (C)   Setbacks for lots subject to design review process. For lots subject
to
Subchapter H, setback distances from lot lines with street frontage are
determined through the design review process, using a build-to line of between
20 and 30 feet.
   (D)   Setbacks for lots in the Old Village Historic District. For lots
located within the Old Village Historic District (see
Subchapter B, Part 4, Subpart 4.3), setback distance is determined during the
certificate of appropriateness (COA) review process, with consideration of
existing conditions and setbacks of adjacent lots.
   (E)   Setbacks for postage stamp lots. Normal setback and yard requirements
do not apply to lot lines for “postage stamp” lots subdivided pursuant to the
provisions of §
155.047(C)(1)(a). The setback and yard requirements of the zoning district
classification apply to the perimeter of the larger parcel in which these lots
are located.
   (F)   Setbacks for the subdivision of lots with more than one dwelling unit.
Normal setback and yard requirements do not apply to lot lines for lots
resulting from the subdivision of lots with more than one dwelling unit
pursuant to the provisions of §
155.047(C)(1)(b).
   (G)   Determinations and interpretations. When making determinations or, if
necessary, interpretations under this subpart, the Zoning Administrator shall
consider the following characteristics of the lot and surrounding lots:
      (1)   The orientation of existing or proposed buildings containing the
principal use;
      (2)   The orientation of adjacent buildings and other buildings along the
street;
      (3)   The location of a dwelling’s curtilage;
      (4)   Means of gaining safe access;
      (5)   The relative dimensions of the lot and yards;
      (6)   Delivery of services to the lot, including mail and trash
collection;
      (7)   Setbacks on surrounding lots; and
      (8)   Other features related to site design and safe circulation.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1646 LOT ORIENTATION, YARDS, AND SETBACKS.
   (A)   A front yard is adjacent to the front lot line, and is typically
located along a street. A rear yard is adjacent to the rear lot line, and is
generally located parallel to the front yard. Side yards are adjacent to side
lot lines, and are generally located perpendicular to the front and rear yards.
   (B)   
Figure 156.1646-1: Typical Location of Yards and Setback Lines illustrates
yards and setback lines on typical lots. Setback lines are located parallel to
the associated lot line. The Zoning Administrator determines the location of
yards and setbacks on irregularly shaped lots using the criteria specified in
this section and in §
156.1645(G).
Figure 156.1646-2 depicts the typical location of yards and setback lines on
two types of irregularly shaped lots, marsh front lots and flag lots.
   (C)   Typically, the shorter lot dimensions are considered the front and
rear lot lines and the longer lot dimensions are considered the side lot lines.
This provides the most buildable area on a lot. However, where a lot has street
frontage that is wider than the lot is deep and was platted prior to adoption
of the Town Zoning Code on August 13, 1979:
      (1)   The front yard setback may be applied along the street frontage,
and the rear yard setback along the parallel lot line (longer side). The side
yard setbacks may be applied on lot lines of adjacent parcels (shorter side)
when consistent with the lots on either side of the subject lot or the majority
of the lots within the block; and
      (2)   The principal structure must conform with the setback adjustment.
If any portion of an existing or proposed principal structure does not comply
with the adjusted setbacks, a variance to allow the establishment of setbacks
must be approved by the Board of Zoning Appeals.
   (D)   In the case of new construction on a corner lot, the owner may
establish the location of the front and rear yards based on preference of
orientation, taking into consideration orientation of adjacent structures and
existing development patterns.
Figure 156.1646-1: Typical Location of Yards and Setback Lines
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13147.png]
Figure 156.1646-2
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13149.png]
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1647 HOW TO MEASURE SETBACKS.
   Setbacks are measured from the lot line to the closest projection of any
portion of a building or structure, except for encroachments as allowed by §
156.1651.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1648 FRONT YARDS AND SETBACKS.
   (A)   Definition.
      (1)   A front yard is an open, unoccupied space on a lot (except for
encroachments as allowed by § 156.1651) that generally faces a street and
extends across the entire width of a lot between the side lot lines.
      (2)   For lots without frontage on a street, the front lot line is the
lot line where access to the lot is provided.
      (3)   The horizontal distance between the principal structure and the
front lot line shall be at least equal to the minimum front setback for the
zoning district in which the lot is located (see
Subchapter B).
   (B)   Front setbacks on double frontage lots. For double frontage lots, the
front setback requirements apply along both streets as illustrated in Figure
156.1648-1: Front Setbacks on Double Frontage Lots.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/6694e965e9dfdd7b2e635f55b75a6af65807bdd7/
IMAGES/0-0-0-13151.png]
   (C)   Average front setbacks.
      (1)   The minimum front yard setback requirement for dwellings does not
apply on any lot where the average setback of existing buildings located,
wholly or in part, within 100 feet on each side of such lot within the same
block and zoning district and fronting on the same side of the street, is less
than the minimum required setback.
      (2)   In these cases, the setback on such lots may be less than the
required minimum setback, but not less than the average of the setbacks of the
aforementioned existing buildings.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1649 REAR YARDS AND SETBACKS.
   (A)   A rear yard is an open, unoccupied space (except for encroachments as
allowed by §
156.1651) that extends across the entire width of a lot between the side lot
lines.
   (B)   The horizontal distance between the principal structure and the rear
lot line shall be at least equal to the minimum rear setback required for the
zoning district in which the lot is located (see
Subchapter B).
   (C)   The horizontal distance between an accessory structure and the rear
lot line shall be at least equal to the minimum rear setback required for the
type of accessory structure (see
Subchapter C, Part 4).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1650 SIDE YARDS AND SETBACKS.
   (A)   A side yard is an open, unoccupied space (except for encroachments as
allowed by §
156.1651) that extends from the front yard to the rear yard.
   (B)   The horizontal distance between the principal structure and each side
lot line shall be at least equal to the minimum side setback required for the
zoning district in which the lot is located (see
Subchapter B).
   (C)   The side yard setback requirement applies where a side yard abuts a
street (corner lot). However, accessory buildings shall not be located closer
to the street than the front yard setback line of the adjacent lot.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1651 ENCROACHMENTS.
   (A)   This section specifies allowed encroachments into required yards.
   (B)   REQUIRED YARD means that portion of any yard constituting the minimum
area required in any zoning district, but excluding that portion of the yard in
excess of the minimum required area.
   (C)   Items such as sills, eaves, belt courses, window air-conditioning
units, chimneys, cornices, ornamental features, and bay windows may protrude
into a required yard a distance not to exceed 24 inches; provided, however, a
bay window projection is limited to maximum span length of ten feet along the
exterior wall of the building.
   (D)   Items such as open fire escapes; elevators; outside stairways leading
to a building entrance, but not to an uncovered porch or deck; balconies; and
outside air-conditioning units and propane/heating oil tanks may be permitted
to project into the required yard for a distance of not more than four feet,
when so placed as to not obstruct light and ventilation, but in no case closer
than three feet from the property line.
   (E)   Uncovered porches and uncovered decks may encroach into a required
rear or side yard not more than 40% of the required setback, but no closer than
three feet from the property line; except that when a zero-lot line provision
is in effect, the 40% reduction applies to the minimum required distance
between structures. No additional encroachments for outside stairways is
allowed.
   (F)   Ramps for ADA accessibility may encroach into any required yard and do
not have a minimum setback from a lot line.
   (G)   Minor accessory uses and structures may encroach into any required
yard and do not have a minimum setback from a lot line (see
Subchapter C, Part 4).
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1652 THROUGH 156.1659 RESERVED.
SUBPART 2.10: USE SEPARATION
§ 156.1660 GENERALLY.
   (A)   This subpart describes how to measure the required minimum separation
distance between certain conditional and special exception uses specified in
Subchapter C, Part 3, Subpart 3.3.
   (B)   Depending on the regulated use,
Subchapter C, Part 3, Subpart 3.3 specifies a minimum separation distance
between the new regulated use and:
      (1)   Certain zoning districts; and/or
      (2)   Certain sensitive land uses, such as residential uses.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§ 156.1661 HOW TO MEASURE SEPARATION DISTANCE.
   Measurements shall be taken in a straight line from the nearest portion of
the lot line where the new regulated use is proposed to the nearest portion of
the lot line or zoning district boundary line of the uses and districts from
which the regulated use must be separated.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)
§§ 156.1662 THROUGH 156.1674 RESERVED.
SUBCHAPTER N : DEFINITIONS AND ACRONYMS

   The purpose of this part is to define acronyms used in this chapter.
(Ord. passed 1-14-25)

   ADU.   Accessory dwelling unit.
   ANSI.   American National Standards Institute.

   BOZA.   Town of Mount Pleasant Board of Zoning Appeals.
